webTitle: Phillips to rouse the beast in Brazil

fields.headline: Phillips to rouse the beast in Brazil
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with one eye on making high profits in the lowlands, knows what's going to happen at Wembley on Saturday. Don't say you weren't tipped off
fields.trailText: The only problem with recommending Phillips as a first scorer is that Keegan may try out several of his striker combinations - so there's no telling how long he'll stay on the pitch.
fields.body:
Here are the reasons Brazil might lose to England on Saturday. Ronaldo's not playing and neither is Romario (heel problems); Ecuador scored against them in a World Cup qualifier last month after Columbia had held them to a goalless draw; and they only scored three goals against a makeshift Welsh side on Tuesday.

Apart from that, England's best hope lies in another mysterious attack of unexplained World Cup Final hookey, in which the entire Brazil squad goes a bit mad on the morning of the match and throws John Motson into disarray.

The safest bet is that most of the day's finesse will come Brazilian boots. The visitors know that one part blinding skill roughly equals nine parts graft - and if all goes well for them, they can transform any opposition into headless chickens. The very nature of the "friendly" should also work to Brazil's advantage. England's first-choice players will not fearlessly steam into this game at full tilt for fear of injury before Euro 2000, even though several among the squad will know they may only have this chance to impress bossman Keegan.

Any hesitation will prove disastrous. Keegan should take this opportunity to experiment with his options - which will prove very useful for Euro 2000 but not so handy for winning on Saturday afternoon. What he's really looking for is a goal from Kevin Phillips, even if the final result doesn't go England's way. Gary Lineker believes the Sunderland man could be the key to England's Euro 2000 and a fine showing on Saturday should tee him up nicely.

The only problem with recommending Phillips as a first scorer is that Keegan may try out several of his striker combinations - so there's no telling how long he'll stay on the pitch. It's certainly not worth chancing him under the 8-1 offered by Ladbrokes.

Although it's mildly heart-warming to see Nick Barmby in for Jason Wilcox on left, Brazilian right back Cafu will spend no sleepless nights worrying about how he's going to keep the rejuvenated Everton man at bay. Barmby's club form may have picked up but he's never been a threat at international level and there's no real reason to think that the force will be with him on Saturday. Best look to the right, where David Beckham may not have Roberto Carlos to get past, in the likely event that the over-thighed Brazilian fancies a rest after his sapping mid-week glory night in Paris.

Welsh manager Mark Hughes probably had it just about right when, after the Tuesday defeat, he said: ''I think England will also have to work very hard against [Brazil] at Wembley because their squad has such ability they will always cause you problems. They do things that most normal footballers aren't capable of doing. With their tricks and flicks you just have to stand up and applaud them. It was wonderful to watch.''

Take Brazil to win 2-1 and Kevin Phillips to score first - if he starts.

webTitle: Malik banned for life as Pakistan blows the whistle

fields.headline: Malik banned for life as Pakistan blows the whistle
fields.standfirst: More about corruption in cricket
fields.trailText: Salim Malik became the first major casualty of the match-rigging scandal yesterday when he was condemned in a report as guilty of corruption and it was recommended that he be banned for life from any involvement in cricket.
fields.body:
Salim Malik became the first major casualty of the match-rigging scandal yesterday when he was condemned in a report as guilty of corruption and it was recommended that he be banned for life from any involvement in cricket.

The report, the result of a two-year judicial investigation by Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum and released by the Pakistan Cricket Board in Rawalpindi, recommends that eight players be penalised. It also suggests that Ata-ur-Rehman be banned for life after finding him guilty of match-fixing and perjury, and proposes fines for six other players: Mushtaq Ahmed, Wasim Akram, Waqar Younis, Saeed Anwar, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Akram Raza.

In Australia there will be a sense of relief that the commission decided the evidence given by two of their players, Shane Warne and Mark Waugh, was key in proving the charges against Malik - even though they had admitted taking money from bookmakers.

Throughout the international game last night there was satisfaction that a culprit has been exposed and a name blackened. Cricket, its genteel image forever destroyed, badly needed a victim. International cricket will believe that the Qayyum Report has delivered a guilty verdict against a man whose corruption is now beyond doubt.

Malik again professed his innocence and said he was being victimised by the PCB. "I will swear any oath, to God, that I am innocent. My hands are clean," he said, adding that his lawyers will appeal within two days.

For some, uncertainty still persists. The commission found the evidence against Wasim Akram was not strong enough to justify a ban but Judge Qayyum held that allegations against him rendered him "too sullied" to captain Pakistan again. According to the commission, Wasim, due to take up a commentating role with Channel 4 for the West Indies series, survives only because a testimony against him by Ata-ur-Rehman, "could not be believed with any degree of certainty".

The sheer weight of evidence in the Qayyum Report, and the fact that the PCB, after much soul-searching, dared to release it, strengthens its position at next month's International Cricket Council meeting: the board has sought to put its house in order.

The recommendation that Malik is banned for life might be an irrelevance since he retired from international cricket after last summer's World Cup in England. But a proposed fine of $18,500 would prove more painful, as would the conclusion that he should be banned from holding any further office in Pakistani cricket. That so many matches could be the subject of suspicion and so many leading Pakistani players have been caught up in the web of deceit will deeply shock as the report is digested.

The much-leaked judicial investigation might have contained few surprises. But the detail provided into the greatest scandal in cricket's history made it compelling reading. The commission concluded that Warne truthfully accused Malik of trying to bribe him and others to throw the 1994 test between Pakistan and Australia in Karachi, and the subsequent one-day match in Rawalpindi. It decided that the Australians' admission that they had accepted bookmakers' money previously for "information" in Sri Lanka did not damage their credibility.

For Malik there is total condemnation. The report concludes: "There have been a lot of general allegations against Malik. Everyone seems to name him as the main culprit in match-fixing. Imran Khan, Javed Miandad, his own coaches, managers and fellow players." Most crucial was the testimony of his own vice-captain, Rashid Latif, whose reputation as a whistle-blower on a cancer destroying the game will be enhanced.

The extent of Malik's involvement in match-fixing is breathtaking. The commission accepted testimonies from Intikhab Alam and Saeed Anwar that he was involved in the throwing of a one-day international against New Zealand on the 1993/4 tour. Latif stated that before the Christchurch one-day international Malik, who was Pakistani captain, summoned him to his hotel room and offered him $18,500 (£11,500) to play badly.

Malik returned home early from Pakistan's tour to Sri Lanka the following year, when it was alleged that he met bookmakers looking to fix the Singer Cup series also involving India, Sri Lanka and Australia. The bookmaker, Saleem Pervez, further stated that he paid Malik (and his team-mate Mushtaq Ahmed) $100,000 (£67,600) to throw the Pakistan v Australia game in that competition. Judge Qayyum concluded: "The statement of Saleem Pervez has a lot of weight. It is, no doubt, true and admitted by Saleem Pervez that he has some criminal record and that he had even been involved in a murder case but that does not mean that the man is lying."

Pakistan's players, practising in Antigua for the third test against West Indies, refused to comment on the findings.

webTitle: Defiant Pru presses on with Egg flotation

fields.headline: Defiant Pru presses on with Egg flotation
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Prudential is to defy the market scare over dot.com stocks and press on with the flotation of its loss-making Egg banking subsidiary, albeit at a reduced price.
fields.body:
Prudential is to defy the market scare over dot.com stocks and press on with the flotation of its loss-making Egg banking subsidiary, albeit at a reduced price.

While the market had been expecting Egg to be valued at £1.5bn to £2bn after the share sale, analysts said yesterday they expected £1.5bn to become the upper end of the price range.

As Pru insisted that the flotation was "proceeding as planned," it began to run into controversy over its intention to let only customers and employees buy shares over the internet with a debit card.

The insurer, which clarified its position after speculation that the deal was in jeopardy, intends to issue a prospectus by the end of the week.

The document will be scrutinised for an indicative price range for the share sale, further details of when Egg might break into profit, and the terms under which Mike Harris, the bank's founder, and his management team have been locked in.

Egg has already promised to give its 1,400 employees £100 of free shares as well as £900 in options but has yet to reveal any longer-term bonus schemes for its senior staff.

They are expected to be generously rewarded as the Pru, which is expected to retain 80% ownership of the banking unit, has already admitted that one of the reasons for the share sale is to make it easier to retain staff.

To avoid the problems over pricing and demand for shares incurred by Lastminute.com, Pru is conducting the share sale over the internet and restricting purchases to applicants who have debit cards. To cope with potential demand, Pru is restricting the share sale to £1,000 for the 1m customers of Egg and Pru bank and all of its employees and will accept applications only over the internet.

Industry sources believe that Goldman Sachs, which is advising Pru on the flotation, has decided to proceed with the share sale after receiving indications of sufficient demand from institutional investors.

Pricing the shares is expected to be more difficult than usual given the volatility of the market for technology shares, which is languishing at half its record high of three months ago.

One leading analyst said that the Pru would be more concerned if it failed to incur enough demand for shares, rather than the amount of money it stood to raise.

fields.headline: Hip hop at a crossroads
fields.standfirst:
Mos Def
Astoria, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Mos Def
Astoria, London
*****
fields.body:
Mos Def has defied the wisdom that hip hop innovation means ugliness, and has been held up as an iconoclast. The expansiveness of his mindset is showcased best on the third song aired here, New World Water, which scratches at the sour underbelly of social policy by outlining our need and exploitation of water: an uncharacteristic hip hop subject.

It's this combination of probing thought and battle ready flow that first caught the attention of his former mentors, A Tribe Called Quest. Unlike ATCQ frontman Q-Tip, who has slowly lost the plot, Mos Def knows that staying true to the best in yourself means talking in dark, visionary tongues. After all, there isn't room in his systematic principles for a rented approach.

This was no ordinary hip hop show: Mos Def took the unprecedented step of dispensing with a DJ and employing a distinguished live band. The band, which included On-U-Sound stalwart Doug Wimbush on bass, had the good sense to understate rather than compete. Tending to begin with a couple of rhythmic or melodic fragments and expand outwards, the four-piece tapped New York's passion for electro funk. After a stint with jazz beats, the band cranked up the P-Funk meter, keeping the melodies minimal and the drums hard and snapping.

As Mos Def grew more focused, he became less faithful to one style. A slippery chameleon, he seemed equally at home singing the heartfelt ballad Love, rocking out to a full metal racket or leading a traditional call-and-response routine. At this musical crossroads, Mos Def has created several types of music at once, with acoustic beats as stark as x-rays. That you couldn't always hear him was a testament to the crowd's raucous participation, even though only a few songs qualified as sing-along anthems: the clear-eyed prose poems on his solo debut, Black on Both Sides are far too abstract and radical for that.

Before slipping into a perfect rendition of Sly and the Family Stone's Stand, Mos Def pushed his versatility to its limits with his forthcoming single, Umi Says. "Umi says, shine a light on the world, let my people be free," he sang, pitching his smooth vocals over humungous, low resolution beats. It may be a cliche, but in the mouth of Mos Def it felt vital, a sign that hip hop's future is bright.

webTitle: Miracles are not just for the US - George

fields.headline: Miracles are not just for the US - George
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Information technology might be putting Britain on the verge of a productivity miracle, Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Information technology might be putting Britain on the verge of a productivity miracle, Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, suggested yesterday.

In the forward to the Bank's annual report, Mr George said that the economy looked set for a period of strong growth and low inflation as intense high street competition and the potential of e-commerce reduced price pressures. He suggested that investment in IT might have raised the speed at which the economy could grow without causing inflation.

"There is also a possibility - no more than that at the moment, because of the lack of statistical evidence - that the spread of IT will raise the overall growth potential of the economy," Mr George noted.

Mr George said that while any improvement in the potential growth rate was "in the realms of speculation," the economy had been growing strongly, and above its trend rate.

Mr George said the Bank had kept interest rates lower than they would have been if the pound had not been so strong. This had allowed faster growth in domestic demand.

webTitle: Two crazy days, one big hangover

fields.headline: Two crazy days, one big hangover
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: For two days in December the net goldrush reached dizzying heights. Only a few days before Christmas 24-year-old entrepreneur Jonathan Rowland saw his family's stake in investment company JellyWorks increase tenfold to £70m on its market debut.
fields.body:
For two days in December the net goldrush reached dizzying heights. Only a few days before Christmas 24-year-old entrepreneur Jonathan Rowland saw his family's stake in investment company JellyWorks increase tenfold to £70m on its market debut.

JellyWorks appeared to be a notable example of how the "new" economy worked. The business was formed just six weeks before it joined the market and was given an instant value of £100m. Its only assets were £11m cash and another £9m loan facility - wily observers noted investing in JellyWorks made for expensive money.

A day later Mark Slater, son of the renowned financier Jim Slater, saw shares in his investment fund Internet Indirect soar ninefold on their market debut. Mr Slater's stake was valued at £9m after the first day's trading.

For many observers the extraordinary performance of the clutch of internet investment funds or incubators which joined the market at the end of last year marked the height of the boom.

As a consequence they seem to have been punished more than most: the idea of notional wealth has probably never been better expressed.

In a subsequent placing Internet Indirect raised further money and is now sitting on around £75m in cash and a market capitalisation of just £56m. "It's a pretty perverse situation to be at a discount to your cash," Mr Slater said. Internet Indirect shares have slumped from a peak of 94.5p to 17.5p; JellyWorks has stumbled from a high of 127p to 22.5p. Durlacher, an investment bank which has specialised in internet stocks, has seen its share price rise to 447p in a couple of months and then sink back to 60p in the same length of time.

"Investment funds or incubators are a leverage play on the health of the internet market," said Peter Bradshaw, an internet analyst at investment bank Merrill Lynch.

"When things are good they outperform their peers, and when they are not so good they underperform."

JellyWorks has made a number of investments, including stakes in hardware and software company Com Telco International, digital media group TalkCast Corporation and MatchNet, an online dating agency.

Net Investor raised £100m, and has so made around 130 investments totalling £20m in US venture funds. The company's market capitalisation - at around £75m - is, like Internet Indirect, lower than the cash still in the bank. "That means you get all of our investments for zip," said Net Investor's Tim Childs.

The outlook, however, is not necessarily bleak. Internet Indirect has probably been one of the more cautious and has made only one investment so far. But Mr Slater is anything but downbeat.

"The key thing is we have a lot of cash and the price of potential targets has come down significantly.

"If you have a lot of cash in a weak market that puts you in a hell of a position - you can get three or four times for your money what you could a few months ago.

"The ideal position would be that our shares were flying, we had loads of cash and our targets' shares were crashing - but that's not how real life works."

His comments were echoed by Mr Childs, who also noted that as the brakes are put on market flotations, the number of investment opportunities for funds correspondingly increases.

"The current state of the market is creating enormous opportunities. It's excel lent for us because a large part of our fund will be invested at very attractive prices.

"If the correction had happened in a couple of years' time when our money was all invested it would be different, but as it this is excellent for us."

For Net Investor the slide has not been quite so marked: its shares have dropped from 252p to 145p - but then it was never valued at five times its cash.

The precipitous nature of the slide in companies such as JellyWorks and Internet Indirect has been an acute expression of two crazy days in December.

"If you have a lot of cash in a weak market that puts you in a hell of a position - you can get three or four times for your money what you could a few months ago. "The ideal position would be that our shares were flying, we had loads of cash and our targets' shares were crashing - but that's not how real life works." His comments were echoed by Mr Childs, who also noted that as the brakes are put on market flotations, the number of investment opportunities for funds correspondingly increases. "The current state of the market is creating enormous opportunities. It's excel lent for us because a large part of our fund will be invested at very attractive prices. "If the correction had happened in a couple of years' time when our money was all invested it would be different, but as it this is excellent for us." For Net Investor the slide has not been quite so marked: its shares have dropped from 252p to 145p - but then it was never valued at five times its cash. The precipitous nature of the slide in companies such as JellyWorks and Internet Indirect has been an acute expression of two crazy days in December.

webTitle: Brown defends his choice of academic who flunked exam

fields.headline: Brown defends his choice of academic who flunked exam
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday issued a defiant response to MPs urging him to rethink his plan to fill a vacancy on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee with Oxford don Christopher Allsopp.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday issued a defiant response to MPs urging him to rethink his plan to fill a vacancy on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee with Oxford don Christopher Allsopp.

He told the treasury committee that Mr Allsopp was one of a line of distinguished academics to serve on the committee and that there was no question of his changing his mind about the appointment.

"The appointments to the MPC are a matter for the chancellor," the Treasury said in a statement. "Mr Allsopp's appointment has been widely welcomed including personally by the governor and deputy governor of the Bank of England."

The treasury committee questioned Mr Allsopp's competence in a report issued yesterday after a stormy hearing on Monday where Labour MP Brian Sedgemore said replacing Charles Goodhart with Mr Allsopp was like substituting a player from Arsenal or Manchester United with one from the Vauxhall league, maybe Kidderminster.

The report said the committee had been "disappointed in his answers to our questions, and believe that this casts doubt on whether he possesses the skills required to take part in meetings of the MPC". By a vote of five to four it called on the chancellor to rethink Mr Allsopp's appointment.

Giles Radice, the committee chairman, who only votes if there is a tie, said he sided with the minority which felt that Mr Allsopp's academic background and practical experience outweighed his sometimes hesitant performance at Monday's hearing.

"I side with the minority which felt that just because he flunked the viva [oral exam], you shouldn't fail him on the whole examination," Mr Radice said.

But Labour MP James Plaskitt said the MPC was not an academic debating forum and that members should be able express and defend their views and decisions in a convincing way to business and the wider community.

fields.headline: Susan Hiller's Witness
fields.standfirst:
Susan Hiller's Witness
***
The Chapel, London
fields.trailText:
Susan Hiller's Witness
***
The Chapel, London
fields.body:
In Artangel's latest commission Susan Hiller fills a disused chapel near London's Westway with the sounds of people describing UFO encounters. The effect is strange, of course, but also familiar as you climb a spiral staircase to the installation - just as you did with Douglas Gordon's Artangel piece - and enter the kind of dilapidated space Iain Sinclair might inhabit with a dead scholar. Artangel specialises in quirky spaces, but it would be good to see one of its commissions in a McDonalds or a car park.

Meanwhile, we get Hiller's collection of hundreds of eyewitness accounts of UFOs landing in fields in Buckinghamshire, hovering over Sydney or buzzing around villages in the Philippines. Entering the upper room of the chapel you see a multitude of little loudspeakers hanging on wires. A babble of voices talk at once, muttering like the voices of the dead or the legion of the damned. It is called Witness, but the sounds are blurred in this scary hive of noise, which is cinematic in its creation of atmosphere but also glib in a Hollywood way; we are encouraged not to listen to the details but to soak up the background hum. Put your ear to a speaker and an Australian is describing something odd he and his mates encountered. Leave him, the hum gets louder, and a girl from Spain is telling an equally eerie story. Are these actual witnesses or actors?

In the fictive space Hiller has created there is an echo of Plato's cave where people watch shadows on the wall mistaking them for reality. The little round loudspeakers might have doubled as flying saucers in Plan 9 From Outer Space, an effect heightened when you see their shadows on the floor. These shadows are like the remote experience of the witnesses; something that can only be known at second hand.

The sheer quantity of voices is unsettling. There is conviction in numbers. But what is missing from Witness is attention to detail. In Hiller's rightly celebrated collection From the Freud Museum (1991-6) she precisely noted the tangle of historical and personal meaning in even the most trivial thing. Here that web gives way to a fog of sound and light. It's impressive, in a highly aestheticised way. For hardcore Hiller go and see From the Freud Museum at Tate Modern. Meanwhile, it may be time for Artangel to get less aesthetic, more tacky. It is time for Plan 9 - yes, Plan 9

At the Chapel, London W10 (020-7336 6803), till June 25.

fields.headline: Gleeful musical tag
fields.standfirst:
Cologne WDR Symphony Orchestra/ Semyon Bychkov
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Cologne WDR Symphony Orchestra/ Semyon Bychkov
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Founded in 1947 and conducted throughout its history by such luminaries as Otto Klemperer, Fritz Busch and Herbert von Karajan, the Cologne WDR Symphony - effectively the West German Radio orchestra - isn't as well known to UK audiences as some of its counterparts. This formidable concert, under its current music director Semyon Bychkov, will hopefully have strengthened its reputation. It proved an impressive ensemble with a luscious string sound and vibrant, slightly edgy brass; its chief glory was its woodwind, finely honed and by turns sensual and pointillistic. The relationship with Bychkov is, one suspects, something special: the evening found him on much better form than I've heard him for some time.

The programme paired Mendelssohn with Strauss. The flamboyant Labecque sisters, Katia and Marielle, were the soloists in Mendelssohn's E Major Concerto for Two Pianos, written for him and his sister Fanny when he was only 14. In some respects it shows its juvenility, gathering together the influences that eventually formed the mature composer. Allusions to Bach, late Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven are welded into a whole that has the melodic ingenuity and textural buoyancy of the overture to A Midsummer Night's Dream, with which it is roughly contemporaneous. The nocturnal slow movement is a bit of a cheat: since the soloists rarely play together, it technically could be done with one pianist. The outer movements, however, found the Labecques alternately vying with each other in bravura panache - there were some stunning double cadenzas - and playing gleeful, rip-roaring games of musical tag.

Ein Heldenleben followed, done comparatively straight and missing the flashes of irony that some (myself included) have read into Strauss's portrait of himself as a star composer fending off the sallies of his critics. There were some minor flaws here: the balance at the beginning of the battle sequence came slightly adrift, with the percussion threatening to obliterate the brass; the final section, begun with opulent spaciousness, dawdled towards the end. Elsewhere, however, it was supremely sumptuous, full of cocksure bravado, cannily sexy in the love scenes and gloriously played throughout. The encores were generous, with a wistful, translucent performance of the Polonaise from Dvorak's Slavonic Dances followed by a galvanic version of the third-act prelude from Lohengrin. The Labecques brought the house down, meanwhile, improvising jazzily on themes by Gershwin. Great fun.

fields.headline: Money Channel signs with Telewest
fields.trailText: The Money Channel will be hoping to stem the slide in its share price this morning with the announcement that the pay-TV business has agreed a carriage deal with cable company Telewest.
fields.body:
The Money Channel will be hoping to stem the slide in its share price this morning with the announcement that the pay-TV business has agreed a carriage deal with cable company Telewest.

The company, founded by former pop singer Adam Faith, is understood to have reached terms for transmission on the Telewest digital service which aims to have 500,000 subscribers by the end of this year. It can only be seen at present on BSkyB's digital service.

Shares in the Money Channel have fallen from a peak of 548.5p in January to a low for the year of 80p yesterday, off a further 7p. The continuing decline prompted a statement from the company saying it knew of no reason for the slide and describing its recent split from adviser Grant Thornton as entirely amicable. The Money Channel has consolidated its advisory business with broker CCF Charterhouse.

Mr Faith said he was bemused by the behaviour of the market. "Who knows what will happen to our share price with the markets the way they are. We seem to have bundled in with the hi-tech sector. But I'm certainly not selling any shares because the future is so exciting for this business."

The schedule for the channel, which launched in February, includes shows for the over-50s, corporate profiles, personal finance phone-ins and short City bulletins.

Mr Faith has had the unfortunate experience of launching a pay-TV channel aimed at amateur investors just as the markets turned sour. The plunge in hi-techs has in many cases hurt those people it would be keenest to attract.

Much of the channel's hopes are pinned on the introduction of interactive services which could allow the business to become a lucrative cypher for the sale of financial services.

Mr Faith was reluctant to give viewing figures but said he was pleased with the progress so far. He will no doubt hope that it is pure coincidence that the slide in the company's share price began just after the channel first went on air in February and that investors are not being turned off by what they see on screen. If that is the case, a carriage deal with Telewest will only accelerate the plunge instead of fixing it.

fields.headline: Developer pushes for city shopping
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The "experience" of city centre shopping rather than the "convenience" of out of town shopping centres must be promoted if bricks and mortar retailers are to beat off net rivals, according to Land Securities.
fields.body:
The "experience" of city centre shopping rather than the "convenience" of out of town shopping centres must be promoted if bricks and mortar retailers are to beat off net rivals, according to Land Securities.

As a result of pressure on the profit margins of big retailers from online shoppers, Ian Henderson - the property developer's chief executive - believes shopping will have to become an increasingly sophisticated event.

"This means a focus on city centres which provide a range and diversity not available in the out of town shopping mall," Mr Henderson said.

He said changing shopping habits showed why it was increasingly important that London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, promoted better transport and applied consistent planning policies in the capital.

Reporting a 12% rise in pre-tax profits for the year to the end of March of £328m, Land Securities attempted to dismiss speculation that smaller rival Capital Shopping was preparing to launch a bid by highlighting Capital's recent move to halve its 3% stake in the group.

Mr Henderson said London had continued to perform well outside the euro zone and said he would need "quite a lot persuading" to back Britain's entry into the euro.

Land Securities' shares, of which it bought back £250m last year when they fell out favour during the dot.com frenzy, rose 22.5p to 827.5p. It will pay a 31p dividend - a rise of 5.1%.

fields.headline: United buyout threatens BA
fields.standfirst:
Air deal creates east coast powerhouse

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A new threat faces British Airways after the world's biggest airline, United Airlines, bought out US Airways for more than $11bn (£6.9m) yesterday.
fields.body:
A new threat faces British Airways after the world's biggest airline, United Airlines, bought out US Airways for more than $11bn (£6.9m) yesterday.

The deal, which includes $4.6bn in cash, will create a powerhouse in the eastern US. US Airways, the 6th largest airline in America, has been struggling for some years as low-cost airlines challenged its dominance on the short haul east coast market.

Under the deal each share of US Airways will be converted into the right to receive $60 a share in cash. That represents a hefty 137% premium to US Airways' closing price of 25 15/16 on Tuesday on the New York stock exchange.

US Airways was once part of an alliance with British Airways, which held a 24% stake in the company.

BA had been looking for a toehold in the eastern US and thought that it had succeeded when it bought a chunk of US Air. But the deal ended in acrimony when it emerged that BA was trying to merge with American Airlines.

The door appeared to be left open for other airlines to bid for US Airways last night. The company's chairman and chief executive, Stephen Wolf, said US Airways would still consider other potential rival offers to United's $11.6bn bid.

Speaking at a joint news conference, Mr Wolf said: "We are committed to the merger ... but if someone else comes along we'll have to consider that, too."

United is confident the deal will go through. The merged airline would have 145,000 staff, nearly 1,000 aircraft - 50% more than its nearest rival, American - and 6,500 flights daily.

United said it would freeze domestic fares for two years, except for fuel cost rises, to allay fears that the merger would be anti-competitive.

However the deal still faces regulatory hurdles and drew criticism from United workers. Pilots said they have strong concerns over the proposed merger, adding they were deeply disappointed the deal was made without the full agreement of their union.

The UAL-Master Executive Council, representing 10,000 United pilots, will hold a meeting next week in Chicago to review the issues created by the US Airways transaction, together with legal and financial advisers and UAL's senior management team. The pilots are in a pivotal position as they own 25% of United's stock.

To meet competition concerns United is to sell most of US Airways' routes at Ronald Reagan airport in Washington DC to entrepreneur Robert L Johnson, chairman and chief executive of Black Entertainment Television.

fields.headline: The final cut
fields.trailText: 25 May: I don't want to be a hairdresser but how can I give my friend the chop?
fields.body:
The problem

I am a hairstylist, working three days a week at a small but busy salon. I am also a full time college student. The problem with this is that my boss, who is also a friend, is trying to have children and has it in her mind that when she does I will be the one to take over her heavy work load.

I have other things I'd like to do with my life. How should I tell her this? She already knows that I am continuing my education and in the past I have talked to her about my plans to move out of the area. I don't know how to get her to understand.

The solution

It seems that you have told her, but in her enthusiasm for planning your life, she is preferring not to listen. I wouldn't worry too much about this because, despite your friend's efforts to make this your problem, it isn't. If and when your friend becomes pregnant, she will then have eight or nine months to find and train up her successor. You could perhaps help for an interim period, but she will have to understand that your career aspirations lie elsewhere.

So, how to get through to her? The next time she makes a remark about you being her successor for all eternity, you could take her aside over a cup of tea and explain that whilst you are flattered by her faith in you, and will endeavour to help with any transitional period, it is not what you want in the long-term. After all this is why you are at college. There's no need to take it further at this stage since she will have plenty of time to get the salon sorted, with your help, as and when the time comes.

Just don't delay your career plans out of some misplaced loyalty for this friend. And don't let anyone else plan your life - that is your job.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Notre-Dame de Paris, Dominion Theatre, London

fields.headline: Notre-Dame de Paris
fields.standfirst:
Dominion Theatre, London
*
fields.trailText:
Dominion Theatre, London
*
fields.body:
Alan Ayckbourn imagines a future in Comic Potential whereby TV soaps are performed by androids. We seem to have got to a similar point with this ghastly robotic Gallic musical. The characters are simply cartoon ciphers, and they all sport headset mikes, which rule out any close encounters and suggest they're all in contact with HQ. The music is from a backing track, adding to the air of inhuman detachment.

The bitter irony is that all this is applied to a highly theatrical Victor Hugo story that reeks of frustrated passion. The Gypsy, Esmeralda, is loved by the hunchback Quasimodo and lusted after by the priestly Frollo. Esmeralda adores an amorous captain, the rising Phoebus, himself engaged to the frenzied Fleur-de-Lys.

Enough love there to generate a bit of heat. But in Gilles Maheu's antiseptic production we seem to have a rock concert in frocks spiced up with displays of muscular aerobics from performers purporting to be asylum-seeking refugees.

The story sinks under the relentless barrage of Richard Cocciante's music, which has a seamless Gallic monotony. And Luc Plamondon's lyrics, rendered into something passing for English by Will Jennings, are often impenetrable - or raise a derisory titter. "Arrest that man, he's the hunchback of Notre-Dame", suggests that Mr Jennings was not born under a rhyming star. And lyrics like Esmeralda's "He is shining like the sun, he's my dream, my only one" prove that Cole Porter's reputation is not under immediate threat.

What is so dismaying is that the show denies narrative, emotion and human contact; we just get cardboard cut-outs bawling at each other. And there's a cold gigantism - towering columns detach from the cathedral facade and prowl the stage, at one point threatening to do Frollo serious injury. Acrobats climb the wall (I know how they felt), and no fewer than three Quasimodos swing from the bells like drunk campanologists.

Quasimodo is the hero, appropriately for what is a quasi-musical. fields.bodyText: Alan Ayckbourn imagines a future in Comic Potential whereby TV soaps are performed by androids. We seem to have got to a similar point with this ghastly robotic Gallic musical. The characters are simply cartoon ciphers, and they all sport headset mikes, which rule out any close encounters and suggest they're all in contact with HQ. The music is from a backing track, adding to the air of inhuman detachment. The bitter irony is that all this is applied to a highly theatrical Victor Hugo story that reeks of frustrated passion. The Gypsy, Esmeralda, is loved by the hunchback Quasimodo and lusted after by the priestly Frollo. Esmeralda adores an amorous captain, the rising Phoebus, himself engaged to the frenzied Fleur-de-Lys. Enough love there to generate a bit of heat. But in Gilles Maheu's antiseptic production we seem to have a rock concert in frocks spiced up with displays of muscular aerobics from performers purporting to be asylum-seeking refugees. The story sinks under the relentless barrage of Richard Cocciante's music, which has a seamless Gallic monotony. And Luc Plamondon's lyrics, rendered into something passing for English by Will Jennings, are often impenetrable - or raise a derisory titter. "Arrest that man, he's the hunchback of Notre-Dame", suggests that Mr Jennings was not born under a rhyming star. And lyrics like Esmeralda's "He is shining like the sun, he's my dream, my only one" prove that Cole Porter's reputation is not under immediate threat. What is so dismaying is that the show denies narrative, emotion and human contact; we just get cardboard cut-outs bawling at each other. And there's a cold gigantism - towering columns detach from the cathedral facade and prowl the stage, at one point threatening to do Frollo serious injury. fields.headline: Marathon man of the crease
fields.standfirst: Prolific Sales is hungry for a test spot should England's top six falter
fields.trailText: While his Northamptonshire colleagues prepared for today's championship match against Middlesex in the indoor nets, David Sales was driving around a saturated Silverstone racetrack in a saloon car yesterday morning.
fields.body:
While his Northamptonshire colleagues prepared for today's championship match against Middlesex in the indoor nets, David Sales was driving around a saturated Silverstone racetrack in a saloon car yesterday morning.

But those concerned that Sales is about to have his head turned at a time when his potential as a test player is being seriously talked about need not worry. His morning off was for the benefit of Channel 4's Cricket Roadshow and came with his club's blessing. And he was back in the nets in the afternoon.

"It was a bit wet and there were a couple of scary moments," he said. "One wheel wouldn't grip because there were a few puddles out there. We were on the small track and I got up to between 90 and 100." Which is disappointing, really, because he usually prefers to go past 200.

Four years ago he became the first Englishman to score a double century on his championship debut. His 210 not out against Worcestershire at the age of 18 years and 237 days also made him the youngest English double centurion.

And there is more. Last season he became the youngest English batsman to score a triple century, 303 not out against Essex. A month later he compiled 205 against Leicestershire and in this month's match against Nottinghamshire he was stopped on 276.

"I was run out by my colleague Michael Davies, unfortunately," he said ruefully. "It was a bit of a 'yes, no, yes, sorry' situation. I had three wickets to bat with and I was homing in on another triple century and looking to take the club record." He was 47 runs short of surpassing Mal Loye's 1998 mark.

Sales has played for England at Under-15 and Under-19 level and has been on two A tours, scoring a century in the final international of last winter's series in New Zealand. The statistics suggest that, at 22, he is ready for a test call-up.

So what are the selectors waiting for?

First, there is no obvious opening in the England side. Michael Vaughan, when he is fit, and Graham Thorpe, when he finds form, are sure to be ahead of him should England's top six from Lord's begin to unravel.

Second, though no one questions his appetite for runs, one or two have questioned his appetite. Sales would not look out of place down the road at Franklins Gardens, the home of Northampton RFC.

"I'm about 15st 4lb and through the season I'm trying to lose about 1st," he admitted. "It will help me in the long run so I'm giving it a go. We're trying to turn the fat into muscle and so I've been doing a lot more exercises like bench pressing. I'm trying to burn off calories as well."

Sales, who played his first match for Northamptonshire at 16, blames his heavy frame on the culture shock of leaving home at a young age. "When I first came away from home I didn't eat very well for two years because I didn't have my mother cooking for me," he said. "Being 16, 17, the last thing you want to do is go into the kitchen and cook something. My options ran from baked beans on toast to scrambled egg on toast, and that gets a bit boring after a while so you tend to eat junk food."

Northamptonshire are supportive of their talented young player. As well as working closely with the club's fitness expert Richard Smith, Sales has received the backing of captain and coach. "David Sales is not going to run a marathon in double quick time but he's got a reasonable-to-good standard of fitness," said Bob Carter, Northamptonshire's director of coaching. "He's quick between the wickets and he's a very good fielder."

In an extraordinarily idiosyncratic piece of research, Carter has also uncovered that Sales has already made as many scores over 200 as Sir Colin Cowdrey, another player with a fuller figure. It's not only journalists who find facts to fit a good story.

Sales's captain, the Australian Matthew Hayden, used other solid examples. "Allan Border, Mark Taylor and David Boon were always fairly stocky and there you are talking about some magnificent cricketers," he said. "If David Sales wants to do something like play for England, it's within his potential."

webTitle: Kirtley's three strikes put smile back on Adams' face

fields.headline: Kirtley's three strikes put smile back on Adams' face
fields.trailText: Essex 59-3 v Sussex
fields.body:
Chris Adams can be forgiven for feeling the whole world is against him. The season is only a month old, his Sussex side are bottom in Division Two and he has already patched up a disagreement with the umpire David Constant over his dismissal at Hove.

Next Tuesday he appears before the England and Wales Cricket Board disciplinary committee to answer charges of verbally and physically abusing the Essex all-rounder Danny Law during the Benson & Hedges cup tie here last month.

Adams will deny the allegations at the hearing, when Nasser Hussain, his England captain in South Africa last winter, is expected to give evidence against him.

Yesterday, he behaved impeccably but he had no cause to throw a tantrum as Essex were reduced to 59 for three on a day curtailed by the rain.

Adams was able to adopt a wide grin in the second over, when James Kirtley collected the first of his three wickets. Paul Prichard stayed long enough to gather seven runs from two scoring strokes before being beaten and bowled by a full-length delivery.

Soon afterwards Darren Robinson, after one lucky edge, chopped a short delivery on to his stumps and then Kirtley claimed the most prized Essex wicket, that of Stuart Law.

The Australian, who had scored 258 runs on his three previous first-class trips to the crease, had already survived one confident appeal for a catch behind before Kirtley's next was upheld. This time Law's outside edge was found as he pushed forward and the wicketkeeper Andy Patterson was engulfed by his team-mates, Adams among them, as he gleefully held a straightforward catch.

It was just reward for Kirtley, who had been lively rather than venomous but who seldom wasted a ball. His nagging line and length, plus his ability to get the occasional delivery to move away quite sharply, always posed problems and has so far earned him figures of three for 30 from nine overs.

On a couple of other occasions Kirtley beat the bat without reward as Essex were left questioning their decision to bat first. Not that Adams was complaining.

webTitle: Kent cry foul as Dravid leads Indian exodus

fields.headline: Kent cry foul as Dravid leads Indian exodus
fields.trailText: Surrey 135-2 v Kent
fields.body:
The Kent chief executive Paul Millman is wearing a face as long as a cricket pitch, and not just because only 47 overs were bowled here yesterday.

Rahul Dravid, the exotic Indian batsman who is Kent's overseas player this season, heads for Bangladesh at the weekend to play in the Asia Cup. He will be away until June 8 and will miss two championship matches and two one-day games.

He will be accompanied by Leicestershire's Anil Kumble and Lancashire's Sourav Ganguly. Cricket's club-versus-county debate is not limited to those England players centrally contracted to the England and Wales Cricket Board.

In the past the availability of overseas players posed few problems because cricket was played virtually nowhere else during England's summer months. That has changed in recent years, with the plethora of one-day tournaments complicating the issue.

When Kent signed Dravid last October they knew nothing about the Asia Cup and, because of the late notice of the tournament, Millman asked India to exclude Dravid from the squad. He did not receive a reply but, having seen Dravid not only named but appointed vice-captain this week, he assumes his request fell on deaf ears.

Now he wants the issue discussed at the International Cricket Council's June meeting and also at the next get-together of the first-class forum. It is difficult enough to market county cricket without star players being dragged away.

Kent already have plenty of headaches, with Dean Headley likely to miss the season and Mark Ealham certain to make England's one-day squad. With Julian Thompson (knee), Martin McCague (ankle) and Ben Phillips (back) also out of action their bowling is in crisis.

At least this resulted in Kristian Adams, a left-arm seamer who swings the ball in, making his championship debut yesterday and he marked it by claiming the notable wicket of Graham Thorpe.

There was half a day's play, which made everyone feel rather privileged when the news came in from the rest of the country. Kent and Surrey have now lost more than 700 overs to the weather in this embryonic season.

Surrey won the toss and scored 135 for two with Ian Ward, whose 73 not out has included 10 fours, playing the best. Ben Hollioake, who was almost caught at third slip before he had scored, is on 24.

Ward and Mark Butcher put on 66 for the first wicket before Butcher was caught behind off Ealham. Thorpe followed three runs later, also caught behind, and for a while it looked as though dynamite might be required to remove him from the crease; he looked most disconsolate, although this may have been because of his indifferent form as much as the decision.

He had made only three runs from 15 balls after surviving a confident lbw appeal, and in all cricket this season he has scored 110 runs in nine innings. His championship scores have been 0, 18, 1, 11 and 3. And all this with the former England coach David Lloyd on his back. He must feel that his England place is as far away as ever.

 Alan Mullally said yesterday that he hopes to make his Hampshire debut in next Tuesday's National League match against Surrey at the Oval, having missed the start of the season with a rib injury.

webTitle: Spanish ready to serve up feast

fields.headline: Spanish ready to serve up feast
fields.standfirst: Real and England hope for more of McManaman's best tonight
fields.trailText: David Lacey previews tonight's showdown in Paris and finds more than Spanish interest in the individual performances of players on show in the run-up to Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Just in case the city's brasseries cannot cope, a truckload of paella will arrive here from Spain today, courtesy of Valencia's sponsor, to ensure that the supporters of whoever wins tonight's all-Spanish Champions League final will not have to celebrate on empty stomachs.

As for the other side's fans, if Real Madrid, seven times winners of the European Cup and appearing in their 11th final, are beaten in the Stade de France their supporters are likely to lose their appetites.

Valencia, comparative upstarts in this competition, may not have Real's pedigree but they have struck an awesome run of form in getting this far, knocking out Lazio and Barcelona amid a glut of goals. Back home, moreover, they have just overtaken Real in the Spanish league to finish third, guaranteeing themselves a place in next season's final qualifying round for the Champions League. Fifth-placed Real, on the other hand, can only stay in the tournament by winning tonight.

It promises to be an intriguing confrontation and a better game of football than last season's final in Barcelona, even if stoppage-time is unlikely to produce the high drama of Manchester United's bag-snatching victory over Bayern Munich. Both Real and Valencia are capable of playing attacking football of the highest order, backed by solid defending and shrewd midfield play.

The final concerns more than purely Spanish interests. Several individual performances will be studied for any signals they might send out for the European Championship starting in less than three weeks.

For French eyes Nicolas Anelka, whose recent return to scoring form has made him a serious candidate for a striker's role in their squad for Euro 2000, will hold the attention in the Real attack, if and when he appears. Likewise the performances of Raul and Fernando Morientes will be closely assessed for what they might represent in terms of Spain's chances.

Then there is Steve McManaman, fast becoming Kevin Keegan's totem on the basis of his recent Champions League games for Real, even if his poor showing for England in Poland last September appeared to offer final proof that he was not an international footballer.

"I don't think that there's any better player than Steve McManaman playing in Europe at present," declared Keegan somewhat startlingly this week. "He has suddenly hit a vein of form that he hasn't had for two or three years. He was superb against Manchester United in the quarter-finals."

Certainly McManaman has prospered playing on Real's right and drifting towards the middle to link with Raul and Morientes. Keegan, however, has him earmarked for the problem position on England's left and hopes to be further persuaded tonight of the former Liverpool player's versatility. "The way he's performing at the moment you could play him anywhere," the coach added. "I've asked him to go deep, and so have Real. I've seen him back defending on his own goalline. And he already does a lot of work down the left side."

If Vicente del Bosque's Real are to win tonight McManaman will surely need to be the influence he was against United in both legs of that tie. Much will depend on Fernando Redondo and Ivan Helguera creating the platform in midfield from which McManaman can operate while Michel Salgado and Roberto Carlos push up on the wings.

With Javier Farinos and Gerard seeking to establish a similar command for Valencia the game may take a little while to open up, although given the attacking propensities of both sides the early goal which all these big occasions need is not impossible.

Valencia's main threat is likely to come from their captain Gaizka Mendieta on the right and Kily Gonzalez. Real will look to Raul for goals, although Anelka could be the wild card that wins the match.

With the left-back Amadeo Carboni suspended, Valencia may recall the Swedish international Joachim Bjorklund to their defence. Savio, Real's Brazilian left-winger, is very doubtful with a damaged knee, Salgado less so after twisting an ankle.

Hector Cuper, Valencia's Argentine coach, has threatened to perform a striptease should his team win. Just so long as there is enough naked aggression to make this one of the more memorable finals, even if it has to be settled by a golden goal in extra-time.

 Vicente del Bosque was yesterday rewarded for guiding Real Madrid into the Champions League final with a one-year contract as coach. The former Real player stepped up from head of youth development at the Bernabeu stadium to take control in a caretaker role when John Toshack was sacked in November.

Both Real and Valencia are capable of playing attacking football of the highest order, backed by solid defending and shrewd midfield play. The final concerns more than purely Spanish interests. Several individual performances will be studied for any signals they might send out for the European Championship starting in less than three weeks. For French eyes Nicolas Anelka, whose recent return to scoring form has made him a serious candidate for a striker's role in their squad for Euro 2000, will hold the attention in the Real attack, if and when he appears. Likewise the performances of Raul and Fernando Morientes will be closely assessed for what they might represent in terms of Spain's chances. Then there is Steve McManaman, fast becoming Kevin Keegan's totem on the basis of his recent Champions League games for Real, even if his poor showing for England in Poland last September appeared to offer final proof that he was not an international footballer. "I don't think that there's any better player than Steve McManaman playing in Europe at present," declared Keegan somewhat startlingly this week. "He has suddenly hit a vein of form that he hasn't had for two or three years. He was superb against Manchester United in the quarter-finals." Certainly McManaman has prospered playing on Real's right and drifting towards the middle to link with Raul and Morientes. Keegan, however, has him earmarked for the problem position on England's left and hopes to be further persuaded tonight of the former Liverpool player's versatility. "The way he's performing at the moment you could play him anywhere," the coach added. "I've asked him to go deep, and so have Real. I've seen him back defending on his own goalline. And he already does a lot of work down the left side." If Vicente del Bosque's Real are to win tonight McManaman will surely need to be the influence he was against United in both legs of that tie. Much will depend on Fernando Redondo and Ivan Helguera creating the platform in midfield from which McManaman can operate while Michel Salgado and Roberto Carlos push up on the wings. With Javier Farinos and Gerard seeking to establish a similar command for Valencia the game may take a little while to open up, although given the attacking propensities of both sides the early goal which all these big occasions need is not impossible. Valencia's main threat is likely to come from their captain Gaizka Mendieta on the right and Kily Gonzalez. Real will look to Raul for goals, although Anelka could be the wild card that wins the match. With the left-back Amadeo Carboni suspended, Valencia may recall the Swedish international Joachim Bjorklund to their defence. Savio, Real's Brazilian left-winger, is very doubtful with a damaged knee, Salgado less so after twisting an ankle. Hector Cuper, Valencia's Argentine coach, has threatened to perform a striptease should his team win. Just so long as there is enough naked aggression to make this one of the more memorable finals, even if it has to be settled by a golden goal in extra-time.  Vicente del Bosque was yesterday rewarded for guiding Real Madrid into the Champions League final with a one-year contract as coach. The former Real player stepped up from head of youth development at the Bernabeu stadium to take control in a caretaker role when John Toshack was sacked in November.

webTitle: No Giggs and no joy for Wales

fields.headline: No Giggs and no joy for Wales
fields.standfirst: Elber 62, Cafu 70, Rivaldo 72
fields.trailText: The scoreline might suggest that Wales could have pulled in the touchline 50 metres instead of five, played on treacle and still lost. But there was no disgrace in defeat last night. Until Brazil's burst of three goals in 10 minutes it seemed they might hold out.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
The scoreline might suggest that Wales could have pulled in the touchline 50 metres instead of five, played on treacle and still lost. But there was no disgrace in defeat last night. Until Brazil's burst of three goals in 10 minutes it seemed they might hold out.

Harrying and tackling impressively there were a number of positive aspects to their performance. Only when Elber gave Brazil the lead did the South Americans come to life and tear them apart. At 1-0 down John Robinson even had the temerity to hit a post.

But the signs were there beforehand that this might be a night of glorious failure for Wales. As the kick-off approached several surviving members of the team beaten 1-0 by Brazil in the 1958 World Cup quarter-finals were introduced to the crowd. Missing the totemic John Charles because of injury that day, Wales succumbed to a late Pele goal.

Last night it was the current star, Ryan Giggs, who was out of action because of a thigh problem. The disappointment was obvious among the 72,500 spectators, although there was a frisson of excitement when it was announced that the stadium roof would be closed, so producing Britain's first 11-a-side indoor football match.

If anyone had real cause to get excited, though, it was the Swansea goalkeeper Roger Freestone, handed his international debut at the age of 31 in the absence of the injured Paul Jones. In recent months he has been playing at such venues as Macclesfield and Brighton in the Third Division. Now Rivaldo & Co loomed.

His back four hardly exuded experience either, three of them First Division players and with 51 caps between them, so the former Chelsea goalkeeper must have been pleasantly surprised at his initial lack of action.

There was one worrying moment in the eighth minute when Franca's touch gave Rivaldo sight of goal, but the Barcelona player's shot skidded wide via a deflection and despite the occasional communication breakdown, Freestone had few wobbles.

Excitement, sadly, was also minimal. Although Brazil dominated possession and Rivaldo showed the odd touch of class, they were far from fluent. An uncharacteristic number of passes were misplaced and they conjured little in attack, though Wales defensive determination deserved some credit for that.

Iwan Roberts caused problems with his height up front but there was little to quicken the pulse until just before half-time. When Speed tried his luck from a long-range free-kick, Brazil's goalkeeper Dida looked shocked that he had been called upon to do something but Wales failed to capitalise when he spilled the ball.

Wales might have gone ahead within a minute of the second half when Gareth Roberts whipped in a cross. But Dean Saunders, scorer of the winner against Brazil in Cardiff in 1991, snatched at his shot.

Not surprisingly, Brazil continued to look the more likely to score, though there was little in their play to worry Kevin Keegan prior to Saturday's game at Wembley or to convince the Brazilian public that Wanderley Luxemburgo is the coach to lead them to a fifth World Cup.

Rivaldo saw a shot from 20 yards fly inches past Freestone's left post before the breakthrough came in the 62nd minute. Freestone saved well from Franca initially but could only parry the ball and Elber tapped in. Cafu scored Brazil's second not long after with a spectacular shot across Freestone before Rivaldo added the third with a header from Denilson's centre.

Wales (4-4-2): Freestone (Swansea); Delaney (Aston Villa), Page (Watford), Melville (Fulham), G Roberts (Tranmere); M Jones (Leeds; Bellamy , Norwich, 76min), Savage (Leicester; Johnson, Nottingham Forest, 76), Speed (Newcastle), Robinson (Charlton); Saunders (Bradford; Barnard , Barnsley, 84), I Roberts (Norwich).

Brazil (2-4-2-2): Dida (Corinthians); Antonio Carlos (Roma), Aldair (Roma; Emerson Carvalho , 84)); Cafu (Roma; Evanilson, Borussia Dortmund, 84)), Emerson (Bayer Leverkusen), Cesar Sampaio (Palmeiras), Silvinho (Arsenal); Ze Roberto (Bayer Leverkusen), Rivaldo (Barcelona; Marcos Assuncao , Roma, 84); Elber (Bayern Munich; Denilson , Real Betis,71), Franca (Sao Paulo).

Referee: V Pereira (Portugal).

webTitle: Celtic tempt O'Neill with £2m wage bait

fields.headline: Celtic tempt O'Neill with £2m wage bait
fields.trailText: Celtic are ready to offer Martin O'Neill the opportunity to transform the fortunes of the club he supported as a child.
fields.body:
Celtic are ready to offer Martin O'Neill the opportunity to transform the fortunes of the club he supported as a child.

Leicester City's manager now stands at the top of a shortlist which was shortened further yesterday when the Dutch coach Guus Hiddink was all but ruled out of the running for a post which has been vacant since the sacking of John Barnes three months ago.

Although O'Neill has not been formally approached by Celtic, he is aware of their interest and, despite his affection for Leicester, is likely to be interested in a job which has been described as the most difficult in British football.

He has two years left on the contract he signed last year, when he insisted on the inclusion of a get-out clause which guarantees him immediate release if an interested party agrees to pay a pre-set compensation fee, believed to be £1m.

The former Northern Ireland midfielder is also thought to have struck a loyalty agreement with Leicester designed to ensure the club will not suffer major disruption during a season. O'Neill, 48, reportedly promised his chairman John Elsom that he would talk to prospective employers only from mid-May to mid-June. It would seem Celtic are ready to use this window of opportunity to succeed where Everton and Leeds have failed in recent seasons.

Although O'Neill enjoys considerable support inside the Parkhead boardroom, at least two members of the Celtic hierarchy are in favour of hiring Mick McCarthy, the Republic of Ireland manager. But with the Celtic fans clamouring for a high-profile manager of experience and proven ability, a formal approach to Leicester for permission to open talks with O'Neill is believed to be imminent.

A move to Scotland would not only provide him with the opportunity he has long craved to make his mark at the highest level, it would also guarantee him financial security. Already one of the better-paid managers in Britain with a weekly wage of some £18,000, he could expect to pick up around £2m a year.

Although it is inevitable Leicester will launch yet another "O'Neill must stay" campaign, this time they may discover that their manager has finally outgrown a club who have the potential to succeed but not grow.

It is only O'Neill's commendable loyalty to Leicester and the fans which has kept him at the club. In the summer of 1998 he rejected the chance to succeed Howard Kendall at Everton and only six months later, perhaps reluctantly, he turned a deaf ear to overtures from Leeds after George Graham walked out to take over at Tottenham.

Since making a shaky start after arriving at Filbert Street from Norwich City in December 1995, he has transformed Leicester. In his four full seasons he has won two League Cups and steered the side to four top-10 finishes in the Premiership.

If O'Neill does decide to move, Leicester are likely to instal the long-serving Steve Walsh as manager, possibly on a short-term contract. The club's fear would be that Neil Lennon, Muzzy Izzet and Matt Elliott might also seek moves north of the border.

fields.headline: Loose-limbed Owen defies the doubts
fields.standfirst: The striker is raring to go after a year of hamstring trouble
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe finds Liverpool striker Michael Owen is raring to go after a year of hamstring trouble.
fields.body:
Michael Owen goes into his second major international tournament in a very different mood from his first. Two years ago the bright young kid on the block breezed into France brimming with the fearless self-belief of youth and departed a world star.

Two years ago it seemed the sole doubt about Owen was Glenn Hoddle only belatedly accepting that the 18-year-old's immediate inclusion for England was the natural next step in an unstoppable career. Now the doubts are all Owen's.

At Derby County in March last season he pulled his hamstring. After a few games out he returned, tried to run on to a through-ball at Leeds and dropped to the ground in agony.

His recovery was slow and he missed the first three games of this season. Eventually, when it looked as though the fault had been rectified, he limped off in the 29th minute of Liverpool's game against Middlesbrough in January and suddenly questions were being asked about whether Owen would ever return.

It is his first major injury and it came as a huge shock to a player whose career had, until then, progressed faultlessly from boy genius to world-renowned scorer of goals of the class that stunned Argentina.

Now, not only does Owen go into Euro 2000 with a reputation to uphold rather than to make, but with an injury to protect as well.

Every time he stretches for a ball or strains for the extra yard of pace that is so fundamental to his game, he hears an inner voice wondering whether the hamstring is about to go again.

"When I came back the first time I was a nervous wreck playing," he admits. "The hardest part of the injury by a mile has been thinking: 'Has it gone again?' "

Through more careful nursing and treatment, however, the injury has responded well enough to allow him to play all but one game of Liverpool's last two months of the season. And although Owen came through without any problems - he finished as the club's leading scorer with 11 goals in 27 league games - some wariness remained.

"It's natural that you think about the hamstring, but I don't think it's a risk," he replies. "If you can get the ball you've got to get the ball.

"As each game has gone on I've gained more confidence in the hamstring. I've played all these games and felt really sharp. I'm mentally fine now and physically OK. I definitely feel my game and fitness are back to where they were."

The final piece of confirmation Owen was waiting for came last Tuesday when he made another visit to his German specialist, Hans Müller-Wohlfahrt, who finally helped him diagnose the problem.

"When I first went, he felt my hamstring and the bottom of my back and immediately said: 'This specific disc is tight and it's causing this, and there is such and such here.' It really gave me confidence in him.

"When I visited him again on Tuesday he said: 'Perfect; 100% improvement.'

"Now, you can say it was a trip for nothing because he never did anything. But the biggest thing for me was to just put it in my mind that it was much better."

With his fitness and confidence restored, Owen may still be the player that lit up St Etienne. The only outward sign of change is in his warm-up, which now consists of 20 minutes of special exercises. And having appeared in only about 30 matches this season - he had played for two years without a break leading up to the injury - Owen even reckons he will be fresher than most.

"There is absolutely no problem with Michael Owen," Kevin Keegan says of his first-choice striker. "The medical people had a chat. He will not be treated any different to any other player."

The ultimate irony, of course, will be if Owen scores against Germany after being rehabilitated by Müller-Wohlfahrt. He used to be their team doctor.

fields.headline: Real Madrid 3 - 0 Valencia
fields.trailText:
Teams:
Valencia: Canizares, Angloma, Pellegrino, Djukic, Angulo, G. Mendieta, Gerard, Gerardo, Kily Gonzalez, Lopez, Farinos. Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Sanchez, Milla, Albelda.
Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Helguera, Karanka, Campo, McManaman, Morientes, Redondo, Carlos, Raul, Anelka. Subs: Illgner, Hierro, Sanchis, Savio, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu.
Referee: Stefano Braschi (Italy)
fields.body:
Teams:
Valencia: Canizares, Angloma, Pellegrino, Djukic, Angulo, G. Mendieta, Gerard, Gerardo, Kily Gonzalez, Lopez, Farinos. Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Sanchez, Milla, Albelda.
Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Helguera, Karanka, Campo, McManaman, Morientes, Redondo, Carlos, Raul, Anelka. Subs: Illgner, Hierro, Sanchis, Savio, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu.
Referee: Stefano Braschi (Italy)

1 min Valencia kick off. They also have the first chance of the game when Pellegrino sets up Claudio Lopez for a shot on the edge of the box. The Argentinian's strike deflects off Ivan Campo and spins off for a corner which comes to nothing.
3 Valencia appear to have settled the better of the two sides with Farinos and Mendieta dictating play in midfield.
4 McManaman has his first spell on the ball, beating three Valencia men before Gerardo forces the ball out for a throw-in.
5 Real claim a penalty after a Redondo corner appears to come of the arm of Pellegrino. The referee ignores the cries.
9 Mendieta strikes from long range. The ball flies way over the bar, but Real cannot afford to offer up space in dangerous areas of the field like that too often.
14 McManaman and Nicolas Anelka combine to put the Valencia back four under some pressure. A one-two between the former Premiership pair lets in Anelka who is only denied a shot by Pellegrino's last-ditch tackle.
16 Anelka causes a few Valencia hearts to flutter when he rises to meet a Raul cross. His header is firm, but not well-positioned and Santiago Canizares palms away to save.
17 Valencia break at speed, and not many teams do it faster. The ball finally ends up at the feet of Mendieta on the edge of the box, but his usually trusty right foot lets him down and the ball squirms into the arms of Iker Casillas.
21 A better spell for Valencia. Gerard has a header palmed away by Casillas, and the ball is immediately worked back into the Real area by Farinos, and Casillas has to be quick again to prevent the marauding Lopez from reaching the ball.
25 The game is now largely being contested in midfield. Redondo and Farinos are setting up play while McManaman and, uncharacteristically, Mendieta are giving it away. Still no clear-cut chance, but if the game continues to be played at the pace it is currently, one will surely arrive.
29 Lo and behold, the first chance arrives, and it falls to Steve McManaman. A hopeful cross from Redondo on the left falls to the Scouser who clips it with his right foot. The ball is edging inside the far post, but a sprawling Canizares manages to claw the ball away. The resulting corner ends up with McManaman again, and he duly loses the ball.
34 Jocelyn Angloma, perhaps the world's nippiest 35-year-old full-back, attempts to take on the entire Real back line. Sadly for the Frenchman he is tackled by the last man, Ivan Helguera.
36 A typically fiery left-foot strike from Kily Gonzalez flies narrowly over Casillas's bar.
39 GOAL! Real 1 - 0 Valencia A Roberto Carlos free-kick fires into the wall as usual, but great retrieving work from first Michel Salgado and then Nicolas Anelka maintains possession for Real. Salgado gets the ball back inside the area and scoops a cross to the back post where Fernando Morientes is waiting. His clean header squeezes between Canizares and the post.
46Half-time.
Second half
45 Real restart.
47 Valencia already look to be playing more offensively, with both Gerard and Farinos making incursions with the ball into the final third of the field. They win the first corner of the half, but Mendieta's kick is well-claimed by Casillas.
48 Valencia's second-half dilemma is encapsulated in one one-man attack by Anelka. Valencia may be the natural counter-attacking side, but now they must take the game to Real leaving the likes of Anelka and Raul a lot more space. Anelka on this occasion opts to take full-back Gerardo on for pace, succeeds and cracks in a shot from a tight angle that forces a save from Canizares.
52 Valencia have a lucky escape when Miroslav Djukic is uncharacteristically uncertain inside his own box. Anelka swiftly puts the Yugoslav under pressure, and then Morientes robs him, only for Djukic to poke the ball off Morientes' toes at the last minute.
56 After criticising him for losing possession in the first-half, it is only fair to point out that Steve McManaman is performing a sterling defensive job for Madrid. Always willing to cover for (the often advancing) Roberto Carlos, McManaman has also made several important challenges, and toe pokes, in the opening stages of this half.
58 To emphasise the point, McManaman makes a vital sliding challenge on Mendieta inside the box. The tackle is so obviously clean that Valencia players don't even bother to claim a penalty.
67 MACCA GOAL! Real 2 - 0 Valencia Flipping heck. England's prospective left-winger hits a right-footed volley from the 18-yard line that sneaks inside Canizares' left-hand post. His team-mates go wild, but cool hand Macca just runs back to the centre spot.
71 Valencia substitution: Ilie for Angulo. 72 Valencia's best chance of the game. A long pass from Gerard is flicked on by Mendieta, and finds Claudio Lopez free in the area. The Argentinian tries to flick it around Casillas but scuffs it instead and holds his head in his hands.
74 Real substitution: Savio for Morientes.
75 GOAL! Real 3 - 0 Valencia Raul puts the game beyond doubt. Catching the Valencia defence up the field once more, he sprints the length of the field, shimmies past Canizares, tucks the ball beyond Pellegrino and inside the far post.
78 Real substitution: Sanchis for Anelka.
83 McManaman begins to enjoy himself, teasing Kily and Farinos on the touchline. He even manages to dodge Farinos' lunging challenge and get a free-kick in the process.
84 Real substitution: Hierro for Salgado.
90 Savio is brought down 20 yards out from the Valencia goal. Roberto Carlos has damaged his groin, so Hierro strikes the free-kick and curls it over.
92 Full-time. Real Madrid are European Champions for a record eighth time.
