Subs: Bartual Molina, Bjorklund, Oscar, Ilie, Sanchez, Milla, Albelda. Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Helguera, Karanka, Campo, McManaman, Morientes, Redondo, Carlos, Raul, Anelka. Subs: Illgner, Hierro, Sanchis, Savio, Baljic, Geremi, Karembeu. Referee: Stefano Braschi (Italy) 1 min Valencia kick off. They also have the first chance of the game when Pellegrino sets up Claudio Lopez for a shot on the edge of the box. The Argentinian's strike deflects off Ivan Campo and spins off for a corner which comes to nothing. 3 Valencia appear to have settled the better of the two sides with Farinos and Mendieta dictating play in midfield. 4 McManaman has his first spell on the ball, beating three Valencia men before Gerardo forces the ball out for a throw-in. 5 Real claim a penalty after a Redondo corner appears to come of the arm of Pellegrino. The referee ignores the cries. 9 Mendieta strikes from long range. The ball flies way over the bar, but Real cannot afford to offer up space in dangerous areas of the field like that too often. 14 McManaman and Nicolas Anelka combine to put the Valencia back four under some pressure. A one-two between the former Premiership pair lets in Anelka who is only denied a shot by Pellegrino's last-ditch tackle. 16 Anelka causes a few Valencia hearts to flutter when he rises to meet a Raul cross. His header is firm, but not well-positioned and Santiago Canizares palms away to save. 17 Valencia break at speed, and not many teams do it faster. The ball finally ends up at the feet of Mendieta on the edge of the box, but his usually trusty right foot lets him down and the ball squirms into the arms of Iker Casillas. 21 A better spell for Valencia. Gerard has a header palmed away by Casillas, and the ball is immediately worked back into the Real area by Farinos, and Casillas has to be quick again to prevent the marauding Lopez from reaching the ball. 25 The game is now largely being contested in midfield. Redondo and Farinos are setting up play while McManaman and, uncharacteristically, Mendieta are giving it away. Still no clear-cut chance, but if the game continues to be played at the pace it is currently, one will surely arrive. 29 Lo and behold, the first chance arrives, and it falls to Steve McManaman. A hopeful cross from Redondo on the left falls to the Scouser who clips it with his right foot. The ball is edging inside the far post, but a sprawling Canizares manages to claw the ball away. The resulting corner ends up with McManaman again, and he duly loses the ball. 34 Jocelyn Angloma, perhaps the world's nippiest 35-year-old full-back, attempts to take on the entire Real back line. Sadly for the Frenchman he is tackled by the last man, Ivan Helguera. 36 A typically fiery left-foot strike from Kily Gonzalez flies narrowly over Casillas's bar. 39 GOAL! Real 1 - 0 Valencia A Roberto Carlos free-kick fires into the wall as usual, but great retrieving work from first Michel Salgado and then Nicolas Anelka maintains possession for Real. Salgado gets the ball back inside the area and scoops a cross to the back post where Fernando Morientes is waiting. His clean header squeezes between Canizares and the post. 46Half-time. Second half 45 Real restart. 47 Valencia already look to be playing more offensively, with both Gerard and Farinos making incursions with the ball into the final third of the field. They win the first corner of the half, but Mendieta's kick is well-claimed by Casillas. 48 Valencia's second-half dilemma is encapsulated in one one-man attack by Anelka. Valencia may be the natural counter-attacking side, but now they must take the game to Real leaving the likes of Anelka and Raul a lot more space. Anelka on this occasion opts to take full-back Gerardo on for pace, succeeds and cracks in a shot from a tight angle that forces a save from Canizares. 52 Valencia have a lucky escape when Miroslav Djukic is uncharacteristically uncertain inside his own box. Anelka swiftly puts the Yugoslav under pressure, and then Morientes robs him, only for Djukic to poke the ball off Morientes' toes at the last minute. 56 After criticising him for losing possession in the first-half, it is only fair to point out that Steve McManaman is performing a sterling defensive job for Madrid. Always willing to cover for (the often advancing) Roberto Carlos, McManaman has also made several important challenges, and toe pokes, in the opening stages of this half. 58 To emphasise the point, McManaman makes a vital sliding challenge on Mendieta inside the box. The tackle is so obviously clean that Valencia players don't even bother to claim a penalty. 67 MACCA GOAL! Real 2 - 0 Valencia Flipping heck. England's prospective left-winger hits a right-footed volley from the 18-yard line that sneaks inside Canizares' left-hand post. His team-mates go wild, but cool hand Macca just runs back to the centre spot. 71 Valencia substitution: Ilie for Angulo. 72 Valencia's best chance of the game. A long pass from Gerard is flicked on by Mendieta, and finds Claudio Lopez free in the area. The Argentinian tries to flick it around Casillas but scuffs it instead and holds his head in his hands. 74 Real substitution: Savio for Morientes. 75 GOAL! Real 3 - 0 Valencia Raul puts the game beyond doubt. Catching the Valencia defence up the field once more, he sprints the length of the field, shimmies past Canizares, tucks the ball beyond Pellegrino and inside the far post. 78 Real substitution: Sanchis for Anelka. 83 McManaman begins to enjoy himself, teasing Kily and Farinos on the touchline. He even manages to dodge Farinos' lunging challenge and get a free-kick in the process. 84 Real substitution: Hierro for Salgado. 90 Savio is brought down 20 yards out from the Valencia goal. Roberto Carlos has damaged his groin, so Hierro strikes the free-kick and curls it over. 92 Full-time. Real Madrid are European Champions for a record eighth time.

fields.headline: Belgians 'fear the worst' at Charleroi
fields.trailText: Concern over security at England's Euro 2000 clash against Germany increased yesterday after a team of Belgian politicians visited the Charleroi stadium where the match is due to take place and said they feared "the worst".
fields.body:
Concern over security at England's Euro 2000 clash against Germany increased yesterday after a team of Belgian politicians visited the Charleroi stadium where the match is due to take place and said they feared "the worst".

Members of the Belgian parliament's interior affairs committee were shown around the Stade du Pays and said they were concerned at the steep banks of seating that could put spectators at risk, and that violence between opposing fans could mar the Group A match on June 17.

Paul Tant, the committee's chairman, said the tour "could not relieve the sense of worry on the part of some colleagues".

Pieter de Crem, a committee member, added: "We fear the worst. Everybody always says they are prepared but the security risk is especially big. One has the feeling of being in an extremely dangerous position and that is an especially big risk."

Politicians are particularly concerned over the steep seating in the 30,000-capacity stadium which could pose problems in an emergency. During recent tests at the stadium, mountain rescue techniques had to be used to evacuate people.

The stands have been built steeply because the stadium is hemmed in by other buildings and extra seats have been installed to meet the minimum 30,000 capacity.

Concerns have also been voiced that thousands of ticketless English and German supporters could attend the match given Belgium's proximity to both countries.

The Belgian Federal Police Union has voiced concerns over the stadium, claiming that upgrading work and the erection of steep stands did not take into account the safety of fans.

But Euro 2000 and Uefa officials have defended the Charleroi stadium and rejected calls to move the England against Germany match to a bigger venue, such as Brussels or Rotterdam.

The Stade du Pays will also host England against Romania on June 20 and Yugoslavia against Slovenia on June 13.

With just over three weeks to go to the England-Germany match, Belgian police are finalising the security operation. About 2,000 officers are expected to be on duty for the match and special mobile courts will be brought into Charleroi to deal with any troublemakers.

Local officials have still not decided whether bars in the town will remain open on the day of the match, although British politicians have asked for them to be closed as part of an alcohol ban.

Officially England and Germany have an allocation of about 5,000 tickets each but many more tickets are available on the black market with touts in England asking £500 a ticket.

Tournament organisers have said that anyone with a ticket which does not have their name on it will be refused entry to grounds and fans will also have to carry some form of identification throughout Euro 2000, which begins on June 10.

fields.headline: Waterloo sunset
fields.standfirst: Recent visitors to London's South Bank Centre might have noticed a giant screen on one of the walls of the National Theatre. Sean Dodson investigates London's most unusual cinema event
fields.trailText: Recent visitors to London's South Bank Centre might have noticed a giant screen on one of the walls of the National Theatre. Sean Dodson investigates London's most unusual cinema event
fields.body:
The sun is slowly setting behind London's Waterloo Bridge when the giant screen finally cracks into life. A straggle of drinkers out on the terrace of the National Theatre stop their conversations, produce miniature radios from their pockets, and, gazing at the screen, fit the earphones. On the bridge below, a small group is gathering, gazing upwards, their silhouettes casting long shadows down on to the South Bank's promenade.

Capturing the audiences' attention is a head and shoulders shot of a young girl that takes up most of the huge screen that dominates one side of the National Theatre. She is staring straight at the camera. The background is blurred, the girl's inscrutable gaze gives the composition the look of a huge school photo. As you gaze at the screen, it becomes gradually apparent that this is not a static shot - the ends of the girl's long brown hair is moving, impossibly slowly, blown by a slow-motion wind. She closes her eyes langorously and reopens them, with the hint of a shy smile. After a minute or so, the scene changes to a wide-angle shot of a caravan park. Over the earphones comes a series of flat London accents reciting names, of people, of rivers, seemingly at random. It is oddly compelling as you listen for patterns and rhythms, and play the game yourself as you try and think up rivers that the mystery speakers didn't mention.

The brown-haired girl is one of 40 such portraits that make up the first half of Time After, Time Along, The River, a film by Swiss artist Marie Jose Burki. It is the inaugural event of the Thames and Hudson Rivers project - a two-year-long series of events being held on the banks of the two great rivers of two of the world's greatest cities - London and New York. It is surely one of the most unusual cinematic events Londoners are likely to encounter this year.

Not only is Burki's film being shown outside rather than inside a cinema, but you need to tune to the correct frequency to hear the soundtrack and get the full effect. A special FM channel has been installed to transmit the voiceover soundtrack, and 1,000 custom-designed portable radios are available to buy on the South Bank. By tuning into 87.9FM, people within a two-mile radius of the South Bank can pick up this extraordinary film's soundtrack. You have to be a bit nearer to see it, much not much.

Time After, Time Along, The River - the London version - follows the Thames and people who live, work and play along its banks, from Canby Island in the east, westwards to Richmond. Burki achieved her slow motion effect by filming each portrait for three or four seconds with a special camera that takes thousands of frames a minute, and then slowing down and stretching the footage so that the three seconds become a minute and a half. The effect is eerie and mesmerising.

The soundtrack behind the images features the voices of Thames people reciting names of friends and colleagues, and names of rivers - whatever and whoever they can remember. Says Burki: "I didn't want to capture their intimacy, I didn't want to make a documentary - that's not my thing. So I just asked them to give me the names of people who they worked with, or hung around with or went to school with... and then to tell me the names of rivers they know which might bring them further away.

"I began to become interested in people's voices," explained Burki, "their thick accents, their timbre, the way they spread out. The way they express themselves."

Born in Switzerland, Burki lives and works in Brussels and is a world-renowned video artist. Her work features in a number of permanent collections in Europe and America, and she has won a number of awards in her native country.

Although the £9 price tag for the customised radios might seem a little steep, they can be reused, and on Friday nights throughout May a selection of films selected by Burki will be shown on the screen (known as the Fourth Wall). Both Disney classics and Hollywood westerns are rumoured to be among the super-screen's forthcoming attractions.

The second part of Burki's film will be shown in New York next September - with scenes from the Hudson intercut with New York monologues.

Time After, Time Along, The River is shown every night - bar Sunday - at the National Theatre's Lyttleton Flyover (the Lyttleton terrace) at 9.30pm. Further details and the soundtrack can also be found at www.londonart.co.uk, or check the National Theatre's website.

webTitle: Wenders hits back at cynical Brits

fields.headline: Wenders hits back at cynical Brits
fields.trailText: Wim Wenders has hit back at English critics of his latest film, The Million Dollar Hotel, which was universally panned on its UK release last month. He reckons they only slated it because his movie lacked cynicism. "It's got a lot to do with contemporary English culture [which is] totally driven by cynicism."
fields.body:
Wim Wenders has hit back at English critics of his latest film, The Million Dollar Hotel, which was universally panned on its UK release last month. He reckons they only slated it because his movie lacked cynicism. "It's got a lot to do with contemporary English culture [which is] totally driven by cynicism."

"There is not a grain of cynicism in [Million Dollar Hotel], and in England, in the year 2000, that is probably the worse thing you can do," Wenders said shortly before the Portuguese premiere of his movie.

British critics said the film's defects ranged from a predictable script plagued with cliches to overacting.

Many, noting that the rock star Bono co-wrote the script, said the film looked more like a rock video than a feature film. "Wenders shows appalling judgment in reducing a set of reliable actors to drooling cliches of the irritating-freak variety," said the Guardian's Andrew Pulver.

But Wenders countered by saying he had expected his new venture would meet with a vitriolic response in Britain: "Bono and I said, 'When the film comes out in England, it'll be slaughtered.' I didn't think he was going to be so right."

Italian critics were kinder. "It is by far the most successful European film in Italy over the last few years," the misunderstood director pointed out.

webTitle: Are we arming Sierra Leone's children?

fields.headline: Are we arming Sierra Leone's children?
fields.standfirst:
The government today said the Sierra Leone army would be armed under 'strict supervision' after pictures appeared showing a boy soldier with a British gun. Mark Tran reports
Special report
fields.trailText: The government today said the Sierra Leone army would be armed under 'strict supervision' after pictures appeared showing a boy soldier with a British gun. Mark Tran reports
fields.body:
The government today said it would try to keep British guns from ending up in the hands of child soldiers amid reports that UK-supplied guns were ending up in young hands.

The pledge came after the Evening Standard published a photo of a boy soldier holding what appeared to be a British-supplied weapon. The government yesterday announced it would send light weapons and ammunition to the ragtag Sierra Leone army. Defence officials insisted the programme to equip the Sierra Leone army would be carried out under strict supervision and it was precisely to avoid the use of child soldiers that the UK wanted to help construct a modern, well-disciplined, accountable and humanitarian army.

Prime Minister Tony Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said British aid was aimed at helping Sierra Leone "construct a responsible army". He said: "We have instructed the high commissioner in Sierra Leone to remind the president of his undertaking last year that UK-supplied weapons would be used only by regular soldiers and in accordance with international law."

Aid workers also expressed concern about the prospect of more weapons flooding into the violence-wracked country, and said Britain should use its influence to deter underage recruitment.

"While there is little the U.K. government can do to prevent the RUF from recruiting child soldiers, the British military obviously has significant influence over Sierra Leone's army," said Antonio Cabral, Sierra Leone program officer for the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development.

As Britain stepped up its involvement in Sierra Leone, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said he favoured the deployment of African troops to the front line. Mr Cook said: "European troops in the front line are not necessarily helpful in achieving [a] reduction in tension. It is better if the front line is provided by African troops facing African situations."

West African countries have discussed sending in troops, mostly Nigerians, who have already had experience in Sierra Leone. Mr Cook said Europe could provide logistical support and leadership for an African force, adding that any UN peacekeeping force must have a "robust mandate" and be able to use force to protect itself and civilians under its protection.

The day after Britain committed itself to arming and training the beleaguered Sierra Leone army, Mr Cook said Europe could provide logistical backup and leadership to an African force. He said any UN peacekeeping force must have a "robust mandate" and be able to use force to protect itself and civilians under its protection.

"We do not envisage any circumstances in which our fighting units will become a combat force within the UN," Mr Cook said. Britain had received thanks from Sierra Leone President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah for its "extremely valuable" role in stabilising the West African country, Mr Cook added.

Mr Kabbah's troops have made significant gains against Revolutionary United Front rebels since British paratroopers flew in to the former British colony earlier this month. Last week, paratroopers experienced their first fight against anti-government forces, killing at least three people. Defence sources said it appeared that the rebel RUF forces had split into two factions and said UN and Sierra Leone forces were pushing out of Freetown along main supply routes, with the rebels pulling back.

fields.headline: Kramer says yes to Ken
fields.standfirst:
Minutes of the Greater London Assembly meeting
Susan Kramer's campaign website
fields.trailText: In another boost for Ken Livingstone's bid to build a grand mayoral coalition, his defeated Liberal Democrat rival, Susan Kramer, has accepted a key transport role.
fields.body:
In another boost for Ken Livingstone's bid to build a grand mayoral coalition, his defeated Liberal Democrat rival, Susan Kramer, has accepted a key transport role.

Ms Kramer will take a seat on the transport for London board, the body which will oversee the capital's train, bus and tube services.

"It is important for positive politics that we should collaborate with Mr Livingstone's administration on the areas where we have common interests," she said today. "Transport was the key issue of the mayoral election and is still the key issue for Londoners."

Ms Kramer's decision was announced as Mr Livingstone faced his first question time-style interrogation at the hands of London assembly members, the first of 10 regular public sessions the mayor will face this year.

During the mayoral elections, Mr Livingstone and Ms Kramer promised to fight the government's proposed public-private partnership for funding the modernisation of the London underground. Both proposed an alternative bond system, which Ms Kramer recommended based on her business experience in the City arranging major infrastructure and transport projects across Europe.

"I will bring all my experience in raising finance for infrastructure projects to the board," she said today. In his election speech after his May 4 victory, Mr Livingstone offered jobs in his administration to all three defeated candidates from the main parties, although Frank Dobson and Steven Norris are widely expected to turn down the roles they were offered.

The independent mayor's key advisers now include Labour MP John McDonnell, radical black activist Lee Jasper, business adviser Judith Mayhew, who sought a Conservative seat at the 1997 election, and Darren Johnson, the Green party's mayoral candidate.

fields.headline: Livingstone faces job questions
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone will today face the first public test of his mayoralty when Tory members of the Greater London assembly accuse him - and his Labour colleagues - of feather bedding the administration with unneeded staff.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone will today face the first public test of his mayoralty when Tory members of the Greater London assembly accuse him - and his Labour colleagues - of feather bedding the administration with unneeded staff.

Mr Livingstone, who yesterday pulled off a coup by recruiting the Labour MP, John McDonnell, to his team, faces two hours of question time - a novel form of accountability in local government - from GLA members.

With the backing of Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green members he will argue that he has found the extra money for extra GLA staff from within his own budget. At issue is the number of personal assistants each member of the 25-strong GLA will have. webTitle: Ben Elton: from Peter Pan to Maybe Baby

fields.headline: Ben Elton: from Peter Pan to Maybe Baby
fields.standfirst:
• Ask Ben Elton a question
 Download a clip of Ben introducing himself and his movie
fields.trailText: Not content with success as a stand-up comedian, playwright and novelist, Ben Elton has now branched into film direction and scriptwriting with his fertile comedy Maybe Baby
fields.body:
Stand-up comedian, playwright, novelist and film director, Ben Elton's first taste of fame came at 10 years old when he appeared as a lost boy in his local amateur dramatics society's production of Peter Pan. Born in Catford, south east London, the son of a university professor and a teacher, Elton went on to study drama at Manchester university where he soon hooked up with fellow performers Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson. During his time there, he wrote 23 plays and, on graduating in 1980, was employed by the BBC and became their youngest ever scriptwriter.

Ben's stand-up career began in 1981 when he took to the stage at London's Comedy Store "because he was short of money." It wasn't long before he was thrust into the limelight as the shiny-suited, motor-mouthed host of the newly launched Channel 4 show Friday Night Live. Remembered mainly for his anti-Thatcher rants, Elton was seen as part of the emerging alternative comedy circuit that included the now household names of Alexei Sayle, and French and Saunders, along with Mayall and Edmondson.

The phenomenal success of his TV shows, The Young Ones, Filthy Rich and Catflap and Blackadder, led to a lucrative publishing contract and to date Elton has published six novels. He has also written two plays, Blast from the Past and Popcorn (based on his best-selling novel). He has headlined in two successful solo shows for the BBC while his peak-time TV sitcom The Thin Blue Line attracted a whopping 11 million viewers. As if all that wasn't enough, he's also presented the Brit Awards, twice, and stood in for master of chat, Terry Wogan on the BBC's chat show Wogan.

Describing himself as 'the least cool person I know' he believes George Michael is a songwriting genius, and lists meeting the Spice Girls as one of his all-time highs. He married Sophie, an Australian saxophonist, in 1994 and is now the proud father of twins, Charlotte and Albert (Lotte and Bert).

Elton's latest novel, the semi-autobiographical Inconceivable came out of the couples' struggle to conceive. His directorial debut, Maybe Baby, is an adaptation of this novel and stars Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson.

 Ben Elton will be live on Film Unlimited's talkboards on Friday at 1pm. Whether you want to question him on how make it as a scriptwriter, what he thinks of New Labour, has life as a father mellowed him, why has he cast all his friends in his movie - whatever, post your questions now, and follow the chat live on Friday.

fields.headline: Oxford blues
fields.standfirst: Oxford University is under fire for refusing entry to this A-grade, state-educated student who was later snapped up by Harvard. Class discrimination in action? Not a bit of it, says Alan Ryan
fields.trailText: Oxford University is under fire for refusing entry to this A-grade, state-educated student who was later snapped up by Harvard. Class discrimination in action? Not a bit of it, says Alan Ryan
fields.body:
Admissions tutors all over Oxford will no doubt be thanking whatever deity presides over them that it wasn't them that refused to let in Laura Spence to study medicine.

Once the Daily Mail gets its teeth into yet another story of the way in which southern, snobbish, class-bound Oxford rejects northern, working-class talent, the first thing to fly out of the window is common sense. As Thomas Jefferson might have said, a slander on Oxford is half-way round the world before truth has got her boots on.

Laura Spence thought she had been turned down because she hadn't come across well in an interview. I've no idea if that is true, but I am, unusually in Oxford, utterly opposed to basing admissions decisions on interviews. Unless interviewers are carefully trained, they are suckers for charm and liveliness. The process gives the students impolitely described by one researcher as "middle-class bullshitters" a flying start. And when a tongue-tied student comes to life in an interview, it's likely to be sheer luck that the interviewer has hit on a question that has finally sparked the student's interest. Tutors like interviews because they can see whom they're going to teach next year, but interviews are a much worse way of detecting ability than written evidence. Yet Oxford and Cambridge (not to mention London School of Economics, Imperial College, and University College London) have problems with using A levels and GCSE results alone. Laura Spence's headteacher made a great to-do about her having 10 A and A* grades in GCSE; but every candidate for admission has 10 or more A and A* grades in GCSE and almost all of them will go on to get a minimum of three A grades at A level. You need some way of picking the one applicant you can take from among the three or four who look equally well qualified on paper.

Oxford got rid of entrance examinations because it was thought that it would make life easier for applicants from state schools; and now it seems that interviews are the trouble. Short of offering places by lottery to anyone who shows up with 10 A or A* grades at GCSE, it is not obvious what the critics suppose we might try. (There is, in fact, something to be said for a lottery for half the places; the top 10 or 15% of applicants would walk in under any system, and the bottom 15% are, for all sorts of reasons, not going to thrive at Oxford. What happens to the middle 70% is already closer to a lottery than most of us like to acknowledge. An open and above-board lottery might actually cause less misery than the present system.)

There are many things about Laura Spence's case that myth-making reporters are not very likely to notice. One is that critics of Oxbridge chronically confuse qualification and entitlement. Just about everyone who applies to Oxford is "qualified". That is, all but about 15% could cope with the courses they want to take, and they'd get out at the other end with an upper or lower second. But teachers and journalists talk as if being qualified was the same thing as being entitled to a place, and it simply can't be.

In most subjects, three perfectly good applicants are turned away for every one that can be taken. In medicine, it can be as many as six or seven who are turned away. Indeed, throughout the country, there are thousands of students who have not been accepted at medical schools. Are they bad students? Not a bit. They are simply the ones that tutors working with the limited evidence at their disposal think would do less well than their competitors. The situation at Oxbridge and other elite universities is very much like the finals of the Olympics. To call a sprinter who is edged out by two hundredths of a second "slow" is perfectly crazy; to think that students who are edged out of an Oxford place have been declared "inadequate" is equally crazy. Who, one might ask, do the reporters and Laura Spence's headteacher suppose should have been refused a place so that she could go to Oxford?

Why do teachers from state schools think they are discriminated against? The answer is depressingly simple. It is a matter of numbers. A school such as Winchester or Manchester Grammar has dozens of sixth-formers applying for Oxford and Cambridge every year. And every year lots of their pupils are turned down by Oxford and Cambridge. Give or take the occasional indignant letter from an outraged teacher who thinks that only some dark combination of stupidity and malice can account for a college's failure to take some dazzling pupil, they put up with the fact that Oxford's judgment on its pupils is not always in line with their own. After all, dozens of their pupils do get in.

Leaving aside extraordinary places such as Hills Road Sixth Form College in Cambridge, which is a powerhouse like very few others, most state schools will not send many applicants to Oxbridge each year. Once you have very small numbers of applicants, a school's hopes are bound to be more invested in them than would be the case if there were hordes of them. If three students apply and two are rejected, it looks like a terrible snub.

So, what of the fact that Oxford says no to a young woman to whom Harvard says yes? And what of the fact that Harvard apparently coughs up £65,000 so that she can take up the place? A Harvard education costs more than £20,000 a year; four years of that comes to £80,000. Harvard University has an endowment of some $14bn. It is an institution that promises every student who applies that, if they are accepted, Harvard will ensure they can afford to go. This is what is meant by "need-blind admissions", practised by every Ivy League university and by most of the best liberal arts colleges.

It is a very good system, but what Laura Spence has been offered is what any US student from a modest background would get from Princeton, Yale, Dartmouth and the rest. It will be a means-tested award, and some of it will be in the form of loans, and some of it will be in form of work on campus. So, far from being something glamorous, extraordinary, and a slap in the face for Oxford, it is exactly what a few hundred English students will have been offered this year, along with many thousands of Americans.

And although Harvard is perhaps the best large research university in the world - just as Princeton is quite clearly the best small research university in the world - its standards for undergraduate admission are lower than Oxford's. They have to be. US students leave school a year earlier than English students, and American high school courses are less academically demanding than A level. American deans of admissions sigh over students from Britain, Hong Kong and Singapore and murmur phrases like "so intellectually mature". Laura Spence has been lucky in having an American headteacher who knew how to apply to Harvard. She will have a very good time at Harvard. And, with any luck, she will while she is there learn the sort of respect for the complexity of the truth that will make her a good doctor - but which would have killed this silly little story in its cradle.

Alan Ryan is warden of New College, Oxford.

webTitle: Pakistan cricketers found guilty of match-fixing

fields.headline: Pakistan cricketers found guilty of match-fixing
fields.trailText: Former Pakistan captain Salim Malik and medium pace bowler Atta-ur Rehman have been found guilty of match-fixing by a judicial inquiry.
fields.body:
Former Pakistan captain Salim Malik and medium pace bowler Atta-ur Rehman have been found guilty of match-fixing by a judicial inquiry.

After one year and interviewing 60 witnesses, Justice Malik Qayyum recommended a life ban for both players, Pakistan Cricket Board Chairman Lt.-Gen. Taqueer Zia told reporters in the federal capital. The board will accept all the recommendations of the inquiry, he said. The inquiry also recommended a 1 million rupee (£12,000) fine against Malik.

According to the inquiry report "Salim Malik is the main culprit," Zia said. "He has brought the Pakistan national team into disrepute."

Qayyam recommended Malik be banned from any connection with cricket, either as a player or manager. The inquiry report also was critical of former cricket captain Wasim Akram saying he was "not above suspicion." It recommended a 300,000-rupee (£3,500) fine for Akram for failing to cooperate with the judicial inquiry.

The report said that neither Akram nor Mushtaq Ahmed, who was also fined 300,000 rupees (dlrs 5,5000), should be allowed to captain the national team. "Looking at the allegations in their totality, the commission feels that... Wasim Akram is not above board," the inquiry report said. He cannot be said to be above suspicion. It is therefore recommended that he be censured and be kept under strict vigilance."

The report also called for an inquiry to be held into Akram's assets to determine whether his possessions exceed his income.

Zia said there were some unanswered questions about both Akram and Ahmed, but the players were given the benefit of the doubt. Several other players were fined 100,000 rupees (£1,200) for not co-operating with the board. They were Waqar Younis, Inzamam-ul Haq, Akram Raza, and former captain Saeed Anwar.

The inquiry was launched in response to charges of betting and match-fixing against several of Pakistan's top cricketers, including former captains Akram and Malik, spinners Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed, medium pace bowler Rehman and batsman Ijaz Ahmed. The players denied the charges.

On Tuesday, Malik told reporters in the eastern city of Lahore that he was innocent of any wrongdoing. However he refused to answer questions saying the advice of his lawyers was to say nothing.

Qayyum's judicial inquiry investigated several allegations of corruption dating back to 1994, including one made by Australian cricketers Shane Warne and Mark Waugh.

The Australian players accused Malik of offering them bribes to perform poorly during an Australian tour of Pakistan. A number of Pakistani cricketers, including former captains Rashid Latif and Aamir Sohail, also accused their team mates of throwing matches.

webTitle: Share volumes fall 28% as day traders call it a day

fields.headline: Share volumes fall 28% as day traders call it a day
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Day traders, the foot soldiers of the internet revolution, were described as a "diminished force" on Wall Street yesterday. Average trading volumes on the Nasdaq composite have fallen 28% in the past month and even more from their March highs, when 1.9bn shares a day were traded.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Terry Macalister
fields.body:
Day traders, the foot soldiers of the internet revolution, were described as a "diminished force" on Wall Street yesterday. Average trading volumes on the Nasdaq composite have fallen 28% in the past month and even more from their March highs, when 1.9bn shares a day were traded.

At this peak, the securities and exchange commission estimated that day traders, who earn a living by personally buying and selling shares, contributed 15% of total volume.

There have been no official reports on levels of day trading since the market dropped more than a third from its March 10 peak. Anecdotal evidence suggests the figure is far lower and certainly less than 10%.

Alan Davidson, the president of the Independent Broker Dealer Association, said the crash had caused most liquidity to dry up, including that of day traders.

"They are a diminished force because of market decline not because of structural change in the industry," he said yesterday. "The best cure for excess or a bubble in the market is a decline."

One risk arbitrage trader said he had watched volumes dry up completely over the past three weeks. "Do I think there are fewer day traders out there? Absolutely."

The US experience has been mirrored in Britain. Sonia, a 39 year old Nottingham housewife, began trading stocks last October but has now effectively withdrawn from the market.

"As soon as I saw shares such as Baltimore Technologies start to go down strongly I withdrew almost everything I had. Anyone who has not got out by now is silly," she says.

She was first introduced to day trading when she bought shares in Pace Microsystems and realised how much information there was on companies in different internet sites.

"I am just an ordinary person. I never knew it was so easy to buy and sell shares but once I had started it just grew." She managed to get out before the real downturn but will not say how much she has gained. "I haven't worked it out," she said.

Not everyone will be sad to see the day traders leaving the market. One London merchant banker said: "50% of the volatility in bulletin board stocks is caused by day traders who control less than 10% of the shares. Its no bad thing they are being flushed out."

fields.headline: Tories brand dome 'monument to New Labour vanity'
fields.standfirst: Deputy prime minister John Prescott defends the £29m national lottery bailout.
fields.trailText: Deputy prime minister John Prescott was forced to defend the national lottery's £29m lifeline to the Millennium Dome as the Tories labelled the faltering tourist attraction a "monument to the vanity and emptiness of New Labour".
fields.body:
Deputy prime minister John Prescott was forced to defend the national lottery's £29m lifeline to the Millennium Dome as the Tories labelled the faltering tourist attraction a "monument to the vanity and emptiness of New Labour".

Shadow Commons leader Sir George Young, deputising for Tory leader William Hague, reminded Mr Prescott that he had said the dome would be the "first big test of competence for the Labour government". He asked the deputy prime minister why the government had conceded money that could have gone elsewhere.

Fifty Labour MPs have signed an early day motion expressing "deep concern and alarm" about the decision to give more money to the dome, fearing it would deprive the lottery's new opportunities fund of resources that could otherwise go to health, education and the environment. Sir George asked the deputy prime minister if he was happy.

Mr Prescott, in charge of the country while Tony Blair takes two weeks' paternity leave, said he would not be overruling the £29m donation. He said the dome was a success and argued that it had attracted nearly 6m visitors, making it the second most popular venue for tourists in Britain.

Sir George challenged the deputy prime minister: "If it's been such a success, why are so many being sacked? The contents of the dome stand as a monument to the vanity and the emptiness of New Labour."

"If you feel that the dome is a monument to what you call New Labour, what does rail privatisation, which you brought in, feel as a monument to the previous administration?" asked Mr Prescott.

The dome was an idea established by the previous administration and endorsed by the current government, he said. Mr Prescott added that Mr Hague had stated that "we should all get behind it and support it".

fields.headline: Woodhead whips LEAs into line
fields.standfirst:
In light of the criticisms meted out by Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead, education correspondent Rebecca Smithers wonders whether the government was right in naming and shaming poor-performing LEAs
External consultants to advise 'failing' LEAs
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 5pm: In light of the criticisms meted out by Ofsted chief Chris Woodhead, education correspondent Rebecca Smithers wonders whether the government was right in naming and shaming poor-performing LEAs
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools Chris Woodhead may have been out of the limelight recently, but today he made a spectacular comeback with a devastating attack on failing local education authorities (LEAs).

Never backwards in coming forwards, he used the publication of inspection reports on six LEAs (five of them critical) to warn local councils that they were still failing to give local pupils and parents the standard of education services they deserved.

The Office for Standards in Education (Ofsted) has now inspected 75 local authorities in England - half the total - including those where problems had already been identified. Of these, 29 were found to have "significant and in some cases debilitating weaknesses", Mr Woodhead said.

In his own inimitable, colourful style, he added: "We're talking about inadequate political leadership, waste of resources, poor relationship with schools, a lack of focus ... and an ingrained culture in some inner-city LEAs of failure and hopelessness, and what is even worse, complacency and self-delusion."

Among the latest reports, only London's Chelsea and Kensington authority was singled out for praise. The other five were "to a greater or lesser extent" doing a bad job, the education chief said.

In Bradford in particular, he described the situation as "very serious". External consultants are to be sent into Bradford within the next few days in the first steps towards inevitable privatisation of some of the services there.

Woodhead, who is seen as no friend of education authorities, said he supported the government's drive to privatise education services in areas where there was poor delivery. "It seems to me right and proper that if the authority has demonstrated it is incapable of doing the job ... then we've got to look to someone else to do it," he said.

But what is interesting about the latest batch of critical reports is that it raises serious questions about whether the government was right to pursue its controversial policy of "naming and shaming" failing schools before it had examined the more serious, long-standing problems lurking in town halls.

fields.headline: Age of innocence
fields.standfirst: The sexual exploitation of children during Victorian times was widespread, and little has changed since then. But Ian Sparks welcomes new government guidelines that recognise these children as victims not criminals
fields.trailText: The sexual exploitation of children during Victorian times was widespread, and little has changed since then. But Ian Sparks welcomes new government guidelines that recognise these children as victims not criminals
fields.body:
The eagerly anticipated guidelines on child prostitution issued by the government last Monday don't change the law, but they do make it clear, for the first time, that children involved in prostitution are victims of abuse and not criminals. Most significantly, the guidelines recognise that "children do not voluntarily enter prostitution: they are coerced, enticed or are utterly desperate".

Safeguarding Children Involved in Prostitution makes it clear that children - under the age of 18 - caught up in prostitution should be given the same help, support and protection as any other child in need. There can now be no doubt that child prostitution is a child protection issue.

It may seem bizarre that there should ever have been any debate about whether children involved in prostitution are being abused. Yet deliberations about child prostitution have a long history.

The guidelines recognise the major role of charities such as The Children's Society in highlighting the extent and nature of this issue. We began campaigning for a change in the treatment of children involved in prostitution in the early 1990s when it became apparent that some children who had run away from home had resorted to selling sex to survive. Our campaign was shocking, but so was the subject. We needed to highlight the fact that children as young as 12 - and in one case a 10-year-old - were being cautioned for offences relating to prostitution. Children, we discovered, were being punished for being abused.

We were met with disbelief and anger by some. It was somehow easy to believe that child prostitution existed thousands of miles away but not on our own doorstep.

Yet the debate only mirrored an outcry in Victorian times, 120 years ago. That was just around the time The Children's Society was begun and our founder, Edward Rudolf, challenged church and society to do something about the disgrace of children on the streets of London.

Throughout the 19th century, philanthropists, church groups and others flourished, working to "rescue" children from "moral danger" - an all encompassing definition which covered anything from sexual activity before marriage to child prostitution.

In 1848, it was claimed that almost 2,700 girls in London between the ages of 11 and 16 were hospitalised because of venereal disease, many as a result of prosti tution. In 1875, the age of consent, which had remained at 12 since 1285, was raised to 13, partly as a result of concerns about child prostitution.

But concern continued and, in 1881, a select committee, set up to investigate the issue, reported that child prostitution was rampant. One police officer told the committee that, in London, children above the age of 13 could be procured "without any difficulty whatsoever". Another spoke of how it was "scarcely possible for anyone between nine o'clock in the evening, and one o'clock in the morning to walk along Pentonville Road without being accosted by about a dozen young girls between 13 and 14 years of age".

The famous editor of the Pall Mall Gazette, William Stead, launched an investigative campaign to uncover the extent of child prostitution by visiting brothels, and actually bought a child prostitute for himself to expose the double standards of the Victorian public. Stead was a brilliant publicist and before long the country was in uproar. A mass demonstration of 250,000 people converged on Trafalgar Square to demand an increase in the age of consent. In 1885, the Criminal Law Amendment Act was passed, raising the age of consent to 16.

Yet exactly a century later, in 1985, when The Children's Society opened Britain's first refuge for child runaways, we found that chil dren were still selling themselves on the streets to get money for food and shelter.

Through our work with child runaways and in our research, we found that this appalling form of abuse is often accompanied by sickening violence, drug abuse and horrendous risk to health and life.

Melanie, a girl we interviewed in our report, One Way Street, told us that she was abused from the age of three by her brother, followed at the age of five by her godfather and later by his friend. They gave her money for sweets. "You could say I've been a prostitute since the age of seven," she told us.

Louise had been involved in prostitution from the age of 11 to get money to buy food for herself and her younger siblings because her alcoholic, violent mother spent all of her money on drink.

Their stories had a common theme - family conflict overlapping with drugs, violence and poverty. For many, the transition from being abused in the home to being abused on the street was seamless.

The guidelines announced on Monday are important in that they focus the criminal justice system on the abuser and recognise children and young people as victims of abuse and children in need. The priority for police must be to investigate those who abuse children and to prosecute the perpetrators.

For social services, it will mean they must decide, alongside other professionals, what services are needed to support a child caught up in prostitution and whether to instigate a child protection investigation.

The guidelines also recognise that many young people abused in prostitution are reluctant to engage with statutory services. The voluntary sector has an important role in offering services that can build the trust of these incredibly damaged children, help them explore safer options and exit from prostitution.

The government has mapped out a way ahead. The challenge now lies with police and social services departments throughout the country. We know that good practice already exists. In Yorkshire and Humberside, for example, agencies such as social services, police, regional government and voluntary organisations such as The Children's Society have come together to put in place integrated strategies to prevent and protect these vulnerable children.

After nearly seven years of campaigning, these guidelines are welcome news for The Children's Society and welcome news for children caught up in prostitution, who will no longer face being abused by the legal system after being sexually abused by adults.

 Ian Sparks is chief executive of The Children's Society

fields.headline: Hard lives, hard cases
fields.standfirst: David Barrett and  Patrick Ayre question whether our protection system can cope with children damaged by life on the streets
fields.trailText: David Barrett and Patrick Ayre question whether our protection system can cope with children damaged by life on the streets
fields.body:
In its new guidance, the government has made it clear that we must adjust our approach by responding to the young people subjected daily to sexual exploitation primarily as victims rather than offenders.

Heavy emphasis is placed on the responsibility of the child welfare and child protection systems to meet these young people's needs. This responsibility includes a duty to consider whether they should be treated as at risk or in need within the framework established by The Children Act (1989).

While such an approach is clearly appropriate in principle, we must ask ourselves how well these young people will fit within existing patterns of provision. Much of the culture and many of the services which characterise the child protection system are configured to address the needs of helpless young children in need of rescue. But many young people involved in prostitution just do not present like that.

Fundamentally aggressive, streetwise, anarchic young people who have been living on their wits, who steal and "do" drugs as well as prostitution, are not the staple diet of the child protection system. In a situation of fierce competition for resources, can we realistically expect that their needs will be prioritised? Will the workers involved have a clue what to do with them?

Another aspect of the proposed semi-decriminalisation of the activities of these young people has received little attention but could prove of crucial importance. Evidence suggests that in many areas it is really only the police who are keeping any kind of an eye out for young people involved in prostitution. If their activities are no longer of direct interest to the police, this whole sphere of activity may sink back into the shadows and become effectively invisible.

The gathering of evidence against the pimps and paedophiles is vastly more complex and labour intensive than is picking up young people standing on street corners and, as in the field of child protection, this work may struggle for resources.

The retention of a residual power to prosecute young people for prostitution causes many commentators considerable concern. However carefully dressed up, the concept that vulnerable young people engaged by adults in dangerous and damaging sexual activities may still finish up being prosecuted rather than helped is, for many, perverse.

We must recognise that they seldom freely choose the way of life in which they are engaged, with its attendant degradation and danger. If they are to be able to break away, we must help them to address the whole range of difficulties, disadvantages and oppressions which brought them to prostitution in the first place and have trapped them in it thereafter.

A world where abused children and young people are prosecuted instead of protected, and where the victims of sexual assault are more likely to be arrested than are the perpetrators, is perplexing. The new guidance is a start, but we must all try harder.

 David Barrett is dean of the faculty of healthcare and social studies at the University of Luton; Patrick Ayre is senior lecturer in the department of applied social studies.

fields.headline: M&S slashes dividend
fields.standfirst:
Chairman says he needs more cash to rescue ailing business

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer yesterday slashed its dividend for the first time in its 74 years as a public company, as new chairman Luc Vandevelde said he needed more money to invest in turning around the struggling high-street chain.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer yesterday slashed its dividend for the first time in its 74 years as a public company, as new chairman Luc Vandevelde said he needed more money to invest in turning around the struggling high-street chain.

The "rebasing" of the dividend was announced as Britain's biggest retailer revealed its second successive slump in annual earnings, with profits down 11% to £557m, excluding exceptional items.

In a further sign that he was asserting his authority on the business, Mr Vandevelde also announced a boardroom cull, which will see two executive directors leave and a third demoted.

Mr Vandevelde, who was appointed in February to work alongside chief executive Peter Salsbury, sounded a confident note on the prospects for recovery, saying: "I'm even more certain now than when I arrived three months ago that we can succeed."

The year-end payout to Marks & Spencer shareholders will be 5.3p, reducing the total for the year from 14.4p to 9p. Mr Vandevelde said this reflected the "prudence we need to show at this point in time".

He has written to shareholders justifying the cut. He said: "It is time to bring the dividend back to a sustainable level, and grow it from here."

Property director Roger Aldridge and merchandise boss Joe Rowe are to leave the group in July with payoffs of a year's salary - about £315,000 each. Womenswear director Barry Morris has quit the board but will retain his responsibilities as a business unit director.

Mr Vandevelde said he wanted the board to concentrate on overall strategy and corporate governance, rather than day-to-day functions. He declined to rule out further departures: "One can never exclude changes in the board as circumstances and strategic priorities change."

During the year, Marks & Spencer suffered a 4% fall in British sales as shoppers shunned a womenswear range that was criticised as drab and conservative.

However, sales have risen 4.2% in the eight weeks since the group's year-end, with an improvement in clothes as well as food and furnishings.

A £140m restructuring charge depressed pretax profits to £417m but the shares rose 40p to 260.75p.

Analysts gave the results a cautious welcome. Paul Smiddy of Credit Lyonnais said: "The bad news has probably stopped but the good news is yet to arrive." Marks & Spencer intends to spruce up its stores, giving them better lighting and a simpler layout. Three prototype stores are to be tested in Sutton, Leicester and Kensington.

Mr Vandavelde said he wanted to adopt a holistic approach to the customer, reacting more swiftly to what they want.

A "customer insight unit" has analysed the spending patterns of 3.5m chargecard holders and has conducted 1m interviews with customers. The results will include more casual clothing, cosmetics and childrenswear and a shift in emphasis from prepared meals to fresh food.

Analysts increased their forecasts for 2001 profits from around £510m to £570m.

What they said

"We're confident we have bottomed out. We have taken the first steps to recovery and we are starting to work on future growth." Peter Salsbury , on annual profits of £628m on 18 May 1999

"We are clear on the direction we must take. This is a significant programme of change and customers will see the benefits this autumn." Peter Salsbury at Marks & Spencer's annual meeting, 15 July 1999

"We have clearly bottomed out as far as the financial performance is concerned." Luc Vandevelde , on profits of £557m, 23 May 2000

"By the end of this year, we would hope to clearly demonstrate an improved performance in driving the top line." Luc Vandevelde

fields.headline: Definitely, Maybe and No
fields.trailText: ANFIELD'S NEW MACCA?
fields.body:
ANFIELD'S NEW MACCA?

Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier has just done every armchair fan in the country a massive favour. By signing Gary McAllister, 53, with the intention of playing him alongside the likes of Steven Gerrard, 4, Houllier has raised the average age of his team to such an extent that commentators will be forced to stop wittering on about how youthful his side is and find something less tediously predictable to say.

According to Reuters, Houllier has offered Coventry's captain, who will cost nowt on a Bosman free, an initial one-year deal with an option of a second year if Liverpool don't bottle a place in Big Cup again. All this despite a day of denials. "Nothing has happened yet," the shiny-topped Scotsman had said earlier. "I haven't signed and I haven't held any talks with Liverpool - but I am going to see what they have to say later this week." It's just as well that City chairman Bryan Richardson had already started to shop around for a replacement.

The bald playmaker's first task may be to help Jamie Redknapp pack his boots. Redknapp's long-term occupation of the centre circle at Anfield will end if someone offers £7m, and both Gianluca Vialli and George Graham are admirers of the player's range of back passes and sideways balls into touch. Sorry, we meant to say 'range of skills'.

The advertisement for the manager's job at Celtic has been pinned up in jobcentres all over Europe for a fair while now. The wiser men of football have sussed out that the ad is in fact a Magic Eye picture, and if you stare at it for long enough the words "Don't even think about it unless you want to ruin everything you've ever worked for" appear in the shape of a shamrock. But for those whose eyes are clouded with love, the words do not appear.

This may explain why boyhood Celtic fan Martin O'Neill is showing an unhealthy interest in the post. Celtic are set to offer O'Neill the chance to wreck his reputation, sorry, turn Celtic's fortunes around, and the Leicester manager seems more than interested. "Anyone would have to be interested in a club like them," O'Neill said today. "Celtic are absolutely massive, one of the biggest clubs in Europe and would interest most managers," he continued, without reference to Guus Hiddink.

O'Neill insists he hasn't been approached yet - "I have not been offered and I have not accepted a job by Celtic" - but if he does leave Filbert Street, the Fiver reckons Celtic Park won't be the only place in tatters come a year or so. "If he decided to leave, it would be disastrous and I think a few of the lads would reconsider their positions here," Leicester midfielder Neil Lennon said today. Bearing these impending disasters in mind, the Fiver is already in discussions with both Glasgow and East Midlands branches of the Samaritans. We'll be there for you.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Sadly, Newcastle wouldn't throw in Alan Shearer as well" - Elgin City director Norman Green after his club bought 1,000 seats from St James' Park.

THE LONG BAD WEDNESDAY

The Fiver was still basking in the soothing Ralgex-like glow of yesterday's world-exclusive rant from Joe Ashton MP, who accused Sheffield Wednesday of being "an absolute bloody disgrace" and called for Joe Kinnear to be appointed manager, when we opened our mailbox this morning and discovered a tear-stained email from a Mr D Wilson, pleading with us to show some compassion and balance.

So with faces sullen and heads bowed, we phoned Roy Hattersley for a woolly, but generally loyal, angle on Wednesday's season and the continuing Kinnear saga. Unfortunately, four hours later (a long lunch at the Ivy, perhaps), his Lordship still hadn't bothered to answer. But rather than get all bitter and spit furiously all over the place, we turned to Wednesday's website, which reported that although Kinnear held talks with Wednesday earlier today, he sensationally headed back to London without giving the club an answer.

The news is all the more surprising considering that Kinnear had told the Yorkshire Post that he was "delighted to be returning to management at such a big club with enormous potential... Sheffield Wednesday is special." Special, the Fiver presumes, because they've actually offered him a job. Wednesday later tried to limit the damage by insisting: "We have had constructive discussions with Joe Kinnear. Unfortunately not all the issues raised were resolved."

Now the Fiver's no Cracker, but phrases like "constructive discussions" and "issues not resolved" are usually sure-fire indicators of blazing rows about money. And when the club says they are "optimistic that he will get back to us before the weekend with his decision," our suspicions that the decision will be a hearty "No!" only increase. No wonder the odds on Steve Bruce are continuing to fall.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Atletico Madrid today confirmed they have been in negotiations with Chelsea about £14m-rated Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink. "Nothing has been decided yet, but the talks are still going on," the club said.

Gabriel Batistuta appears certain to join AS Roma after nine years at Fiorentina. Batistuta's agent Settimio Aloisio met officials from Roma on Tuesday night for lengthy talks on the player's future.

Manchester United have been linked with Valencia's Spanish keeper Santiago Canizares. The former Real Madrid keeper has an offer on the table to move to Old Trafford in the summer.

Manchester City will offer near-neighbours Bolton £6m for Icelandic striker Eidur Gudjohnsen.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Valencia are likely to be without midfielder Kily Gonzalez for tonight's Big Cup final against Real Madrid. The Argentinian injured his left knee during a training session on Tuesday.

Hull City have had their Boothferry Park stadium repossessed after failing to pay the rent, solicitors for Bridgestate Developments Limited, the freeholders of the ground, said today.

Birmingham have signed Coventry left-back David Burrows on a free transfer.

France coach Roger Lemerre's contract with the World Cup holders has been extended until the end of 2002.

Leicester City will host an international friendly between India and Bangladesh at Filbert Street on July 29.

Dennis Bergkamp has pledged to finish his career with Arsenal and discuss a new contract when he returns from Euro 2000 duty with Holland. "I'll finish my career at Arsenal," he said today. "I've always said I would, but I won't talk about an extension to my current contract until after Euro 2000."

According to Reuters, Houllier has offered Coventry's captain, who will cost nowt on a Bosman free, an initial one-year deal with an option of a second year if Liverpool don't bottle a place in Big Cup again. All this despite a day of denials. "Nothing has happened yet," the shiny-topped Scotsman had said earlier. fields.headline: External consultants to advise 'failing' LEAs
fields.standfirst: Today's Ofsted reports in full
fields.trailText: External consultants will be sent in to advise three Labour-controlled local education authorities which were ruled to be failing in Ofsted reports published today.
fields.body:
External consultants will be sent in to advise three Labour-controlled local education authorities which were ruled to be failing in Ofsted reports published today.

Bradford, Rochdale and Waltham Forest in north-east London were all criticised by chief inspector Chris Woodhead, but Bradford was singled out for particular blame.

"Bradford LEA does not do enough to avoid using social disadvantage as an excuse for low standards of expectation, and is failing its children miserably," Mr Woodhead said.

Until the local elections, Bradford was Labour-run but it now has a hung council with a Conservative leader.

Mr Woodhead said all three authorities had an "ingrained culture of failure and hopelessness. For many children in these three LEAs their education is their best hope for a decent life.

"These children and parents deserve the best possible support from their LEAs and it is depressing to report this is not what they receive. This cannot be allowed to continue."

Half-way through the national inspection process, Ofsted has now recommended intervention in 15 local authorities. Schools minister Estelle Morris formally announced the decision today, saying that the government wanted to see "irreversible change" and "no slipping back" in failing authorities.

In the two other reports on LEAs published today, Labour-controlled Luton was found to have made only uneven progress and Conservative Westminster was declared to have made a "measurable improvement, albeit fragile". Weaknesses still outnumbered strengths in the borough, inspectors found.

Tory-controlled Kensington and Chelsea, however, was singled out for special praise. Last year education secretary David Blunkett criticised the borough for wasting money, but according to today's report it has improved its service enormously in the past twelve months.

"While the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea spends a lot on its schools, it gives good value for money. The LEA supports its schools very effectively and, in particular, its strategy for school improvement is exemplary," Mr Woodhead commented.

fields.headline: Court in the crossfire
fields.standfirst: You've split up. You hate him. He hates you. So how do you sort out what happens to the children?  Anne Garvey  meets the men and women who step into the breach
fields.trailText: You've split up. You hate him. He hates you. So how do you sort out what happens to the children? Anne Garvey meets the men and women who step into the breach
fields.body:
Just over a week ago, Will "Love Rat" Carling was photographed playing with Henry, his two-year-old son with Ali Cockayne. The next day, he was photographed on the steps of the high court, where he was demanding greater access to his son. No decision was taken at the 90-minute hearing and the case was adjourned until later this year. But the show goes on. Last Sunday, the cameras were out again: this time, a tearful Cockayne was snapped handing Henry to Carling for one of his regular access days.

Most separated parents manage to bury the hatchet for long enough to sort out by themselves their children's living arrangements, visits and holidays. But for the 15% who cannot or will not, the only solution lies in court, where a judge must resolve their rows about contact and residence.

Before they get anywhere near a judge, however, the Children Act requires that a warring couple have a meeting with a family court welfare officer (FCWO). While Carling plays out his personal family drama on the public stage, it is these shadowy figures who, behind closed doors, assess the family scene, draw up a thorough report and, finally, make recommendations to the judge.

FCWOs are currently probation officers but that is set to change when, in March 2001, a new service, the children and family court advisory service (Cafcas), will embrace all children's services. Not before time, according to Jess Oliver, an FCWO in Peterborough. "People panic when they get letters with probation service at the top," she points out. "They think they've done something criminal."

What it won't do, however, is make the FCWO's job any easier. "Given the degree of fury in the air," Oliver says, "you sometimes wonder how the children ever came to be conceived in the first place. The other day I met the most ordinary man: cardigan-wearer, worked in a bank. And then there was his wife, bedizened with exotic eastern gear - a belly dancer, it turned out."

However different parents might be, the FCWO's job is to promote the child's right to contact with both - no mean feat when emotions are running high. "People leap to their feet, shouting: 'If I stay here another moment, I shall hit her/him.' They often storm out," says Brian Kirby, senior FCWO in Peterbrough. Though violence is rare, the threat of it is often felt: "We know that as many as one in three of the separations we deal with is riddled with physical aggression."

Oliver recalls a recent case where parents were rowing over whether or not a child should be taken to Henley Regatta: "Quite suddenly, the mother swung round and just cracked the father over the head with the file she was holding."

In another case, two enormous extended families turned up for the court hearing. "We had to arrange separate exits and even then there was a major dust-up in the car park. Oddly, when brought together alone, the actual couple agreed their differences before the case was heard."

If this first interview doesn't work, the FCWO will visit the child's school or nursery and both homes, taking time to talk to the child alone. The resulting report is long and detailed, and as judges usually follow its recommendations, it can be an alarming process for parents.

"You know that this person is forming opinions about you that could shatter your life," says one mother who was recently "grilled" by FCWOs. "Even when you know you have done everything as well as you can, you feel disturbed by it. You know how much is riding on this interview."

Howard Bramwell of Manchester probation service has deeper worries about the process. "By definition, at least one person in every couple we see is difficult," he explains. "Yet the system favours the ones who dig in and refuse to compromise."

Men and women can be equally at fault here. "There are the depressing cases of abusive, bullying men whose contact applications to the court are simply ploys to pursue a woman who has otherwise left their ambit," Bramwell explains.

On the other hand, a parent with contact - often the mother - can be bitterly determined that her ex will not see the child. One mother, while being interviewed by a FCWO, greeted a telephone call from the father with: "Is this you, you piece of filth?" But at least such cases of outright hostility are straightforward, unlike the brainwashing practised by more sophisticated clients. "I was on a home visit the other day," Oliver says, "when the mother began to cry. Her small child climbed on her knee and said: 'It's all right, Mummy, I won't see Daddy again if it makes you unhappy'."

On one Christmas visit, another FCWO remembers a child weeping over his toys in a corner. "Just look at all this you've got. Why are you crying?" the FCWO said cheerily. "Because my Dad's a bastard!" the five-year-old replied. Looking on, the mother said triumphantly: "You see now, don't you? He hates him!"

Worst of all, though, Oliver says, are accusations of child abuse, "When you just know it's a ruse to stop contact. Unfounded accusations like this are a form of child abuse in themselves."

"All sorts of excuses are made for parents like these," Bramwell adds. "Many are emotionally immature and cannot separate their own needs from their children's. But the bottom line is that they are damaging the children by denying them the basic human right of knowing both parents."

In his opinion, the system is not working as well as it could. "It's a class issue," he says. "If these people were in a criminal court, members of the poorer end of the working class, no amount of pleading would absolve them from following a court order. But many are middle-class, otherwise blameless characters and they are allowed to defy the law with impunity."

Kirby takes a more sympathetic line. "People are in pain, in crisis," he says. "We are trained to deal with all this, take the temperature down, take breaks, mediate, agree where we can. Frankly, miracles can happen."

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: With GCSEs and A Levels just around the corner, what can parents do to help their children through the ordeal?
fields.trailText: Michele Elliot Director of the child safety charity, Kidscape
fields.body:
Michele Elliot Director of the child safety charity, Kidscape

My son has just gone through the US equivalent of A Levels. I think the most important thing is to back off: don't tell them to do the dishes or pick their laundry off the floor. You know the flashpoints, so lay off them because your child is already under such a lot of pressure and you've got to give a bit. Don't be taken in if they're acting all cool and couldn't-be-bothered: they do care, they know a lot depends on these exams. Remind them to take breaks, suggest they go out for a walk. Give them lots of small snacks, and let them sleep in whenever possible.
Verdict: Back off

Hereward Harrison Policy director for Childline, the children's helpline

Exam stress is as much an issue for parents as for their children: be aware of this. Lots of the young people who phone us are worried because their parents are worried, so look at how you're handling the anxiety yourself and try not to pass it on to your child. If you haven't already, sit down with your child and talk through what's going to happen if he or she fails: it's very important to let your child know that it won't be the end of the world, you will be able to work things out. This will do a lot to lower your child's anxiety, and maybe your own.
Verdict: Discuss failure

Daphne Metland Mother of two children, a boy aged 20 and a girl aged 15

When my son did his exams we all thought they were so important - and they are, but if it all goes wrong they can always do them again. Now my daughter is doing her GCSEs and, this time, I'm more relaxed. I keep reminding her that she does know her stuff, but that if she fails it's not the end of the world. Stay on your child's side: let them know your love isn't conditional. Give them food they'll enjoy and do anything you can to give them a bit of extra love and care. Protect them: don't have the house full of friends, and don't expect them to put in an appearance at family events.
Verdict: Be on their side

Robert Godber Head of Wath-on-Dearne comprehensive, Rotherham

Provide a calm and supportive environment at home: try to be there for your child, both to provide practical things like food, and to help when there's an emotional crisis because a paper was unexpectedly hard or a romance has broken up. Don't offer a bribe - these almost always backfire and leave smouldering resentments - or anything that's conditional on success. But organising an event to look forward to when it's all over, an evening out or weekend way, can be a good idea. And make sure your expectations are realistic, and tie in with your child's.
Verdict: Be there

John Wilding Cognitive psychologist specialising in student learning

Research shows that memory is the key to exam success; it also shows that strategic learning is crucial when it comes to remembering things. So you can help your child by helping him or her devise a revision strategy. Encourage her to be organised, to have a plan. This is very important, and it's something you really can help with, especially at times when the enormity of the task seems overwhelming for the young person. You might not understand the details of their work, but you can help them plan it. And don't panic: it's never too late.
Verdict: Help them plan
fields.bodyText: Michele Elliot Director of the child safety charity, Kidscape My son has just gone through the US equivalent of A Levels. I think the most important thing is to back off: don't tell them to do the dishes or pick their laundry off the floor. You know the flashpoints, so lay off them because your child is already under such a lot of pressure and you've got to give a bit. Don't be taken in if they're acting all cool and couldn't-be-bothered: they do care, they know a lot depends on these exams. Remind them to take breaks, suggest they go out for a walk. Give them lots of small snacks, and let them sleep in whenever possible. Verdict: Back off Hereward Harrison Policy director for Childline, the children's helpline Exam stress is as much an issue for parents as for their children: be aware of this. Lots of the young people who phone us are worried because their parents are worried, so look at how you're handling the anxiety yourself and try not to pass it on to your child. If you haven't already, sit down with your child and talk through what's going to happen if he or she fails: it's very important to let your child know that it won't be the end of the world, you will be able to work things out. This will do a lot to lower your child's anxiety, and maybe your own. Verdict: Discuss failure Daphne Metland Mother of two children, a boy aged 20 and a girl aged 15 When my son did his exams we all thought they were so important - and they are, but if it all goes wrong they can always do them again. Now my daughter is doing her GCSEs and, this time, I'm more relaxed. I keep reminding her that she does know her stuff, but that if she fails it's not the end of the world. Stay on your child's side: let them know your love isn't conditional. Give them food they'll enjoy and do anything you can to give them a bit of extra love and care. Protect them: don't have the house full of friends, and don't expect them to put in an appearance at family events. Verdict: Be on their side Robert Godber Head of Wath-on-Dearne comprehensive, Rotherham Provide a calm and supportive environment at home: try to be there for your child, both to provide practical things like food, and to help when there's an emotional crisis because a paper was unexpectedly hard or a romance has broken up. Don't offer a bribe - these almost always backfire and leave smouldering resentments - or anything that's conditional on success. But organising an event to look forward to when it's all over, an evening out or weekend way, can be a good idea. And make sure your expectations are realistic, and tie in with your child's.
