So you can help your child by helping him or her devise a revision strategy. Encourage her to be organised, to have a plan. This is very important, and it's something you really can help with, especially at times when the enormity of the task seems overwhelming for the young person. You might not understand the details of their work, but you can help them plan it. And don't panic: it's never too late. Verdict: Help them plan

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: A brief guide to paddling pools
fields.trailText: Rainbow shade and pool, ages 12 months and up. £10 from the Early Learning Centre. Call 01793 443322 for nearest store.
fields.body:
Rainbow shade and pool, ages 12 months and up. £10 from the Early Learning Centre. Call 01793 443322 for nearest store.

I can't help being completely won over by this. Babies and toddlers have notoriously sun-sensitive skin, so the vibrant rainbow-coloured shading pod is perfect at keeping outdoor water play skin safe. The two-tier outer rings are a vivid blue with sweet white clouds dotted at regular intervals. Our young tester loved the yellow sun face perched on top of the pod with his huge grin and rather trendy shades. Unlike larger pools, blowing this one up won't leave you in a heaving heap (it takes about 15 minutes). Because of its size, emptying is easy, with a simple plug to release the water. For taller toddlers, the rainbow shade makes standing up awkward, but ultimately this is a winning design for a first paddling pool .
Rating: 9/10

Olympic Pool, ages 5 and up. £59.99 plus p+p £3.95 from Letterbox on 01872 580885 or www.letterbox.co.uk.

A straightforward rigid-frame pool which has the distinct advantage of needing no inflation. Although it lacks the vibrancy of novelty pools, it is deep enough (50cm) to have a swim without children's tummies scraping the floor. Unlike it's inflatable counterparts, this pool seems to be virtually indestructible with a double-seamed plastic liner which can take any amount of boisterous play. Its impressive measurements are 255cm by 165cm, making it large enough for several children at once, and the odd adult in need of cooling down. The downside is that it needs a lot of water, which may not be a problem when you fill it up, but when it comes to emptying, what do you do with it? Wilting flowers only need so much.
Rating: 7/10

Yellow Panel Paddling Pool ages 4 and up. £14.95 from Tesco. Call 0800 505555 for nearest branch.

While there is no particular novelty value to this bright but basic paddling pool, it is well made and robust. Measuring 152cm in diameter and 38cm in depth, the sides have been reinforced with wooden panels within the material, making it pretty well indestructible. Inflating the curved outer lip which holds the pool together takes a matter of moments, and it also priovides a comfortable ledge to climb over. A drain plug on the bottom lining makes emptying out the out straightforward. Also included in the packaging is a plastic repair patch. Extremely easy assembly is a huge asset, and putting it away again is a doddle. Hassle-free, no frills, and essentially good value for money.
Rating: 8/10

Inflatable Playground, ages 2 and up. £39.99 plus 3.95 p+p, hand pump £12.99 from the Great Little Trading Company on 08700 768696.

This giant construction is a water play paradise for younger children. Measuring a cool 229cm by 229cm, with a potential depth of 30cm of water in the larger pool area and 60cm in the enclosed section, the activity playground has a short slide, a hoop for throwing balls through and a palm tree sprinkler system (which needs a hose attachment). The enclosed space, although small, can be filled with sand by those keen to create a beach and the low side height makes it easy to climb in and out. The downsides are that it is difficult to clean because of the size, and not particularly easy to release all the air out of. Even with a pump it takes determination and a good 20 minutes to inflate. Ultimately worth the time and trouble for the lengthy play factor.
Rating: 6/10

Fire Engine Pool, ages 3 and up. £30 from the Early Learning Centre.

The box instructions imply that this can be inflated by mouth alone, but we switched to a footpump very early on, and even then it took a good 25 minutes. However, once up, the children couldn't stay away. The steering wheel and squeaky horn are hidden under a shaded area which means there is a cool corner for anyone overheating. The detachable hose was considered a plus by children and a minus by wet adults. Essentially, this is a novelty pool which encourages water-shy children to get wet and have fun. The potential depth (63cm) may be off-putting for the nervous, as may the high sides which make getting in and out difficult for younger ones, but there is a recommended maximum water level of 29cm. Although it is actually quite small this was the children's favourite, simply because of the fire engine shape.
Rating: 6/10

Family Size Frame Pool & Cover, age 6 and up. £299 from branches of Argos, Makro, John Lewis and Costco. Call 01480 414361 for nearest stockist.

This is a paddling pool with attitude at 366cm in diameter and 76cm depth. Construction is supposed to take two adults half an hour, but it took us almost an hour. Filling its 2271-litre capacity takes around four hours. This must be viewed as a summer-long addition to the garden - it includes a water filter. My children took their first freezing swim in the rain because they couldn't wait. The downside to this is the safety aspect and water consumption. If you are prepared for long hours of supervision, or fancy a dip yourself (there is plenty of room, after all) the pool is a worthwhile investment for a lot of water fun. When putting away, you are advised to let the water out over a period of time rather than let it gush out and flood the garden.
Rating: 8/10

fields.headline: Wham! Bam!
fields.standfirst: Musical chairs is violent and should be banned, says one report. Toy guns are OK, says another. So how do we handle aggression in children, asks  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: Musical chairs is violent and should be banned, says one report. Toy guns are OK, says another. So how do we handle aggression in children, asks Emma Brockes
fields.body:
The game of musical chairs, as every child knows, is not about brains, skill or the agility to take tight corners at breakneck speed. The winner of musical chairs is the child who has the right combination of aggression and body weight to knock a competitor off their seat and sit tight while they take a swing at them. As such, it has been identified in a report published this week as a game that encourages children to be aggressive and should be phased out in favour of its gentler stable mate, musical statues. Ironically, it coincides with a report published by a scholar at the University of North London, arguing that toy guns should be allowed back into the nursery as encouragers of imaginative play.

The question of how to deal with aggression in children relies on one's definition of its cause and function. If, as Sue Finch, the author of the report, Towards a Non-Violent Society, believes, a child who acts violently is copying bad behaviour they have witnessed in others, then musical chairs reads as a tutorial on how to whack your little playmates under the approving eye of an adult. It is a view that has been endorsed by the employment minister, Margaret Hodge. If, on the other hand, you believe that the violence children display is an innate and not necessarily damaging impulse, then something like musical chairs becomes a healthy outlet for natural aggression.

It is a fiercely contested field in child psychology, and one that can still be characterised by the disagreement that raged between two groundbreaking psychologists in the 1940s, Melanie Klein and Donald Winnicott. "Melanie Klein believed all babies are born with the death instinct," says Jan Abram, the director of the Squiggle Foundation and author of the Language of Winnicott. "The death instinct is an innate envy, sadism and aggression. Winnicott disagreed with this, and saw babies' primary aggression to be benign. He put the emphasis on how the mother treated the child, channelling the aggression into assertion."

For Winnicott, while a baby can certainly be ruthless, it is meaningless to attribute emotions such as envy to it, since it has yet to reach that stage of cognitive development. The ruthless child is not, according to Winnicott, behaving with intentional cruelty, but with a pre-conscious, pre-guilt inducing selfishness. The baby is testing the boundaries between itself and its mother, learning slowly that when it pinches her, the baby does not feel pain, distinguishing the difference between "me" and "not-me". Aggression, in this sense, is not the expression of some essential sadism, but a natural development in the child's journey to independence, creating a context in which pushing another child is done with a dim awareness of the consequences.

Whichever side one falls down on, it is an uncontested fact that the way in which a parent reacts to a child's violent behaviour is crucial to the way in which its aggressive tendencies develop. The "terrible twos" is the phase during which the expression of this sadism/ruthlessness is most flamboyantly expressed. Infants may pinch and scratch their mother, pull terrified faces and have tantrums, as a way of testing her emotional response to their distress. "We are all born homicidal maniacs," says Peter Fonagy, Freud memorial professor at UCL and a consultant on Bill Clinton's commission on violence prevention. "Every infant is born impulsive. Aggression in infancy is a normal response to anxiety that isn't met by comforting."

"All infants are born with the capacity for destructive impulses based on anxiety," says Margot Waddell, psychoanalyst and consultant child psychotherapist at the Tavistock Clinic. "If the primary carer can understand it and react appropriately, then those aggressive impulses will be more contained. But if the baby's distress comes up against a brick wall and bounces back, then the infant or the young child will find it more difficult to keep their natural impulses under control." The responsible adult, therefore, understands the child's need to occasionally hurl itself at other children, without actually endorsing it.

The key word in all of this, is containment. It is well known that a child throwing a tantrum is testing the boundaries of its carer. Psychoanalysts talk about the need for the parent to "detoxify" the situation, not to over-react with erratic punishment, but to absorb their child's anger and understand the frustration that might be causing it.

"Anxiety is at bottom, a fear of death," says Robert Young, professor of psychotherapy at the University of Sheffield. "It is a fear of non-being, a nameless dread. People who are feeling that way must be held, metaphorically, not too tight, not too lose, until the desperation drains away. You have to find safe outlets and I would have thought musical chairs is an excellent one. People who try and get their children to always be good are really building up trouble for the future."

Detoxifying aggressive behaviour in US schools is something that Peter Fonagy has worked on extensively. In Tulsa, he helped implement the Gentle Warrior Programme, a martial arts course that allowed children to exercise their aggression while teaching them self-defensive moves and how to stand up to bullies. "There are studies that have suggested that classroom aggression can be modified by a more systematic use of discipline," he says. "If the teachers use more positive intervention, trying to praise the child rather than humiliate him, it can be a constructive and powerful lesson to the others. They must sensitise the whole class to aggression and show that they do not tolerate it." It is not enough simply to ban an aggressive activity, since this is a symptom rather than a cause of the problem. "It's not like getting rid of a bacteria or a virus. No single activity will in itself either create the problem or deal with it. At school, it needs to be a system-wide approach. If you get rid of musical chairs because it is against a principle that you hold that is relevant to preventing violence, then fine. But it needs to be accompanied by many other implementations of that principle."

The principle is founded on the belief that as children become older, inadequate responses to their emotional demands may provoke them into using violence as a means of boosting their self-esteem. "Inadequacy" in this context can range from obvious parental abuse and neglect, to the more insidious problem of over-indulgence. Psychoanalysts have talked of the tyranny of structurelessness, of the danger of tolerating a child's whims in a way that can be as damaging to them as over-punishment, since a child's psychology is a fragile, impressionable thing.

Expressing aggression is not in itself damaging; playing competitive games does not induce the child prematurely into the cut-throat world of adulthood. "There is no evidence suggesting that schools where there is greater competitiveness between the kids creates more aggression," says Fonagy. "If aggression is allowed to be a means by which a child whose self-esteem is low can enhance their self-esteem, that's bad." The answer, perhaps, is not to ban musical chairs, but to make sure that the little sod who wins by pushing other children out of the way, is not awarded the prize.

webTitle: Can we talk? I don't think so

fields.headline: Can we talk? I don't think so
fields.standfirst:
Why is the government seeking advice from the likes of Sony and Coca-Cola on how to stop teenagers smoking? Sally Weale reports

Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Why is the government seeking advice from the likes of Sony and Coca-Cola on how to stop teenagers smoking?
fields.body:
W hen was the last time you tried to give your teenage son or daughter some advice? Did they a) thank you and say, "What a great idea, I must remember that in future"; b) look at you with utter contempt and blatantly ignore you; c) give the appearance of listening and then do precisely the opposite?

Communicating with teenagers can be a difficult business - they want to make their own choices and preachy advice from any figure of authority is an instant turn-off, if not the perfect incentive to rebel.

Teenagers also feel invincible - illness and death are things that happen to other people - and they are more worried about what their peers think than their parents. This is, therefore, a particularly difficult age group at which to target health advice. So how, for example, do you discourage your teenage son or daughter from smoking?

The government, it emerged this week, is asking exactly the same question. It wants to tackle teenage smoking but previous campaigns, which have patronised and lectured, have done little to halt the figures. According to a 1998 survey, 12% of girls and 9% of boys aged between 11 and 15 are regular smokers.

Now public health minister Yvette Cooper is consulting the only people who seem to have no trouble in getting their message across to a teenage audience - youth brand leaders like Sony PlayStation, Coca-Cola and Nike.

"We felt we could learn from them," a Department of Health spokesman said. "These companies have all had great success in getting young people to buy their products and we thought the same tactics could be used to encourage teenagers not to smoke."

John Shaw of advertising agency Wieden and Kennedy, which has been responsible for both Nike and Coca-Cola advertising campaigns, acknowledges it is very different asking people not to do something (don't smoke) than to do it (buy these trainers). "With the youth market, if you tell them not to do something, it's more likely to make them do it. I suppose that's the problem everyone's had.

"The campaign I remember quite well was an Aids one about five years ago which was all about going too far - don't go too far before you put a condom on. It was different from some of the previous campaigns because it was very factual.

"It used language that teenagers could relate to. It was not preachy. The honesty and frankness of that would be one place I would look, particularly with a message that's fairly serious."

This was the very tactic used by an anti-smoking campaign in Florida which has resulted in 80,000 fewer teenagers smoking. The campaign, called The Truth, has been devised and driven by teenagers themselves. It is factual, aggressive, and sounds like teenagers talking to teenagers. "Their brand is lies. Our brand is truth," is the slogan.

The success of the Florida experiment doesn't surprise John Shaw. "Teenagers like to be able to make up their own minds, or at least think they are making up their own minds. If you present certain things about smoking and the tobacco industry, in a way that's non-judgmental but encourages teenagers to think about it, I don't think it's a losing battle."

Significantly, the teenagers behind the Florida campaign chose to target the tobacco companies as the villains, rather than young smokers. One advertisement features an awards ceremony hosted by a satanic figure who hands out the "demon" award to tobacco as the year's biggest killer of young children.

"It's the Ab Fab thing," says Shaw, "where the parents were more drunken and debauched than the child. Teenagers know their parents probably had a pretty wild time when they were teenagers - taking drugs and that sort of thing. Rebelling against the establishment starts to mean something different.

"The main thing is teenagers don't want to be typecast," he adds. "We have an over-simplified idea of what a teenager is."

Consultant clinical psychologist David Spellman agrees: "Teenagers are a diverse group but they are lumped together. They are emerging from childhood and trying to assert and explore their own identities. One of the ways to do that is to try things out and not to take as the truth something that your parents say, or the Guardian says, but to try it out for yourself. They have to make their own choices and their own mistakes.

"As a parent, you want to protect, but if that's the only string to your bow you are going to come a cropper. Unless you want to sever your relationship with your teenage children, you've got to find a way of living with the choices they make."

According to Jeannie Milligan, a psychotherapist specialising in adolescence at London's Tavistock Clinic, teenagers feel easily excited but also frightened, vulnerable but omnipotent.

"Parents come to me and say give me instructions how to talk to my child so they will listen to me and do what I want," says Milligan.

"But that never works. The more you can help them feel rounded, reasonably secure citizens who have got something to offer and can manage the bits of themselves that are flakey, then you are more likely to be able to talk with them about risks and have something taken on board. But it's a very difficult balance not to come over as wildly patronising."

For Spellman, teenagers get a bad press. The vast majority of them get on well with their families, he says, and are more like their parents than is usually appreciated.

"There is a cliched stereotype, the stroppy adolescent, the Harry Enfield character. But there are far more harmonious relations between parents and teenagers than you might think.

"The vast majority do care what their parents say and do listen. They might make different choices, but it's not that they don't listen."
fields.bodyText: W hen was the last time you tried to give your teenage son or daughter some advice? Did they a) thank you and say, "What a great idea, I must remember that in future"; b) look at you with utter contempt and blatantly ignore you; c) give the appearance of listening and then do precisely the opposite? Communicating with teenagers can be a difficult business - they want to make their own choices and preachy advice from any figure of authority is an instant turn-off, if not the perfect incentive to rebel. Teenagers also feel invincible - illness and death are things that happen to other people - and they are more worried about what their peers think than their parents. This is, therefore, a particularly difficult age group at which to target health advice. So how, for example, do you discourage your teenage son or daughter from smoking? The government, it emerged this week, is asking exactly the same question. It wants to tackle teenage smoking but previous campaigns, which have patronised and lectured, have done little to halt the figures. According to a 1998 survey, 12% of girls and 9% of boys aged between 11 and 15 are regular smokers. Now public health minister Yvette Cooper is consulting the only people who seem to have no trouble in getting their message across to a teenage audience - youth brand leaders like Sony PlayStation, Coca-Cola and Nike. "We felt we could learn from them," a Department of Health spokesman said. "These companies have all had great success in getting young people to buy their products and we thought the same tactics could be used to encourage teenagers not to smoke." John Shaw of advertising agency Wieden and Kennedy, which has been responsible for both Nike and Coca-Cola advertising campaigns, acknowledges it is very different asking people not to do something (don't smoke) than to do it (buy these trainers). "With the youth market, if you tell them not to do something, it's more likely to make them do it. I suppose that's the problem everyone's had. "The campaign I remember quite well was an Aids one about five years ago which was all about going too far - don't go too far before you put a condom on. It was different from some of the previous campaigns because it was very factual. "It used language that teenagers could relate to. It was not preachy. The honesty and frankness of that would be one place I would look, particularly with a message that's fairly serious." This was the very tactic used by an anti-smoking campaign in Florida which has resulted in 80,000 fewer teenagers smoking. The campaign, called The Truth, has been devised and driven by teenagers themselves. It is factual, aggressive, and sounds like teenagers talking to teenagers. "Their brand is lies. Our brand is truth," is the slogan. The success of the Florida experiment doesn't surprise John Shaw. "Teenagers like to be able to make up their own minds, or at least think they are making up their own minds. If you present certain things about smoking and the tobacco industry, in a way that's non-judgmental but encourages teenagers to think about it, I don't think it's a losing battle." Significantly, the teenagers behind the Florida campaign chose to target the tobacco companies as the villains, rather than young smokers. One advertisement features an awards ceremony hosted by a satanic figure who hands out the "demon" award to tobacco as the year's biggest killer of young children. "It's the Ab Fab thing," says Shaw, "where the parents were more drunken and debauched than the child. Teenagers know their parents probably had a pretty wild time when they were teenagers - taking drugs and that sort of thing. Rebelling against the establishment starts to mean something different. "The main thing is teenagers don't want to be typecast," he adds. "We have an over-simplified idea of what a teenager is." Consultant clinical psychologist David Spellman agrees: "Teenagers are a diverse group but they are lumped together. They are emerging from childhood and trying to assert and explore their own identities. One of the ways to do that is to try things out and not to take as the truth something that your parents say, or the Guardian says, but to try it out for yourself. They have to make their own choices and their own mistakes. "As a parent, you want to protect, but if that's the only string to your bow you are going to come a cropper. Unless you want to sever your relationship with your teenage children, you've got to find a way of living with the choices they make." According to Jeannie Milligan, a psychotherapist specialising in adolescence at London's Tavistock Clinic, teenagers feel easily excited but also frightened, vulnerable but omnipotent. "Parents come to me and say give me instructions how to talk to my child so they will listen to me and do what I want," says Milligan. "But that never works. The more you can help them feel rounded, reasonably secure citizens who have got something to offer and can manage the bits of themselves that are flakey, then you are more likely to be able to talk with them about risks and have something taken on board. But it's a very difficult balance not to come over as wildly patronising." For Spellman, teenagers get a bad press. The vast majority of them get on well with their families, he says, and are more like their parents than is usually appreciated. "There is a cliched stereotype, the stroppy adolescent, the Harry Enfield character. But there are far more harmonious relations between parents and teenagers than you might think. "The vast majority do care what their parents say and do listen. They might make different choices, but it's not that they don't listen."

fields.headline: Can he play football?
fields.trailText: It was announced that Alex had to have four milk teeth out, to make way for his adult ones. Not unusual: lots of kids have overcrowding problems. However, with an extra sensitive mouth and a startle reflex which sends his arms and legs shooting out and his head back, I felt nervous about how the extraction was going to be achieved.
fields.body:
It was announced that Alex had to have four milk teeth out, to make way for his adult ones. Not unusual: lots of kids have overcrowding problems. However, with an extra sensitive mouth and a startle reflex which sends his arms and legs shooting out and his head back, I felt nervous about how the extraction was going to be achieved.

The consultant at the orthodontics surgery seemed reluctant to consider a general anaesthetic, but the very nice orthodontist peered at Alex over the top of his glasses and declared himself willing to pull them out in the normal manner: "If he jerks away they'll just come out quicker!" He also agreed to Alex staying in his wheelchair which would mean that at least his lower body would be strapped down.

I took to this man straight away - we have to deal with so many medical professionals, and the ones I dread are those who get so fazed by cerebral palsy that they've failed before they've begun: the locum who visited Alex when he had flu, and demanded a blow-by blow account of Alex's birth; the speech therapist who thought that Alex's undeveloped speech meant she should carry out endless cognitive tests; the radiologist who took one look at the wheelchair and declared that the X ray would be impossible - "Well, that won't fit, will it?" (Later, when I had got him settled on cushions under the camera, she shoved a metal clamp into his mouth with no warning. Alex squirmed, as any child would - more evidence, in her eyes, that he was, indeed, an unsuitable candidate for x-ray).

But Mr Hodges seemed calm and confident, and he had a sense of humour. Thank God, because we ended up unable to keep Alex still long enough for the extremely long thin needle to go in, and he had to yank all four eye teeth out at great speed with no more than a pair of pliers and a tube of pink anaesthetic gel. The blood flowed and Alex yelled, and in no more than a minute it was done.

Only a couple of hours later, while I still shook, Alex was cheerfully eating spaghetti hoops and demanding chocolate cake for bravery. The teeth have rather long pointy roots. Alex has taken them to school today in a box to show everyone. I'm having the day off to recover.

webTitle: Mir Cosmonauts prepare to journey home

fields.headline: Mir Cosmonauts prepare to journey home
fields.standfirst:
Mir homepage
Mir live tracking
Energia Ltd
fields.trailText: Russia's Mir space station will again be left unmanned next month while its foreign investors search for money for another mission, space officials said Tuesday.
fields.body:
Russia's Mir space station will again be left unmanned next month while its foreign investors search for money for another mission, space officials said Tuesday.

Cosmonauts Sergei Zalyotin and Alexander Kaleri, aboard Mir since April 6, are scheduled to return to Earth in mid-June, said Mission Control spokesman Valery Lyndin.

"The next mission is subject to availability of funds and is tentatively planned for November, but no firm date has been set," Lyndin said.

Zalyotin and Kaleri have resuscitated the ageing station, which had been flying unmanned for eight months, fixing a small air leak and doing other maintenance work.

The Russian government had planned to dump the 14-year-old Mir around March because it lacked the funds to keep it aloft, but extended its life after the Netherlands-based MirCorp signed a lease agreement on the station and provided funds for the new mission.

RKK Energia company, which built and runs Mir, has a 60-percent stake in MirCorp and the remainder belongs to private investors. One of them, Chirinjeev Kathuria, said preparations already have begun for a mission in the fall and another one early next year.

"After demonstrating Mir's viability and completing essential renovations, we are convinced more than ever of the station's long-term usefulness as a commercial space platform," a MirCorp statement quoted him as saying this week.

"The cosmonauts inspected Mir in detail and confirmed the station is in good shape," he said in the statement. "With minor continuing renovation, the station will be operational for the long term."

MirCorp president Jeffrey Manber said last week that the company was holding negotiations to send Italian Carlo Viberti to Mir as a visiting cosmonaut. Viberti, formerly with the European Space Agency, has undergone training for a Mir flight.

The U.S. space agency Nasa has been annoyed by Russia's effort to extend Mir's life, saying it diverts scarce Russian resources from the International Space Station project. The new station is far behind schedule because of Russia's failure to launch a key component, the Zvezda service module, currently set to be launched in July.

webTitle: Shuttle Atlantis boosts space station to higher orbit

fields.headline: Shuttle Atlantis boosts space station to higher orbit
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
International Space Station homepage
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Astronauts replaced a third battery in the international space station Wednesday to restore power to an outpost getting a much-needed boost from space shuttle Atlantis.
fields.body:
Astronauts replaced a third battery in the international space station Wednesday to restore power to an outpost getting a much-needed boost from space shuttle Atlantis.

The station has been losing altitude at the rate of 1 1/2 miles a week because of heavy solar activity. The natural phenomenon caused the atmosphere to expand and spacecraft to sink to a low orbit of 202 miles.

Commander James Halsell Jr. fired Atlantis' steering thrusters 27 times over the course of an hour Tuesday night to complete the first of three days of orbit boosts. The station's solar wings swayed slightly as it was pushed 10 miles higher.

When Halsell and pilot Scott Horowitz were finished, the 135-ton shuttle-station stack was in an oval-shaped orbit with a low of 212 miles and a high of 219 miles.

"It was basically bang on the money," Mission Control said. "Perfectly done."

Since the engines get too hot after more than an hour of thrusting and need 24 hours to cool, Nasa is splitting the work up over three days. The plan is for Atlantis to shove the station some 25 miles higher in all; the second boost is planned for Wednesday night.

Atlantis is acting as a space tugboat to help save the limited fuel aboard the orbiting complex. Inside the station early Wednesday, American astronaut Susan Helms and Russian cosmonaut Yuri Usachev popped another new battery into the Russian control module, named Zarya, or Sunrise. They installed two batteries on Tuesday; the fourth is scheduled to go in Wednesday night.

The batteries are a top priority for the Atlantis crew. Russian flight controllers forced the repairs by overcharging four of the station's six batteries, killing two of them and leaving two more dying.

It's also important practice for Usachev and Helms. They will perform similar tasks when they move aboard the space station next year along with Atlantis crewmate James Voss, who undertook several station repairs during a spacewalk earlier this week.

"It's been a very valuable experience for them to come up here to see what it's going to be like, so it's no longer a mystery," Halsell told reporters. "They know exactly what they're getting into and they're enthusiastic about returning as a crew onboard the station."

A small glitch during the charging of one of the new batteries forced flight controllers to take it offline. Nonetheless, Nasa managers remained optimistic that the station will be ready to link up with the much-delayed Russian service module in July.

"We're expecting to this mission to leave us with pretty much a pristine spacecraft," space station flight director Paul Hill said.

By the time Atlantis undocks on Friday, the seven-member crew will have hauled more than 2,000 pounds of gear over to the space station for future residents. The first astronauts to live there will arrive in November at the earliest, since the Russian space agency is more than two years behind in launching the service module, which will serve as crew quarters.

fields.headline: Misery behind the curtains
fields.standfirst: Sue Wells on how doctors turned detectives in Bristol to probe beneath their patients' illnesses
fields.trailText: Sue Wells on how doctors turned detectives in Bristol to probe beneath their patients' illnesses
fields.body:
Doctor Taylor and his colleagues at Bradgate surgery in Bristol were puzzled. They felt their medical skills made little impact when it came to influencing their patients' long-term health. Whatever they tried, the health statistics remained the same - and the high health need continued. The doctors were also puzzled because Henbury and Brentry in north Bristol seemed such nice, leafy suburbs. So what was going on?

They decided to find out for themselves. They took the unique step of commissioning a profile of the area to give them a fuller picture of the community in which their patients lived: not only their ages, health and housing, but the quality of their lives - the local crime rate, environmental issues, employment patterns and poverty. Did any of these factors affect their patients' health?

They wanted a holistic picture so they could begin to identify and treat the causes of ill health as well as the symptoms. What they revealed was health statistics that far exceeded the national average and seemed at odds with what appears to be desirable, leafy suburbia.

It is a fascinating survey of photographs, tables of statistics, health profiles, current services for families and children as well as older people. The report is fast becoming a teaching aid in local universities and colleges and is already into its third reprint since April.

The profile shows a community dominated by two polarised groups - a mostly transient group of young, single parents in council accommodation (aged 16 to 24) and a preponderance of elderly people (aged 65 to 80) who moved to the area after the war as young families and have grown old together. Both groups are the products of different eras, different housing policies, employment patterns, poverty and the breakdown of traditional family structures. All this adds up to a lack of identity as a community.

These two disparate groups actually have a lot in common. Both are heavily dependent on health and social services. They both rely on benefits. But, whereas the older population and many of their children form a stable, settled community owning or renting houses in the area, a very different picture emerges for single parents renting council flats.

Tina is a typical example. She is a 20-year-old single parent of two young daughters. They were re-housed to a council block in Henbury because of domestic violence. The flat is OK, according to Tina, but she desperately wants a house with a garden so her children can play safely.

"I can't let them play in the garden at the back of the flats because it's not safe," she says. "There are often needles left lying around by drug addicts, and I can't take the risk." The area is not enclosed, so Tina has to be outside with them and says that some of the other kids that play there are a bad influence.

Tina wants her doctor to prescribe pills for depression. "It really gets me down being shut in so much with the kids," she says. "They drive me mad sometimes. And I can't afford to keep taking them out every day unless we go to the park. I don't have any friends or family here and I get fed up."

Her situation mirrors that of many young mothers in the area living in poverty and ill health, alienated from their communities and unsupported by their families. They are a perfect example of one of the most pressing issues of the nation's health - the widening inequality between the richest and poorest outlined in the Acheson commission's report last year.

All the most telling indicators of poor health abound. These include low birth weight babies - "the most important single cause of preventable infant death" which "can also be an indicator of illness in later life". Leafy Henbury has the highest rate in the Avon health authority area: 13.1%, more than double the city average of 6.4%. The domino effect of social factors such as poor parental care, diet, family stress, poverty and smoking are, not surprisingly, linked.

In Hanbury, reported maternal depression is 17%, compared with a city average of 13.4%; 90% of children aged 18-30 months were reported as having a cough in the same period; and 22% of all Henbury patients aged six to 14 are registered as having asthma.

Add to this the high health need evident in the older group, where statistics reveal record rates of long-term illness, heart disease, hypertension and diabetes. These high rates, concludes the research, can be partly linked to the high smoking rates and body mass index (overweight).

Then throw in equally high rates of mental illness, psychiatric admissions and depression, especially among women, as well as high rates of drug dependence, especially in young men, and it becomes clear why Taylor and his partners had been puzzled.

Research like this boosts the government's argument, set out in Saving Lives: Our Healthier Nation, that health improvement programmes should be tailored to local circumstances. So what do the Bristol doctors hope to do about it? And how can they encourage people like Tina to live more healthily?

"Tackling causes of ill-health, such as poor housing or stress, could pay dividends," says Taylor. "Many patients' basic needs are simply not being met."

A lot of young, single parents are not attending the parent education classes before or after having their babies, and are therefore not getting additional help. Taylor thinks one reason is that the clinic serves a wide area, including mothers they have little in common with - mostly well-heeled, professional women who tend to be older, better educated and with partners. While this group forges bonds and friendships, some younger, single mums miss out, becoming isolated and stressed.

The research has led the health team to start looking at ways of changing things. Recently a local parenting skills project was set up to help parents bond with their children. "It's great to be able to tell them about it when they are depressed and having difficulties with their childrens' behaviour instead of prescribing medication," says Taylor. The same applies to the older population, where social factors may also contribute to poor health - often because simple needs are overlooked.

Taylor sees himself as part of a team where identifying and providing for patients' needs are vital if they want to make an impact on their health rather than "fire fighting" in the surgery. He stresses the importance of a multi-agency approach, using resources efficiently by working in partnership to produce local services, often with government money available through funding.

This practice is not the only one in the UK concerned to treat the causes of ill health. Sandwell council and health authority, West Midlands, recognises the impact of poor housing on health and doctors involved in this scheme are prescribing not only medication but housing repairs in an attempt to improve the health of asthmatic children living in cold, damp homes - at a cost of up to £4,000 for each family.

The Bristol findings fit neatly with the government's renewed emphasis on healthy living rather than the erstwhile aim of living longer. But this costs, and those patients who cannot pay privately for the privilege are still dependent even on enlightened surgeries to meet their needs.

fields.trailText: A new enterprise fund aims to help community businesses in the capital, reports Roger Crowe
fields.body:
Building societies are on the way out, rapidly converting over the past few years to publicly-quoted, multifaceted banks. The banks, meanwhile, have been busy leaving disadvantaged areas of the country, abandoning poor and apparently unpromising neighbourhoods and widening financial exclusion.

Yesterday saw the birth of the London Rebuilding Society (LRS), dedicated to countering such exclusion through a kind of mutuality and showing the banks how to capitalise on the opportunities they have been missing. Pointedly, the celebratory event took place in a disused branch of NatWest bank on the City Road in London, which is also likely to be the new organisation's headquarters. NatWest will not just be the landlord, however. The bank, recently taken over by Royal Bank of Scotland, will also have a member on the LRS board, along with experts in social enterprise. The board is chaired by Ed Mayo, director of the new economics foundation, the think-tank which has influenced Treasury thinking on financial exclusion over the past few years.

LRS is part of a rapidly emerging social finance sector, modelled partly on successful US examples such as the South Shore bank in Chicago. A similar approach is being pursued in Scotland, and the government is currently waiting for the report of a taskforce charged with figuring out how to get more private sector money into social enterprises.

Naomi Kingsley, the managing director of this new kind of bank, has a background in economic regeneration going back to the Greater London Enterprise Board, when Ken Livingstone was last in charge of London. Now she hopes the new initiative will win the support of the new mayor in a quest to find people who can be helped into business and others who can be helped to do more with their existing assets with a bit of commercial acumen and extra funding.

"We are talking about people the banks don't know what to do with, in areas where the public sector doesn't operate and the private sector doesn't want to," she said last week.

The private sector's traditional attitude has been that there is no money to be made from poor people. Traditionally, central and local government responded with a rash of projects based mainly on grant finance plus elements of training and advice. That led to grant dependency, continued lack of employment opportunities and a continued absence of services normally supplied by commercial businesses. The alternative approach, pioneered in Chicago, was to look at such communities through a new lens which combines community development with commercial skills. It recognises that businesses, not projects, can provide sustainable jobs and services. Also, many people in such areas have the ability to run businesses, with a little help and access to finance which is typically denied them because of blinkered banks.

These ideas have been transferred to the UK in the shape of the Local Investment Fund (which, ironically, is national) and local versions such as Aston Reinvestment Trust. London Rebuilding Society aims to build on that experience. Kingsley aims to have an entrepreneurial, community development approach rather than acting like bankers. She says LRS is unique because of a combination of a tiny central staff handling loans and administration with a network of local partners acting as the eyes and ears.

"We believe we are different because we will use local knowledge and expertise, like old relationship banking. It is like old-style banking, but with outreach," the LRS boss explained.

Some of the partners are already on board. They include Charities Aid Foundation, which has its own version of a social enterprise fund in Investors in Society, the Black Regeneration Forum, individual boroughs and local agencies such as Hackney Business Ventures. Pilot programmes will be carried out in the most enthusiastic three or four boroughs to refine the approach and the loan products.

But Kingsley stressed that it would be no good just waiting for people to come looking for money. "We have to employ some very entrepreneurial individuals," she said. "We need staff who will go out and talk to people and get them excited, whip them up into a fervour."

There is an argument that the banks have not lent to the sort of businesses LRS aims to back because there is no real demand. The message from the US is that this is true - up to a point. There are very few people in the disadvantaged areas to be targeted who are desperately trying to raise money to finance their great business idea. But community entrepreneurs in Chicago and elsewhere have shown there is a latent demand. Just as big business creates demand for things we didn't know we wanted, for everything from luxury ice-cream to four-wheel drive cars, LRS and its partners will have to bring to life demand for its money from people who don't yet know they can use it.

"I believe there is quite a big untapped market," Kingsley said. She first has to raise some money to lend to those people. To kick off the process, there will be £1m of ICOF funds available through LRS, plus £0.5m of NatWest money. But if it is to work, the body needs its own funding - up to £20m over seven years - most of which is expected to come from government or the European Union. And a share issue is planned for next year, giving Londoners the opportunity to invest in their own communities.

When LRS is ready to make its first loans in the autumn, it will be open to a wide variety of applicants. There must be some community benefit from the business proposition, but that could range from charities' commercial projects at one extreme, to a traditional shop at the other. It plans a special "mutual aid fund" for voluntary sector organisations to buy shares and obtain small loans.

Crucially, there will be no need to demonstrate track record or collateral - the two things which bar many people from conventional bank borrowing. "We will look at the business proposition differently and work with people to make it happen," Kingsley said. If LRS and other such ventures are successful, they may just convince the banks there is money to be made in poor areas. That is certainly the US experience. It remains for Kingsley to open bankers' eyes here.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Remember Basildon man? Or his close neighbour, Essex man? Back in the late eighties and early nineties, these stereotypical figures were invoked whenever politicians or editorial writers wanted a shorthand way of representing the new face of the British working class.

These shell-suited, vulgar, "loadsamoney" characters were said to have forsaken their traditional allegiance to the cloth cap Labour party and to have found a new home in a Conservative party only too happy to champion individuality and self-betterment. They were hardly an admired cross-section of the population, but the notion that they were a new political entity was a powerful impetus to the creation of New Labour and the "third way".

But sociologists Dennis Hayes and Alan Hudson were able to raise serious doubts about Basildon man's reality. In a 1992 survey, the year Basildon re-elected its Conservative MP, they found little of the brash aggressive materialism they had been led to expect.

Basildon's workers were no better off than their equivalents elsewhere and were even relatively poor by the standards of the south east. They did, however, retain the aspirations they had brought with them from the East End of London. More than anything, they wanted to escape from their working class origins and from a Labour party with its traditional associations with "poverty, welfare, hopelessness, and failure".

Hayes and Hudson were sufficiently fascinated by the working class attitudes they unearthed to undertake a second, more extensive survey of the town in 1997. In their new book based on this work, The Mood of the Nation: Basildon Man Revisited (Demos), they provide further evidence for their original argument that Basildon Thatcherism was only skin deep.

In the early 1990s, there had been considerable support for home ownership, cutting income taxes and restricting immigration. By 1997, only home ownership remained of the Thatcherite flagships.

Not that this is good news for New Labour. "The further seepage of political identification among traditional Labour supporters has not been replaced by the active support of those whose votes put Tony Blair in Downing Street," say the authors. Neither is this lack of political identification compensated for by involvement in such other institutions as trade unions, churches or social clubs. "These voters," Hayes and Hudson conclude, almost fatalistically, "have very little faith in anything other than themselves."

 Laurie Taylor talks to Alan Hudson and Paul Barker about Basildon Man in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Out of uniform
fields.standfirst: After a break of fifteen years, Alison Clarke decided to return to nursing. But not for long
fields.trailText: After a break of fifteen years, Alison Clarke decided to return to nursing. But not for long
fields.body:
A few months ago I decided that, after a break of 15 years, I wanted to go back to nursing. Very noble, you might think (I certainly did), but I was not the only one. Last year, about 2,500 other nurses also decided to do the same thing in response to a government campaign to attract leavers back into the profession. So far, so virtuous. What no one knows, of course, is how long any of us will stay - in my case, it only turned out to be a couple of weeks. Although the government is desperate for nurses to go back, it does not seem prepared to make the process of returning (or staying) easy.

My problems started on the return-to-practice course last February. Everyone knows that nurses are badly paid, so I didn't expect much remuneration to cover the compulsory, 11-week course (four of which are full-time - two in school and two on the wards), but I did expect some. Instead, what I got was an offer to pay some of my travelling and childcare expenses. Needless to say, I'm still waiting for them.

I realised I had made a mistake about four hours into the course - that was how long it took the tutor to explain the new, convoluted system of nurse education. Forget nursing as a practical profession - now it's all theories and intellectual processes. But who cares, I thought? I've got my qualification. Wrong again.

If I understood correctly, my nursing qualification was still valid (just as well as I'd paid £36 to have my name restored to the register), but not, apparently, as valid as it used to be. My qualification was now the equivalent of the first year of a three-year degree course. In other words, the level of a certificate in nursing.

None of which would matter, except that to become a ward sister (which I wanted to do), I now needed a degree. I already have several (although none of them in nursing, I admit) and was not prepared to study for a fifth.

I had also been prepared to take a huge cut in pay (from £27,000 as a solicitor to about £15,000 as a nurse), but there was no way I could survive on the salary of a staff nurse indefinitely. Things were not looking good. But there was still the ward placement to come.

I was apprehensive about going to a stroke unit in the local hospital with highly dependent patients, not least because of problems with my back (scoliosis for years and a broken vertebrae a couple of years ago). I was reassured, however, by the sessions with the manual handling tutor, who showed us how to move patients without actually lifting them. Unfortunately, I managed not to remember any of her tips when I had to do it for real on the ward.

Not that I did very much of anything when I got there - mainly because I was a complete liability. I might have been wearing a blue dress, but I seemed to have forgotten just about everything that a reasonably competent staff nurse should be able to do. It became a bit of an embarrassment explaining to patients and staff alike that I was simply masquerading in the outfit for a week or so.

But in some ways it didn't seem to matter - the health care assistants have taken over what nurses used to do. Some of them are even allowed to take blood (the remit of the junior doctor in my day). I managed to bath a few people, take a couple of temperatures with a thermometer that you stick in the patient's ear (in my day, you popped it in their mouth) and even took a few blood pressures. But it was all so tiring. How come nurses have to work so hard for so little? And the shiftwork - it's just so disruptive. Forget any idea of a social life; the demands of the ward's inadequate staffing levels always come first.

In the end, it wasn't a difficult decision not to go back. Too much has changed in the time I've been away - except, of course, the terrible pay and the awful hours.

fields.headline: In the front line
fields.standfirst: The caring professions can sometimes seem out of touch with the problems of people living in deprivation. That's why students at Leicester are being sent out into the field, reports Wendy Moore
fields.trailText: The caring professions can sometimes seem out of touch with the problems of people living in deprivation. That's why students at Leicester are being sent out into the field, reports Wendy Moore
fields.body:
For most medical students, coming from well-heeled, well-educated backgrounds, deprivation exists largely in text-books. But medical students in Leicester, alongside students in nursing and social work, are meeting poverty face-to-face on a unique training course.

The students are assigned in small mixed teams to meet tenants on St Matthew's estate - described in a survey last year as the second most impoverished estate in the UK - in Leicester's city centre. And not only do the students learn at first hand how social factors affect health, the experience has prompted many to take up the cudgels directly on tenants' behalf.

One team persuaded the local housing manager to find a more suitable flat for a woman who had been offered a three-storey maisonette, despite being blind. Another group cut through red tape to obtain speech therapy for a tenant who had suffered a stroke. And one team was so shocked by the lack of communication between public services they demanded a meeting with the chair of Leicestershire health authority to outline their concerns. Now the students are busy raising a petition against the planned closure of the local library.

The course is the brainchild of Dr Angela Lennox, director of the centre for studies in community healthcare at Leicester University. Lennox, who has been a GP on St Matthew's for the past 12 years, says: "What I would like to see is that anyone entering the caring professions is exposed to this approach."

She believes training future doctors, social workers and nurses together to understand how people struggle with disadvantage will help them collaborate when they become front line staff themselves and, in turn, reduce inequalities. She is already spearheading this approach - bringing GPs, housing workers, police and other professionals together to tackle St Matthew's problems. "I want to see people positively say they want to work in areas that are disadvantaged," says Lennox, who was last year awarded the MBE for services to medicine for the community. Ultimately, she hopes St Matthew's will produce its own doctors, nurses and social workers.

The course has been held up by the government's social exclusion unit as a model for skilling future professionals to tackle inequality and is being copied elsewhere. A similar programme begins in October at Ghent University, Belgium, while visitors have come from as far afield as Russia and China.

Lennox launched the three-week course four years ago, initially for medical students in their third year at Leicester - now Leicester Warwick - medical school. Twenty medical students helped design the curriculum. Student nurses from Leicester's De Montfort University joined the programme in 1997 and in March this year the first social work students, from Leicester University, swelled the ranks.

Students spend their first week getting to know a tenant, then talk to the agencies involved in that patient's care, and finally present their conclusions to senior local health and social care managers. These regularly include Leicestershire's social services director and managers and chairs of the health authority and local NHS trusts.

Training is centred on Prince Philip House, an innovative community centre which opened in 1996 after lobbying by Lennox. Designed with residents, it brings together health services - including four GPs - a police station, a cafe and voluntary organisations, under one roof.

Many of the estate's tenants suffer multiple health problems, explains Lennox, whose surgery is now based in Prince Philip House. Typical of many inner-city estates, St Matthew's has high levels of unemployment, child abuse and debt and a fast turnover of residents, since for many the main objective is to move elsewhere. Many residents are refugees or evacuees, particularly from Montserrat - after the volcano eruption - and Somalia.

Regeneration work is helping revive the estate's fortunes and last year crime fell by 50%. But stress, poverty and lifestyle still lead to high rates of infection, cancer and other health risks, not helped by low levels of immunisation and smear tests.

For most students, visiting St Matthew's is a huge culture shock. "We have never been exposed to this sort of thing before," says medical student Sarah Thomasset. "It does widen your horizons." Nursing student Heather Morris agrees. "It has been a real eye opener," she says.

Yet the students' naivety is also their strength. Medical student Shaista Khan was terrified when assigned in her first week to visit a 37-year-old man with mental health problems. "I have never met anyone with mental health problems," she confessed at the presentation. She found him quiet and gentle, but the man had such a poor relationship with his GP that he always called out-of-hours services when he was ill and stored the follow-up notes - meant for his GP - in the glove compartment of his car. Now Khan and student nurse Lisa Pugh, who also worked on the case, have asked the man's community psychiatric nurse - unaware of the problem - to help him change doctors. "We feel we have made a little difference in this man's life," says Khan.

Another team of this year's students met an Afro-Caribbean woman who was "frightened for her life" because nobody had explained her treatment for cervical cancer, which included a hysterectomy and radiotherapy. The woman thought she was dying and was ostracised by her sister, who feared the cancer was infectious. Medical student Nashat Qamar thought communications were "abysmal" and went with fellow students to see the woman's GP to tell him so.

Social work student Paula Sand ham, who worked on the same case, says: "It has been brilliant working with other students to get their different perspectives." And student nurse Justine Locke, who went to school on St Matthew's and lived nearby, says the course has reinforced her ambition to work on poverty issues.

Residents have unanimously welcomed the students' visits - and many found them therapeutic. One woman with agoraphobia felt more confident after discussing her problems with a student team.

While all medical students normally spend some time in local communities, they do not neccessarily come up against deprivation. Prof Stewart Petersen, head of medical education at Leicester University, says: "Most of our students come from extraordinarily affluent backgrounds. I think the main thing is we are producing a generation of professionals who understand what inequalities are."

The programme helps them understand not only how social factors affect health but that professionals working in isolation are relatively powerless to affect change. "We want to get each professional group to realise they can do more working together," he says. "In many ways, that is the message people take away from this."

Medical student Shaista Khan was terrified when assigned in her first week to visit a 37-year-old man with mental health problems. "I have never met anyone with mental health problems," she confessed at the presentation. She found him quiet and gentle, but the man had such a poor relationship with his GP that he always called out-of-hours services when he was ill and stored the follow-up notes - meant for his GP - in the glove compartment of his car. Now Khan and student nurse Lisa Pugh, who also worked on the case, have asked the man's community psychiatric nurse - unaware of the problem - to help him change doctors. "We feel we have made a little difference in this man's life," says Khan. Another team of this year's students met an Afro-Caribbean woman who was "frightened for her life" because nobody had explained her treatment for cervical cancer, which included a hysterectomy and radiotherapy. The woman thought she was dying and was ostracised by her sister, who feared the cancer was infectious. Medical student Nashat Qamar thought communications were "abysmal" and went with fellow students to see the woman's GP to tell him so. Social work student Paula Sand ham, who worked on the same case, says: "It has been brilliant working with other students to get their different perspectives." And student nurse Justine Locke, who went to school on St Matthew's and lived nearby, says the course has reinforced her ambition to work on poverty issues. Residents have unanimously welcomed the students' visits - and many found them therapeutic. One woman with agoraphobia felt more confident after discussing her problems with a student team. While all medical students normally spend some time in local communities, they do not neccessarily come up against deprivation. Prof Stewart Petersen, head of medical education at Leicester University, says: "Most of our students come from extraordinarily affluent backgrounds. I think the main thing is we are producing a generation of professionals who understand what inequalities are." The programme helps them understand not only how social factors affect health but that professionals working in isolation are relatively powerless to affect change. "We want to get each professional group to realise they can do more working together," he says. "In many ways, that is the message people take away from this."

fields.headline: The gold standard
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot meets the driving forces behind plans for a stadium where all athletes will start on equal terms
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot meets the driving forces behind plans for a stadium where all athletes will start on equal terms
fields.body:
The terms "world-first" and "state-of-the-art" are rarely associated with Boston. Not Boston, Lincolnshire, anyway. Unlike its namesake on the eastern seaboard of the US, it's hardly a bustling metropolis. Indeed, it's a rather isolated town of 60,000 souls, close to the east coast of England and surrounded by flat fields.

One of those fields provides pitches for Boston rugby football club. The white goal posts form one of the few deviations from the horizontal as far as the eye can see. Along with some adjoining agricultural land, this will be the site of Boston's biggest claim to fame since medieval masons bequeathed it one of the tallest church towers in the country, ironically known as The Stump.

Here, on the edge of town, is to be built a world-first athletics stadium with state-of-the-art facilities to make it fully accessible to disabled as well as able-bodied athletes.

From the trackside toilets to the wide doors, the ramps in the viewing areas to the Braille guide rails, everything is to be designed with wheelchair-users, amputees or the visually impaired in mind.

No other town or city will have anything quite like it. Not Barcelona, Atlanta, Sidney or anywhere else that has staged a modern Olympics. And certainly not Boston, Massachussetts. "They tried something similar a few years ago and failed," says Mark James, chief executive of Boston borough council.

The hint of a smile suggests that he is confident that Boston, England, will not fail. And with some justification. Although the £3m put aside by local councillors is less than half of the estimated cost, a head of steam is building up behind the project which suggests that the additional £4.5m will not be too difficult to raise.

Some 32 charities worldwide have made pledges and a dozen companies are being lined up for commercial sponsorship. An application for a national lottery grant is also in the offing. A big company, Granada, has already agreed to manage the stadium and to run a profit-making health and fitness club within the complex.

Letters of support have come from New York and Canberra. Chris Nunn, head coach for athletes with disabilities at the Australian Institute of Sport, described the proposal as "the most exciting facility I have heard of". Closer to home, Dave Moorcroft, of UK Athletics, has professed himself "very impressed" with the plans and offered enthusiastic backing.

The money-raising campaign was launched at the House of Lords, at a reception hosted by Lord Morris of Manchester, a former minister for the disabled. A chance meeting there stiffened Mark James's conviction that Boston was going to provide a much-needed facility. "I was approached by a woman who turned out to be a disabled athlete," he recalls. "She told me how she'd been to a meeting last year where she couldn't get her wheelchair into the shower. She'd had to lie on the floor and crawl out. If ever we had any doubts about what we're planning . . ."

The words trail away but the determination is all too evident. James is a dapper and dynamic Welshman who left Westminster council to come to Boston because he thought it was the sort of place where he could "make a difference". Just how much of a difference he could never have imagined.

"This has gone from being a local project to a national project to an international project," he muses. "It's driving us."

What drove him forward in the first place was a 45-minute telephone conversation with a remarkable 54-year-old blind grandmother called Mary Clark. Like many a resident of Boston, she had read in her local paper that the town was to have an athletics stadium for the first time. Local councillors had apparently been much impressed by proposals from the recently-promoted rugby club. In return for making their ground available for athletics meetings, the club would get a proper stand and indoor training facilities.

That was all very well, thought Clark, but what about sportsmen and sportswomen with some kind of disability? If a new stadium was going to be built from scratch, then surely it should be for all potential competitors.

Unlike most residents of Boston, she has had first-hand experience of stadiums around the world. Back in 1983, she broke a world record in the pentathlon (and the British record for the javelin) during the European Games for the visually impaired in Bulgaria. The following year, she won two silver medals at the Olympics for the disabled in New York and the year after that a silver and a bronze in Rome.

Imagine what it must be like to run as fast or jump as far as you can without being able to see where you're going, and you have some measure of Clark's physical courage. "I'm not a person," she says sweetly, "to be shrugged off easily."

Mark James is all too well aware of that. He had to be dragged out of a meeting by his secretary because Clark "refused to take no for an answer". Three-quarters of an hour later, he put the phone down and began to mull over her detailed proposals, which would add at least £2.5m to the final cost. "Only when we hired a consultant to look into it," says James, "did we discover that this would be something highly unusual." Unique, in fact.

"If somebody's got to do it, why not little old Boston," beams Mary Clark. "I'm just sorry that it didn't happen in my day.

"Only in the last 10 years has awareness grown about people with disabilities and the way they should be treated. As athletes, we had the same thrills and disappointments as anyone else."

She's looking forward to taking her place in the new stadium's wheelchair-friendly stands, hopefully in August 2001. "I have a friend who'll give me a running commentary," she says. "There's nothing wrong with my ears."

fields.headline: Back to nature
fields.standfirst: Prince Charles urged us to adopt a more sacred view of the planet.  Scientist Mae-Wan Ho believes he has a point
fields.trailText: Prince Charles urged us to adopt a more sacred view of the planet. Scientist Mae-Wan Ho believes he has a point
fields.body:
Prince Charles embarrassed the government and the scientific establishment with his Reith lecture on BBC Radio 4 last week. In his wide-ranging talk, which drew on the work of theologians, philosophers, scientists and economists, he said much that surely expressed the views of the majority in this country. Is it possible that the prince is more in touch with the common people than our elected government?

The idea that there is a sacred trust under which human beings accept stewardship for the earth is common to most spiritual traditions, including those that do not acknowledge a creator. The prince urged us to recapture this sense of the sacred, in which we accept that there are bounds of balance, order and harmony in the natural world and that development is progress only if it is sustainable. He singled out gene biotechnology for attack as an unacceptable transgression of nature's limits, treating our entire world as a "laboratory of life" with potentially disastrous consequences.

Did he attack science? Was he anti-science, as has been claimed? Not at all. Many scientists, myself included, were quite comfortable with what he said. His attack was aimed at the "impenetrable layers of scientific rationalism" (he might have said "rationalisation") that obscure our sense of the sacred and respect for the earth, and in the end lead us to regard the whole of nature, including human beings, as something that can be "engineered for our own convenience or as a nuisance to be evaded and manipulated". That view may indeed infect science, but is not at all inherent in it.

Prince Charles was speaking for the people when he called for support for organic farming. Who could disagree when he argued that if a fraction of the money currently being invested in developing genetically manipulated crops was applied to understanding and improving traditional systems of agriculture, which have stood the all-important test of time, the results would be "remarkable"?

There is already a holistic approach to sustainable agriculture that integrates indigenous with western science, and is adapted to local ecological and social conditions. Some 12.5m hectares world wide are successfully farmed in this way. Yields have doubled and tripled, and are continuing to increase far in excess of anything GM crops have to offer. Support for this is growing among farmers, trade unions, consumers, indigenous peoples and diverse public interest organisations. Not, however, from industry, because when farmers are free to keep their seeds, and to harvest and sell their produce locally, corporate monopolies cannot hold the hungry to ransom.

Prince Charles could have taken heart from the fact that the mechanistic view is rapidly losing ground within contemporary western science. An organic revolution is sweeping across the disciplines, from quantum physics to the ecology of complexity and molecular genetics. Proponents of gene biotechnology are stuck in the mechanistic era, and our mainstream academic institutions are perpetrating the outmoded paradigm if only because it serves so well to promote the genetic engineering of life.

The emerging science of the organism reinstates the holistic perspectives of indigenous cultures. It also reveals that the romantic poets' vision of the oneness of nature is the truly rational point of view, while the mechanistic tradition is deeply flawed and irrational.

I was disappointed that he ended by saying that taking a cautious approach or achieving balance in life is never as much fun as the alternatives. He made it sound as if living in a sustainable world means leading a less satisfying life. Precisely the opposite is the case. Instead of being isolated and anxious in a culture dominated by competition and exploitation, we can look forward to experiencing the joy of being connected and sustained.

 Dr Mae-Wan Ho, reader in biology at the Open University, is among a group of more than 300 scientists from 39 countries who are calling for a moratorium on environmental releases of GMOs and who support organic, sustainable agriculture. Further details at www.i-sis.org

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A squatter granted possession of a council flat he had occupied for 13 years in Brixton, south London, sold it for £100,000 and moved back to Australia to live near Bondi Beach
fields.body:
Life's a beach: A squatter granted possession of a council flat he had occupied for 13 years in Brixton, south London, sold it for £100,000 and moved back to Australia to live near Bondi Beach.

Batty idea: Egyptian fruit bats at a wildlife park in Leeds have had their nocturnal house decorated in the style of a pharaoh's tomb by two local art students.

Express service: The driver of a double-decker bus took 80 passengers on a chase through Bristol in pursuit of a car that had forced him to brake sharply.

Given a break: Hampshire police have decided to withdraw the £20 fixed penalty ticket issued to a man who was seen driving one-handed on the M3 while eating a KitKat.

Fishy business: Doctors at a GP practice in Stromness, Orkney, are giving herring on prescription to patients who have suffered heart problems.

Strained relationship: Confusion over the recent change in Northern Ireland's telephone numbers has resulted in a Catholic marriage counselling service's helpline receiving a flood of calls for Sinn Fein.

Crestfallen: Two fans of Huddersfield Town had the football team's badge tattooed on their legs just two days before the club announced a new design.

Three's company: A newly-wed couple from Newport, Gwent, took their 3ft pet iguana with them on honeymoon to Torquay.

Frozen in: An ice-cream company from Ashington, Northumberland, has won a £100,000-a-year contract to export frozen drinks to Iceland.

Flight of fancy: A man arrested trying to steal a helicopter from a police base at Bodelwyddan, Denbighshire, was convinced that playing a computer simulator game had given him the skills needed to fly the aircraft.

Ring of truth: Police who found a man wandering along the fast lane of the M23 in Surrey were told that he was looking for the wedding ring his wife had thrown from the car window during a row.

Cutting edge: Four people applied to become a circus knife-thrower's assistant after the vacancy was advertised at a job centre in Newport, Gwent.

Star treatment: Plans have been proposed for a redundant psychiatric hospital in Carmarthen to be converted into the first five-star hotel in west Wales.

King's ransom: An insurance broker from Southend, Essex, has given up his £50,000-a-year job to become an Elvis impersonator.
