webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.trailText:
The nightmare rushes to an end
Israel capped its humiliating retreat from Lebanon early Wednesday with a series of vengeful air on Beaufort Castle, sending ancient stones of the 11th century Crusader fortress tumbling down into the wadi below.
fields.body:
The nightmare rushes to an end
Israel capped its humiliating retreat from Lebanon early Wednesday with a series of vengeful air on Beaufort Castle, sending ancient stones of the 11th century Crusader fortress tumbling down into the wadi below.

But one issue remains with the potential to make a mess of the entire process.

The Shebaa Farms suddenly assume far more importance than virtually any other tiny piece of agricultural land on Earth... the Israelis freely admit that the Shebaa Farms are not theirs... The Syrians have informed the United Nations that in their judgement, the land is Lebanese ­ so there will be no objections from Damascus. What disagreement exists is therefore based primarily on timing and on the byzantine semantics of international diplomacy.
The Daily Star - Lebanon

Israel's hysteric aggression
How could be analysed this hysteric aggression launched by Israel all the night of the day before yesterday against Lebanon? Its warplanes bombed all what they could reach. Even children and women weren't safe from this aggression at the time. Israel is filling the universe with cries about the withdrawal and the preparation for it.

It is Lebanon that always surpasses itself and rises above wounds, blood and destruction for the nation and future to triumph it. Therefore, Lebanon becomes a giant by its pioneer national and patriotic stance that doesn't kneel before arrogance, but disdains and challenges it to hurt its solidarity and firmness.
Al Thawra - Syria

The tragedy hits home
Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon was not supposed to be like this. Yet the idea of an "orderly unilateral withdrawal" always seemed a contradiction in terms, like a controlled free fall. The unsettling pictures of fleeing Lebanese and rejoicing forces, however, do not change Israel's fundamental objectives, nor the chances of achieving them.

Israel must do its part, as it seems to be doing, by taking in all those Lebanese who seek refuge because of their connection to Israel. It is [the UN's] job, however, to help protect those who choose to stay in Lebanon, and help create conditions that will allow a maximum number of Lebanese refugees to return home.

For the war to end, messages from the US and the UN to Syria and Lebanon must go beyond the usual request for calm in the region. The US and the UN need to hold these countries equally responsible for the full implementation of UN Security Council Resolution 425.
The Jerusalem Post - Israel

A cruel but inevitable chapter
The Israel Defense Forces is facing a little unpleasantness as it leaves Lebanon. But this is nothing in comparison with what it has faced while it was there'. 'Israel is not doing anyone a favor and is finally acting according to its own national interest.

There is no truth in the complaints of Likud Chairman MK Ariel "Arik" Sharon and of the right that Israel is folding and the army being defeated in its withdrawal... No one promised a rose garden when - with a delay to which the right contributed with all its might - Israeli politics did what it should have done long ago.
Ha'aretz - Israel

Palestinians hail Israel's Lebanon pullout
The Palestinian Authority welcomes Israel's withdrawal from south Lebanon and congratulates the Lebanese people for regaining sovereignty over their land.

[But] Palestinians often have complained that [Israeli Prime Minister] Barak, who came to power last year promising accelerated talks with the Palestinians, was more interested in forging peace with Syria and ending Israel's 22-year occupation of south Lebanon.
The Jordan Times

fields.trailText: The Guardian and Observer won the right yesterday to challenge court orders to hand over to the police special branch any documents or emails they may have relating to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
The Guardian and Observer won the right yesterday to challenge court orders to hand over to the police special branch any documents or emails they may have relating to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.

Their lawyers told the high court that the orders had serious implications for press freedom and the principle of freedom of expression enshrined in the European convention on human rights.

Government lawyers want the Guardian editor, Alan Rusbridger, to produce the original of a letter emailed to the newspaper from Paris, where Mr Shayler lives, part of which was published in February.

It related to allegations of MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy.

They also want Roger Alton, the Observer's editor, and Martin Bright, its home affairs correspondent, to hand over material relating to a front-page article headlined "Two spies named in Libya plot", also published in February.

Michael Tugendhat QC, for the newspapers, said there was "simply no material at all" before Judge Stephens, the Old Bailey judge who made the orders in March, on which he could arrive at the conclusion that the interests of national security outweighed the fundamental rights of the journalists to protect the confidentiality of their sources.

Ben Emmerson QC, for Mr Bright, pointed out that his client was threatened with a criminal prosecution under the Official Secrets Act, and self-incrimination was outlawed by the European court of human rights.

There was a clear public interest, he said, in protecting the confidentiality of relations between journalists and whistleblowers.

Clare Montgomery QC, for the director of public prosecutions, said material which the newspapers might possess would be of "substantial value" to the police investigation into Mr Shayler. The fact that Mr Shayler was a "serial letter writer and a serial offender of the official secrets act" was irrelevant", she said.

"We have got to prove Mr Shayler gave some information to somebody," she added. All the other information published and sourced to Mr Shayler could be dismissed by him as "hearsay" if he was tried for betraying secrets.

Mr Justice Tucker ruled that the newspapers had an "arguable case" for a judicial review, which should be heard urgently by a two-judge court.

Guardian Newspapers Ltd said in a statement: "We are very pleased with the judgment today. This is clearly a matter of public interest with significant implications for freedom of expression."

 David Shayler's website
 Draft freedom of information bill
 Campaign for Freedom of Information

fields.headline: Hague goes grey
fields.standfirst: Political editor Michael White explains the background to Conservative proposals to reform the state pension
fields.trailText:
Wednesday, 1pm: Political editor Michael White explains the background to Conservative proposals to reform the state pension.
Special report
fields.body:
Pensioner groups and poverty lobbyists fell upon William Hague's new pension proposals with almost as much fury yesterday as government ministers - and rather loftier motives.

Social security expert and Labour ex-minister, Frank Field, counter-intuitive as ever, jumped the other way and backed Mr Hague. ''It's not the Tories, it's the pensioners that are de-stablising this government,'' he predicted. It was another lively day for ''grey power.''

The Conservative leader used a speech in London to fuel pensioner suspicions that they are not important in the Blairite ''young country'' scheme of things. He also promised to re-allocate some of Labour's pension schemes, notably the £150 a year winter fuel allowance and the free TV licence for over-75s.

Both are tax-free and go to dukes as well as retired dustmen. Under Mr Hague's £2 billion scheme the money would be re-allocated on the basic pension ( taxable) at between £5 a week for the single pensioner aged 65-75 and £10 pw for pensioner couples over 75, of whom relatively few survive as couples. Men still die younger.

Government statisticians fell on the Hague plan to prove that, once assorted benefits have been clawed back - or tax paid in some cases - many of the poorest pensioners will either be 30p better off or (said Liberal Democrat MP and tax expert, Professor Steve Webb) 66p worse off, if they pay tax.

The government has been on the backfoot over pensions since April when Britain's 10 million pensioners received an inflation-proofed 75p a week extra in their pension books - courtesy of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Mr Brown is determined to concentrate his efforts to help those pensioners who are poorest, usually the very old. Had he taken his critics advice and re-linked pensions to average earnings not inflation, he says, he would have spent £600m less on pensioners than his own mix of measures is giving them.

''The dishonesty of these Tory proposals is breathtaking,'' he said in a statement. the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, was even more scathing. The poorest will be poorer still, he predicted.

The Tory spokesman, ex-Treasury official David ''Two Brains'' Willetts, as expert in his way as his rivals, disagrees. These are his considered plans, not the quickie response that Labour claims they are. But the Tory leader and his staff have spotted a rich seam of discontent. Pensioner lobbies and other s have long complained that the basic state pension is becoming a safety net, withering away as average wages rise much faster than inflation and occupational pensions make the majority better off - in some cases spectacularly so.

Some pensioners want more money on the basic rate as a matter of principle, they are old enough to be sensitive to any talk of ''handouts'' - and feel they have worked and paid all their lives for a pension that keeps them out of poverty.

They mistrust one-off payments like the fuel allowance, which could be withdrawn. They resent means-tested benefits, increasingly the government's policy -''targeting'' help on the most needy - and want the political solidarity which goes with a universally payable pension benefit.

The trouble is with such payments - including child benefit at the other end of the scale - is that they are costly and they give money to dukes who may not need it, as well as many comfortably-off middle c lass pensioners.

It is hard to get the mix right, but one thing remains certain. Pensioners remember to vote better than young people. They also remember slights. No wonder Mr Brown is jumpy.

webTitle: 24 May: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 24 May: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText:
In brief and the latest casting news

M I 2 is reviewed, Allen's latest flick is biggest in 20 years, the return of Jar Jar Binks, the Shaft trailer, and on the casting couch Jamie Bell and Portia de Rossi
fields.body:
 Harry Knowles of Ain't It Cool News offers his own inimitable take on Mission: Impossible 2. "This is a mediocre film, that happens to have around 30 to 45 minutes of incredible John Woo absurd/genius/magical action at the end of the nap. Is it worth going to the theater to suffer through a mediocre film for this end orgy? Yeah. It is This film reminded me of The World is Not Enough in its lack of coherent or compelling plot and character." Undeterred by lukewarm reviews, John Woo recently told the BBC that M: I 3 might yet be made. "We've talked about it," he said, "and Tom Cruise is open to it."

 Woody Allen's latest movie, Small Time Crooks, a rags-to-riches caper about a bumbling petty thief (Allen) and his manicurist wife (Tracey Ullman), has proved that audiences love it when Allen does what he does best - screwball comedies. The movie took $3.8m in his opening weekend, making it Allen's biggest opening in 20 years.

 Now that Lucas has cast his Anakin Skywalker for Episode 2, thoughts turn anxiously to whether Jar Jar Binks will make a return. And it doesn't look good. Talking to the San Francisco Chronicle, Lucasfilm spokesperson Lynne Hale said, "Ohhh, but the kids love Jar Jar Binks. We get more mail for Jar Jar than anybody."

 The Shaft trailer is nowonline in Quicktime format.

Casting couch

 The young British star of the new movie Dancer, one of the sensations of the Cannes film festival, could scoop one of the most coveted roles in Hollywood - the lead in the Harry Potter film. Following his debut in Dancer, Jamie Bell, 14, has been asked to audition for the role of the teenage magician. Dancer-director Stephen Daldry believes Bell's got what it takes to make it big in the movies: "Jamie has the charisma to hold the whole movie."

 Open Your Eyes director Alejandro Amenabar's next project will be supernatural ghost story The Others, with Nicole Kidman, Christopher Eccleston and Elaine (Felicia's Journey) Cassidy.

 Oscar winner Cuba Gooding Jr and James Caan are to star in the indie thriller In the Shadows. Matthew Modine and Joey Lauren Adams have also been cast in the film, which is set against the backdrop of the Hollywood stunt world.

 Sony Family Entertainment has acquired rights to Roman Dirge's cult comic Lenore for an animated film that will be scripted by Caroline Thompson and Larry Wilson, who last collaborated on The Addams Family. The Lenore of the title is a 10-year-old girl who returns from the dead, primarily because she feels her family needs her. The tone, said Thompson, is much in line with that of South Park.

 Ally McBeal actress and the newly extremely thin Portia de Rossi has signed to play the female lead in Cletis Tout opposite Christian Slater, Tim Allen and Richard Dreyfuss.

fields.headline: William Hague's pensions speech
fields.standfirst:
'Common Sense for Pensioners'
William Hague's full speech to the LSE
fields.trailText: A few weeks ago the Evening Standard published a story under the headline 'Trendy oldies join Cool Britannia'. It read: 'Ministers want to "rebrand" pensioners with a trendy name that will appeal to younger people. Some of Whitehall's finest minds are working on the problem, while the Government is also seeking outside help to try to come up with the new title Ministers believe words like "pensioners" or "elderly" carry a grey image with deters young people from thinking ahead' (29th March 2000).
fields.body:
A few weeks ago the Evening Standard published a story under the headline 'Trendy oldies join Cool Britannia'. It read: 'Ministers want to "rebrand" pensioners with a trendy name that will appeal to younger people. Some of Whitehall's finest minds are working on the problem, while the Government is also seeking outside help to try to come up with the new title Ministers believe words like "pensioners" or "elderly" carry a grey image with deters young people from thinking ahead' (29th March 2000).

That story sums up this Government's attitude towards Britain's pensioners.

It sums up the attitude of Tony Blair when he talks about Britain becoming a 'young country' and has no time for those forces of conservatism who don't fit in it.

It sums up the attitude of Peter Mandelson, the man in charge of Labour's election plans, who says there is 'no mileage' in targeting elderly voters because they are not 'aspirational' (Sunday Times, 16 April 2000).

It sums up the attitude of the Chairman of the Labour Parliamentary Party, who recently came out with the breathtaking insult that pensioners are often 'racist'. Of course he also said they were 'predominantly Conservative' (Sunday Times, 16 April 2000) and we intend to prove him right at least about that.

It sums up the attitude of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who has patronised older people by trying to buy them off with a series of badly targeted, bureaucratic gimmicks and then was only able to offer them a 75 pence increase in the basic state pension.

Britain's eleven million pensioners know that they are the unwanted, unwelcome, uncool guests at New Labour's banquet. And they know that they have paid the price through their pockets.

For three years pensioners have been at the sharp end of the Chancellor's policies.

At the sharp end of £150 average rises in Council Tax for Band D properties as Labour Councils and a Labour Government worked together to waste their money. The Government talks of a £150 winter fuel payment. Many pensioners have found that by the time they've paid their increased Council Tax the money has all gone.

At the sharp end of increases in petrol prices. Pensioners who depend on their cars to preserve their independence have seen prices driven close to the £4 a gallon mark.

At the sharp end too, when this Chancellor scrapped dividend tax credits, leaving 300,000 pensioners whose income is below the income tax threshold, having to pay an average of £75 a year more to the exchequer.

In the same £5bn a year raid on pension funds, Gordon Brown set a timebomb for future pensioners by forcing working people to put up to £200 a year extra into their pension funds. Last year he abolished the Married Couples Allowance for all future pensioners too.

He has also scrapped the Widows Bereavement Allowance without compensating all widowed pensioners properly, scrapped tax relief on medical insurance for the over 65s and abolished retirement relief for older people selling off their small businesses.

Pensioners remembered all these blows when they reacted so angrily to the 75p basic rate rise.

Gordon Brown hoped no one would notice. He hoped the anger of pensioners wouldn't matter. How wrong he was.

As anyone who campaigned in this year's local elections, who knocked on doors and listened to hard pressed pensioners, knows: boy, did they notice, and boy, are they angry.

Angry at a Labour Government that promised to be the pensioners' friend and has comprehensively betrayed them.

Angry at a Labour Government that used every low-down trick to win pensioners' votes at the general election and then forgot all about them the day after.

Angry at a Labour Government that has produced one gimmick after another, but doesn't trust pensioners with a decent weekly income they can spend as they see fit.

I have listened to their anger and their feelings of betrayal first-hand in hundreds of meetings around Britain.

I listened to the elderly man in Bolton who told me 'Labour's priorities are all wrong - look at Europe, the Dome, these asylum seekers - more should be done on health and for the pensioners'.

I listened to the lifelong Labour supporter in Plymouth who summed up what she thought of Tony Blair and his policies: 'He thinks people like me are old has-beens, who aren't important or glamorous, people who they think can simply go to the back of the queue'.

I listened to the pensioner in Leeds who could barely contain his anger when he said to me '75p was a joke, an insult  We don't want all these gestures and gimmicks - we just want a decent basic pension'.

And I listened also to another pensioner here in London who had a message for Conservatives. 'I voted Labour because they promised so much. I'm terribly disappointed but I wonder if there is any alternative'.

We've been busy listening to people while this Government has been busy forgetting them.

Now we are offering an alternative. Our Party has listened to all these people, and in all sorts of areas we are now offering an alternative to the failed polices and broken promises of this Government.

We offer a law and order policy that will back up the police, punish the criminal, and protect those, such as the elderly, who are particularly vulnerable to crime.

We offer a health policy that will build a stronger NHS that puts patients before politicians, and which doesn't treat older people as second class patients.

We offer a long term care policy that protects the assets of responsible people who save for their retirement.

Today, I want to build on those policies by tackling the central concern of millions of pensioners: the level of their weekly income and the basic state pension.

What pensioners say over and over again is that they would rather have a reliable weekly income which is theirs by right to spend as they think best, than a series of handouts and gimmicks.

Today we are setting out a carefully costed package based on a Conservative pension uprating in April 2001. It shows what we would do for pensioners in hard figures and in hard cash. We are calling it Common Sense for Pensioners.

We would start by putting the money used on the winter fuel payment and the free TV licence into the basic pension instead. This also brings a bureaucracy bonus as we can save £40 million currently being wasted on administering, often very incompetently, these new schemes. Many pensioners received their winter fuel payments as winter drew to a close. We're going to take that £40 million out of the budgets of bureaucrats and put it directly into the pockets of pensioners.

We have also identified extra social security savings. We would abolish the New Deal for Lone Parents which is a £90 million a year flop. On the Government's own figures, it is having zero impact on the employment prospects of lone parents. We have already announced separately our far more effective approach to lone parents. We would also recoup some money from the Social Fund, which has recently been increased substantially by the Government.

Taken together, these measures yield almost exactly £2 billion. We would then put all this money into helping pensioners in the most straight-forward, honest, and effective way - increases in the basic contributory state pension. We would add it to the expected increase in next year's pension uprating which, if awarded on the basis of current inflation forecasts, would be £2 to a single pensioner and £3 for a married couple.

On this basis, if the normal uprating followed inflation, the Conservative uprating in April 2001would be:

 £5.50 extra (£73 a week) for a single pensioner aged under 75.
 £7 extra (114.90 a week) for a pensioner couple aged under 75.
 £7.50 (£75.25 a week) for a single pensioner aged 75 or over.
 £10 (£118.15 a week) for a pensioner couple aged 75 or over.

We would also adjust tax allowances for older people to compensate pensioners for any extra that they might otherwise pay. And we would adjust means tested benefits to ensure that the poorest pensioners gain at least as much as other pensioners. I heard the Social Security Secretary on the radio this morning claiming that the poorest pensioners would lose out from our proposals. So let me make it absolutely clear that these increases will go to all pensioners, including those on means tested benefits. All pensioners will be entitled to these increases.

These, then, are big increases in the basic state pension.

In the main, we achieve these increases by consolidating all of the gimmicks into something which pensioners would far prefer - reliable increases in their weekly income. In other words, no more gimmicks means more on the basic pension.

But on top of that we are also adding the £40 million bureaucracy bonus, as well as adding money found elsewhere in the social security budget. In total, this amounts to £320 million of new money for pensioners. Our increase in basic state pension will leave all pensioners better off with the Conservatives than under Labour.

And to make sure pensioners can rely on it and that they will know that this is a promise that will be delivered, these increases in the basic state pension would be financed out of National Insurance. It would be a return on all those contributions pensioners have made through their working lives.

This reform means dignity and choice and respect for pensioners. It means a larger state pension as an entitlement rather than making pensioners depend on occasional handouts from Government.

By turning the handouts into entitlements, into a proper return on national insurance contributions, and by adding in the extra savings, all pensioners will be better off with the Conservatives. In other words, Common Sense for Pensioners means we are offering a real improvement in the income of all pensioners.

Unlike the Labour Party, I am not going to make exaggerated promises that unrealistically raise people's expectations only to shatter them later. I know that many pensioners find it difficult to make ends meet. I don't pretend that an extra £10 a week will solve all the problems of pensioners.

Let me tell you what I do promise.

First, Common Sense for Pensioners means dignity and respect for pensioners.

It rightly angers pensioners, who have paid national insurance contributions their entire lives, to have the government announce payments on budget day as if they were the charitable act of a merciful Chancellor. The basic state pension is not charity, it is a return on years of payments. Understanding this and reflecting this in pension policy is a matter of respect for pensioners. My Party is determined to show that respect.

Quite apart from the fact that the Chancellor's measures restrict pensioner choice and personal independence they are also patronising. They assume the Government knows better than pensioners how to budget for periods of greater expense and shouldn't give pensioners money until the Government thinks they should spend it. This patronising attitude, too, shows little respect and is accordingly resented.

Second, our policy simplifies a key part of the benefits system. This is true to another Tory principle that deplores government waste and inefficiency. Gordon Brown has deliberately made both our tax and benefits system more complicated. He prefers to act by stealth. In this way he is undermining confidence in politics and Government. With our reform pensioners will know exactly what they are getting and how much it is worth. That really is common sense.

But let me deal here in advance with some of the slurs and attacks which I expect from our political opponents.

Labour will claim that their policies are targeted on poorer pensioners, whereas we offer across the board increases. That is rubbish. Many of their schemes have been indiscriminate. The winter fuel payment goes to the 220,000 more affluent pensioners in residential accommodation or nursing homes who do not claim Income Support; but the payment is not available for the 280,000 in such accommodation who do claim Income Support. In other words better off pensioners get it and worse off ones don't.

What we are proposing is better targeted than Labour's measures. We guarantee that this increase in the basic pension will reach all pensioners including those on means-tested benefits, so that poorer pensioners getting at least as much from the package as others. Moreover, we know that poorer pensioners tend to be older and we have therefore put extra money particularly towards pensioners aged over 75.

Labour will also try to scare pensioners by claiming that the Tories are simply abolishing the winter fuel payment and the free TV licence.

To save them the effort, let me remind the Millbank spindoctors now of what their own former Minister, Peter Kilfoyle, says: 'pensioners believe that winter fuel payments and concessionary television licences are a diversionary measure  What pensioners want is an increase, week on week, in the basic pension. This is not just a matter of economics: it is a question too of pensioners' dignity' (Hansard, 27th March 2000).

The dignity of pensioners is what our package is all about. The key fact, that no amount of Labour lies can obscure, is that all pensioners, regardless of which gimmicks they currently receive, will be better off.

There will be others who say that our policy is no substitute for far-reaching welfare reform. I completely agree. This is not our last word on pensions policy. It is the beginning of presenting our vision for the future, one in which more and more pensioners enjoy rising living standards as a result of the savings and the funded pensions they have built up during their working lives.

We want to ensure that pensioners participate in the rising living standards of the country as a whole. We will be setting out further proposals to spread funded pensions still more widely to the next generation of pensioners.

But that is a policy for people of working age who have yet to become pensioners. It is too late for current pensioners. Many of the pensioners who are managing on such modest incomes retired without any entitlement to a funded pension. However strongly we push forward better funded pensions for the next generation, we still have a debt to the current generation of pensioners. That is what today's package is all about.

It gives pensioners a real choice, a choice which gets to the heart of the difference between our two parties.

They can choose New Labour's way. The way that treats pensioners as unfortunate misfits in their dreams of Cool Britannia. The way that patronises pensioners with handouts and treats them almost like charity cases.

Or they can vote for a genuine Conservative alternative, from a Party which has been listening - a reliable guaranteed increase in the contributory basic state pension.

It is quite simply a choice between being treated with contempt or being treated with respect.

Today's pensioners have contributed so much to building Britain into the great nation it is today. They have served in our armed forces and fought to keep our nation free; they have worked in our country's businesses and built up its economy; and have they raised our generation and bequeathed us a Britain that begins this new century free and proud and prosperous.

Yet despite all they've done their contribution isn't in the past. They are part of our nation's future too. For they are among our most active citizens. Among the most important contributors to voluntary organisations. Among the most important supports for family life. They support much which this country depends on.

Today's pensioners do not want sops or charity. They want to feel that they are getting benefits to which they have all their lives contributing to. They want the independence and respect that they have every right to deserve.

This year, the Conservative Party has been speaking for the great mainstream majority of the British people on crime, on asylum seekers, on tax and on Europe. That is why we won the local elections so convincingly.

Now we are moving on to new areas - areas which Labour have for too long regarded as their own. Today we are speaking for the great mainstream majority of pensioners who feel betrayed and neglected by this Government; today we offer substantial increases in the basic pension instead of gimmicks; today we offer a bold, common sense policy for pensioners.
fields.bodyText: A few weeks ago the Evening Standard published a story under the headline 'Trendy oldies join Cool Britannia'. It read: 'Ministers want to "rebrand" pensioners with a trendy name that will appeal to younger people. Some of Whitehall's finest minds are working on the problem, while the Government is also seeking outside help to try to come up with the new title Ministers believe words like "pensioners" or "elderly" carry a grey image with deters young people from thinking ahead' (29th March 2000). That story sums up this Government's attitude towards Britain's pensioners. It sums up the attitude of Tony Blair when he talks about Britain becoming a 'young country' and has no time for those forces of conservatism who don't fit in it. It sums up the attitude of Peter Mandelson, the man in charge of Labour's election plans, who says there is 'no mileage' in targeting elderly voters because they are not 'aspirational' (Sunday Times, 16 April 2000). It sums up the attitude of the Chairman of the Labour Parliamentary Party, who recently came out with the breathtaking insult that pensioners are often 'racist'. Of course he also said they were 'predominantly Conservative' (Sunday Times, 16 April 2000) and we intend to prove him right at least about that. It sums up the attitude of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who has patronised older people by trying to buy them off with a series of badly targeted, bureaucratic gimmicks and then was only able to offer them a 75 pence increase in the basic state pension. Britain's eleven million pensioners know that they are the unwanted, unwelcome, uncool guests at New Labour's banquet. And they know that they have paid the price through their pockets. For three years pensioners have been at the sharp end of the Chancellor's policies. At the sharp end of £150 average rises in Council Tax for Band D properties as Labour Councils and a Labour Government worked together to waste their money. The Government talks of a £150 winter fuel payment. Many pensioners have found that by the time they've paid their increased Council Tax the money has all gone. At the sharp end of increases in petrol prices. Pensioners who depend on their cars to preserve their independence have seen prices driven close to the £4 a gallon mark. At the sharp end too, when this Chancellor scrapped dividend tax credits, leaving 300,000 pensioners whose income is below the income tax threshold, having to pay an average of £75 a year more to the exchequer. In the same £5bn a year raid on pension funds, Gordon Brown set a timebomb for future pensioners by forcing working people to put up to £200 a year extra into their pension funds. Last year he abolished the Married Couples Allowance for all future pensioners too. He has also scrapped the Widows Bereavement Allowance without compensating all widowed pensioners properly, scrapped tax relief on medical insurance for the over 65s and abolished retirement relief for older people selling off their small businesses. Pensioners remembered all these blows when they reacted so angrily to the 75p basic rate rise. Gordon Brown hoped no one would notice. He hoped the anger of pensioners wouldn't matter. How wrong he was. As anyone who campaigned in this year's local elections, who knocked on doors and listened to hard pressed pensioners, knows: boy, did they notice, and boy, are they angry. Angry at a Labour Government that promised to be the pensioners' friend and has comprehensively betrayed them. Angry at a Labour Government that used every low-down trick to win pensioners' votes at the general election and then forgot all about them the day after. Angry at a Labour Government that has produced one gimmick after another, but doesn't trust pensioners with a decent weekly income they can spend as they see fit. I have listened to their anger and their feelings of betrayal first-hand in hundreds of meetings around Britain. I listened to the elderly man in Bolton who told me 'Labour's priorities are all wrong - look at Europe, the Dome, these asylum seekers - more should be done on health and for the pensioners'. I listened to the lifelong Labour supporter in Plymouth who summed up what she thought of Tony Blair and his policies: 'He thinks people like me are old has-beens, who aren't important or glamorous, people who they think can simply go to the back of the queue'. I listened to the pensioner in Leeds who could barely contain his anger when he said to me '75p was a joke, an insult  We don't want all these gestures and gimmicks - we just want a decent basic pension'. And I listened also to another pensioner here in London who had a message for Conservatives. 'I voted Labour because they promised so much. I'm terribly disappointed but I wonder if there is any alternative'. We've been busy listening to people while this Government has been busy forgetting them. Now we are offering an alternative. Our Party has listened to all these people, and in all sorts of areas we are now offering an alternative to the failed polices and broken promises of this Government. We offer a law and order policy that will back up the police, punish the criminal, and protect those, such as the elderly, who are particularly vulnerable to crime. We offer a health policy that will build a stronger NHS that puts patients before politicians, and which doesn't treat older people as second class patients. We offer a long term care policy that protects the assets of responsible people who save for their retirement. Today, I want to build on those policies by tackling the central concern of millions of pensioners: the level of their weekly income and the basic state pension. What pensioners say over and over again is that they would rather have a reliable weekly income which is theirs by right to spend as they think best, than a series of handouts and gimmicks. Today we are setting out a carefully costed package based on a Conservative pension uprating in April 2001. It shows what we would do for pensioners in hard figures and in hard cash. We are calling it Common Sense for Pensioners. We would start by putting the money used on the winter fuel payment and the free TV licence into the basic pension instead. This also brings a bureaucracy bonus as we can save £40 million currently being wasted on administering, often very incompetently, these new schemes. Many pensioners received their winter fuel payments as winter drew to a close. We're going to take that £40 million out of the budgets of bureaucrats and put it directly into the pockets of pensioners. We have also identified extra social security savings. We would abolish the New Deal for Lone Parents which is a £90 million a year flop. On the Government's own figures, it is having zero impact on the employment prospects of lone parents. We have already announced separately our far more effective approach to lone parents. We would also recoup some money from the Social Fund, which has recently been increased substantially by the Government. Taken together, these measures yield almost exactly £2 billion. We would then put all this money into helping pensioners in the most straight-forward, honest, and effective way - increases in the basic contributory state pension. We would add it to the expected increase in next year's pension uprating which, if awarded on the basis of current inflation forecasts, would be £2 to a single pensioner and £3 for a married couple. On this basis, if the normal uprating followed inflation, the Conservative uprating in April 2001would be:  £5.50 extra (£73 a week) for a single pensioner aged under 75.  £7 extra (114.90 a week) for a pensioner couple aged under 75.  £7.50 (£75.25 a week) for a single pensioner aged 75 or over.  £10 (£118.15 a week) for a pensioner couple aged 75 or over. We would also adjust tax allowances for older people to compensate pensioners for any extra that they might otherwise pay. And we would adjust means tested benefits to ensure that the poorest pensioners gain at least as much as other pensioners. I heard the Social Security Secretary on the radio this morning claiming that the poorest pensioners would lose out from our proposals. So let me make it absolutely clear that these increases will go to all pensioners, including those on means tested benefits. All pensioners will be entitled to these increases. These, then, are big increases in the basic state pension. In the main, we achieve these increases by consolidating all of the gimmicks into something which pensioners would far prefer - reliable increases in their weekly income. In other words, no more gimmicks means more on the basic pension. But on top of that we are also adding the £40 million bureaucracy bonus, as well as adding money found elsewhere in the social security budget. In total, this amounts to £320 million of new money for pensioners. Our increase in basic state pension will leave all pensioners better off with the Conservatives than under Labour. And to make sure pensioners can rely on it and that they will know that this is a promise that will be delivered, these increases in the basic state pension would be financed out of National Insurance. It would be a return on all those contributions pensioners have made through their working lives. This reform means dignity and choice and respect for pensioners. It means a larger state pension as an entitlement rather than making pensioners depend on occasional handouts from Government. By turning the handouts into entitlements, into a proper return on national insurance contributions, and by adding in the extra savings, all pensioners will be better off with the Conservatives. In other words, Common Sense for Pensioners means we are offering a real improvement in the income of all pensioners. Unlike the Labour Party, I am not going to make exaggerated promises that unrealistically raise people's expectations only to shatter them later. I know that many pensioners find it difficult to make ends meet. I don't pretend that an extra £10 a week will solve all the problems of pensioners. Let me tell you what I do promise. First, Common Sense for Pensioners means dignity and respect for pensioners. It rightly angers pensioners, who have paid national insurance contributions their entire lives, to have the government announce payments on budget day as if they were the charitable act of a merciful Chancellor. The basic state pension is not charity, it is a return on years of payments. Understanding this and reflecting this in pension policy is a matter of respect for pensioners. My Party is determined to show that respect. Quite apart from the fact that the Chancellor's measures restrict pensioner choice and personal independence they are also patronising. They assume the Government knows better than pensioners how to budget for periods of greater expense and shouldn't give pensioners money until the Government thinks they should spend it. This patronising attitude, too, shows little respect and is accordingly resented. Second, our policy simplifies a key part of the benefits system. This is true to another Tory principle that deplores government waste and inefficiency. Gordon Brown has deliberately made both our tax and benefits system more complicated. He prefers to act by stealth. In this way he is undermining confidence in politics and Government. With our reform pensioners will know exactly what they are getting and how much it is worth. That really is common sense. But let me deal here in advance with some of the slurs and attacks which I expect from our political opponents. Labour will claim that their policies are targeted on poorer pensioners, whereas we offer across the board increases. That is rubbish. Many of their schemes have been indiscriminate. The winter fuel payment goes to the 220,000 more affluent pensioners in residential accommodation or nursing homes who do not claim Income Support; but the payment is not available for the 280,000 in such accommodation who do claim Income Support. In other words better off pensioners get it and worse off ones don't. What we are proposing is better targeted than Labour's measures. We guarantee that this increase in the basic pension will reach all pensioners including those on means-tested benefits, so that poorer pensioners getting at least as much from the package as others. Moreover, we know that poorer pensioners tend to be older and we have therefore put extra money particularly towards pensioners aged over 75. Labour will also try to scare pensioners by claiming that the Tories are simply abolishing the winter fuel payment and the free TV licence. To save them the effort, let me remind the Millbank spindoctors now of what their own former Minister, Peter Kilfoyle, says: 'pensioners believe that winter fuel payments and concessionary television licences are a diversionary measure  What pensioners want is an increase, week on week, in the basic pension. This is not just a matter of economics: it is a question too of pensioners' dignity' (Hansard, 27th March 2000). The dignity of pensioners is what our package is all about. The key fact, that no amount of Labour lies can obscure, is that all pensioners, regardless of which gimmicks they currently receive, will be better off. There will be others who say that our policy is no substitute for far-reaching welfare reform. I completely agree. This is not our last word on pensions policy. It is the beginning of presenting our vision for the future, one in which more and more pensioners enjoy rising living standards as a result of the savings and the funded pensions they have built up during their working lives. We want to ensure that pensioners participate in the rising living standards of the country as a whole. We will be setting out further proposals to spread funded pensions still more widely to the next generation of pensioners. But that is a policy for people of working age who have yet to become pensioners. It is too late for current pensioners. Many of the pensioners who are managing on such modest incomes retired without any entitlement to a funded pension. However strongly we push forward better funded pensions for the next generation, we still have a debt to the current generation of pensioners. That is what today's package is all about. It gives pensioners a real choice, a choice which gets to the heart of the difference between our two parties. They can choose New Labour's way. The way that treats pensioners as unfortunate misfits in their dreams of Cool Britannia. The way that patronises pensioners with handouts and treats them almost like charity cases. Or they can vote for a genuine Conservative alternative, from a Party which has been listening - a reliable guaranteed increase in the contributory basic state pension. It is quite simply a choice between being treated with contempt or being treated with respect. Today's pensioners have contributed so much to building Britain into the great nation it is today. They have served in our armed forces and fought to keep our nation free; they have worked in our country's businesses and built up its economy; and have they raised our generation and bequeathed us a Britain that begins this new century free and proud and prosperous. Yet despite all they've done their contribution isn't in the past. They are part of our nation's future too. For they are among our most active citizens. Among the most important contributors to voluntary organisations. Among the most important supports for family life. They support much which this country depends on. Today's pensioners do not want sops or charity. They want to feel that they are getting benefits to which they have all their lives contributing to. They want the independence and respect that they have every right to deserve. This year, the Conservative Party has been speaking for the great mainstream majority of the British people on crime, on asylum seekers, on tax and on Europe. That is why we won the local elections so convincingly. Now we are moving on to new areas - areas which Labour have for too long regarded as their own. Today we are speaking for the great mainstream majority of pensioners who feel betrayed and neglected by this Government; today we offer substantial increases in the basic pension instead of gimmicks; today we offer a bold, common sense policy for pensioners.

fields.headline: Hurley and Grant end relationship
fields.trailText: The Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant roadshow, at one time the toast of the movie premiere paparazzi, is "temporarily" at an end, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The Elizabeth Hurley and Hugh Grant roadshow, at one time the toast of the movie premiere paparazzi, is "temporarily" at an end, it emerged last night.

Putting their relationship on ice, the couple declared through a spokeswoman that their split was "a temporary thing, a mutual and amicable decision".

They denied that there was any third party involved but the news will fuel tabloid speculation about the pair, who have been an item for 13 years but have reportedly not been seen together in the last four months.

They have blamed work commitments for the long absence.

Rumours of a split gained currency when Hurley went to the Cannes Film Festival alone, for the first time in six years.

Hurley, 34, who models for Estee Lauder, has been linked to New York billionaire Ted Forstmann, while Grant, 39, was reportedly seen dining with a mystery woman at a London hotel in March.

The couple said yesterday that they would continue to run Simian Films, the production company they formed five years ago to capitalise on Grant's celebrity.

Their relationship last reached a public crisis point in June 1995, when Grant was fined the equivalent of £75 after admitting engaging in a sex act with the Los Angeles prostitute Divine Brown after picking her up on Sunset Boulevard.

The world watched as the humiliated couple retreated to their country home to discuss the delicate situation.

They stayed together, but Hurley revealed that she "felt like she'd been shot" when she learned that her boyfriend had been arrested. The affair is said to have changed the dynamic of their relationship.

Since then Hurley has warmed to her new role as a movie producer, impressing director Michael Apted, with whom she worked on the 1996 film Extreme Measures which starred Grant and Gene Hackman.

Apted described her as "a hands-on producer at all times. She was the one who had the passion for this project. She was determined to get it made."

By contrast, despite the commercial success of Notting Hill, critics say Grant has been typecast as an upper class English twit.

Hurley's next acting role will be playing the devil in the Twentieth Century Fox movie Bedazzled, while Grant has a role in the Woody Allen comedy Small Time Crooks.

In a magazine interview last autumn, Hurley gave a cool appraisal of their relationship. She said: "We're not like some fabulously happy Adam and Eve all the time. We bicker like mad, but it's like arguing with my sister."

She added: "We talk for hours. We laugh a lot and like every embarrassing couple we have silly acts and characters and nicknames that we repeat incessantly."

She said then: "Even if for some bizarre reason, one of us fell in love with someone else. I couldn't cope with not speaking to him every day. I just couldn't. I couldn't bear to lose Hugh as a friend."

Hurley and Grant were catapulted into the limelight in July 1994, when she arrived at the London premiere of Four Weddings And A Funeral in the Versace dress that launched a thousand flashbulbs.

fields.headline: Joking apart
fields.standfirst: 'It's the actor's joke - Peter Brook phoned and asked me to play Hamlet. But it happened to me' Adrian Lester tells  Claire Armitstead about his escape from Hollywood
fields.trailText: 'It's the actor's joke - Peter Brook phoned and asked me to play Hamlet. But it happened to me' Adrian Lester tells Claire Armitstead about his escape from Hollywood
fields.body:
Adrian Lester's arrival is almost presidential: he bounds out of a courtesy car with his publicist in tow. He has spent the morning rehearsing for Channel 4's Richard Blackwood show and has dashed off to be interviewed before the live recording in the afternoon. He is neat, fit and topped off with an immaculate head of dreadlocks. Of course, he says, they wanted him to show off his break dancing in the studio, but he is in the middle of filming, and body-popping is not the kind of publicity stunt that makes a movie insurer's day.

For years now, Lester has been teetering on the brink of stardom. First there was Rosalind, in a celebrated all-male production of As You Like It, then - after a series of increasingly high-profile theatre roles - he was whisked off to Hollywood to play the earnest campaign manager in Mike Nichols's film of Primary Colors. The 11th-hour summons from Nichols meant he had to renege on an earlier commitment to play Othello for Sam Mendes at the National Theatre; the buzz was that the theatre had lost this most talented of actors.

But here he is, two years later, at the age of 32, whiling away his time on a shoal of movies while preparing for the big one: he has been cast by Peter Brook as Hamlet, in an international production that will start life at the Bouffe de Nord in Paris and then tour the great theatres of Europe. This, he says, is the actor's dream - "In fact, it's the actor's joke: 'Brook phoned last night and asked if I'd play Hamlet.' Ho ho."

But stardom hasn't always played a straight game with Lester. It is one thing to be in demand, quite another to be offered the right work. After making Primary Colors, he returned home to England and waited for the phone to ring. For a year. He could have allowed himself to be swallowed up by Hollywood, but he didn't want that. "A lot of talent is nurtured here and at the first taste of success, it gets up and goes." The problem, he has since discovered, was that everyone assumed he had done the same.

Look at Lester's career and you see a fascinating reflection of the times. He was born and brought up in Birmingham, one of three children to Jamaican immigrant parents. His father owned a cleaning company. The young Adrian sang in the cathedral choir and became obsessed, in his teens, with the local youth theatre. By the time he was 16, he had given up on school but was writing, directing, starring in and touring his own play. Like other black actors of his age, he had no role models then. "I never grew up thinking 'I want to be like him', because there was no him to want to be when I was 13 or 14. The only models were Americans and they weren't for me." Unusually, he says he was unaware of any barriers. "My parents said, 'OK, you want to do this. Then do it. It'll be hard.' And I said, 'How hard?' I wasn't very good at school and never did my homework, but I was up till four in the morning typing plays. I was very driven, and it came from people saying, 'You can do it.' "

He left Birmingham for Rada and and emerged from drama school just as colour-blind casting was catching hold in the theatre. His big break was being cast by Declan Donnellan as Rosalind in As You Like It in 1991; the part of the smooth confidence trickster in John Guare's Olivier award-winning Six Degrees of Separation followed; then Sam Mendes picked him up to play the lonely Bobby in the Sondheim musical Company.

As a teenager, he had played bell-boys and car thieves in Crossroads; he soon learned to turn down lucrative work in TV series such as The Bill because they always wanted him to play the mugger. So determined was he to avoid being typecast as the black thug that for a while he was in danger of creating another stereotype for himself - the boy next door, soft, gentle, so generous with his feminine side that a lot of people assumed he was gay. In fact, he is married to an actress, Lolita Chakrabarti, a fellow Brummie he met at drama school.

It was his Lolita who, inadvertently, was the model for Rosalind. "A couple of friends who knew my wife very well came to see it and said I had put Lolita on the stage." With a magpie instinct, he had hoarded his wife's mannerisms - "her wit, her speed, her agility" - and moulded these unconsidered trifles into a new character. "It was strange for her, because, once it had been pointed out, she began to see little bits of Rosalind that were definitely her."

One of the qualities that marks out Lester's work is his ability to resist cliche. He brought a clear note of desolation in Company to Bobby - everyone's friend and nobody's lover - and reached a new peak in Primary Colors, in which his character, Henry Burton, had to carry the possibility of integrity in a corrupt world. In an extraordinary final confrontation between him and John Travolta, Travolta wheedles and bullies him to say he's still behind the presidential campaign. As the film dawdles into real time, Lester's face is not so much impassive as impassable, allowing every possibility to play across it and none to take possession. It is a scene so finely judged that it comes as a shock, at the end, to see him lined up and smiling behind the new president.

Primary Colors taught him about the public side of acting. Suddenly he found himself on prime-time TV being quizzed about everything from Clinton's morals to the plausibility of a black campaign manager. One story that did the rounds was that a kissing scene between him and Emma Thompson was cut because the preview audiences didn't like the display of interracial lust. The truth, he says, was much more banal. "That scene killed the film, because once people knew that Henry was corrupt, they didn't care any more." It was only at that stage that it became clear to what extent this young, unknown British actor was carrying the film.

After he finished Primary Colors, he was pigeonholed as an upper-class New Yorker. His next role, though, was very different: a troubled man working with disturbed children in an orphanage, in a 90-minute TV film Storm Damage. It was a long-standing project of his friend Lennie James, which only finally made it into production once it had the cachet of Lester's Primary Colors appearance behind it. Lester is too shrewd to underestimate the power that comes with success - "It means I'm getting the chance to do things I wouldn't have done before"- but doesn't bang political gongs, and he is almost perversely determined not to become "a star" in the old sense of the word.

"If you're a star you are becoming something over and above the job, and that's not something I want to do. To play someone who is just a version of yourself over and over again is boring." This might seem a truism, but it takes some will power. He would not, for instance, consider taking a big part in a soap. "Small parts are all very well, but I wouldn't be interested in doing a long-running character because you're not given a chance to step out. It means destroying one of your main talents as an actor, which is to become someone else."

This strategy has its risks. He has just come and gone as a break-dancing courtier in Kenneth Branagh's musical verson of Love's Labours Lost, and a barman in a best-forgotten biopic of George Best. Next month he is back in Maybe Baby, Ben Elton's directorial debut, about a couple's problem conceiving. None is either a conspicuously great part or a great film - bringing to mind the wise wise words of another performer who straddles both theatre and film, Kathleen Turner. "As an actor," she said, "you're as known for what you do not do as what you do do."

But then there is the film he and Lolita are writing together, and there is Hamlet. The long gestation that is customary with Peter Brook is already under way: there have been workshops and "terrifyingly intelligent" discussions. Is he daunted? "Yes." Does he have any ideas about how he is going to play it? "There are always all these questions: is he mad or not? Does he love his mother or not? The answer is yes to all of these things." He is relaxed and driven, self-doubting and confident - and open to all the possibilities these qualities create. A Hamlet for the 21st century.

Maybe Baby is released on June 2.

In fact, he is married to an actress, Lolita Chakrabarti, a fellow Brummie he met at drama school. It was his Lolita who, inadvertently, was the model for Rosalind. "A couple of friends who knew my wife very well came to see it and said I had put Lolita on the stage." With a magpie instinct, he had hoarded his wife's mannerisms - "her wit, her speed, her agility" - and moulded these unconsidered trifles into a new character. "It was strange for her, because, once it had been pointed out, she began to see little bits of Rosalind that were definitely her." One of the qualities that marks out Lester's work is his ability to resist cliche. He brought a clear note of desolation in Company to Bobby - everyone's friend and nobody's lover - and reached a new peak in Primary Colors, in which his character, Henry Burton, had to carry the possibility of integrity in a corrupt world. In an extraordinary final confrontation between him and John Travolta, Travolta wheedles and bullies him to say he's still behind the presidential campaign. As the film dawdles into real time, Lester's face is not so much impassive as impassable, allowing every possibility to play across it and none to take possession. It is a scene so finely judged that it comes as a shock, at the end, to see him lined up and smiling behind the new president. Primary Colors taught him about the public side of acting. Suddenly he found himself on prime-time TV being quizzed about everything from Clinton's morals to the plausibility of a black campaign manager. One story that did the rounds was that a kissing scene between him and Emma Thompson was cut because the preview audiences didn't like the display of interracial lust. The truth, he says, was much more banal. "That scene killed the film, because once people knew that Henry was corrupt, they didn't care any more." It was only at that stage that it became clear to what extent this young, unknown British actor was carrying the film. After he finished Primary Colors, he was pigeonholed as an upper-class New Yorker. His next role, though, was very different: a troubled man working with disturbed children in an orphanage, in a 90-minute TV film Storm Damage. It was a long-standing project of his friend Lennie James, which only finally made it into production once it had the cachet of Lester's Primary Colors appearance behind it. Lester is too shrewd to underestimate the power that comes with success - "It means I'm getting the chance to do things I wouldn't have done before"- but doesn't bang political gongs, and he is almost perversely determined not to become "a star" in the old sense of the word. "If you're a star you are becoming something over and above the job, and that's not something I want to do. To play someone who is just a version of yourself over and over again is boring." This might seem a truism, but it takes some will power. He would not, for instance, consider taking a big part in a soap. "Small parts are all very well, but I wouldn't be interested in doing a long-running character because you're not given a chance to step out. It means destroying one of your main talents as an actor, which is to become someone else." This strategy has its risks. He has just come and gone as a break-dancing courtier in Kenneth Branagh's musical verson of Love's Labours Lost, and a barman in a best-forgotten biopic of George Best. Next month he is back in Maybe Baby, Ben Elton's directorial debut, about a couple's problem conceiving. None is either a conspicuously great part or a great film - bringing to mind the wise wise words of another performer who straddles both theatre and film, Kathleen Turner. "As an actor," she said, "you're as known for what you do not do as what you do do." But then there is the film he and Lolita are writing together, and there is Hamlet. The long gestation that is customary with Peter Brook is already under way: there have been workshops and "terrifyingly intelligent" discussions. Is he daunted? "Yes." Does he have any ideas about how he is going to play it? "There are always all these questions: is he mad or not? Does he love his mother or not? The answer is yes to all of these things." He is relaxed and driven, self-doubting and confident - and open to all the possibilities these qualities create. A Hamlet for the 21st century. Maybe Baby is released on June 2.

webTitle: Nuclear fuel plant closures mark end of era

fields.headline: Nuclear fuel plant closures mark end of era
fields.standfirst: As the pioneering stations which generated the world's first nuclear electricity are wound down, Guardian environment correspondent Paul Brown asks what the future holds for BNFL
fields.trailText: As the pioneering stations which generated the world's first nuclear electricity are wound down, Guardian environment correspondent Paul Brown asks what the future holds for BNFL
fields.body:
The closure programme for eight of Britain's oldest nuclear stations and the companion reprocessing works at Sellafield in Cumbria, which deals with their spent fuel, heralds the end of an era for the industry.

Those earmarked for shutdown were the pioneering stations which made the plutonium for Britain's nuclear bomb and generated the first nuclear electricity in the world. The first closed yesterday and the last will cease in 15 years.

This effectively converts British Nuclear Fuels from an electricity producer to a clean-up company. Any new fuel produced by BNFL will mainly be for the newer British and overseas nuclear stations, which are owned by other companies.

These companies currently send their spent fuel back for reprocessing in the modern THORP reprocessing works at Sellafield. But now THORP is also under threat.

Under new management after scathing safety reports and scandals over falsified fuel quality documents, the state-owned BNFL is desperately trying to regain lost business and restore public confidence.

The Japanese have refused to sign new contracts and want to send fuel with falsified documents back. The Germans and Swiss have suspended shipments of fuel for THORP. There is a growing international demand for all reprocessing of spent fuel to be shut down and there is a massive surplus of its products, plutonium and uranium.

The closure timetable for the older works is a bid to deflect attempts by Ireland and Denmark to stop all reprocessing, at an international meeting in June. The OSPAR Convention which controls pollution in the Irish and North Seas has the power to shut all the reprocessing works at Sellafield.

The UK has promised to put an end to radioactive discharges into the Irish Sea by 2020 but Ireland and Denmark have submitted resolutions to OSPAR demanding an immediate end to reprocessing which causes most of the radioactive pollution on their shores.

However, the new management's greatest threat is home grown. British Energy, the privatised nuclear company which runs the newer nuclear stations, is itself in deep financial trouble. One of its greatest expenses is reprocessing, and it is demanding that its fuel should be in less expensive dry storage, thus threatening the future of THORP.

The £2.3 billion THORP plant was opened just six years ago. Green groups claimed at the time it was a white elephant which would never make a profit. It looks as if their predictions could be proved right.

webTitle: Study reveals violence in kids' movies

fields.headline: Study reveals violence in kids' movies
fields.trailText: A recent US study of 74 animated films, from Snow White (made in 1937) to last year's The King and I, has revealed that the violence in children's films is on the increase. The average amount of time depicting acts of violence has risen from six minutes in 1940 to 9.5 minutes in 1999.
fields.body:
A recent US study of 74 animated films, from Snow White (made in 1937) to last year's The King and I, has revealed that the violence in children's films is on the increase. The average amount of time depicting acts of violence has risen from six minutes in 1940 to 9.5 minutes in 1999.

The Harvard University researchers who released the report said that parents should be aware that a G (UK equivalent U) rating does not necessarily mean that children will be spared violent scenes.

"The Motion Picture Association of America should consider changing the current age-based rating system to one based on content, which is what an overwhelming number of parents prefer,'' they said.

For the purpose of the study, violence was listed as light or funny (eg Dumbo shooting peanuts at the ringmaster), neutral, or dark and sinister (eg a hunter killing Bambi's mother).

Films that contain an above-average amount of violence include Warner Bros' Quest for Camelot (28%), The Sword in The Stone (21.4%) and A Bug's Life (19.3%).

Animated movies with below-average "violence time" included A Goofy Movie (2.7%) and Dumbo (2%). The Disney classic, Cinderella, has 273 seconds of violence (5.9% of the film) while Bambi clocked up 6.1%.

The authors said they found 125 injuries in the films, 62 of which resulted in death; but bad characters were 23 times more likely to die from an injury than good ones. In addition, violent acts by good characters were most often portrayed as light or funny, while violent acts by bad ones were most often dark or sinister.

"Our content analysis reveals a striking behavioural message implied by many of the G-rated animated films that the good guys triumph over the bad through the use of physical force,'' the authors said.

webTitle: Gladiator wrestles rival pics off top spot

fields.headline: Gladiator wrestles rival pics off top spot
fields.trailText: Despite being knocked off the top of the US box office by Disney's Dinosaurs, Gladiator looks to be one of this year's biggest international hits.
fields.body:
Despite being knocked off the top of the US box office by Disney's Dinosaurs, Gladiator looks to be one of this year's biggest international hits.

Ridley Scott's epic movie went straight to the top box-office slot in each of the 18 countries where it opened; it is enjoying its second week at number one in the UK, and has so far raked in $41.7m overseas, and counting.

Meanwhile, American Beauty passed the double century mark overseas, hitting $200.1m, $33.6m of which came from UK audiences.

And while critics might have panned it, Fox's The Beach has just passed $100m overseas, with top markets including the UK, Japan and France.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.trailText: I'm told that back from the days when Manchester United were mortal, they had a game abandoned when winning 5-0 (all scored by Denis Law), but lost the replay. Truth or fiction? asks Ian Richardson
fields.body:
I'm told that back from the days when Manchester United were mortal, they had a game abandoned when winning 5-0 (all scored by Denis Law), but lost the replay. Truth or fiction? asks Ian Richardson

That didn't happen, but Law did experience an FA Cup nightmare which was probably worse. In a fourth round FA Cup tie against Luton in 1961, Law scored all six goals for Manchester City as they stormed into a 6-2 lead. Sadly, storm became the operative word as the match was abandoned and Law's goals were struck from the record books.

He did manage a goal in the replayed match, but to no avail: City lost 3-1 and were out of the Cup. But if it makes City fans feel any better, Sheffield Wednesday knocked their arch-rivals out of that year's competition by whipping them 7-2.

I recently had an argument with a hairdresser, as to the origins of David Beckham. We both agreed on his upbringing in London, but disagreed on which club he began his training with. I was sure that someone told me it was Tottenham, while he insisted that it was Arsenal. A free haircut is riding on this, so if you could enlighten me on the correct answer I would be very much obliged says Tom H

You're both wrong. Beckham was indeed brought up in Leytonstone, a stone's throw away from Upton Park, but even as a kid he supported Manchester United. He first visited Old Trafford as an 11-year-old when he won the TSB Bobby Charlton Soccer Skills Champion for his age group and was also the club's mascot at West Ham when he was 12. So even though Arsenal and Spurs were both interested in signing him as a trainee, Beckham's heart was always on United and he signed apprentice forms on the 8th July 1991.

Only one team have scored and conceded 100 goals or more in the same season. Who were they? asks Terry

In the 1957-8 First Division, Manchester City scored 104 goals but conceded 100, a unique achievement. They finished a respectable fifth in the league, having scored one more goal than champions Wolves (but letting in an extra 53).

Why do the English press keep referring to Jerrel Hasselbaink as "Jimmy Floyd" Hasselbaink? In Holland Jerrel is his given name. I spoke to a Dutch Guy recently about this and he couldn't understand where "Jimmy Floyd" came from. Any ideas? asked John Askew last week

"It is true that 'Jimmy Floyd' is not his real name," claims Claire Skaife. "However, neither is 'Jerrel'. In fact, as any Leeds fan knows, the 'J' stands for 'Judas' - in a similar way that the 'J' in Jorge Graham does. Hope that's cleared it up." Wellmaybe not. Any one else got an idea?

What is the highest number of different countries represented by the starting 22 players in a Premiership match? asked Phil Brown

The highest total we managed last week was 14. But, as Tim Burgis points out, when Newcastle played Chelsea on March 4 this year, there were an amazing 16 different nationalities on display.

1. De Goey (Netherlands), 2. Petrescu (Romania), 3. Leboeuf (France), 4. Babayaro (Nigeria), 5. Morris (England), 6. Poyet (Uraguay), 7. Ferrer (Spain), 8. Zola (Italy), 9. Thome (Brazil), 10. Flo (Norway), 11. Given (Ireland), 12. Dabizas (Greece), 13. Solano (Peru), 14. Ketsbaia (Georgia), 15. Speed (Wales), 16. Ferguson (Scotland). Can anyone beat that?

Why was the May 1968 FA Cup Final televised in colour, but not the European Cup Final a few days later, although both were at Wembley? There must be someone in the world who knows the answer! reckoned Alan Sheridan

And there is. Step forward David Perth who says the 1968 European Cup Final was shown in black and white because the colour cameras in those days would not work under lights. He says he remembers MoTD showing games that started off in full glowing colour then the second half went all black and white as the natural light faded and the floodies kicked in.

Last week we highlighted the four English teams that have had three managers who won European Cup medals as players: Blackburn, Manchester City, Newcastle and Preston.

But there's also a fifth side: Rotherham - who've had Emlyn Hughes, John McGovern and Archie Gemmill managing them. Cheers to Alan Fisher for the spot.

We also mentioned that eight cities that have had two different teams in the European Cup semi-finals (Milan, Glasgow, Dundee, Moscow, Madrid, Belgrade, Bucharest and Vienna). But Prague also sneaks in as Dukla were defeated by eventual winners Celtic in the 1967 semi-finals and Sparta reached the semi-final group stage (not the quarter-finals as we said) in 1992.

Can you help?

What became of Idwal Robling, the winner of the BBC's "Find a Commentator" competition before the 1970 World Cup? enquires Simon Kaplan.

Which footballer has won 14 league titles, the European Cup, Uefa Cup,League Cup, FA Cup, European player of the year and once scored 40 goals in a season? asks Rob Jordan. We think the question is fake - do you know different?

Since the advent of the squad numbering system, when was the last time a Premiership side started a match with a team numbered 1 to 11? asks Patrick O'Brien

webTitle: Yorkshire charges come up smelling of roses

fields.headline: Yorkshire charges come up smelling of roses
fields.trailText: They used to say that when Yorkshire were doing well, so were England. Two things changed what was a pretty tenuous theory anyway. England were knocked off their pedestal at the end of the 1950s, first by Australia, then West Indies. And a few years later the other counties started star-gazing overseas, leaving Yorkshire, who refused to recruit from any further south than Sheffield, in their wake. The England slide has lasted until today - well, until last Sunday actually, when they turned back the clock and administered to Zimbabwe the sort of beating they used to hand out to up-and-coming nations in the '50s.
fields.body:
They used to say that when Yorkshire were doing well, so were England. Two things changed what was a pretty tenuous theory anyway. England were knocked off their pedestal at the end of the 1950s, first by Australia, then West Indies. And a few years later the other counties started star-gazing overseas, leaving Yorkshire, who refused to recruit from any further south than Sheffield, in their wake. The England slide has lasted until today - well, until last Sunday actually, when they turned back the clock and administered to Zimbabwe the sort of beating they used to hand out to up-and-coming nations in the '50s.

So guess who's top of Division 1 of the County Championship? Yup, it's Yorkshire: two innings victories and a rain-ruined draw in their first three games mean they've been more white rose of old than white flag of recent decades. And while rumours of their - and England's - renaissance may be exaggerated (after all, the Tykes have been waiting for the second coming of the title since 1968) this is one that might not wither on the vine.

Captain David Byas usually begins the summer with a hymn of praise to his party of young seamers ("I wouldn't swap them for McGrath, Donald and Ambrose" - that sort of thing). This season though, he opened with a Fred Truemanesque swipe at the ever-increasing comfort zone of some of his younger team-mates, And, so far at least, it seems to have worked.

Now Yorkshire just have to keep their foot down: last season they got off to a flyer before spluttering horribly and crashing empty-handed into the pits. But with a seam attack of Darren Gough (when available), Chris Silverwood, Craig White (when not injured or 12th man for England), Gavin Hamilton, Paul Hutchison, Ryan Sidebottom and Matthew Hoggard to choose from, it will have to be a lemming-like plummet if they don't finish in the top three.

The critics argue that Headingley transforms military tedium, er, medium into world-beating swing and seam. And it's true that their two thumping wins in 2000 have come in Leeds. The figures, though, are far from damning. Last season at Headingley, Yorkshire's seamers claimed 85 Championship wickets at 23.01. At all other grounds the figures were 148 at 24.64. Either their bowlers are flattered everywhere, or they're just pretty good. Then there's the fact that in their two innings wins this summer, Yorkshire have run up scores of 508 for 5 (v Derbyshire) and 399 (v Hampshire). If there's been something in the wickets, the opposition certainly haven't found it.

Yorkshire success doesn't automatically mean England success. But a Yorkshire team that reacquaints itself with the winning feeling - and manages to keep it all summer - will toughen up the County Championship. Now that really would be good news for England.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. You can now read his County View every Wednesday throughout the summer. To see last week's column, click here.

But a Yorkshire team that reacquaints itself with the winning feeling - and manages to keep it all summer - will toughen up the County Championship. Now that really would be good news for England.
