fields.headline: Lara: Blessing or burden?
fields.trailText: It was good to see Brian Lara mingling with the other West Indies players in the dressing room on the final day of the drawn Test against Pakistan in Barbados. For once he was blending in rather than trying to be the headline act. The drama surrounding his apparent retirement and comeback had been Lara at his distracting worst.
fields.body:
It was good to see Brian Lara mingling with the other West Indies players in the dressing room on the final day of the drawn Test against Pakistan in Barbados. For once he was blending in rather than trying to be the headline act. The drama surrounding his apparent retirement and comeback had been Lara at his distracting worst.

Lara has lifted the spirits of cricket lovers everywhere with some amazing batting during his career. On an impressive shortlist is his 277 against Australia, his first Test hundred, when it seemed like nothing in the world could get him out save Ian Healy's gamesmanship; that record-breaking 375; and, my favourite, the amazing 153 not out against Australia in Barbados last year, which he crafted out of extreme personal and cricketing pressure. I was choked by the sheer emotion of it all and if, as commentators often say of his scorching cover drives, "not a man moved", it certainly was the case in my office with everyone standing glued to the television for the mesmeric final hour. Deadlines were completely forgotten. That's what makes Lara the most compelling figure in the game. Unfortunately, the uncertainty over his availability has come to define the man almost as much.

His mother's illness is a very strong reason for him to be uncertain about touring - we wish Pearl Lara a speedy recovery and good health. Reports from Trinidad suggest that she is more ill than many people first realised. Brian's concern was understandable. But his handling of the question of whether he'd tour or not (or whether he said he'd be retiring, something Lara himself has never denied) was a public relations disaster.

It shows his other great talent - disruption - and reinforces the notion that Brian is 31 going on 22. He walked out of the West Indies' tour of England in 1995 after disputes with the captain, Richie Richardson, and manager, Wes Hall. The president of the West Indian board at the time, Peter Short, bent over backwards to placate the great man. Lara then pulled out of the tour of Australia later that year. Throw in the well-documented incidents at Warwickshire, and it all adds up to five years of grief.

It's not been his fault all the time. He was sacked as captain before the infamous Heathrow stand-off, where he staked out a position on behalf of the West Indies players to win improved pay and conditions of travel. In person Lara can be polite and solicitous, and he has always struck me as thoughtful and articulate. Jimmy Adams's appointment as captain has been vindicated by the West Indies' steady improvement under him, but Lara's attributes make him many people's dream team-leader. Instead he's continuing to lead everyone in the number of off-field column inches generated.

I put his apparent change of mind down to pressure from the West Indian board, who realise their team is much better with him in it, however heartening the emergence of Wavell Hinds, Ramnaresh Sarwan and Chris Gayle. Competitive at home and terrible on tour is how the Windies have performed recently, and the risk of a thrashing by England is reduced with the Trinidadian in the team. Also there must have been pressure from the English Cricket Board, who realised that Lara could get bodies through turnstiles like few players are able to. England will probably turn over Zimbabwe - they do not need a severely weakened West Indies to complete their summer.

So what does the future hold for Brian Charles? The time is coming when the West Indian board will have to conclude that he's just not worth the headache, and accept short-term failure by leaving him out so that the team can keep its collective sanity. But I believe that we're not yet close to that time: he should be picked if fit and available, and he should play against England. It is West Indies' most important series in years: defeat by the old colonial master would be shattering. The Windies have to field their best side and that includes the temperamental one. I just wish he'd realise that episodes like those of a few days ago are destabilising for a team that is trying to rebuild.

Orin Gordon works for the BBC World Service. Anglo-Caribbean View appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every other Wednesday. Next week, Kamran Abbasi's Anglo-Asian View returns.

webTitle: Fiji chiefs sympathise with rebel cause

fields.headline: Fiji chiefs sympathise with rebel cause
fields.standfirst: Fiji government
fields.trailText: Fiji's 40 tribal chiefs yesterday condemned the armed men who are holding the prime minister and other officials hostage in the parliament, but sympathised with the rebel cause - the rights of indigenous Fijians over those of descendants of Indian migrants.
fields.body:
Fiji's 40 tribal chiefs yesterday condemned the armed men who are holding the prime minister and other officials hostage in the parliament, but sympathised with the rebel cause - the rights of indigenous Fijians over those of descendants of Indian migrants.

After a full-day meeting, the country's Great Council of Chiefs, which holds moral authority over Fiji's indigenous population, fully endorsed the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. He has condemned the coup attempt, declared a state of emergency and demanded that the hostages be freed.

The rebels, who invaded the parliament last Friday, are holding the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and at least 20 members of his cabinet and governing coalition.

But the chiefs said they sympathised with the cause of the rebel leader, George Speight, and would meet today to decide whether to support the constitutional changes he seeks. Mr Speight wants the posts of president and prime minister reserved for indigenous Fijians.

The council's president, Sitiveni Rabuka, said: "The chiefs do not approve of what Speight has done, although there is a lot of sympathy for the views expressed by his followers."

webTitle: German government faces split over reform of armed forces

fields.headline: German government faces split over reform of armed forces
fields.trailText: Gerhard Schröder, Germany's chancellor, last night faced a split within his "red-green" coalition over the emotionally charged issue of what to do about the country's outdated and inefficient armed forces.
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder, Germany's chancellor, last night faced a split within his "red-green" coalition over the emotionally charged issue of what to do about the country's outdated and inefficient armed forces.

The former president, Richard von Weizsäcker, who chaired a high-level commission of inquiry on reform of the Bundeswehr, yesterday delivered a report arguing that the number of men and women under arms should be cut by almost a third - from 340,000 to 240,000. Almost the whole of the cut would come from among the 130,000 conscripts, whose numbers would fall to 30,000.

The aim would be to adapt the armed forces to the post-cold war era, creating a more professional service, better suited to peacekeeping operations and rapid deployment.

The report also recommends that the number of civilians working for the armed forces be cut to "around 80,000", from 140,000.

But conscious of the political sensitivities the issue arouses among Social Democrats, their defence minister, Rudolf Scharping, announced that he would recommend to the cabinet an overall reduction of only 100,000. He did not indicate how the job losses would be divided between civilians and service personnel - an omission which leaves open the door for a sizeable conscript element.

The Greens, the Social Democrats' coalition partners, who are opposed to conscription, attacked the government's response. The Greens' chairwoman, Antje Radcke, said: "The Social Democrats' conception is at odds with that of a large part of society which has long believed that compulsory military service is nonsensical."

The Social Democrats have traditionally defended conscription on the grounds that it sustains a "citizens' army" and provides an insurance against any return to militarism. Their parliamentary party leader, Peter Struck, yesterday suggested that the commission's proposals might even be unconstitutional.

He said compulsory military service was "the only way to guarantee that the armed forces mirror the wide-ranging discussion in society."

webTitle: Spielberg dispenses wisdom in net masterclass

fields.headline: Spielberg dispenses wisdom in net masterclass
fields.trailText: Hollywood supremo Steven Spielberg is today to present a virtual masterclass for British media students in a live link-up via the internet.
fields.body:
Hollywood supremo Steven Spielberg is today to present a virtual masterclass for British media students in a live link-up via the internet.

Fifty final-year students from Liverpool John Moores University's (JMU) School of Media will be discussing the director's current projects and the future of new media. The seminar is organised by Brookside creator Phil Redmond, with the assistance of JMU Chancellor Cherie Booth.

Spielberg has taken a keen interest in the internet's potential for screening lower-budget films. Last November, his company, Dreamworks, helped launch pop.com to show short films and animations online and to encourage independent film-makers to submit their work.

Students have already put forward their questions for the director, who will lecture from a secret location, believed to be in the south of England.

A university spokesman said the lecture would "provide a realistic and stimulating demonstration of the potential of cyber-seminars, utilising the new fast internet access technology."

fields.headline: Musical chairs 'teaches aggression'
fields.trailText: The children's game musical chairs has been condemned for encouraging aggression in a government-backed booklet, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The children's game musical chairs has been condemned for encouraging aggression in a government-backed booklet, it emerged yesterday.

The booklet, Towards a Non-violent Society, tells nursery teachers that children learn from the game that "the strongest/fastest one who pushes the other children out of the way wins".

The booklet was produced by the Forum on Children and Violence, an umbrella group of children's charities set up after the James Bulger murder, and launched in north London yesterday with the education minister, Margaret Hodge, as guest speaker.

Sue Finch, the author and an early years education specialist, said nursery games could be used to promote cooperation. "A bit of competition is fine but the aim is to encourage children to negotiate instead of fight.

"More cooperative games like musical statues teach something other than that the strongest and biggest wins."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "This is political correctness gone mad. Musical chairs is a popular children's game that has been played by many and enjoyed by many over the years."

A spokesman for the Department of Education said the booklet was neither funded nor distributed by the department and its views were those of the author.

He said: "Margaret Hodge sees musical chairs as a perfectly reasonable traditional game for children and has certainly not suggested otherwise.

"Of course children need a mix of individual and team games but it would be wrong to suggest that musical chairs should be banned."

Ms Finch said: "Margaret Hodge came to the launch and she looked at the booklet and was happy with it."

webTitle: Pixies check out the Tory way to run trains

fields.headline: Pixies check out the Tory way to run trains
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: To Westminster Hall for the exciting announcement of the new Tory policy on the railways. With Archie Norman in charge, the trains are going to resemble a mobile Asda.
fields.body:
To Westminster Hall for the exciting announcement of the new Tory policy on the railways. With Archie Norman in charge, the trains are going to resemble a mobile Asda.

Mr Norman seems to live in a fantasy world in which privatised trains work well, where happy commuters lounge in comfy, uncrowded carriages, everyone arrives on time, and it is possible to travel from, say, Manchester to London without first selling your liver to medical science.

There were, he conceded, a few problems, but these could be ironed out, especially if the government stopped being rude about the privatised trains. "Far from promoting the railways, Prescott has denigrated them. Every time he criticises, he is costing the railways something - such as a new manager who will not now come into the industry!"

At the same time, he has failed to take the railways in hand and build on the first-rate framework left by the Tories. So, the opposition thinks, the government should be more critical, but, at the same time, less critical. This is the sort of thing oppositions are paid to say.

Mr Norman recalled the dark days when he was a member of the old British Railways Board. According to his text, it was housed in "a building of dusty corridors and rigid hierarchy. It was large and formal men in formal suits served tea and coffee in an ante-room." (A puzzle: should nobody have served tea and coffee, or if they did, ought they to have worn jeans and sweaters?) Mr Norman had solutions, all of which were for trains to be more like Asda.

Sunday services should be improved. "Supermarkets don't sell worse products on a Sunday," he said. No queues at ticket offices. At Asda, they open another checkout when the lines build up. And anyone who didn't have a seat would get the journey free.

We hacks inquired whether the companies might simply ban people from the trains if there weren't enough seats. Commuters would get rather cross.

"I don't think that's very likely," said Mr Norman, vaguely. "Anyway, we've got three years to get to that point."

At this point his understrapper, Mr Bernard Jenkin, started chafing. My impression was that Mr Jenkin, who is a bit of a trainspotter, with a smart two-piece tailored anorak, thinks that his boss doesn't know what he's talking about.

"The number of passengers is already subject to regulation," he said briskly. "They are called 'pixies', which means 'passengers in excess of capacity'."

So, after three years, any passenger forced to stand will get a free pointed cap with a bell on top.

"At Asda, we give a refund in all circumstances. That is because we are customer-led," said Mr Norman. That may be the answer to the Tories' problems - loyalty cards and cash back bonuses.

Back at my desk a colleague brings me Hansard, with a speech by Michael Fabricant marked. It's wonderfully barking, even by Mickey's standards. He was taking part in a filibuster on something or other.

"Imagine it is the year 850. Dank mists lie over the water, and all that can be heard is the swish-swash of oars from a longboat as it enters a misty inlet, which, in future, will be known by the Icelandic for misty inlet, Reykjavik Norsemen would debate not in a parliament contained by a roof, but in a parliament contained by the heavens. The acoustics were such that they used to shout at each other, aiming their voices at a cliff. Debates sometimes lasted two, three or four weeks."

So, no change there, then.

fields.headline: Court 'strips Pinochet immunity'
fields.standfirst: Chilean court votes whether Pinochet will stand trial, official decision kept secret
fields.trailText: A Chilean court has voted on whether General Augusto Pinochet will be stripped of immunity and stand trial  on charges of human rights violations, but said the crucial ruling will only be made public in a few weeks.
fields.body:
A Chilean court has voted on whether General Augusto Pinochet will be stripped of immunity and stand trial on charges of human rights violations, but said the crucial ruling will only be made public in a few weeks.

However, local radio stations and an online news agency quoted by the state television said judges voted 12-10 to lift Pinochet's immunity, but the court refused to confirm this. The government said it would not comment "on rumors."

If the ruling indeed went against Pinochet, it can be appealed before the Supreme Court. "A decision has been made," said Ruben Ballesteros, president of the Santiago Court of Appeals, after the surprise session by the court's 22 judges.

"The announcement will be made after the ruling has been written and signed by all the judges, in one or two weeks" Ballesteros said after the 90-minute session.

No explanation was given to why the session, which was originally scheduled for today, was held yesterday. The rescheduling may have been part of an effort to avoid mass demonstrations by supporters and foes of Pinochet that have marked previous hearings in April.

Only small groups from both sides gathered outside the court. The court ruled on whether the former dictator should be stripped of the immunity from prosecution he currently enjoys as a senator-for-life - a post he created for himself during his 17-year regime. If lifted, he would be put on trial for abuses that occurred after his bloody 1973 coup against Chile's elected government.

According to an official report compiled by the civilian government that succeeded Pinochet, 3,191 people died or disappeared under Pinochet's military rule.

There were no indications of what decision the judges had reached. The justices split 11-11 on a request by the Pinochet defence to drop the case on grounds of his deteriorating health.

The judges based their undisclosed ruling on arguments last month by seven lawyers for the plaintiffs and one for Pinochet, and on a report by Judge Juan Guzman, who is handling 108 criminal complaints against the former dictator.

The military, especially the army, remain firmly loyal to Pinochet. A ruling against Pinochet "would not be satisfactory for us," said army chief Gen. Ricardo Izurieta, prompting criticism from anti-Pinochet politicians and human rights activists who claimed the remark placed undue military pressure on the court.

President Ricardo Lagos, a socialist who was briefly jailed under Pinochet, has vowed to make sure the court ruling will be respected and urged "all sectors in the country" to refrain from pressuring the court.

The case picked by Guzman to seek the lifting of Pinochet's immunity and his trial is one of the most emblematic of the abuses under his regime: the so-called "caravan of death." It refers to a group of officers who toured several cities soon after the coup, dragging political prisoners from jail and executing them.

While 75 people were killed, Guzman centred his case against Pinochet on 19 of them who are still missing, calling the situation "a case of ongoing kidnapping." Right-wing followers of Pinochet angrily reject the judge's stance.

"This is a ridiculous joke," said congressman Pablo Longueira, head of the Independent Democratic Union and a staunch Pinochet supporter. "We all know those people are dead."

Last month, Pinochet had defended himself through retired Gen. Luis Cortes, a close associate. After meeting with Pinochet, Cortes said: "He told me: 'Please tell everybody that I never ordered anybody to be killed or tortured."'

Pinochet returned home in February after being held for 16 months in London, where he blocked efforts to be extradited to Spain for trial.

However, local radio stations and an online news agency quoted by the state television said judges voted 12-10 to lift Pinochet's immunity, but the court refused to confirm this. The government said it would not comment "on rumors." If the ruling indeed went against Pinochet, it can be appealed before the Supreme Court. "A decision has been made," said Ruben Ballesteros, president of the Santiago Court of Appeals, after the surprise session by the court's 22 judges. "The announcement will be made after the ruling has been written and signed by all the judges, in one or two weeks" Ballesteros said after the 90-minute session. No explanation was given to why the session, which was originally scheduled for today, was held yesterday. The rescheduling may have been part of an effort to avoid mass demonstrations by supporters and foes of Pinochet that have marked previous hearings in April. Only small groups from both sides gathered outside the court. The court ruled on whether the former dictator should be stripped of the immunity from prosecution he currently enjoys as a senator-for-life - a post he created for himself during his 17-year regime. If lifted, he would be put on trial for abuses that occurred after his bloody 1973 coup against Chile's elected government. According to an official report compiled by the civilian government that succeeded Pinochet, 3,191 people died or disappeared under Pinochet's military rule. There were no indications of what decision the judges had reached. The justices split 11-11 on a request by the Pinochet defence to drop the case on grounds of his deteriorating health. The judges based their undisclosed ruling on arguments last month by seven lawyers for the plaintiffs and one for Pinochet, and on a report by Judge Juan Guzman, who is handling 108 criminal complaints against the former dictator. The military, especially the army, remain firmly loyal to Pinochet. A ruling against Pinochet "would not be satisfactory for us," said army chief Gen. Ricardo Izurieta, prompting criticism from anti-Pinochet politicians and human rights activists who claimed the remark placed undue military pressure on the court. President Ricardo Lagos, a socialist who was briefly jailed under Pinochet, has vowed to make sure the court ruling will be respected and urged "all sectors in the country" to refrain from pressuring the court. The case picked by Guzman to seek the lifting of Pinochet's immunity and his trial is one of the most emblematic of the abuses under his regime: the so-called "caravan of death." It refers to a group of officers who toured several cities soon after the coup, dragging political prisoners from jail and executing them. While 75 people were killed, Guzman centred his case against Pinochet on 19 of them who are still missing, calling the situation "a case of ongoing kidnapping." Right-wing followers of Pinochet angrily reject the judge's stance. "This is a ridiculous joke," said congressman Pablo Longueira, head of the Independent Democratic Union and a staunch Pinochet supporter. "We all know those people are dead." Last month, Pinochet had defended himself through retired Gen. Luis Cortes, a close associate. After meeting with Pinochet, Cortes said: "He told me: 'Please tell everybody that I never ordered anybody to be killed or tortured."' Pinochet returned home in February after being held for 16 months in London, where he blocked efforts to be extradited to Spain for trial.

webTitle: Winners and losers on the north-east's wheel of fortune

fields.headline: Winners and losers on the north-east's wheel of fortune
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Two bulging car parks, barely seven miles apart. One is full of new Nissans bound for export from Europe's most efficient car plant, now fighting for its life. The other, surrounding the country's largest shopping centre, is crammed with shoppers on another spending spree, fuelled by cheap imports.
fields.body:
Two bulging car parks, barely seven miles apart. One is full of new Nissans bound for export from Europe's most efficient car plant, now fighting for its life. The other, surrounding the country's largest shopping centre, is crammed with shoppers on another spending spree, fuelled by cheap imports.

In a region still heavily dependent on manufacturing, where unemployment is more than twice the national average and where several large industries are close to the edge, consumers have thrown caution to the wind. Visits to the MetroCentre, four miles of shopping malls, are up at least 5% on this time last year, although there was a recorded a 22% increase at Easter.

"People here live for today and forget about tomorrow," says Karen Smith, the marketing manager, who is planning to add a further 27 shops to the complex in a £50m expansion. Outside, shoppers are struggling to fit purchases - PCs, televisions, furniture, white goods - into car boots. "Can't get enough of these bargains," says a recently retired middle-manager in his mid-50s. "Grab it while you can. Such good value - just like it is in Europe. Don't you get so much for your pound these days?"

John Thain, manager of the House of Fraser store, says he cannot quite understand why sales are booming. "We took a bad 'hit' 18 months ago, but now it's common to find orders of £6,000 to £8,000 - often big furniture sales, wide and flat screen televisions costing more than £1,000, that sort of thing - so much confidence out there."

Confidence? Tell that to the 5,000 Nissan workers, and the 10,000 others dependent on car production in the north-east, as the struggling company, now effectively run by Renault, warns that the high pound could drive it out of business. With three-quarters of output exported - mainly to mainland Europe - most models are sold at a loss because the pound is strong and the euro weak.

To stay in business and win investment from Renault, John Cushnaghan, the managing director, has told his employees that the 14-year-old plant - more productive than counterparts in Japan - will have to cut costs by 30% in less than two years.

He says Nissan, and all its UK suppliers, carry a "heavy burden because of the high value of sterling."

Outside the plant, thousands of Micra cars are awaiting delivery. At the end of a shift, employees try to be upbeat.

"We were given the financial results for the last year this week and tomorrow we're due to be given a presentation on the survival plan," says a young assembly line worker. "We take things from day to day."

But with 2,500 jobs in Nissan suppliers facing the axe, as the company cuts back on British components, the north-east economy is starting to take another battering.

In the prime minister's nearby Sedgefield constituency, where manufacturing accounts for 48% of the workforce, one big engineering company, which supplies Nissan and other car makers, has sacked its temporary staff. There are fears that up to a quarter of its remaining 900 workers could face redundancy.

The local council is so alarmed by the threat to jobs caused by the high pound that it wrote to Tony Blair asking him to "ease the plight of manufacturing" in the area.

For workers like Julie Richardson, the plea came too late. Three weeks ago she lost her job at the largest employer in the small town of Ferryhill, when a clothing factory closed. Almost 150 others were thrown out of work. joining a further 6,000 textile workers who have lost their jobs in the north-east over the past 18 months.

Their union, the GMB, blames the high pound. Workers blame the government. "Most of us will not vote Labour again," says Julie, who worked in the trade for 15 years.

Other big companies are holding their breath. "There's a real danger that a number of overseas investors that came to the north-east to serve the single market may be thinking of re-siting production in other parts of Europe," warns Keith Burge, head of a large economic consultancy in the region.

"The continued strength of the pound has seriously eroded their ability to compete with rivals and sister plants elsewhere in Europe."

Tomorrow: the French-German axis

fields.headline: Treading the monetary tightrope
fields.standfirst:
In the second of a three-part series, Guardian writers look at the contrasting consequences of a strong pound

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The headlines on the financial news wire services yesterday were all too familiar to students of past Labour governments. Sterling was on the slide, falling to its lowest level against a basket of world currencies this year. But if stories about the pound weakening would once have set alarm bells ringing in Downing Street and the Treasury, this time the government could not be happier.
fields.body:
The headlines on the financial news wire services yesterday were all too familiar to students of past Labour governments. Sterling was on the slide, falling to its lowest level against a basket of world currencies this year. But if stories about the pound weakening would once have set alarm bells ringing in Downing Street and the Treasury, this time the government could not be happier.

For 2000 is unlike 1931, 1949, 1967 and 1976 - the dark days of capital flight, devaluations and the arrival of the International Monetary Fund. This time, Labour's problem is that the pound has been too strong, not too weak, and the growing clamour for the government to do something about it has threatened to blow apart its carefully crafted position on joining the euro.

The fact that the single currency has lost a third of its value since its launch 17 months ago has been a mixed blessing, both for the 11 countries in the euro zone and for Britain. The weak euro has been a political embarrassment in euroland but it has meant that exporters in Germany, France, Italy and elsewhere have seen the price of their goods fall, allowing them to sell more. The beneficiaries of the strong pound in the UK have been consumers, particularly those on low incomes, who have been able to buy more as the price of imported goods has fallen.

But exporters have had a terrible time, with the 20% appreciation of the pound leaving them with the choice of either cutting profit margins or losing overseas customers altogether. Around 200,000 jobs have been lost in manufacturing over the past year and investment plans have been mothballed as firms have tried to cut costs.

As a result, the government has been under mounting pressure to do something about the level of the pound, with those in favour of British membership of the euro arguing that Labour should commit Britain to joining the single currency at a lower rate than today's as the centrepiece of a strategy to make UK exports more competitive. This was the theme of Peter Mandelson's remarks last week in which he said that sterling would always be vulnerable to movements on the foreign exchanges while Britain was outside monetary union.

Despite the political fuss caused by the remarks, the Northern Ireland secretary was broadly correct. Joining the single currency would eliminate all risk of the pound's gyrations affecting exports to Britain's main markets, although, as the 30% fall in the euro against the dollar has shown, there could still be exchange rate problems with the rest of the world.

But life is never quite that simple. Membership of the single currency also entails ceding control over interest rates, which not only involves political questions of nations being able to influence their own economic policies but also entails costs.

Senior treasury officials stress that the downside to putting a stable pound at the heart of economic policy was aptly illustrated in two distinct phases between 1987 and 1992. First, Nigel Lawson adopted a policy of shadowing the German mark, which involved cutting UK interest rates to prevent sterling from rising too far. The result of this was to fuel the unsustainable boom of the late 80s, which was only controlled by a doubling of interest rates to a crippling 15%. Then, when the inevitable recession was just under way, Mrs Thatcher reluctantly took Britain into the European exchange rate mechanism in October 1990.

For the next two years, interest rates in the UK were kept higher than they should have been to prevent the pound from falling, contributing to the record level of bankruptcies and home repossessions in the early 90s. Only after John Major's government was humbled by George Soros on Black Wednesday in September 1992 did interest rates come down and economic recovery begin.

This is the background to the caution being shown by Tony Blair and Gordon Brown over the euro.

Both believe the long slog to win a reputation for managerial competence could be thrown away by the actions necessary to target a lower exchange rate for sterling, and that joining monetary union is too momentous a decision to be made on the basis of short-term expediency.

The government's economic advisers point out that the only way to bring down the pound would be to cut interest rates to a level that would risk stoking up inflation in the domestic economy, plunge the economy back into a boom-bust cycle and perhaps cost Labour the next election.

At root, the government would prefer to remain outside the single currency rather than join when the economic conditions are not right. Despite the recent problems for exporters, the economy has done well since 1992, with an unprecedented period of growth and the lowest inflation in Europe.

As ministers see it, there are two possible ways that Britain could join the single currency. One is that a full-scale economic crisis makes the safe haven of the euro far more attractive to voters. The alternative is that the government minimises the economic risks of joining what was essentially a political project through a period of convergence and is then able to persuade the electorate from a position of strength that it is the right decision for Britain.

Given that the UK economy is more in synch with the United States than mainland Europe, such convergence will be problematical, perhaps even impossible. But one inescapable truth of the 20th century is that bad economics results in bad politics. This government, above all others, does not intend to repeat the old mistakes.

webTitle: MPs snub Brown's choice for Bank

fields.headline: MPs snub Brown's choice for Bank
fields.trailText: The Labour-controlled Commons Treasury select committee will today deliver a sharp rebuke to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, by rejecting his nominee for a vacancy on the Bank of England committee which sets interest rates.
fields.body:
The Labour-controlled Commons Treasury select committee will today deliver a sharp rebuke to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, by rejecting his nominee for a vacancy on the Bank of England committee which sets interest rates.

The unprecedented decision to refuse an endorsement to Chris Allsopp, an Oxford University economist, was taken on a vote after the committee, chaired by Labour's Giles Radice, had cross-examined the New College don on Monday.

It produced a cross-party consensus that Mr Allsopp, whom Mr Brown had nominated to succeed banker Charles Goodhart, was not impressive enough to hold one of the seats on the monetary policy committee (MPC).

The committee has been setting UK interest rates since the chancellor "freed" the Bank from Treasury control in 1997 and is judged a crucial ingredient in marshalling market confidence behind Mr Brown's macro-economic management.

Labour leftwinger Brian Sedgemore said Mr Goodhart was the MPC equivalent of a Premiership football player, while Mr Allsopp was a "Vauxhall League, maybe Kidderminster" performer. Tory MPs agreed.

The Treasury committee has no formal power to veto Mr Brown's nominee, but it is gradually asserting its intention to hold both the Treasury and the Bank more accountable for policies which ministers have passed on.

Its models are the US congress's assertive powers of committee to interrogate, endorse or reject a nominee of the government. Mr Allsopp is the first such reject - and may force Mr Brown to give in gracefully or dig in his heels.

The monetary policy committee decides the level of interest rates. Its nine members are made up by the Bank of England governor, deputy governor and second deputy governor, and six other members - two from the Bank with responsibility for monetary policy and market operations and four "recognised experts" from outside the bank.

webTitle: Chaos and humiliation as Israel pulls out of Lebanon

fields.headline: Chaos and humiliation as Israel pulls out of Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Lebanese snipers yesterday exacted a final humiliation on Israel's 22-year occupation of southern Lebanon, triggering a firefight above columns of refugees at the border, and announcing the enemy's arrival on its doorstep.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg on the Israeli-Lebanese border
fields.body:
Lebanese snipers yesterday exacted a final humiliation on Israel's 22-year occupation of southern Lebanon, triggering a firefight above columns of refugees at the border, and announcing the enemy's arrival on its doorstep.

Yesterday's clash, which raged for more than an hour, while refugees cowered behind cars or paltry pieces of luggage, encapsulated Israel's worst nightmare. After two decades and the loss, according to estimates, of more than 1,000 men, Israel's chaotic withdrawal from southern Lebanon leaves its northern flank dangerously exposed, with Hizbullah guerrillas sitting directly on its border.

With the fighters of its proxy militia, the South Lebanese Army (SLA) fleeing headlong with their families to crossings all along the border, the scale of the Israeli fiasco was beginning to unfold yesterday.

At the Fatima Gate crossing, where men, women and children waited behind a barbed wire fence for five hours in the sun to be cleared for entry by two Israeli security officials, the refugees called out the names of their villages - Khiam, El Qlaia, Kheube. It was a rollcall of defeat that yesterday spread eastwards with astonishing speed across the self-declared security zone. Hizbullah now controls at least two-thirds of the area.

Along with Israel's evacuation of Bint Jubayl, the second largest town in the zone, at least a dozen more villages passed into the hands of Hizbullah yesterday.

Most fell without a shot. After the Israelis pulled out of Bint Jubayl in the middle of the night, their SLA allies, already in a state of collapse in the centre of the strip, simply gave up. Branded collaborators, they and their families headed for exile.

Behind them, they left tanks and other heavy equipment donated by their patrons. The equipment was bombed later yesterday by the Israeli airforce in an attempt to stop Hizbullah in its tracks.

At Fatima Gate, the trail of abandoned cars stretched for more than a mile into Lebanon. Most still had the keys in the ignition. "We left our houses behind. What is the use of a car," said Amelia Moussa, a psychology student. "I lived my whole life in Lebanon - 21 years - and I want to stay. But we can not live in peace and so I am leaving."

At the nearby Maronite Christian village of Raymesh, the entire population of 12,000 fled. Yesterday morning, they arrived by the busload at the Biranit border crossing, and were immediately driven to the resort on the Sea of Galilee which is the main transit camp for a refugee influx that has already reached thousands.

Marwan Makhoul, the nephew of an SLA officer, banged on the side of a bus as it sped past. For days, he had been in constant communication with his family in south Lebanon via Israeli cellphones.

"Last night, he said they would all stay until the end - that they will die there," Makhoul said. "But in the morning, after the Israelis left and Hizbullah arrived and started pulling people out of their houses, they knew they had to go."

According to Israeli military officials, the SLA is still in control of eight posts inside the security zone - although it has fled a further 25. Israel claims to control a further eight posts, including its headquarters at Marjayoun.

However, with refugees arriving from neighbouring villages, the claims seemed less than convincing. Among the most spectacular territories to change hands yesterday was the notorious Khiam prison - the Bastille of south Lebanon - whose 144 prisoners had been regularly tortured, and jailed for years without access to lawyers.

As events galloped beyond Israel's control, the prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday tried to reassure a public that is angrily questioning his decision to go ahead with a unilateral withdrawal.

Many northern Israelis employ relatives of SLA men in their hotels and orchards.

Yesterday they descended on Fatima Gate to see whether their employees had managed to flee, and to shake their heads in dismay at the unruly scenes. "It is like a picture of a ghetto," said a farmer Shlomo Hayun, who lives on Shaar Yeshuv farm. "This is the first time I have been ashamed to be Israeli. This is chaotic and disorganised."

Elsewhere, at least half of the residents of the largest town, Kiryat Shmona, drove south rather than spend another night cowering in the bomb shelters.

Mr Barak had badly wanted an orderly withdrawal with an expanded United Nations peacekeeping force taking control of border areas. But with the SLA in disarray, a refugee influx that has taken the government by surprise and the rapid arrival of Hizbullah well before Israel has had time to complete its electrified border fence and other defences, that prospect has evaporated.

"When we solve the problem from its roots - the withdrawal of the army from Lebanon will take a few days, maybe a week or maybe 10 days - we should not be alarmed," Mr Barak told Israel's armed forces radio.

Last night it appeared that the end could arrive within hours, rather than days. Amid the thud of a distant artillery barrage, a convoy of tanks lined up at the Egel Pass bor der crossing near Metulla, waiting for orders to go into Lebanon, possibly to cover the withdrawal of the last Israeli soldiers.

In the largest pullout so far, 200 troops from Bint Jubayl reached the Tzurit base yesterday morning, standing atop tanks to offer prayers of thanksgiving. Behind them, tanks and armoured personnel carriers were being loaded on to flatbed trucks.

The soldiers said they got their marching orders at noon on Monday - predating the disintegration of the SLA. But the end still came swiftly, with the quartermaster handing out free chocolates from the stores rather than hand them over to Hizbullah.

"It was a mess," said a tank mechanic Nir Sopher, sitting beside the road with his duffel bag and reading a paperback copy of the The Hunchback of Notre Dame.

But it is a mess from which Israel will not easily be able to extricate itself. Like several of the outposts to which Israel has now withdrawn, Tzurit still lives several yards inside Lebanese territory, giving Hizbullah a future pretext to attack.

At the nearby Maronite Christian village of Raymesh, the entire population of 12,000 fled. Yesterday morning, they arrived by the busload at the Biranit border crossing, and were immediately driven to the resort on the Sea of Galilee which is the main transit camp for a refugee influx that has already reached thousands. Marwan Makhoul, the nephew of an SLA officer, banged on the side of a bus as it sped past. For days, he had been in constant communication with his family in south Lebanon via Israeli cellphones. "Last night, he said they would all stay until the end - that they will die there," Makhoul said. "But in the morning, after the Israelis left and Hizbullah arrived and started pulling people out of their houses, they knew they had to go." According to Israeli military officials, the SLA is still in control of eight posts inside the security zone - although it has fled a further 25. Israel claims to control a further eight posts, including its headquarters at Marjayoun. However, with refugees arriving from neighbouring villages, the claims seemed less than convincing. Among the most spectacular territories to change hands yesterday was the notorious Khiam prison - the Bastille of south Lebanon - whose 144 prisoners had been regularly tortured, and jailed for years without access to lawyers. As events galloped beyond Israel's control, the prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday tried to reassure a public that is angrily questioning his decision to go ahead with a unilateral withdrawal. Many northern Israelis employ relatives of SLA men in their hotels and orchards. Yesterday they descended on Fatima Gate to see whether their employees had managed to flee, and to shake their heads in dismay at the unruly scenes. "It is like a picture of a ghetto," said a farmer Shlomo Hayun, who lives on Shaar Yeshuv farm. "This is the first time I have been ashamed to be Israeli. This is chaotic and disorganised." Elsewhere, at least half of the residents of the largest town, Kiryat Shmona, drove south rather than spend another night cowering in the bomb shelters. Mr Barak had badly wanted an orderly withdrawal with an expanded United Nations peacekeeping force taking control of border areas. But with the SLA in disarray, a refugee influx that has taken the government by surprise and the rapid arrival of Hizbullah well before Israel has had time to complete its electrified border fence and other defences, that prospect has evaporated. "When we solve the problem from its roots - the withdrawal of the army from Lebanon will take a few days, maybe a week or maybe 10 days - we should not be alarmed," Mr Barak told Israel's armed forces radio. Last night it appeared that the end could arrive within hours, rather than days. Amid the thud of a distant artillery barrage, a convoy of tanks lined up at the Egel Pass bor der crossing near Metulla, waiting for orders to go into Lebanon, possibly to cover the withdrawal of the last Israeli soldiers. In the largest pullout so far, 200 troops from Bint Jubayl reached the Tzurit base yesterday morning, standing atop tanks to offer prayers of thanksgiving. Behind them, tanks and armoured personnel carriers were being loaded on to flatbed trucks. The soldiers said they got their marching orders at noon on Monday - predating the disintegration of the SLA. But the end still came swiftly, with the quartermaster handing out free chocolates from the stores rather than hand them over to Hizbullah. "It was a mess," said a tank mechanic Nir Sopher, sitting beside the road with his duffel bag and reading a paperback copy of the The Hunchback of Notre Dame. But it is a mess from which Israel will not easily be able to extricate itself. Like several of the outposts to which Israel has now withdrawn, Tzurit still lives several yards inside Lebanese territory, giving Hizbullah a future pretext to attack.

webTitle: Exit strategy linked to weapons aid

fields.headline: Exit strategy linked to weapons aid
fields.standfirst:
Britain to supply up to 10,000 self-loading rifles, ammunition and training to help SLA strike in rebel heartland

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Cabinet ministers meeting in private yesterday mapped out an exit strategy for Britain based on helping the Sierra Leone army to take the fight into the rebel heartland.
fields.body:
Cabinet ministers meeting in private yesterday mapped out an exit strategy for Britain based on helping the Sierra Leone army to take the fight into the rebel heartland.

As a first step in a strategy designed to let Britain leave Sierra Leone with honour, the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, announced in the Commons yesterday that Britain is to supply the bedraggled Sierra Leone army (SLA) with "light weapons and ammunition".

Up to 10,000 self-loading rifles no longer used by the British army will be supplied to Sierra Leone, according to defence sources.

Mr Hoon also made clear that British military involvement in Sierra Leone would continue well after the 700 paratroopers - who will be replaced by 600 marine commandos over the coming week - have left.

He announced that "advance elements" of a British military training team are to start arriving in the capital, Freetown, "very shortly".

The British military advisory training team, will be made up of 90 officers, half of them British.

With MPs expressing concern about whether the SLA could be trained to the necessary level to defeat the rebel Revolutionary United Front, Mr Hoon said the marines would stay "no longer than necessary". They are still expected to be pulled out by mid-June.

He told the Commons: "What we are now setting in place are the arrangements for our continuing support to the government of Sierra Leone."

In the morning, Mr Hoon met key cabinet ministers for a private discussion on the long-term plan for British forces in Sierra Leone. The cabinet committee meeting was chaired by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook. Tony Blair, taking time off to be with his new baby Leo, was said to have been "plugged in".

Later, in the Commons, the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, welcomed the pull-out of the troops but warned there were several different militias loosely associated with the SLA and there was a risk that the British arms might find their way into rebel hands.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, backed moves by the British to arm and train the SLA.

But he added: "If the policy is now to try to turn the SLA into an effective force able to hold the ring once the British go, then of course it means the British can't go until that has been achieved.

"That may well mean that this is a rather more open-ended commitment than we've been told about so far."

Mr Campbell told the defence secretary: "There's some relief that you have now abandoned the fiction that the British forces are not combat troops. Isn't it clear that the success which they have enjoyed is precisely because of the fact that they are ready and capable of combat and that anyone who seeks to interfere with their activities will find that out to their cost?"

Labour's Donald Anderson, chairman of the Commons foreign affairs select committee, said the attainment of the defence secretary's broader political objectives in Sierra Leone would be "formidably difficult".

"Do you really expect the Sierra Leone army, in its degree of fragmentation, lack of morale, even with the light arms that we will supply, being a match or being able, even with the UN, to inflict such a decisive military defeat on the RUF, that they will not be able to move into Liberia and regroup and have a continuing state of turbulence in that country?" he asked.

Mr Hoon said it was important to link the prospect of withdrawal of British forces with an effective training team in Sierra Leone which would be able to carry through the "difficult process" of bringing the remainder of the country under control.

A Labour backbencher, David Winnick, said a good illustration of the crimes and atrocities taking place in Sierra Leone was found in a photograph of a 14-month-old child who had her hand cut off six months ago.

Mr Hoon said: "One of the appalling aspects of what has been taking place in Sierra Leone is that it's not impossi ble that that child lost its arm as a result of the activities of child soldiers who perhaps were only a few years older on the other side.

"That is why it is necessary that Sierra Leone should return to peace and stability and that is why it's important that we should assist that government," he said.

In further exchanges, Mr Hoon said the RUF of Foday Sankoh had to be isolated. "The continued detention of Sankoh assists in that process and we do want to see him brought to trial and we want it to be quite clear that he should no longer have any influence over the RUF in Sierra Leone."

webTitle: Gems key to an end to war

fields.headline: Gems key to an end to war
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Diamonds are the key to stability in Sierra Leone, with the capability of being sold to prolong the country's civil war or to rebuild the nation and create a better-equipped and trained army and police force.
fields.body:
Diamonds are the key to stability in Sierra Leone, with the capability of being sold to prolong the country's civil war or to rebuild the nation and create a better-equipped and trained army and police force.

British ministers meeting yesterday agreed to give more backing to a campaign to clean up the world diamond industry, to prevent smuggled gems being used to fuel conflict in Sierra Leone and elsewhere in Africa.

A boost for the campaign came from Russia, where officials gave tentative support to a British plan for strict certification of rough diamonds, possibly using holograms or chemical isotopes.

Earlier, ministers decided that British forces would back up the Sierra Leone army when it pushed into the diamond-producing area controlled by the rebel Revolutionary United Front, but would avoid direct combat.

Smuggled

Diamonds are the main source of income in Sierra Leone but the production area is in rebel hands. They have traded arms for diamonds that are believed to have been smuggled through neighbouring Liberia.

De Beers in London, which controls most of the world's diamond production has contacted the British government, offering to provide an expert to advise on setting up a properly-run diamond industry in Sierra Leone.

The industry fears being tarnished by the branding of gems from Sierra Leone and Angola, also torn by civil war, as "blood diamonds" - a phrase used by the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain.

Foreign ministry officials in Russia, which produces around one quarter of the world's diamonds, said British calls to crack down on the illegal trade in gems could be agreed at the G8 summit in Japan in July.

webTitle: Life or death at the rebels' whim: the hostage's tale

fields.headline: Life or death at the rebels' whim: the hostage's tale
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leonean rebels trussed up the Norwegian naval commander with wire so tightly that when he was ordered to climb out of the car he could not move. So the young Revolutionary United Front soldier calmly raised his gun to Knut Gjellestad's temple and pulled the trigger.
fields.body:
Sierra Leonean rebels trussed up the Norwegian naval commander with wire so tightly that when he was ordered to climb out of the car he could not move. So the young Revolutionary United Front soldier calmly raised his gun to Knut Gjellestad's temple and pulled the trigger.

"The gun just clicked. It didn't fire," Commander Gjellestad said. "He was about to try again so I asked him to help me get out of the car. He put his gun down and lifted me out. It was completely surprising. A few seconds earlier he had been trying to kill me."

Cmdr Gjellestad, 57, was freed at the weekend after three weeks in the RUF's hands. His arm is bandaged because the wire used to tie him up cut so deep that it turned septic and swelled to several times its normal size. But he is relatively lucky.

At least six of the nearly 500 UN peacekeepers taken hostage by the RUF are dead, and many more have been subjected to beatings, mock executions and near-starvation rations. Thirty or more are believed to have untreated gunshot wounds. Gangrene is the great fear.

At least 250 UN troops are still believed to be held captive. Many are Zambians, who have been given little more than a mango a day to eat."We are worried that many of our men have been very badly treated," said a senior Zambian officer.

"We hear stories of them being tied to trees and whipped, cut with knives, and no food. We hope they are all alive but we cannot be sure."

Cmdr Gjellestad was captured on May 1 when he went in search of a colleague, a Malaysian army major called Jaganathan Ganase, who had been picked up by the RUF a few hours earlier.

A rebel commander, "Colonel Bao", had arrived shirtless and drunk at a UN demobilisation camp in Makeni to demand that Maj Ganase hand over several "deserters" - former RUF fighters who opted to go back to civilian life under the peace accords.

Maj Ganase, 42, told him the demobilised rebels had already returned to their homes. Shortly afterwards another RUF officer arrived, "Brigadier General Kallow". He did not argue, he merely opened fire with his Kalashnikov and arrested Maj Ganase.

"They waved guns and a dagger in my face and said: 'It's the end of you. Say bye bye to your life. You're going to be buried in Sierra Leone'," the major said.

That was the beginning of a three-week nightmare. The Malaysian major was taken to an RUF base and strip- searched while Gen Kallow called the rebel command in Freetown.

"He said the UN had seriously attacked the RUF and captured five of his men and he had captured one of theirs - me," Maj Ganase said.

In the following hours the number of captives grew as more UN officers arrived to check on the fate of Maj Ganase and were in turn locked up. By nightfall 11 men were crammed into one tiny cell. They stayed there for two days. On the third night the RUF unbolted the door.

"They came around midnight," Maj Ganase said. "We were taken out one by one which was very worrying. We could hear some moaning next door so we thought the worst. They stripped us to our underwear and trussed our arms tight behind our backs with electrical wire. It was so tight we lost all feeling in our arms."

The captives were driven south for several hours to meet one of the RUF's most prominent leaders, "General Issa". He immediately made clear his dislike of Cmdr Gjellestad.

"He was saying whites are the cause of all the problems of the human race. I was the only white and they kept threatening me because of it. They said they would shoot me anytime. They were all drunk or drugged. That's the whole culture."

Another nine Kenyan peacekeepers arrived. Next day all 20 were crammed into a Land-Rover and driven through the night to an old diamond plant at Koidu. The car crashed, breaking one of the hostage's legs and giving some of the others back and head injuries.

In their new prison, Cmdr Gjellestad's arm became swollen and Maj Ganase developed malaria.

The hostility eased a little as the guards and their captors got to know each other. Word filtered through to the UN soldiers that they were not the only ones taken hostage. So did news of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh's capture.

"When they heard Foday Sankoh was captured there was not a big problem. They called him a great leader," said the Norwegian officer. "But they told us they were ready to go back to war and that if the UN or the Brits or whoever were to attack they would fight and win. There's no doubt they were ready for another war."

Last week the rebels announced that all of those fit enough would be marched 40 miles to the Liberian border and freedom. But Cmdr Gjellestad's arm and Maj Ganase's malaria delayed their release.

Finally transport arrived to take them to the frontier. But with freedom in sight, the RUF could not resist one last twist of the knife.

"At the last minute they said I could not go across," Cmdr Gjellestad said. 'They said I was a white man and I knew things I could still tell them about the UN. I thought I would never make it."

webTitle: How dome high flyer fell to earth

fields.headline: How dome high flyer fell to earth
fields.standfirst:
Ayling notches up second failure - but some say he is a scapegoat

Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Bob Ayling's fate was sealed when he went cap in hand once again to the millennium commission for a further £38.6m to bail out the dome. The body, chaired by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, had already pumped £509m of lottery money into the Greenwich white elephant and its patience had run out. Agreeing a £29m lifeline to stave off bankruptcy, the commission demanded their man before the New Millennium Experience Company got its dome cash.
fields.body:
Bob Ayling's fate was sealed when he went cap in hand once again to the millennium commission for a further £38.6m to bail out the dome. The body, chaired by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, had already pumped £509m of lottery money into the Greenwich white elephant and its patience had run out. Agreeing a £29m lifeline to stave off bankruptcy, the commission demanded their man before the New Millennium Experience Company got its dome cash.

"There were a lot of angry people being asked to come up with the money once again," claimed a commission insider. "It was the straw that broke the camel's back."

Mr Ayling, 53, is destined to be remembered as the high flyer who fell to earth. Twice. In two months.

Crash number one was in March when Britain's favourite airline dispensed with the services of one of Labour's favourite businessmen as British Airways headed for a 98% cut in profits. Crash number two was the loss of his post as chairman of the dome, a post admirers insisted he enjoyed and critics claimed would earn him a knighthood or even peerage. After failing twice, even a party notorious for rewarding its cronies may now be forced to think twice before adding his name to the honours list.

History has a way of repeating itself and the "resign or be sacked" ultimatum presented to Mr Ayling on Monday - withdrawn last night as a last minute face-saving measure - will have had a familiar ring. Only last February he issued the same threat to Jennie Page, the dome's chief executive, when he orchestrated a coup to bring in the previously obscure Pierre-Yves Gerbeau as the project's saviour.

The captain of industry appears not to have seen the axe coming and had been upbeat last Wednesday when he chose the dome to make his first public appearance since his BA departure.

In jovial mood, he told guests at an airline industry lunch beneath the huge structure that he'd bought a boat the day before and had "several irons in the fire". Describing how he enjoyed travelling to Greenwich on the Jubilee line extension, he boasted the complex was "one of the most popular events in the world".

A diner said last night: "I'm convinced he didn't know he was going to be sacked. He had the air of a man back on the way up, not one thinking he was going to get fired."

Mr Ayling picked up the poisoned chalice that is the dome in February 1997 when he was handed the unpaid chairmanship of the New Millennium Experience Company by Roger Freeman, the Tory cabinet office minister.

Admired by Tony Blair, who at one point hoped he would stand as mayor of London, and so close a friend of Jack Straw he threw a joint 50th birthday party with the home secretary, New Labour automatically kept him on. The decision now to ditch one of their own suggests how brutal New Labour can be in power.

It is inconceivable the culture secretary would have made the move without consulting Downing Street and Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister who is the government's sole shareholder in the New Millennium Experience Company.

Yet a senior official in the culture department maintained Mr Ayling's resignation was not pre-planned and he was no scapegoat. "It was not to my knowledge discussed beforehand," he said. "The anger was genuinely spontaneous."

The same source insisted the decision was backed by most, if not all, the commission members present at Monday's special meeting, including Michael Heseltine and the writer Simon Jenkins.

Mr Ayling liked to be seen as a man of the people. He would eat in the canteen with other staff both at BA and the dome, greeting employees as if they were long lost friends. When BA moved into a new HQ at Heathrow three years ago, it was cold at first so he wore a jumper. Soon other people started to copy him, creating an informal corporate culture.

The son of a shopkeeper, the young Ayling had to leave fee-paying King's school, Wimbledon, at 16 when his father's business collapsed. He joined a law firm and was a partner by 24 before joining BA to climb swiftly up the airline via the legal department and personnel to chief executive in 1996.

Some in the City considered him a failure and were surprised he lasted so long. Ditching the traditional design of red, white and blue tailfins in favour of "world" colours was a disaster; tie-ups with US airlines another disaster; and a three day dispute in 1997 cost BA £125m. Union negotiators dubbed him "Bob Fayling" and would mock the chief executive behind his back.

Peter Ainsworth, the Tory culture spokesman, said Mr Ayling had been made a fall guy to save ministers.

"I don't think his departure halfway through its life will make any difference," said Mr Ainsworth. "I think that he's been scapegoated and we have seen it before. Lord Falconer is the sole shareholder. Where is he? The government wanted the headlines to be about Ayling and not the money."

Mr Ainsworth could also legitimately ask where is Peter Mandelson, who was instrumental in persuading Mr Blair not to ditch the dome when Labour replaced the Tories? He hoped it would be the greatest show on earth, representing all that was good about Cool Britannia with a spectacular closing ceremony this New Year's Eve forming a springboard to a spring 2001 election.

Mr Smith, always a sceptic who feared it would never be a success, will now go into the next election with plans to channel lottery money to the poor, the sick and children in disarray after once again bailing out the dome.

Asked why, when he was still on top of the world, he lived in the same modest south London home bought a couple of decades ago, Mr Ayling just shrugged. "If I got the sack tomorrow everyone I know who lives nearby would still know me as Bob Ayling. I wouldn't be this bloke that has just got the sack."

The politicians who escaped the blame

Lord Falconer of Thoroton: Cabinet Office minister with responsibility for the dome. However, as a peer he cannot be called to account before the Commons and has so far managed to avoid being tainted by the dome chaos. The hunt by the opposition and Labour backbenchers for a ministerial scapegoat could mean some of the mud finally sticks.

Chris Smith: culture secretary and, as chairman of the millennium commission, the dome's banker. Labour critics argue he has a conflict of interest as both "lender and borrower" to and from the dome - authorising loans from the commission and holding final responsibilty in his departmental role. The bail-outs

 The dome will have cost more than £100 per visitor if 7m visit it this year

 The £29m emergency grant means the total lottery money it has received is £538m - £139m more than planned

The body, chaired by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, had already pumped £509m of lottery money into the Greenwich white elephant and its patience had run out. Agreeing a £29m lifeline to stave off bankruptcy, the commission demanded their man before the New Millennium Experience Company got its dome cash. "There were a lot of angry people being asked to come up with the money once again," claimed a commission insider. "It was the straw that broke the camel's back." Mr Ayling, 53, is destined to be remembered as the high flyer who fell to earth. Twice. In two months. Crash number one was in March when Britain's favourite airline dispensed with the services of one of Labour's favourite businessmen as British Airways headed for a 98% cut in profits. Crash number two was the loss of his post as chairman of the dome, a post admirers insisted he enjoyed and critics claimed would earn him a knighthood or even peerage. After failing twice, even a party notorious for rewarding its cronies may now be forced to think twice before adding his name to the honours list. History has a way of repeating itself and the "resign or be sacked" ultimatum presented to Mr Ayling on Monday - withdrawn last night as a last minute face-saving measure - will have had a familiar ring. Only last February he issued the same threat to Jennie Page, the dome's chief executive, when he orchestrated a coup to bring in the previously obscure Pierre-Yves Gerbeau as the project's saviour. The captain of industry appears not to have seen the axe coming and had been upbeat last Wednesday when he chose the dome to make his first public appearance since his BA departure. In jovial mood, he told guests at an airline industry lunch beneath the huge structure that he'd bought a boat the day before and had "several irons in the fire". Describing how he enjoyed travelling to Greenwich on the Jubilee line extension, he boasted the complex was "one of the most popular events in the world". A diner said last night: "I'm convinced he didn't know he was going to be sacked. He had the air of a man back on the way up, not one thinking he was going to get fired." Admired by Tony Blair, who at one point hoped he would stand as mayor of London, and so close a friend of Jack Straw he threw a joint 50th birthday party with the home secretary, New Labour automatically kept him on. The decision now to ditch one of their own suggests how brutal New Labour can be in power. It is inconceivable the culture secretary would have made the move without consulting Downing Street and Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office minister who is the government's sole shareholder in the New Millennium Experience Company. Yet a senior official in the culture department maintained Mr Ayling's resignation was not pre-planned and he was no scapegoat. "It was not to my knowledge discussed beforehand," he said. "The anger was genuinely spontaneous." The same source insisted the decision was backed by most, if not all, the commission members present at Monday's special meeting, including Michael Heseltine and the writer Simon Jenkins. Mr Ayling liked to be seen as a man of the people. He would eat in the canteen with other staff both at BA and the dome, greeting employees as if they were long lost friends. When BA moved into a new HQ at Heathrow three years ago, it was cold at first so he wore a jumper. Soon other people started to copy him, creating an informal corporate culture. The son of a shopkeeper, the young Ayling had to leave fee-paying King's school, Wimbledon, at 16 when his father's business collapsed. He joined a law firm and was a partner by 24 before joining BA to climb swiftly up the airline via the legal department and personnel to chief executive in 1996. Some in the City considered him a failure and were surprised he lasted so long. Ditching the traditional design of red, white and blue tailfins in favour of "world" colours was a disaster; tie-ups with US airlines another disaster; and a three day dispute in 1997 cost BA £125m. Union negotiators dubbed him "Bob Fayling" and would mock the chief executive behind his back. Peter Ainsworth, the Tory culture spokesman, said Mr Ayling had been made a fall guy to save ministers. "I don't think his departure halfway through its life will make any difference," said Mr Ainsworth. "I think that he's been scapegoated and we have seen it before. Lord Falconer is the sole shareholder. Where is he? The government wanted the headlines to be about Ayling and not the money." Mr Ainsworth could also legitimately ask where is Peter Mandelson, who was instrumental in persuading Mr Blair not to ditch the dome when Labour replaced the Tories? He hoped it would be the greatest show on earth, representing all that was good about Cool Britannia with a spectacular closing ceremony this New Year's Eve forming a springboard to a spring 2001 election. Mr Smith, always a sceptic who feared it would never be a success, will now go into the next election with plans to channel lottery money to the poor, the sick and children in disarray after once again bailing out the dome. Asked why, when he was still on top of the world, he lived in the same modest south London home bought a couple of decades ago, Mr Ayling just shrugged. "If I got the sack tomorrow everyone I know who lives nearby would still know me as Bob Ayling. I wouldn't be this bloke that has just got the sack." The politicians who escaped the blame Lord Falconer of Thoroton: Cabinet Office minister with responsibility for the dome. However, as a peer he cannot be called to account before the Commons and has so far managed to avoid being tainted by the dome chaos. The hunt by the opposition and Labour backbenchers for a ministerial scapegoat could mean some of the mud finally sticks. But he has also avoided blame, largely because he is seen as sceptical about the scheme. Peter Mandelson: formerly in charge of the dome until he quit the cabinet in December 1998. His shedding of dome responsibilty was widely seen as the only silver lining to his fall from grace, and he is likely to fight to repel any suggestion of subsequent taint from the scheme's woes. Still one of the dome's overseers, but - in opposition - will be unlikely to have to suffer flak for the latest crisis. webTitle: Corporate killing law stops short of jail for directors

fields.headline: Corporate killing law stops short of jail for directors
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: Tobacco companies, hospitals and schools are among the 3.5m businesses and other "undertakings" which could be charged with the new offence of corporate killing if implicated in disasters, under proposals unveiled by the home secretary last night.
fields.body:
Tobacco companies, hospitals and schools are among the 3.5m businesses and other "undertakings" which could be charged with the new offence of corporate killing if implicated in disasters, under proposals unveiled by the home secretary last night.

But to the anger of some relatives of victims of recent disasters, Jack Straw has stopped short of jail sentences for individual company directors. Instead, executives will be disqualified from involvement in business, and their companies could pay fines that might run into the millions.

The courts will also be able to order companies to put right the failings leading to disasters, which in some cases could also amount to bills worth billions of pounds.

Ministers intend to finish their consultation on the fine detail of the new offence by September, when they will take a final decision on whether to bring in legislation before the next election.

Last night, ministers said they regarded the creation of the offence, which has the backing of the Institute of Directors and the Trades Union Congress, as having been an "urgent matter". They said the reluctance to introduce criminal penalties for directors was because they did not want to create a "scapegoat culture".

Last night, Mr Straw said the transport disasters of recent years had demonstrated that the present law on corporate manslaughter was undeniably ineffective. "All too often, in the past, organisations have been able to escape liability for errors where if an individual had been responsible they would have been convicted. Our aim is to simplify this area of law and make it more effective and understandable."

Mr Straw said he was going farther than the recommendation of the law commission report in 1994. The offence would cover all "undertakings", including schools, hospital trusts, partnerships and charities, and all other organisations with staff, rather than just "incorporated companies".

However, Mr Straw confirmed that the police, the army and some other groups would be exceptions, getting crown immunity from prosecutions under the offence. But if evidence existed, firms such as tobacco companies, could face action under a new "corporate killing" law.

Ministers have also decided that, besides the crown prosecution service, the health and safety executive, and the civil aviation authority should be allowed to investigate and prosecute in corporate killing cases.

But it is the question of how far firms' directors can be responsible for the collective management failures of their organisations - in cases that involve the loss of life - which forms the most controversial proposal in the consultation paper published yesterday.

Mr Straw said he would consider extending the law to include criminal sanctions against individual, named directors, but only as part of a separate charge from corporate killing and only in cases where there was direct evidence implicating the person.

The Labour MP Andrew Dismore, who was a lawyer for relatives of victims of the King's Cross fire, said that he welcomed the home secretary's proposals as a good first step but added that it was "only by putting the senior people in court" that safety issues would be taken seriously by company directors. He added: "They should have imprisonment and heavy fines."

David Bergman, director of the Centre for Corporate Accountability, warned that failing to make directors personally responsible would make it easy for them to wriggle out of responsibility.

But relatives of the 32 who died in the Paddington rail crash last October welcomed yesterday's proposals. "We have not seen all the details, but we welcome anything that makes it easier to prosecute company directors and companies," said Eileen and Geoff Wood, whose son Simon, 40, died in the train crash.

Disasters that led to change

 The Herald of Free Enterprise sinking, March 6, 1987. The inquest jury returned verdicts of unlawful killing in 187 cases.

 The King's Cross fire, November 18, 1987, in which 31 people died. London Underground was criticised for not guarding against the unpredictability of the fire.

 The Clapham rail crash, December 12, 1988; 35 deaths and nearly 500 injuries.

 The Southall rail crash, September 19, 1997; seven deaths and 151 injuries. In July 1999 Great Western Trains (GWT) pleaded guilty to failing to ensure that the public were not exposed to risks to their health and safety.
