fields.headline: Hague pledges £5-£10 rise in pension
fields.standfirst:
Hague pledges pension rise

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will today step up his populist campaign to exploit Labour's mid-term blues when he promises disaffected pensioners immediate increases of up to £10 a week - on top of whatever Gordon Brown produces before the election.
fields.body:
William Hague will today step up his populist campaign to exploit Labour's mid-term blues when he promises disaffected pensioners immediate increases of up to £10 a week - on top of whatever Gordon Brown produces before the election.

In a calculated attempt to cash in on widely documented anger among "grey power" voters at the "miserly" 75p increase which the Treasury's inflation index awarded them last month, the Conservative leader will also stir up pensioners' suspicions that they are not very important in Tony Blair's system of values.

In a speech at the Bankside conference centre in London, Mr Hague will mark a shift towards a wider offensive on social policy - health, education, transport and pensions - by telling pensioners they are the "unwanted, unwelcome and uncool guests at New Labour's banquet."

While ministers manoeuvre to raise basic pensions by between £3 and £5 a year before polling day, Mr Hague will promise £5.50 a week to single pensioners between 65 and 75, £7 to couples under 75, £7.50 to widows and widowers over 75 and £10 to couples over 75, of whom there are relatively few.

Evidently stung by Labour accusations that he is a reckless "tax cut and spend" politician, the Tory leader will lay out in detail the £2bn worth of savings he will make in the pensions budget to finance his plans, including an end to the £150 winter fuel allowance and the free TV licence for older pensioners.

Mr Hague's move reflects months of work by David "Two Brains" Willetts, his social security spokesman, as well as his own determination to find the government's weak spots - crime, asylum and now pensioner anger - and exploit them.

More benefit initiatives are expected this summer. "This is just the start," said one Tory insider.

"Pensioners will be better off under the Conservatives," Mr Hague will assure them. A mixture of anecdotal evidence, private polling and focus groups confirm what Labour MPs know only too well: one reason for the government's poor performance in this month's local elections was pensioner resentment over the 75p increase.

Ironically, Mr Brown's approach to pensioners, concentrating on the poorest - mainly those over 75 - is the one Mr Hague and Mr Willetts also favour.

"Targeting" is also costlier than across-the-board payments to retired dukes as well as dustmen.

But the Tories claim pensioners resent that policy being undermined by across-the-board payments for specific purposes, the £150 fuel allowance, which is tax-free and the TV licence waiver.

"They hate gimmicks, stunts and bureaucracy," one Tory official said last night.

Labour as well as Tory pensioners feel excluded by Blairism.

They resent "young country" rhetoric as well as jibes about the "forces of conservatism", the Tories say.

A series of opinion polls, including the Guardian/ICM poll, have shown the Tories closing the gap on Labour by 4-5% since they banged the law and order drum last month.

Though Mr Hague claimed his plans would have no serious impact on public spending, Labour last night predicted they would leave many pensioners far worse off. Mr Hague would claw back £1bn on the fuel allowance, £360m on TV licence fees, £120m on scrapping the Christmas bonus, and £40m on bureaucratic "savings".

In another controversial move, he would also take £90m from the £600m a year social fund which lends benefit recipients money for emergency furniture and bedding. The Tories would save a similar sum by dropping Mr Brown's New Deal for lone parents, which they say is useless at getting women into work.

webTitle: TV actor takes Labour to task

fields.headline: TV actor takes Labour to task
fields.standfirst:
Blackadder's Baldrick wins grassroots seat on party's national executive committee and lays into Millbank's 'dinosaur tendency'
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Robinson - Baldrick in the TV comedy series Blackadder and a Labour activist for 20 years - was yesterday catapulted on to Labour's national executive committee, and promptly denounced the instinctive control freaks threatening party democracy.
fields.body:
Tony Robinson - Baldrick in the TV comedy series Blackadder and a Labour activist for 20 years - was yesterday catapulted on to Labour's national executive committee, and promptly denounced the instinctive control freaks threatening party democracy.

He said a section of the party leadership was repeatedly shooting itself in the foot and described them as old timers, dinosaurs and forces for conservatism.

Mr Robinson's election, topping the poll on a very low turnout, and his remarks suggest Millbank will have to rethink its strategy towards its party activists.

The editor of Tribune, Mark Seddon lost his seat, but many of the newly elected NEC members are far from Blairite clones.

Apart from Mr Robinson, the party membership also elected Ruth Turner, founder of the northern edition of the Big Issue, and Ann Black, an Oxford activist who has been fighting ,and so far failing, at the party policy forum, to restore the earnings link for pensions.

Shahid Malik, a 34-year-old Asian community worker and the first elected member of the Commission for Racial Equality, was also elected.

Mr Malik told the leadership yesterday that they "were in danger of taking the ethnic minority vote for granted and seeing its instinctive support ebbing away".

Lord (Tom) Sawyer, former party general secretary, came second in the poll, but he too in recent weeks has been warning Downign Street that it is danger of losing contact with the rank and file.

The low turnout in the poll, probably half the average figure for recent years, may reflect a wider disillusionment in the party, or a belated recognitition that the NEC is no longer the important power base of the past.

However, Ms Black said she had also been inundated by party members complaining they had not received ballot papers, or had not been aware the papers had been slipped inside the party's free magazine.

Mr Robinson launched an attack on those on the NEC who had "shot the party in the foot" over internal elections.

He said that the decision on the NEC by seven votes to five to block the chairman of the National Organisation of Labour Students, Joe Goldberg, from standing again epitomised a mentality that had to stop.

He said: "The Labour party has done reasonably well in balancing on the one hand radical polices of redistribution with economic prudence. We have a good story to tell, but we keep shooting ourselves in the foot about internal elections. Once again the Dinosaur Tendency at Millbank has manouevred to ensure there is no contest. These diehards on the NEC are doing everything possible to make themselves just the kind of forces of conservativsim that Tony Blair said Labour was organised agains. To stop this mentality is the single thing I most want to achieve".

Ms Black, secretary of the Oxford East branch, told the leadership: "Stop making unnecessary enemies. They treat their natural friends like nurses, teachers and Guardian readers as if they need to be gratuitously offended.

"It' s not a policy problem. It's an attitude problem. About 5% of the party are oppositionalist, but the party leadership treats anyone who disagrees as out of bounds."

Tony Robinson , 43,526 Tom Sawyer , 35,015 Shahid Malik , 33,118 Ruth Turne r, 32,729 Mark Seddon , 32,502 Ann Black , 31,484 Christine Shawcrof t, 30,487

Valerie Vaz , 29,754 Pete Willsman , 27,974 Delyth Morgan , 25,274 Rosina McCrae , 23,835 Valerie Price , 19,237

The six elected, according to the rules that there must be at least three women elected, were: Tony Robinson,Tom Sawyer, Shahid Malik, Ruth Turner, Ann Black, and Christine Shawcroft

In the MPs/MEPs sections Clive Soley, Helen Jackson, and Dennis Skinner were elected unopposed. Margaret Prosser was elected as treasurer unopposed.

webTitle: Grade tipped to take over Dome as Ayling quits amid scapegoat claims

fields.headline: Grade tipped to take over Dome as Ayling quits amid scapegoat claims
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Bob Ayling resigned as chairman of the Millennium Dome company last night after a heated three-hour board meeting which left directors claiming that the former BA chief executive had been made a scapegoat to protect ministers' reputations.
fields.body:
Bob Ayling resigned as chairman of the Millennium Dome company last night after a heated three-hour board meeting which left directors claiming that the former BA chief executive had been made a scapegoat to protect ministers' reputations.

His allies refused to let him step down until the Millennium Commission lifted its demand that he should do so as a condition of its £29m emergency handout from National Lottery funds.

Opposition parties and Labour backbenchers called for ministers to take some responsibility for the crisis, while the government tried to distance itself from the turmoil.

As the political row intensified, directors of the New Millennium Experience company at yesterday's meeting resisted pressure to accept their chair man's offered resignation until, after telephone calls to Chris Smith, the culture secretary and commission chairman, the gun was removed from Mr Ayling's head.

The dome minister, Lord Falconer, who attended the meeting, said: "Bob decided to resign in the best interests of the dome." He added: "Bob's contribution to the dome has been second to none. But he has made a judgment. He has made a selfless decision."

webTitle: Sidelined committee still provides vital voice for activists

fields.headline: Sidelined committee still provides vital voice for activists
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's national executive committee is probably less influential in the councils of the Labour government than at any time since its formation in 1918. Nevertheless, as yesterday's often impassioned inquest on the local and mayoral elections demonstrated, it still has an important political role as a platform for party activists and trade unions leaders.
fields.body:
Labour's national executive committee is probably less influential in the councils of the Labour government than at any time since its formation in 1918. Nevertheless, as yesterday's often impassioned inquest on the local and mayoral elections demonstrated, it still has an important political role as a platform for party activists and trade unions leaders.

Yesterday the meeting heard the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, confess: "I bloody hate proportional representation," and also complain: "We have set up all these institutions to strengthen the Liberals and other parties like the Greens. We have given up power we fought to retain."

Following a presentation by party pollsters, Mr Prescott also frankly told the 90-minute inquest that pensioners had been alienated by the small rise in the basic pension. Dennis Skinner called for an immediate £5 a week rise whilst the local government unions protested at the continuance of competitive tendering for contracts.

Yesterday's meeting also revealed a recognition that party activists matter. Mr Prescott warned: "We need to get the activists back," as the meeting heard repeated accounts of activists refusing to turn out to campaign.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, the most senior figure in Labour local government, also told the meeting that councillors were the lifeblood of the party, and the leadership needed to show greater respect for local government.

Ian McCartney, the Cabinet Office minister and Prescott ally, said party activists needed revitalising with a "delivery" card outlining the Labour government's achievements so far, on the lines of the five early pledges card employed during the 1997 general election.

Mark Seddon, ironically thrown off the NEC yesterday, said he believed the rank and file may have finally persuaded the leadership to listen.

He said: "We've almost got there, but it has been two and a half wasted years with the leadership knocking people off, block ing people when their face didn't fit and generally letting the control freak charge stick.But I think they are finally starting to listen.

"They realise there have got to be one member one vote elections for city mayors." He predicted the party would abandon or dilute plans to abolish general committees, the main decision making body of local constituencies.

Yet For the past five years the future of the NEC has been in the balance as power and ihnfluence ebbed away. The era when a gaggle of journalists waited all day outside the party headquarters to hear news of a ignominious leadership defeat has long gone.

In the eighties, staff surrounding the Labour leader Neil Kinnock were dedicated exclusively to squaring difficult NEC votes.

Partly through the work of Charles Clarke, his then chief of staff, Mr Kinnock started regularly winning votes until a rump of Dennis Skinner and Diane Abbot were left seconding each other's motions.

Now the machine purrs pretty smoothly, and cliffhanging votes are as rare as in the heyday of Stalin's politburo.

A series of reforms, engineered by Mr Kinnock and the then party general secretary Lord Sawyer, has removed policy making from discordant NEC sub-committees to joint policy commissions in which NEC and MPs share power.

In practice, however, government ministers, aided by Millbank officials, tend to dominate on the joint policy commission.

The more informal behind closed doors biannual policy forum has not yet led to vigorous internal debate. The NEC's status has also been reduced by fewer meetings and the banning of MPs from standing for the constitruency section.

Previously the annual poll for the constituency section became the only serious barometer of party membership opinion, as well as a beauty contest for Labour politicians. Figures like Gordon Brown, Tony Blair, Jack Straw and Peter Mandelson all saw a seat on the NEC as a necessary stepping stone to high shadow cabinet office.

webTitle: Home Office reduces family visit bond

fields.headline: Home Office reduces family visit bond
fields.trailText: The scale of Jack Straw's climbdown over the plan to impose immigration "bonds" on visa applicants who want to visit relatives in Britain became clear last night when the Home Office said it was pressing ahead with a trial scheme for visitors from the Philippines and Morocco only.
fields.body:
The scale of Jack Straw's climbdown over the plan to impose immigration "bonds" on visa applicants who want to visit relatives in Britain became clear last night when the Home Office said it was pressing ahead with a trial scheme for visitors from the Philippines and Morocco only.

The bonds were to have been introduced for the hundreds of thousands of people from the Indian sub-continent who visit Britain each year for weddings, funerals and other events on family visit visas.

The idea was put forward by Indian organisations as an alternative for those refused visas because entry clearance officers suspected they would not leave Britain at the end of their family visit.

It was proposed that the family members in Britain would put up a cash payment in advance of the visit which would be returned when the visitor left the country. Initial reports that the bond was to be fixed at £10,000 stirred fierce opposition to the scheme.

Last night the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said in a Commons written answer that the bond would be set at £3,000.

"The pilot study on financial bonds will begin in October at two posts overseas, Manila and Casablanca," she said. "It will run for six months, followed by a further six months to monitor departure from the United Kingdom, and a further, brief period for analysis of the results."

It would be used in borderline cases: as an alternative to refusing a family visit visa if the applicant's intention to leave the UK was in doubt.

The latest figures show that in 1998 1,500 people were refused a family visit visa at the embassy in Manila and 350 in Casablanca.

A financial bond is expected to be used in only a small proportion of such cases.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Straw's brother remanded
fields.body:
Straw's brother remanded

William Straw, brother of the home secretary, yesterday appeared in court accused of indecently assaulting a 16-year-old girl. Straw, 47, of Bramcote, Nottingham, was remanded on conditional bail by magistrates in Nottingham until June 20. Straw is already facing a charge of common assault against a different 16-year-old girl.

Elegant explanation

The Elegant Universe, a bestseller by American professor Brian Greene, received the £10,000 Aventis science book prize in London last night. The book deals with string theory, which sees all matter as ultimately composed of loops of energy a billion billion times smaller than an atom, rooted in a universe which began with 11 dimensions.

University pay gap widens

The university pay gap between men and women is getting wider, an Association of University Teachers survey shows today. Male academic staff in 1998-99 earned on average 18% more than their female colleagues -an increase of 1% on the previous 12 months.

fields.headline: Oasis star quits world tour
fields.trailText: The future of the rock band Oasis looked precarious last night after Noel Gallagher, its songwriter and driving force, pulled out of its overseas tour amid rumours of a rift with his brother Liam.
fields.body:
The future of the rock band Oasis looked precarious last night after Noel Gallagher, its songwriter and driving force, pulled out of its overseas tour amid rumours of a rift with his brother Liam.

Gallagher is refusing to do the remaining 27 gigs of the world tour, which began in February, causing four, including a gig in Paris last night, to be cancelled while a replacement guitarist is given time to rehearse. He will rejoin the band for the final eight sell-out dates in Britain in July and August, which include two shows at Wembley and the Reading and Leeds festivals.

With the brothers' notorious rivalry coming to the fore once more, these gigs could be the band's last shows. The departure - which the band's management company, Ignition, was quick to insist was only temporary - came as no surprise to the pop world, which was once fascinated but is now jaded with the relentless bust-ups of the two Gallaghers.

On the band's first tour to Japan and America, Noel had walked out threatening to quit, then did so in 1995 after a drunken Liam attacked him. Liam then missed a recording for MTV, and, in 1996, Noel returned to the UK early during a US tour after yet another rift.

But this time the split - which will see the band out of action until next Tuesday's gig in Milan - looks more serious, according to those who have followed each twist and turn of the brothers' love/hate relationship. First, the decision appears to be calculated since the stand-in guitarist, Matt Deighton, is already found, according to Ben Knowles, editor of NME music magazine.

It seems, after seven years in Britain's most successful Britpop band, Noel, now 33, has had enough of touring. The critical panning of the group for its album Standing on the Shoulder of Giants is unlikely to have renewed his enthusiasm, nor is the departure of original band members Paul "Bonehead" Arthurs and Paul "Guigsy" McGuigan.

Noel is also said to be frustrated with his younger brother's adherence to the rock 'n' roll lifestyle. This year he said: "I'm not 'mad for it' any more. On the other hand, Liam's mad for it." Unlike his 26-year-old sibling who apparently fell "off the wagon heavily once more", Noel has renounced drugs.

webTitle: Lib Dem warning on waste burners

fields.headline: Lib Dem warning on waste burners
fields.standfirst: Landfill tax scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher, the environment minister, came under fresh pressure yesterday to abandon plans to build more waste incinerators as part of the government's new strategy to be announced tomorrow.
fields.body:
Michael Meacher, the environment minister, came under fresh pressure yesterday to abandon plans to build more waste incinerators as part of the government's new strategy to be announced tomorrow.

Days after the Tories pledged a moratorium on new incinerators the Liberal Democrats promised to cut landfill dumping, and eventually abolish it altogether. Tom Brake, the party's environment spokes-man, accused Mr Meacher of being " too timid" in his support for recycling.

Lib Dems are worried at a leaked report by the US environmental protection agency, warning of a cancer link to new incinerators from dioxins. The party wants a huge increase in waste recycling and re-use, and a cut in the amount of rubbish sent to landfill sites- responsible for disposing of 70% of waste - which they would scrap altogether within 40 years.

fields.headline: Choked Capri bans tourist cars
fields.trailText: Capri and other resort islands off Naples have decided to try to end traffic chaos by banning visitors with cars. Summer hordes will have to leave their vehicles on mainland Italy if they are to tour beaches and cliffs which have been eulogised since antiquity.
fields.body:
Capri and other resort islands off Naples have decided to try to end traffic chaos by banning visitors with cars. Summer hordes will have to leave their vehicles on mainland Italy if they are to tour beaches and cliffs which have been eulogised since antiquity.

Gridlock and exhaust fumes will be banished to restore tranquillity and safeguard the islands' future, say the authorities. Thirty five of the islands' 44 communes have decided to impose the immediate ban.

Capri will allow only residents' cars to disembark from ferries. The mayor, Costantino Federico, said he would consider blocking the port if daily visitors exceeded 9,000.

The islands of Ischia, Ponza, Filicudi, Giglio and Vulcano will also ban tourists' cars, or impose severe restrictions. Alicudi, Panarea and Stromboli are to block all cars.

Sassi di Matera, a fabled mountain settlement in southern Italy, set up roadblocks last week to stop traffic that was threatening to crumble its medieval streets.

webTitle: De La Rue banks on e-commerce

fields.headline: De La Rue banks on e-commerce
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Think De La Rue, think bank notes. Oh, and a stake in Camelot, runners, pro tem, of the National Lottery. Well, not any longer or, at least, not only that. Rethink De La Rue, think e-commerce, the internet, UMTS mobile phone services, think encryption, brand protection, secure pre-payment.
fields.body:
Think De La Rue, think bank notes. Oh, and a stake in Camelot, runners, pro tem, of the National Lottery. Well, not any longer or, at least, not only that. Rethink De La Rue, think e-commerce, the internet, UMTS mobile phone services, think encryption, brand protection, secure pre-payment.

Ian Much, chief executive, believes he has written Chapter 1 of New De la Rue with that purge of the banknotes and cash systems businesses and is now busy on Chapter 2: "top-line sales growth" through new, web-related, products.

The global services division, headed by Chris Chadwick is the catalyst for growth and yesterday's annual results showed sales of new products up 20%. Roll out the third generation mobile phones and De la Rue will provide a more modern, secure method of pre-payment.

"Instead of a piece of paper you scratch and punch in a code, it will be based on a technology that will go back to a central point and confirm the payment has been received and then your phone is credited with calls," he said.

Three companies -One2One, Vodafone and Orange - have already signed contracts for this system and Mr Much confidently expects the rest, including BT Cellnet, to follow. But the more than 5m customers who pay for services such as electricity, gas and water through pre-payment cards or self-banking have not been left out of the equation. De La Rue's technology, Mr Much says, offers the same kind of security for the utilities in "a very strong growth area".

Another is brand protection or stopping the counterfeiters robbing established names not only of sales but of their reputation. But, perhaps, the strongest potential comes with encryption or winning "trusted third party" status in providing internet security.

But banknotes, including the unloved euros to be launched in January 2002 and bearing holographics provided by De la Rue, remain a backbone of the group and Mr Much sees them providing half its future earnings, with growth coming from central and latin America, Africa and Asia. That painful purge in this division - and the sale for £200m of its smart card business to a French group - helped turn the group's earnings around last year, enabling it to post a 31.3% rise in pre-tax, pre-exceptional profits to £75m - hailed as a "dramatic improvement" on the previous year when the group was, after exceptionals, £7.4m in the red.

The £200m smart card disposal enabled it to return £103.7m to shareholders and gives it up to £180m for acquisitions. It helped restore De La Rue to market favour, with its shares -electronically traded, of course - closing 27p higher at 325p.

fields.headline: Imagination's 162% surge bucks trend with
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Multi-media group Imagination Technologies - hitherto one of the year's hi-tech Cinderellas - became yesterday a heroine of the sector, with a 162% profits surge helping to hold up a sagging Techmark index in London.
fields.body:
Multi-media group Imagination Technologies - hitherto one of the year's hi-tech Cinderellas - became yesterday a heroine of the sector, with a 162% profits surge helping to hold up a sagging Techmark index in London.

The graphics, video and audio specialist made £4.7m in the year to March 31, from £1.8m in 1998/99, well ahead of the £3.9m that had been expected by City analysts.

Imagination owns the rights to the graphics chip for Sega's games console, and has a strategic partnership with ST Microelectronics of France, with whom it is to launch its first graphics chip for personal computers in June.

Imagination shares fell from an all-time closing price high of 610p in February to about 233p at the start of May on concerns over poor sales of Sega's Dreamcast machine, but yesterday it proved one of the anchors of Techmark, with the shares rising 18.5p to 261p.

Imagination's growth has been powered by the relationship with Sega, but the company expects increasing revenue from the partnership, announced last year, with ST, one of the main providers of chips for PCs. With ST, Imagination is producing chips for television set-top boxes.

It expects its £5m acquisition in March of Ensigma, the audio technology company, to bear fruit. Ensigma makes technology for radio studios, home entertainment systems and voice recognition devices, and is a leader in telephone "voice dialling". Its products are in use by the Ministry of Defence.

Imagination said the ST tie-up and the acquisition of Ensigma helped to broaden its intellectual property base, adding it had its eye on further acquisitions in related areas.

Earnings per share rose by 127% to 2.5p, from 1.1p in 1999.

The graphics, video and audio specialist made £4.7m in the year to March 31, from £1.8m in 1998/99, well ahead of the £3.9m that had been expected by City analysts. Imagination owns the rights to the graphics chip for Sega's games console, and has a strategic partnership with ST Microelectronics of France, with whom it is to launch its first graphics chip for personal computers in June. Imagination shares fell from an all-time closing price high of 610p in February to about 233p at the start of May on concerns over poor sales of Sega's Dreamcast machine, but yesterday it proved one of the anchors of Techmark, with the shares rising 18.5p to 261p. Ensigma makes technology for radio studios, home entertainment systems and voice recognition devices, and is a leader in telephone "voice dialling". Its products are in use by the Ministry of Defence. Imagination said the ST tie-up and the acquisition of Ensigma helped to broaden its intellectual property base, adding it had its eye on further acquisitions in related areas. webTitle: Tories stand up for rail commuters

fields.headline: Tories stand up for rail commuters
fields.standfirst:
Norman unveils pledges on crowding and queues and refunds train firms

Tories in opposition: special report
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Tories yesterday unveiled a series of populist transport policies in a bid to woo back rail commuters exasperated by the decline in standards on Britain's railways since privatisation.
fields.body:
The Tories yesterday unveiled a series of populist transport policies in a bid to woo back rail commuters exasperated by the decline in standards on Britain's railways since privatisation.

Passengers will be guaranteed a refund if they are forced to stand on journeys lasting more than 20 minutes and supermarket-style queueing systems will be installed at railway stations, under proposals announced by the shadow transport secretary, Archie Norman.

Inspired by his experience as head of the Asda supermarket chain, Mr Norman said that privatised rail companies should "wake up" to the demands of customers. "Hardly anywhere do we find the sort of customer focus that characterises the best airlines, hotels or even supermarkets in Britain," he said. His proposals, which are aimed at commuters on the "8.10" from Sevenoaks or Southend, include pledges to:

 Give refunds to passengers who cannot find a seat on journeys lasting longer than 20 minutes. Passengers on crowded trains will also be allowed a free upgrade to first class.

 Remodel railway ticket queuing systems along the lines of Asda checkouts to ensure that passengers are not forced to wait too long. Mr Norman said that Railtrack should follow the example of Asda which constantly monitors its queues to ensure that customers do not waste their time at empty checkouts.

 End the "outdated practice" of running slower services on Sunday unless essential repairs have to be carried out. Mr Norman said there was a 30-year-old culture to run down services on Sundays, often for no good reason.

 A "no service no franchise" guarantee to deprive rail companies of their franchise if they fail to maintain clean trains, meet punctuality targets and ensure the security of passengers. Mr Norman, a former British Rail and Railtrack board member, said it was time to apply the same standards to railways which are applied to other industries. "At Asda if you bought a defective product you would get a refund without any argument," he said.

He said the last Tory government was right to privatise BR which had led to record levels of investment. But he conceded that there were "serious shortcomings".

Labour last night dismissed Mr Norman's announcement. A spokesman said: "This is another example of the Conservatives lashing around making spending pledges without saying where the money will come from. Their no standing guarantee is bound to cost millions. Where will the money come from? It was the Tories who left us with the mess of rail privatisation."

fields.headline: Hague's law
fields.standfirst:
We Tories see our key poll ratings shoot up as the leader hits the public's buttons on crime

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The joke doing the rounds with Tory wags in the Commons tea room is that they are delighted that William Hague has at last adopted a shoot-to-kill policy, they just never believed it would be on the mainland.
fields.body:
The joke doing the rounds with Tory wags in the Commons tea room is that they are delighted that William Hague has at last adopted a shoot-to-kill policy, they just never believed it would be on the mainland.

William Hague is making law and order a central issue in his pre-election campaigning. While his pronouncements have been opportunistic, his strategy is carefully planned. Whether Hague's soundbite, "more PCs, less PC", which appeared in the speech he gave to the assembled copperati last Thursday, is more successful than "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime", remains to be seen. But there is no doubt that Conservative Central Office is quietly satisfied with the results.

The Tories have twin political objectives when it comes to law and order. The first is to make the issue salient again. At the 1997 general election, law and order was actually quite low on the public's agenda. The second is to make sure that they are ahead. Again, at the last election, they were running neck and neck, if not slightly behind.

Private polling by Central Office now shows them to be pulling ahead. More importantly, they are making noticeable headway on this issue, over and above all others. Normally, issues tend to move together, mirroring the general direction in which a political party is moving. But opinion polls show that general Tory support is increasing only marginally, while support on law and order is increasing exceptionally.

Hague has been lucky, but a smart man makes his own luck. One of his major advantages is that, on law and order, it pays to be in opposition.

Any home secretary has to retain a quasi-judicial air about him, not least because of his quasi-judicial role. He (and it has always been a he) simply cannot be too outspoken, lest he himself finds himself in the courts being judicially reviewed. Hague has no such constraints and no need to look over his shoulder.

Some of it may make one feel a little queasy, but it has been effective in boosting the party's morale and allowing Hague to set the agenda. As one former Labour adviser puts it: "Tony Martin is your Dunblane." Never mind the policy, feel the popularity.

Hague has also invented an imaginary opposition to tilt at. Just as Blair alludes to the "forces of conservatism", so Hague now has his "liberal establishment". Like Blair's, Hague's attack has an element of truth to it. There is no doubt that the Home Office, while not perhaps as liberal as before, has an air about it of institutionalised defeatism.

Michael Howard on his first day in office was presented with graphs showing an inexorable rise in crime and told that he would be much happier in the job if he came to terms with the fact that he could do nothing about it. One suspects little has changed. In fact, Howard decided not to accept the status quo. The decision earned him the opprobrium of liberals everywhere, quite possibly cost him the leadership of his party, but it was effective. Howard's mantra was that "prison works". The current mantra, from left and right alike, is that "Howard worked".

Last week, in an obscure debate on an obscure bill designed to curtail the trade in stolen goods in Kent, not one Labour MP challenged Michael Howard's record in cutting crime figures. Indeed, many echoed his approach.

The liberal consensus on crime has disappeared. It is much more difficult to draw a distinction between Labour and the Tories as far as the nitty-gritty of policy is concerned. That is why Hague has cleverly invented one, and is doing his best to attach it as closely as possible to the government.

Hague, then, has the opportunity to maximise political gain from his current position. At present, Britain has a perceived relatively low crime rate, partly because most of our crime is property related, less of it is violent.

At the same time, there is no doubt that police morale is close to hitting rock bottom. Police numbers have been cut, stations have been closed, and recruitment is proving difficult. And it is also the case, that in London at least, there is a burglary epidemic that is set to spiral out of control.

Hague can also learn from the way he has played the issue. He has been light on his feet, and to a certain extent brass-necked in his approach. But an even-handed posture does not get headlines, and now he has an enemy to attack. At the same time, Hague must recognise that he cannot play just one tune.

Attacking the liberal establishment will play well in education, but not in health. And in a recent speech, Hague also acknowledged that he must ensure that he returns to the mainstream issues, in a more mainstream manner.

Going out on a limb gets you noticed. The trick is not to fall off.

Ed Vaizey was a Conservative candidate at the last general election.

fields.headline: Water Industry
fields.trailText: Water company shareholders used to be able to rely upon sparkling double-digit dividend growth. But Ian Byatt, the water industry regulator, has put paid to that.
fields.body:
Water company shareholders used to be able to rely upon sparkling double-digit dividend growth. But Ian Byatt, the water industry regulator, has put paid to that.

The industry's results season, which kicked off yesterday with figures from Thames Water, is expected to be decidedly flat. The companies will be doing their best to hang on to as much of last year's profits as they can to help deal with the problems of the coming years.

They all face swingeing price cuts this year as a result of Mr Byatt's new price regime. They will have to invest heavily if they are to meet the regulator's efficiency targets.

On top of that, there is the huge extra environmental spending programme imposed by the government.

Much of that will have to be funded through borrowings. If the boards continue their past policy of lavish dividend payments, then their pleas of poverty during the price review will be seen as a sham.

Yet if they slash dividends too harshly, they will alarm the capital markets, and borrowing costs will rise. It is a fine calculation.

Certainly, the army of small shareholders who bought into the water companies as income stocks will suffer. Thames, which raised last year's dividend by 9%, turned the screw further on its small shareholders by delaying payment until the next financial year.

Other water companies, which also have large advanced corporation tax sums to recover, may well follow Thames's example.

The regulator and the government have dramatically changed the world in which the companies operate. And further change is afoot. The government is keen to introduce more competition into the industry to create the sort of price cuts seen in the gas and electricity sectors.

British water utilities offer little chance for growth.

Instead the water companies will be looking to their small and varied collection of non-regulated businesses to drive profits forward.

webTitle: Toyota beset by image of the rising son

fields.headline: Toyota beset by image of the rising son
fields.standfirst: Clash between nepotism and meritocracy rocks boardroom
fields.trailText: Shareholders' meetings in Japan are usually orchestrated demonstrations of corporate harmony, notable more for drab ceremony and self-congratulation than high intrigue.
fields.body:
Shareholders' meetings in Japan are usually orchestrated demonstrations of corporate harmony, notable more for drab ceremony and self-congratulation than high intrigue.

But when stockholders and executives of Toyota meet at the company's headquarters next month there is likely to be a buzz at the prospect of corporate confrontation.

The drama is unfolding around Akio Toyoda, eldest son of former company president Shoichiro Toyoda and the latest member of the founding family to be nominated to the Toyota board of directors.

There is no question that he will be voted on to the board at the meeting on June 28, but what happens after that is the focus of intense speculation.

At 43, Akio is young to be taking up such a senior position in Toyota. Commentators say he is being groomed to take over the helm of the world's third-biggest car maker. After all, four members of the Toyoda family have been president in the past.

Akio, who has spent the past year in America as vice-president of a plant in California, makes plain his ambitions. "It is the founding family's mission to keep setting the direction for the company," he said in a recent interview.

Ten years ago his ascent to power would have been a foregone conclusion, but times have changed. Facing a harsher economic climate, Japanese workers are having to justify themselves in terms of talent and results rather than seniority and connections. Questions are being asked about whether Akio's appointment is a step back to Toyota's roots as a provincial family business rather than the image it wants to project as a forward-looking multinational corporation.

The most sceptical critic has been Toyota's chairman, Hiroshi Okuda. "Nepotism just doesn't belong in our future," he told the Wall Street Journal. "Akio-class talents are rolling around all over Toyota, like so many potatoes."

In part, these comments are a sign that the tough-talking Mr Okuda is trying to practise what he has been preaching. As head of Keidanren, Japan's leading business organisation, he has spent much of the past year underlining the need for more meritocracy.

But commentators say his words also reflect frustration at the re-emergence of the Toyoda clan, whose influence he has worked hard to dissipate since 1995, when he become the first non-family member in 30 years to take control of the company.

The last member of the Toyoda clan to take top spot was Tatsuro, Akio's uncle. Nicknamed "Tatsuro the dumb" even before he took the post, he was appointed against all neutral advice and proved a disaster. After he had a stroke struggling to cope with the twin shock of falling market share and a high yen, Mr Okuda was brought in to turn the company round. Cynics said an outsider was chosen only because the Toyoda family did not want to be associated with any job cuts that might have to be made.

Mr Okuda's attempt to dilute the family influence took a step forward last year with the first flotations of Toyota stock in London and New York, a reminder that the company has to meet global standards.

But the chairman has not had it all his own way. Although the Toyoda family owns less than 1% of the shares, it continues to shape the identity of the firm and cast a long shadow over management.

The spinning and weaving business that later branched out into motor vehicles was established in 1918 by Sakichi Toyoda. Successive generations of Toyoda managers have conquered the domestic market and taken on Ford and General Motors, bringing prosperity to an army of workers and dealers. Such is the gratitude that the town near company headquarters was renamed Toyota City.

Today, Toyota employs 183,00 people in 56 factories and its sales exceed the combined output of Ireland and New Zealand. Nonetheless, its heart remains in Toyota City and its head is still largely governed by the founding family. Shoichiro handpicked most of the senior management and he has weekly meetings with Mr Okuda to discuss policy.

"The Toyoda family act as a centripedal force that unites our manufacturing units and sales agents," said a company insider. "Everybody is very aware that the company has grown to its current status thanks to the hard graft of generations of the Toyoda clan."

It is not only Toyota where hereditary succession has such a hold. Corporate dynasties still wield considerable clout in Matsushita, Tokyo Gas, the Jusco supermarket chain and dozens of other big firms. About a third of the country's MPs inherited their seats from parents. Yuko Obuchi, daughter of the recently deceased prime minister, announced yesterday that she plans to run in her father's constituency.

A famous name can work both ways, however, according to Akio Toyoda. "There is a faction friendly to me and a faction which is completely against a founding family member like myself."

Akio has striven to prove his critics wrong, first with a stint outside the company at in vestment banks in London and New York, then by being the first member of the founding family to take the Toyota entrance exam. He has proved himself a no-nonsense manager, abrasive in criticism but willing to take risks with his own money and reputation.

The key to his latest promotion was Toyota's spectacularly successful internet arm, Gazoo.com, which he brought into existence despite opposition from many of the company's executives.

Even so, Akio has always been able to call on help from the highest places. His greatest ally and mentor is Fujio Cho, a Toyoda family loyalist who was appointed as president of the company last year.

"The Toyoda family reasserted itself with Cho, who looks like he will hold the post until a member of the clan is ready to take over," said industry commentator Jim Treece.

Despite Mr Okuda, it is starting to look like family business as usual at Toyota.

webTitle: Shareholders need to know what's in store

fields.headline: Shareholders need to know what's in store
fields.standfirst: M&S dividend cut only a beginning
fields.trailText: A modest cheer for Marks & Spencer's decision to cut the dividend. It may be easier for incoming management to take hard-nosed action but, for all the logic of cutting your coat according to cloth, managements that trim the pay-out to shareholders are taking a risk with investor sentiment.
fields.body:
A modest cheer for Marks & Spencer's decision to cut the dividend. It may be easier for incoming management to take hard-nosed action but, for all the logic of cutting your coat according to cloth, managements that trim the pay-out to shareholders are taking a risk with investor sentiment.

That is especially true for M&S which has a solid base of small shareholders. But if the decision was brave, it was also prudent. Even after cutting the pay-out M&S's retained profits would scarcely buy a house anywhere in the home counties.

For all that, biting the bullet over the dividend is likely to provide the easy part of the management challenge. M&S needs to show precisely how it is going to use the money it has not paid out to shareholders. Worryingly, chairman Luc Vandevelde sounded hazy on this, muttering vaguely about investing for growth. In fact capital expenditure is expected to fall this year.

True management has shown some energy in tackling the problems of an institution where the "venerable" tag has taken on pejorative connotations. It has axed the outdated St Michael brand, given its stores a facelift and slashed the cost of sourcing; albeit at heavy cost to manufacturing industry and, arguably, to its own standing.

But unless Mr Vandevelde and his colleagues can persuade a younger clientele that M&S offers more than frilly knickers and grey polyester pullovers, the outlook does not look promising. Perhaps the dividend cut is a signal that M&S is not expecting to produce profits topping the £1bn mark - as it did in 1997 and 1998 - anytime soon.

Overtaken

The takeover directive's glacial progress through the European Union's political and bureaucratic mechanisms is painful to behold. Though a draft directive was agreed almost a year ago it ran into a road block in the form of an Anglo-Spanish spat over Gibraltar.

Now that that hurdle has been cleared it is the turn of the EU's learned linguists to have their say. Lawyers and language experts are pouring over the text to make sure it is consistent in 11 EU languages. The process is expected to take weeks, if not months.

Little wonder that supporters of Britain's takeover code - voluntary, flexible and quick - are uneasy about a statutory directive from Brussels with the prospect of endless legal challenges and the expense and uncertainties they will involve. It is not as though the new directive is likely to provide better protection for UK investors than the City's existing takeover code.

If that, however, is a battle already lost another is looming. The takeover directive is in grave danger of being overtaken by events. One of its provisions is that companies should fall under the regulations of the country of the stock market on which they are listed, rather than the one in which they are registered. A year ago when the draft legislation was agreed that appeared a rather academic problem. But if any of the mooted mergers between Europe's leading stock markets ever do get off the ground the issue of the country in which a company has its listing will become far more sensitive.

Still no need to start worrying for a while yet. The various exchanges are hardly greased lightening when it comes to the merger stakes.

Worm turns

The flight from hi-tech stocks is already taking its toll. Several planned flotations have been delayed or rethought and the number is growing by the day. Yet there are no guarantees the volatility will fade away, leaving investors ready once again to pay through the nose for anything with dot.com connections.

Nevertheless, every cloud has a silver lining for someone - in this case for the European Central Bank in Frankfurt. The change in stock market sentiment in the US is also changing perceptions towards the dollar. As a result the euro, which has spent most of its life testing fresh lows against the US currency is showing signs of rallying. It may be going a little too far to suggest the foreign exchange market is about to embark on a love affair with the single currency on the back of stock market weakness but the euro is up some 3.5% against the dollar since last week. The worm may have turned.

Mauer strasse

German shareholders seem to be having little difficulty in adapting to Anglo-Saxon style equity culture judging by Volkswagen's annual meeting yesterday. There top management came under fire for the company's rather lacklustre stock market performance. "There is no point in VW just building perfect cars," according to the representative of one shareholder association. The company needs to "construct a perfect share price" too. What's the German for short- termist?

fields.headline: Brighter fortune
fields.standfirst: Volkswagen vows to drive up share price
fields.trailText: Volkswagen said yesterday it would strive to revive its flagging share price with a hefty improvement in earnings this year after shareholders criticised its stock market showing.
fields.body:
Volkswagen said yesterday it would strive to revive its flagging share price with a hefty improvement in earnings this year after shareholders criticised its stock market showing.

The group said that it remained on course to lift earnings and sales this year following strong growth in the first four months of the year. VW's share price hit a three-year low of €42 (£26) in February after its 1999 net profit fell more than 25% to DM1.65bn (£517m).

"With a substantial improvement in earnings relative to 1999, we also intend to drive our share price back up from its currently unsatisfactory low level," VW chief financial officer Bruno Adelt said.

VW, which makes Rolls Royce cars until 2003, said in March it would strive to raise its profits this year by at least 10%. But 20% profit growth was more probable and 30% desirable.

"We feel confirmed in our forecast for the fiscal year 2000 and anticipate considerable increases in sales, turnover and earnings," company chairman said Ferdinand Piech before VW's AGM in Hamburg yesterday.

The company said its unit sales and earnings at the end of April remained on the same positive track as in the first quarter.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The world's biggest drinks company, Diageo , tumbled 47.25p to 547.5p as a report that it wants to buy the US group Bestfoods went down the wrong way. Critics want the company to exit food, rather than expand in it, so it can concentrate on its more profitable beers and spirits.
fields.body:
The world's biggest drinks company, Diageo , tumbled 47.25p to 547.5p as a report that it wants to buy the US group Bestfoods went down the wrong way. Critics want the company to exit food, rather than expand in it, so it can concentrate on its more profitable beers and spirits.

Insiders played down the chances of a deal, suggesting Bestfoods was talking to anybody and everybody. Unilever , another contender for the US company, slipped 1p to 467.25p.

Fears of an apocalypse for technology stocks proved over the top - the market was generally calmer after Monday's slump. The FTSE 100 yo-yoed during the day - but at the close, the FTSE 100 index was 51.3 points easier at 6,086.8, above session lows at 6,026.3, but well be low its early peak at 6,128.5. Volume was moderate, with 1.205bn shares changing hands in 101,461 transactions - Vodafone Airtouch was again the biggest traded stock (141m shares), but M&S also saw large volumes (52m). Vodafone's rise - to nearly 259p - accounted for most of the Footsie's improvement.

Far and away the biggest FTSE percentage gainer was high street retailer Marks & Spencer , up nearly 18% percent at 260p in a sharp recovery from Monday's near 10-year low.

The move came despite a slump in profits and the first dividend cut in the com pany's history, a move analysts took as signalling Britain's biggest clothing retailer might have finally halted its fall from grace.

Barclays jumped 29p to £16.51 on the back of plans for a net push, while dealers squirted life into Lloyds TSB , lifting them 8p to 664p.

It was not all good news in the old economy. British Airways failed to take off - losing 8p at 366.5p, as smaller-than-expected losses failed to lift the shares.

Marconi was up 18p at 771p after announcing further expansion moves, with plans to acquire US data centre, IT Business for $113m.

CSFB has also raised its price target for Marconi to 1,050p in the wake of last week's results, reiterating its "buy" rating.

Tech stocks had a mixed day - BATM saw big gains, rising 292p to £32.92 But other new economy shares fell hard. Celltech Group topped the FTSE 100 fallers list, shedding 80p to 920p, with ARM Holdings close behind, off 34p at 516p, followed by Kingston Telecom, down 19p at 516p, and Colt Telecom, off 57p at 1,805p.

Software group CMG dropped 138p to £33.76 after acquiring a 50.9% stake in SDS Software of Germany for a total of around £9.2m.

webTitle: EMI blames US for lost ground

fields.headline: EMI blames US for lost ground
fields.standfirst: Robbie Williams leads album fightback
fields.trailText: EMI will launch a beefed-up array of new releases this year, including albums from Robbie Williams, the Spice Girls, Radiohead and Sarah Brightman, as it attempts to recapture global market share.
fields.body:
EMI will launch a beefed-up array of new releases this year, including albums from Robbie Williams, the Spice Girls, Radiohead and Sarah Brightman, as it attempts to recapture global market share.

The group's share of the recorded music market slipped from just over 13.2% to 12.5% last year, with the company blaming the US for ground lost where "new main stream pop and R&B underperformed".

Elsewhere it was a different story. EMI saw its market share in Europe rise slightly, while Japan turned in a strong performance thanks to artists such as Utada Hikaru, Tomoyasu Hotei and Dreams Come True.

Overall some 30 EMI albums from artists such as Queen, George Michael, Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and Chemical Brothers sold more than 1m copies.

EMI said yesterday that its fall in global market share was more than accounted for by the decline in the US. It said it had already taken action to bolster its position in the world's biggest music market by adding to resources devoted to recruiting new talent.

"However the time lag between signing and releasing new records means that the benefits have not yet flowed through." One result has already come through, however- the platinum soundtrack Romeo Must Die, featuring Aaliyah.

EMI said that it is forging new relationships to exploit developments in technology; signing agreements with 15 companies with activities ranging from internet sites to live concert webcasting and internet radio channels. It has joined forces with a number of organisations in the music and consumer electronics industries to try to clamp down on piracy. Spending on internet related operations is expected to double to £20m in the current year.

Music publishing had a good year, benefiting from the acquisition of the Windswept Pacific catalogue in the US and from encouraging partnerships such as that between song writer Rob Thomas from Matchbox Twenty and Carlos Santana, which produced the hit Smooth.

Despite the decline in market share for recorded music EMI turned in pretax profits of £245.4m - up just more than 8% on the previous year and at the top end of analysts expectations - on sales which were little changed on the previous year at £2.39bn.

The group's chairman Eric Nicoli described the year as "encouraging and eventful".

"After less than two months of the new fiscal year, trading is on track. Given our stronger recorded music release schedule and the momentum in our music publishing business, I am confident that we will make satisfactory progress in the year ahead."

However analysts at Commerzbank Securities in London said that while EMI had turned in profits in line with expectations, sales had been lower than anticipated.

webTitle: Airbus says A3XX is on course for take-off

fields.headline: Airbus says A3XX is on course for take-off
fields.trailText: Airbus last night denied reports that its plans to build the world's largest airliner, the 900-seat A3XX, had gone off course.
fields.body:
Airbus last night denied reports that its plans to build the world's largest airliner, the 900-seat A3XX, had gone off course.

Doubts were expressed last week when an Airbus supervisory board meeting was cancelled, but chief executive, Noel Forgeard said this was due to "fine tuning of some technical issues".

He insisted the project was still on track to get under way at the turn of the year.

Emirates and Singapore Airlines have already sent letters of intent to the European consortium, expressing interest in 26 aircraft. Airbus director of sales, John Leahy said last night that the company requires 40-50 expressions of interest to go ahead.

Mr Forgeard said he had received four other letters from among the 20 airlines which originally showed interest, as well as two others "which are in the pipeline".

British Airways is among the 20 airlines but has yet to respond.

Mr Forgeard said he began a series of meetings with potential customers in February and "progress has been fast." Among interested customers is a cargo airline.

Mr Forgeard has been instructed by the supervisory board to test the market and he said the potential take-up needed to be well researched before final approval.

webTitle: Grid turns its back on UK

fields.headline: Grid turns its back on UK
fields.trailText: National Grid yesterday undertook further steps to turn its back on the "dead-end" UK utility sector and promote growth overseas by building a trans-Andes telecoms network in Latin America and expanding its presence in the New England power market.
fields.body:
National Grid yesterday undertook further steps to turn its back on the "dead-end" UK utility sector and promote growth overseas by building a trans-Andes telecoms network in Latin America and expanding its presence in the New England power market.

With its British electricity activities increasingly hemmed in by the regulator, Ofgem, the Grid has assembled a £2bn warchest to fund the acquisition of another north American power company - probably on the east coast - after the net £2.9bn it spent on NEES and EUA in New England, with a move likely in the autumn.

Its New England operations, insiders said, are now promis ing a rate of return a third higher than its UK transmission business, with much lower risks, but the group now also wants to ramp up its activities in the high-growth economies of Latin America - Argentina, Brazil and Chile.

This emerged as the Grid, which retains a 36.3% stake in telecoms operator Energis and realised a £1bn gain from selling a 6% tranche earlier this year, announced a rise in pre-exceptional, pre-tax profits from £458.9m to £473.7m.

"Our strategy is on international growth; there is no significant growth in the UK and the economies of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay are growing at 12% a year," Stephen Box, group finance director, said.

Through its 50% stake in In terlige, the Grid has captured 15% of Brazil's national and international long-distance market or 1.2m regular customers. Yesterday it said it had spent £55m for a 30% stake in Chile's Telefonica Manquehue to help fund the Santiago-based group's fibre optic network and a further £60m to develop, with its new Chilean partner and Williams Communications of the US, Southern Cone as provider of a broadband network across Argentina and Chile.

With its residual stake in Energis worth around £2.3bn, the Grid has signalled it will exit the business telecoms operator within three years and the further sale or float of a tranche is likely within the next year to help fund its overseas expansion.

webTitle: The 'Leo effect' may spur radical change in childcare

fields.headline: The 'Leo effect' may spur radical change in childcare
fields.standfirst:
As Tony Blair bonds with his son, other parents await a fairer deal

The TUC
fields.trailText: Hello Leo! In this tiny personage is now vested high hopes of radical change. There is a groundswell of anger about our over-working, brutalising long hours culture and Labour's deliberate weakening of every EU directive aimed at making life bearable for working families.
fields.body:
The world welcomed baby Leo, but few as warmly as those pressing the government to revise its Dickensian policies on work/life balance. By chance the Blair baby has arrived right into the middle of national childcare week and its organisers could hardly contain their grins. In Westminster junior ministers and MPs (all of them women) were nudging one another, gloating and beaming.

Hello Leo! In this tiny personage is now vested high hopes of radical change. There is a groundswell of anger about our over-working, brutalising long hours culture and Labour's deliberate weakening of every EU directive aimed at making life bearable for working families. Not so much New Labour as Hard Labour. Now in the air there hovers the inescapable image of the infant Leo.

It's not that anyone thinks the prime minister has gone soft. Perish the thought. Only last week he went out of his way to promise the CBI that there would be ever less regulation on employers, boasting that Britain's employers are even more lightly regulated than in the United States.

His government is still trying to deny parental leave to the great majority of parents, even as his wife acted in court for the TUC. Yesterday, disgracefully, the government effectively got its way.

Although the judges said the TUC case was "likely to prevail", they still sent the case off to Brussels where it may take two years, by which time many of the disputed parents will have lost their rights as their children will be over five years old: a good example of justice delayed being justice denied.

But whatever his father thinks, Leo's presence will not let the issue to go away. Look at that charming picture of the prime minister taking his parental leave, lolling on a sofa in his casual clothes cooing happily to his baby while his government prevents most other parents doing likewise. It just doesn't look good.

It's another worrying example of how Downing Street is losing its political touch. Obstinacy on parental leave is needless folly when the case could have been gracefully withdrawn with a sincere promise to think again. Why do they bother fighting it so hard when this unpaid parental leave will be taken by very few? Only parents in countries where the leave is paid can afford to take it.

Little Leo will raise other questions. For example, when will his mother go back to work? Will it be as soon as paid maternity is over at 18 weeks, like most women have to, far too soon? Or will it be after the other 11 weeks unpaid which only a few well-off women can afford to take - also too soon?

Then comes childcare. Most families don't and can't afford to pay for childcare. If Leo was lucky enough to get into one of the very few Westminster council nurseries (there are only 117 places in the whole borough for non-special needs children), it would cost £171 a week.

The maximum poor families can claim in childcare tax credits is £70 a week. Although that seemed a huge and generous sum when Gordon Brown gave this first ever significant state help with childcare, alas, it turns out that most childcare now costs between £130-£160 a week. (In London it is even more.)

It may be unfair but there will be no avoiding these comparisons between Leo and other babies. Perhaps it was partly invited in that moving part of last year's prime ministerial party conference speech: "There is no more powerful symbol of our politics than the experience of being on a maternity ward, seeing two babies side by side, delivered by the same doctors and midwives.

"Yet with two totally different lives ahead of them. One returns with his mother to a bed and breakfast that is cold, damp, cramped. A mother who has no job, no family to support her, sadder still - no one to share the joy and triumph of the new baby, a father nowhere to be seen. . . . The second child returns to a prosperous home, grandparents desperate to share the caring and a father with a decent income and an even larger sense of pride."

He called for "strong families cherished by strong communities", and although he was talking mainly about this fine promise to abolish child poverty in 20 years, it takes good, family-friendly policies to support strong families.

Today a Mori poll for national childcare week asks mothers what hinders them returning to work. Three quarters of parents polled said it as lack of affordable childcare. Employers have done virtually nothing to help - only 3% have workplace nurseries, only 5% offer help with costs.

It helps explain why not nearly enough mothers invited to join the New Deal for Lone Parents have taken up the offer. The main point of childcare tax credits was to try to entice the 900,000 single mothers living on benefits into work: so far few have, even in this booming employment market. Although 103,000 families have taken up the credits, they only get an average £33 a week. (Low because they are higher earners so they qualify for less, or because they are only claiming for part-time work).

It was hoped childcare credits would stimulate a whole new market in nurseries and childminders. But in the poorest areas there are virtually none, with no capital to build nurseries and no community organisations to seize the opportunity. Collette Kelleher, director of the Day Care Trust, says many mothers in deprived areas won't work until they have bright, lively local nurseries, staffed with well-trained people.

Many say they don't trust childminders or see no reason to hand their child over to a less good mother. The lottery's new opportunities fund has done well in spreading after-school and holiday clubs around the country, but for the under threes there is very little. A network of state-of-the-art young children's centres, as found in much of Europe, is still an age away.

We await July's spending review. Margaret Jay, Margaret Hodge, Yvette Cooper, Tessa Jowell and many women backbenchers led by Harriet Harman are now arguing fiercely for more childcare and for a radical new focus on the whole work-life agenda.

It was he who tried to whittle part-time workers rights down to almost nothing. But now even he has seen the light and is bidding strongly with the Treasury for paid parental leave to be promised in the next manifesto. It must be the Leo effect.

fields.headline: Refugees pour over frontier
fields.standfirst:
SLA exodus Israel tries to cope with influx of its former allies

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Visitors to the Amnun Beach holiday village do not ordinarily arrive in khaki uniforms reeking of sweat, and with their belongings bundled into a black plastic rubbish bag.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Amnun Beach, northern Israel
fields.body:
Visitors to the Amnun Beach holiday village do not ordinarily arrive in khaki uniforms reeking of sweat, and with their belongings bundled into a black plastic rubbish bag.

And they would usually be more attentive to their idyllic environment - a palm shaded swath on the northern shore of Galilee, just down the road from where Jesus preached his sermon on the mount, and now popular for its wind surfing and pedal boats.

But for the multitudes who fled their villages in southern Lebanon in the last ignominious moments of Israel's 22-year occupation, the resort was just a transit stop on a journey to an uncertain future.

In the new reality emerging in southern Lebanon, the men here are pariahs back home - branded as traitors, facing long prison terms or death for serving in Israel's proxy militia, the South Lebanon Army. Their women and children are guilty by association. All are terrified by the advance of the Hizbullah guerrillas, and the retribution that awaits them if they return.

Their predicament sat oddly with their surroundings. As a Madonna pop song boomed out over the public address system, children who had fled their homes in their pyjamas paddled in the lake, or clambered over the pedal boats beached nearby. There was a minor stampede when Israeli officials began handing out popsicles and plates of fried chicken, but otherwise people just stoically waited to be told their fate.

By noon yesterday, some 1,400 people had washed up on these shores, according to Israeli officials. But as the day wore on, it became evident - despite official claims - that the refugee influx had reached several thousand.

With the Israeli troops on their way out, and the SLA collapsing around them, the villagers realised that they had to save themselves.

"We saw the Israelis leaving and our soldiers resting alone and we knew that they could not defend our territory from the Hizbullah," said Antoinette Hannadik, a teacher from the village of Ayn Ibil.

"If the Hizbullah is not in our village by now, then they will be there tonight, that is for sure."

At several crossing points along the border yesterday, Israeli soldiers were bundling the new arrivals on to buses for the journey south.

At the Biranit crossing alone, soldiers said that 30 coachloads of refugees had entered Israel in the last 24 hours. The traffic at other border points was even higher, although painfully slow, with the refugees waiting for hours in the sun to cross.

The numbers have clearly come as a shock to Israeli officials, who had been insisting gamely that their SLA allies would rather die in south Lebanon than live in a foreign land.

As a handful of Israeli officials began the painfully slow process of registering the refugees and allotting them shelter - apart from the holiday villas - their reluctant hosts tried to make it up to them by promising to enrol their children in summer camps.

For many of their abandoned allies, lounging under palm trees in the rumpled uniforms of the SLA, the chaos was a final indignity.

"For 22 years we have been together and now Israel has just up and left us," said Izzat Gadban, an SLA man with a blue tattoo of a sword occupying most of his forearm, who had fled the village of Meiss ej-Jebel. "Why are we here? Why are five-year-olds driven from their homes?"

webTitle: Soldiers celebrated IRA death with cake

fields.headline: Soldiers celebrated IRA death with cake
fields.standfirst:
Security forces kept memorabilia of shot suspects

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Undercover soldiers in Northern Ireland would celebrate the shooting dead of a terrorist suspect with a cake adorned with the victim's name in icing, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Undercover soldiers in Northern Ireland would celebrate the shooting dead of a terrorist suspect with a cake adorned with the victim's name in icing, it emerged yesterday.

The BBC released a photograph of one of the cakes, in the shape of a cross, baked to mark the SAS killing of the IRA man William Price, 28, in Ardboe, Co Tyrone, 16 years ago. It was marked RIP, with his name and where he died.

The reporter Peter Taylor discovered it when interviewing members of the security forces for Brits, the BBC2 series on the role of intelligence during the troubles. They often kept memorabilia, including snaps of shot suspects, and the cake photo was no big deal to them, he said.

In tonight's episode, a member of 14 Intelligence Company, an undercover army unit, denied there was any shoot to kill policy. Soldiers adhered to the yellow card stipulating when they could legitimately open fire, she said. But they would mark the killing of suspected IRA volunteers.

The woman, identified as Anna, said: "We celebrated, if you like, as the IRA would if they had shot somebody. They made no secret of the fact that they celebrate the death of a soldier or a policeman, and they can be highly public about their celebrations. We celebrated in the same way. We went to the bar. We drank quite a lot. The cooks made us a cake."

She added: "After a shooting occurred, if a terrorist was killed there was a cake made with their name on it, part of the celebration. Some of the cakes were in the form of a cross with RIP on it."

Asked by Taylor whether she thought that macabre, she replied: "Possibly, but the saying is: Live by the sword and die by the sword."

Price was shot four times in July 1984 as the IRA planned an incendiary attack on a factory to coincide with the death of the hunger striker Martin Hurson. The SAS was laying in wait.

Two soldiers told the inquest they had opened fire fearing Price was about to shoot. He was hit in the legs and then in the head as he was in a sitting position.

An IRA statement at the time said Price was scouting a way to the factory with another IRA man, adding: "When they got within 20 yards or so of the bushes, three to four figures rose in front of them, and suddenly the whole place lit up with gunfire. William Price fell moaning. The other volunteer crawled back through the long grass to make his escape.

"From the time William Price was shot and wounded to the time the other volunteer got out of the firing line, the shooting never stopped. Some time after that shooting the other volunteers heard the SAS whooping hysterically like Indians in a wild west film. A good three minutes after the firing, there seemed to be one shot and then a burst of shots."

A private in the parachute regiment said on the programme that he had arrived on the scene after a shootout in Belfast between undercover soldiers and the IRA. It was hard to know who the enemy was. He began dressing the wound of an injured with his own shoulder dressing, reassuring him. The victim was going blue when the private learned he was an IRA man.

The private added: "Without thinking, I took the shoulder dressing off, threw it on the floor, picked up a handful of grass and sod of earth and shoved that where the shoulder dressing had been in his femur, obviously creating a load of pain and alarm." Asked if he had said anything, he replied: "'It looks like you're on the way out, mate,' and that was it. Thought no more of it."

 David Trimble's plan to return to power sharing with Sinn Fein is to be challenged with alternative proposals by opponents in his Ulster Unionist party. They would be put to the party's council before Saturday's crucial vote, said Jeffrey Donaldson, MP for Lagan Valley, and would deal "with the issue of arms and the issue of government".

webTitle: Auto Trader publishers close to joining forces

fields.headline: Auto Trader publishers close to joining forces
fields.trailText: Guardian Media Group and the venture capital firm BC Partners are close to a deal to unite Auto Trader in a group of classified advertising magazines spanning Britain and Europe.
fields.body:
Guardian Media Group and the venture capital firm BC Partners are close to a deal to unite Auto Trader in a group of classified advertising magazines spanning Britain and Europe.

At present, GMG and BC Partners each own a string of regional editions of Auto Trader. They are negotiating to put these together to create a jointly controlled business called Trader Media Group.

The newly created company would include a string of other titles such as Bike Trader, Top Marques and Auto Freeway. With annual profits of more than £60m, it would employ around 3,500 people.

Insiders said yesterday that talks to create Trader Media Group were at an advanced stage. The two sides are keen to pool their resources, ending an arrangement whereby they publish parallel regional titles with a cross-licensing arrangement over the Auto Trader name.

The origins of the existing situation date back around 20 years. GMG started a car advertising magazine at the same time as a rival publication was launched by John Madejski, now the multi-millionaire chairman of Reading football club.

GMG and Mr Madejski each expanded into different areas of the country and eventually agreed to divide the regions between them.

Mr Madejski sold his Auto Trader titles to BC Partners three years ago, reportedly making a fortune of some £170m.

In some regions, GMG and BC Partners already have joint ownership of magazines. Trader Media Group is expected to be owned 50-50 by the two companies.

As a venture capital group, BC Partners is likely to want to sell its interest at some point in the future, possibly to GMG.

Trader Media Group's total portfolio would contain over 790 publications, with a combined weekly circulation of more than 1m. Other interests would include Auto Trader's website, autotrader.co.uk, which is one of the ten most visited retail sites in Britain.

International operations include businesses in Belgium, Holland, Italy and South Africa.

Magazines intended for inclusion in Trader Media Group have more than 200,000 automotive items for sale at any one time, plus 140,000 other items.

GMG's chief executive, Bob Phillis, is likely to be chairman of Trader Media Group with Graham Luff as chief executive.

GMG's businesses include the Guardian, the Observer, the Manchester Evening News and a series of ventures in television and new media. Insiders say GMG is being advised by Lehman Brothers.

BC Partners was formerly part of Barings, the merchant bank.
