fields.headline: Israel leaves its Vietnam
fields.standfirst:
The retreat from south Lebanon has turned into a rout. But Ehud Barak has learned an invaluable lesson

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The general is in retreat. His soldiers have been chased out, their exit not the orderly withdrawal he had wanted but a humiliating, urgent dash for the border. Like the Americans choppered out of Saigon or the Soviets hounded from Afghanistan, Ehud Barak's Israelis are being driven out of Lebanon.
fields.body:
The general is in retreat. His soldiers have been chased out, their exit not the orderly withdrawal he had wanted but a humiliating, urgent dash for the border. Like the Americans choppered out of Saigon or the Soviets hounded from Afghanistan, Ehud Barak's Israelis are being driven out of Lebanon.

Barak, the general-turned-prime-minister, had wanted a stately pullback over several weeks, to be completed by July 7. Instead, he has had to watch the mighty prizefighters of his beloved Israel Defence Force rush to get home in a matter of days - expelled by the 500 or so volunteers of Hizbullah. Lands the Israeli army had ruled for 22 years, they have had to leave in 22 hours.

Israelis will be relieved to be shot of the place: time spent travelling around the country last week told me that much. Lebanon had become their Vietnam, a place where soldiers went to die for a cause no one believed in. That's why the homecoming troops waved their flags, honked their horns and kissed the soil as they returned yesterday. But their relief will be coated with shame: Israel's aura of military invincibility, established since the Yom Kippur war of 1973, has been punctured by the few, but unexpectedly skilled fighters of Hizbullah. It could prove a devastating blow for the Jewish state - and for its leader.

For Ehud Barak is the man who was meant to work miracles. Elected in a landslide one year ago this week, he was hailed as the saviour who would capture the two holy grails of Israeli life: peace and security. As the most-decorated soldier in the country's history - a former commando who had risen to become chief of staff - he promised Israelis would feel safe. But as the leader of the Labour party, he also pledged to be a peacemaker. He would pick up where his mentor, general-turned-politician Yitzhak Rabin, had left off (before his assassination in 1995). Armed with the credibility of his uniform, he would make rapid peace with the Palestinians, the Syrians and the Lebanese; he promised an end to the entire Arab-Israeli conflict within a year. What happened along the way, between that May of hope and this May of humiliation, teaches an unexpected lesson - that war and warmaking is hard, but politics and peacemaking is harder.

Take the current flight from Lebanon. Although the manner of the departure has been forced on Barak, the fact of it has not. On the contrary, a unilateral pullback to Israel's northern borders was one of Barak's key election promises last year. He told Israelis they would quit their "security zone" whether there was a peace deal with Lebanon and its Syrian masters or not. It seemed winningingly simple: vote Barak and what he called the "ongoing tragedy" to the north would be over.

Events have not proved so clearcut. Besides the loss to Israel's prestige, there is a variety of new dangers. The residents of the country's border towns have understood the most obvious threat instantly: with no buffer zone, they are now within staring distance of the Hizbullah guerrillas and their hi-tech weaponry. Their response has been swift: they have got into their cars and headed south. Some suggested that the homes they have left behind should now become military posts, to guard the border and fend off Hizbullah.

But there is a less immediate danger, too. As one of Israel's leading military analysts, Ze'ev Schiff, has argued, the current rout in Lebanon may set a bleak precedent. "In the Arab world, more and more people are saying that the only language Israel understands is the language of force," Schiff wrote in the left-leaning paper, Ha'aretz. Arab leaders used to believe, following the lead set by Egypt in 1979, that only peace treaties would prompt Israel to give up land. But the fighters of Hizbullah in southern Lebanon, like the stonethrowers of the intifada in the West Bank and Gaza before them, have proved that when force is applied, Israeli troops leave - eventually.

Might this explain last week's surge in violence on the West Bank, the worst trouble in four years? Have the Palestinians been inspired by Hizbullah? Moreover, if this is what happens when Barak gives up southern Lebanon - whose loss no Israeli will mourn - then how much harder will it be for him to sell a withdrawal from the fondly-held Golan Heights? Israel's prime minister is willing to return that land to the Syrians: but will his fellow countrymen accept such a move, when it will put yet more Israelis within shooting range of a hostile nation?

What all these questions amount to is the sober lesson Ehud Barak has had a year to draw: that politics is different from soldiering. As a commander, he could give an order and his will would be done. In international diplomacy, nothing is ever so easy.

So he arrived in office wanting a deal with the Syrians, assuming his will and determination would be enough to make it happen. What he has learned is that Damascus does not go in for Damascene conversions; it does not change overnight. Even though a deal on the Golan may seem tantalisingly close, the Syrians are holding it up - by demanding the shoreline of the Sea of Galilee. Progress on the Palestinian track is more hopeful, but the current trouble on the West Bank is a worry: last week Barak told the Israeli delegation at back-channel peace talks with the PLO in Stockholm to fly home.

The problem for the PM is that the world will not bend to his will the way his elite unit once did. He cannot issue an order demanding that Israel instantly absorb the 1m immigrants who have arrived from the former Soviet Union over the past decade. Nor can he heal the rift between Israel's religious and secular Jews simply by uttering a command.

In fact, under Israel's byzantine electoral system, he cannot even make his own government function properly. Cabinet ministers refuse to work together: drawn from minor parties that hate each other he has to spend, he estimates, 80% of his time nudging and cajoling them all just to keep his coalition together. It is frail and could well break up before the year is out: Barak may go back to the country, pleading for a decisive parliamentary mandate to match the personal one he received last year.

So the transition from khaki to Knesset has not been smooth for Ehud Barak. And yet he is such a quietly impressive man. Quoting Kant and Jefferson in interviews, playing his Steinway piano at night, he has somehow turned down the volume of Israeli politics. The hysteria, and corrosive sleaze, of the Netanyahu years has gone. He has replaced it with a hard-headed realism which is prepared to tell Israelis the uncomfortable truth: that they must live within their own, shrunken borders; that they must live in peace with their neighbours, and that they cannot rule over another people. General Barak has fought impossible missions before - and won. Let's hope his greatest victory is still ahead.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: EC clears way for Pfizer deal
fields.body:
EC clears way for Pfizer deal

The European commission said yesterday that it had cleared with conditions a plan by US drug company Pfizer to buy its rival Warner-Lambert.

The takeover will create the biggest pharmaceuticals group in the US and the second largest in the world. The commission said in a statement the companies had agreed to three divestments to address competition concerns on particular markets.

The new group will divest all assets relating to Warner-Lambert's anti-Alzheimer drug Cognex and will out-licence Warner-Lambert's Dilzem drug in Austria. Dilzem is used to treat high blood pressure and angina.

The new group has also agreed to sell all assets for either Pfizer or Warner-Lambert's antihelmintic products - drugs used to destroy worms in the gastro-intestinal tract - in Germany and Austria to third parties.

CBI cites firms' complaints

Firms are being distracted from tackling skills shortages because they have to deal with an increase in employment laws, a leading business group said yesterday.

A Confederation of British Industry survey of more than 800 firms showed that improving skills was a top priority, with many reporting shortages of specialist staff such as engineers and computer workers.

Employers complained they were being distracted by the burden of rising employment legislation.

John Cridland, the CBI's director of human resources policy, said: "Companies are increasingly aware of the need to improve staff skills, but red tape is distracting business from focusing on this and improving productivity."

US may make appeal to Opec

American energy secretary Bill Richardson said yesterday the United States may ask Opec countries at their meeting next month to consider increasing oil production in a bid to lower US energy prices.

Mr Richardson said that there were some fluctuations in the US petrol market that needed to be dealt with. Opec countries are scheduled to meet on June 21 in Vienna to discuss oil production.

Wickes keeps up the fight

Wickes, the home improvement stores chain fighting a £327m bid from rival Focus Do It All, yesterday said one of its largest shareholders was backing its continued independence.

Bill Grimsey, the Wickes chief executive, said Royal and Sun Alliance, which owns 4.2% of the company, had said it would not be accepting the FDIA offer.

webTitle: Anti-GM battle hots up as farmer destroys crop

fields.headline: Anti-GM battle hots up as farmer destroys crop
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: An angry Suffolk farmer yesterday dug up 27 acres of GM contaminated oilseed rape, which he - like more than 500 other farmers - planted after it was imported accidentally because there were no government checks.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, John Vidal  and  Geoffrey Gibbs
fields.body:
An angry Suffolk farmer yesterday dug up 27 acres of GM contaminated oilseed rape, which he - like more than 500 other farmers - planted after it was imported accidentally because there were no government checks.

John Sanderson, who owns a 450 acre mixed arable farm near Harleston, said he was flabbergasted when he learned last week that the seed he had bought contained genetically modified contamination.

He is to re-sow his fields with uncontaminated seeds which he knows he can sell - and take legal advice about gaining compensation for his losses and extra work.

In a separate incident yesterday, 20 anti-GM activists occupied the Ministry of Agriculture's headquarters in central London for several hours, accusing the government of contamination of the countryside.

The contamination, which has resulted in over 30,000 acres being planted with GM seed, centres on supplies produced by Advanta and imported from Canada.

The government was first told on April 17 about the mistake, but did not make it public until a month later. No decision has been made on compensation.

Supermarket chains who use the oil in foods like margarine and biscuits specify their products contain no GM ingredients and will refuse to buy the contaminated crops. The husks go for animal feed which some chains also now want to be GM-free.

Mr Sanderson, 44, said he had been contacted by a seed merchant last week and told that he had been mistakenly sold GM spring seed.

He said that he would be taking legal advice in an attempt to gain compensation for loss of the crop, which he said was worth £5,000.

He said: "It may be that in the future I will decide to grow GM crops. But that has got to be my decision and I will take it if I feel the public is ready for it."

Advanta is understood to have advised UK farmers not to destroy their crops. The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, told MPs there were "no health or environmental risks" following the accidental planting.

Friends of the Earth campaigner Pete Riley said: "This is a brave action by an individual farmer facing company pressure and government indifference. But it is a disgrace that farmers have been put in this position."

Tension between the Welsh assembly and the Department of the Environment in London will come to the boil today when assembly members vote to oppose planting of GM crops in Wales.

The issue is seen by some opposition members as a key test of the assembly's devolved powers and follows uproar over farm trials of GM forage maize in north east Wales.

The GM crop was planted at Sealand, Flintshire, earlier this month in the face of opposition in Cardiff and pleas by the Welsh agriculture secretary, Christine Gwyther, for the trial to be switched to a site in England.

webTitle: Defensive Annan promises more peacekeeping troops

fields.headline: Defensive Annan promises more peacekeeping troops
fields.standfirst:
UN Expanded force to verify withdrawal

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations suffered another setback to its battered credibility yesterday by being caught out by the speed of events in southern Lebanon.
fields.body:
The United Nations suffered another setback to its battered credibility yesterday by being caught out by the speed of events in southern Lebanon.

In spite of repeated warnings from Israel and others in the region, the organisation did not have enough peacekeepers in the area as the situation descended into chaos.

The secretary general, Kofi Annan, pushed emergency measures through the security council yesterday, promising to almost double the UN peacekeeping force.

And he defended his organisation, saying: "You want us to be a punching bag in the middle with everybody taking pot shots at us? And then everybody will blame the UN for everything that we are not responsible for."

Western diplomatic sources expressed sympathy for Mr Annan. One said: "Lebanon is bandit country. What could the UN do unless it has a full, well-trained western force, and it is not going to get that because they are committed in the Balkans."

The UN has 4,515 troops in the area. Mr Annan said reinforcements will be sent to take them up to 5,600. The force will be increased later to 7,900 to confirm the withdrawal and help the Lebanese government in its attempt to regain control over the area.

UN forces would dispatch verification teams, protected by infantry detachments, to confirm the Israeli pullout.

Mr Annan added: "Obviously right now the situation is volatile and dangerous but we will verify and certify full Israeli withdrawal and work with the Lebanese government to restore authority in the region."

He said in his report to the security council that as soon as the UN had verified Israel's withdrawal, the Lebanese government should resume "the normal responsibilities of a state throughout the area".

He added: "The United Nations cannot assume law and order functions which are properly the responsibility of the government."

The report said that Israel must pull out its military forces and civilian personnel from all Lebanese territory, including its airspace and territorial waters. And Mr Annan indicated that without the cooperation of the parties involved, the UN would "not be in a position to carry out its mandated responsibilities".

The US backed Mr Annan's plans, while making it clear it will not be sending troops to the area.

22 years of invasion and retribution

1978
Israel invades Lebanon after Palestinian rocket attacks. UN security council passes resolution calling for pullout

1982
Israel invades again. Massacres of Palestinians at Sabra and Shatila refugee camps by Christian militia

1985
Israel sets up nine mile deep buffer zone

1993
Israeli blitz in response to killing of its soldiers leads to exodus from south Lebanon

1996
Israel unleashes Operation Grapes of Wrath, which results in 170 casualties

1999
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak promises pullout as part of Middle East settlement

May 2000
Israel, which has lost 200 soldiers since 1985, begins pullout ahead of July 1 deadline. Hizbullah, backed by Syria and Iran, moves in. Chaos results as Israel's SLA allies and their families pour into Israel

webTitle: Europe to rule on parental leave

fields.headline: Europe to rule on parental leave
fields.standfirst: The TUC
fields.trailText: Nearly 3m working parents may have to wait up to two years for the right to parental leave, after two senior judges decided yesterday to refer the issue to the European court of justice in Luxembourg.
fields.body:
Nearly 3m working parents may have to wait up to two years for the right to parental leave, after two senior judges decided yesterday to refer the issue to the European court of justice in Luxembourg.

The lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, and Mr Justice Morison, signalled that they believed the decision to limit the right to parents of children born after December 15 1999 breached European law. But they opted to send the case to Luxembourg rather than take the decision themselves.

Unless the Trades Union Congress, which challenged the government's regulations in the high court, appeals successfully to the House of Lords, the case could take up to two years to resolve through Luxembourg's long winded machinery.

The judgment was a victory for the prime minister's wife, Cherie Booth QC, because the judges said her arguments on behalf of the TUC were "likely to prevail" in Luxembourg.

The TUC challenged the regulations, which give parents the right to 13 weeks leave for family responsibilities during a child's first five years, but limit the right to those whose children were born or adopted after the regulations came into effect on December 15 1999.

The TUC argued the European directive on parental leave did not intend that 2.7m parents of children born or adopted before then but still under five would be excluded.

The government argued that the words of the directive, which provide for parental leave "on the grounds of the birth or adoption of a child", mean that the right is triggered once the regulations are in force and a child is subsequently born or adopted.

Ms Booth argued that the words included anyone who had a child up to the age of five at the time the rules came into effect or later.

The judges said that although they believed the TUC's arguments would prevail, the position was not clear enough for them to decide the point without guidance from the Luxembourg court. But they urged the European court to hear the case quickly.

fields.headline: Thames Water justifies deferred dividend
fields.trailText: Thames Water is delaying payment of its final dividend for at least seven months to avoid paying advance corporation tax which it might not recover.
fields.body:
Thames Water is delaying payment of its final dividend for at least seven months to avoid paying advance corporation tax which it might not recover.

It admitted that the move could inconvenience its small shareholders some of whom relied upon the shares for income but said that, with plans to claw back £159m of ACT over the next five years, it would add £44m in shareholder value.

Roger Carr, Thames Water's chairman, said that shareholders would be compensated for the delay with an extra 1.5p a share, lifting the final dividend to 32.7p a share.

Thames also plans to delay payment of the 2001 interim dividend by at least two months. Both delays have yet to be approved by shareholders.

The group yesterday re ported that full year pre-tax profits for the year to March 31 rose from £418.6m to £419.6m.

Operating profits of its regulated British water business rose 3% to £488m while those of its non-regulated businesses jumped 47% to £85m.

webTitle: Sun's deputy to edit News of World

fields.headline: Sun's deputy to edit News of World
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch signalled a change in direction for Britain's biggest-selling newspaper yesterday when News International unexpectedly replaced the editor of the News of the World.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch signalled a change in direction for Britain's biggest-selling newspaper yesterday when News International unexpectedly replaced the editor of the News of the World.

Phil Hall, who has run the paper since 1995, was forced out to make way for Rebekah Wade, who until yesterday was the deputy editor of the Sun, the NoW's daily stablemate.

It is thought that a recent dip in circulation figures was the deciding factor for Mr Murdoch, chairman of the group.

Ms Wade, who at 31 becomes the youngest serving national newspaper editor, has been given a wide brief to rethink the Sunday tabloid: some observers feel the sex-and-celebrities formula has begun to look dated.

At the Sun, she and editor David Yelland have been credited with refreshing the paper and making it more appealing to women. Ms Wade currently chairs the Women in Journalism organisation.

In a statement yesterday, News International said Mr Hall had resigned and "agreed to discuss other roles he might play within the company".

Les Hinton, the executive chairman, paid tribute to Mr Hall, saying he had made a "huge contribution" to running the paper, which had "won numerous awards under his leadership and increased market share against its competitors". He called Ms Wade an "excellent and extremely well-qualified successor".

The move came as a surprise to staff at the NoW. Mr Hall was popular with most staff, but Ms Wade too is well-liked - she was deputy editor of the paper before moving to the Sun two years ago. She is described as dynamic and ambitious, but her relationship with some long-serving staff at the Sun is said to have been tense at first.

It is understood that Ms Wade had indicated to Mr Hinton recently that she wanted to edit her own title, and would leave News International if a post was not available there.

Executives at the company believe the position of Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, is vulnerable following the shares scandal under his leadership, and feared Ms Wade could be poached to succeed him at the helm of the Sun's main rival. Appointing her to the editor's chair at the NoW secures her position in News International.

The NoW has a reputation for breaking agenda-setting stories. Claims of drug-taking forced Lawrence Dallaglio to quit as captain of the England rugby team, and the actor John Alford was jailed after the paper exposed his cocaine dealing.

But its last major exclusive, the claim that Lord Archer persuaded a friend to lie on oath during a libel trial, which cost the former Tory chairman his candidature for the London mayoral election, was in November last year. More recently, the paper has struggled to keep its circulation above 4m.

It was criticised for its role in the trial of Gary Glitter for paying a witness, Alison Brown. The judge said the payments were a "a highly reprehensible state of affairs", and the press complaints commission issued a rebuke. A lenient sentence was passed on the Earl of Hardwicke, after a judge accepted that had he not been entrapped by a NoW reporter into taking cocaine he would not have committed the offence.

Mr Murdoch is said by some to have become fed up of the number of stories about drug-taking by stars. "Rupert is far less surprised that celebrities take cocaine than Phil appears to be," one insider said.

It is thought that Ms Wade's changes will be evolutionary: at the Sun, she changed the way the Page 3 girl was presented, without abolishing the feature. At the NoW, the sex scandal diet may be updated, but not abandoned. "Reporters will still be making their excuses and leaving," another source said.

Ms Wade's position at the Sun is to be filled by Fergus Shanahan, 45, who joined in 1989 as assistant night editor.

Mr Yelland said: "I will miss Rebekah. We worked together for two wonderful years. However, her departure is good news both for her and the company."
fields.bodyText: Rupert Murdoch signalled a change in direction for Britain's biggest-selling newspaper yesterday when News International unexpectedly replaced the editor of the News of the World. Phil Hall, who has run the paper since 1995, was forced out to make way for Rebekah Wade, who until yesterday was the deputy editor of the Sun, the NoW's daily stablemate. It is thought that a recent dip in circulation figures was the deciding factor for Mr Murdoch, chairman of the group. Ms Wade, who at 31 becomes the youngest serving national newspaper editor, has been given a wide brief to rethink the Sunday tabloid: some observers feel the sex-and-celebrities formula has begun to look dated. At the Sun, she and editor David Yelland have been credited with refreshing the paper and making it more appealing to women. Ms Wade currently chairs the Women in Journalism organisation. In a statement yesterday, News International said Mr Hall had resigned and "agreed to discuss other roles he might play within the company". Les Hinton, the executive chairman, paid tribute to Mr Hall, saying he had made a "huge contribution" to running the paper, which had "won numerous awards under his leadership and increased market share against its competitors". He called Ms Wade an "excellent and extremely well-qualified successor". The move came as a surprise to staff at the NoW. Mr Hall was popular with most staff, but Ms Wade too is well-liked - she was deputy editor of the paper before moving to the Sun two years ago. She is described as dynamic and ambitious, but her relationship with some long-serving staff at the Sun is said to have been tense at first. It is understood that Ms Wade had indicated to Mr Hinton recently that she wanted to edit her own title, and would leave News International if a post was not available there. Executives at the company believe the position of Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, is vulnerable following the shares scandal under his leadership, and feared Ms Wade could be poached to succeed him at the helm of the Sun's main rival. Appointing her to the editor's chair at the NoW secures her position in News International. The NoW has a reputation for breaking agenda-setting stories. Claims of drug-taking forced Lawrence Dallaglio to quit as captain of the England rugby team, and the actor John Alford was jailed after the paper exposed his cocaine dealing. But its last major exclusive, the claim that Lord Archer persuaded a friend to lie on oath during a libel trial, which cost the former Tory chairman his candidature for the London mayoral election, was in November last year. More recently, the paper has struggled to keep its circulation above 4m. It was criticised for its role in the trial of Gary Glitter for paying a witness, Alison Brown. The judge said the payments were a "a highly reprehensible state of affairs", and the press complaints commission issued a rebuke. A lenient sentence was passed on the Earl of Hardwicke, after a judge accepted that had he not been entrapped by a NoW reporter into taking cocaine he would not have committed the offence. Mr Murdoch is said by some to have become fed up of the number of stories about drug-taking by stars. "Rupert is far less surprised that celebrities take cocaine than Phil appears to be," one insider said. It is thought that Ms Wade's changes will be evolutionary: at the Sun, she changed the way the Page 3 girl was presented, without abolishing the feature. At the NoW, the sex scandal diet may be updated, but not abandoned. "Reporters will still be making their excuses and leaving," another source said. Ms Wade's position at the Sun is to be filled by Fergus Shanahan, 45, who joined in 1989 as assistant night editor. Mr Yelland said: "I will miss Rebekah. We worked together for two wonderful years. However, her departure is good news both for her and the company."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Macbeth
fields.body:
Macbeth

(Orson Welles, 1948)

4pm, Sky Cinema

A weird and wild tilt at Shakespeare's cautionary tale on the dangers of ambition, as one might expect with Welles as scriptwriter, star and director. It was filmed in three weeks on the cheap, and it shows in the wobbly papier maché scenery; but it is no dull stagebound rendering of the play. With Welles's imagination swirling and John L Russell's dark and shadowy photography, this is the Bard as vivid, if flawed, cinema, acted out by a lusty cast - apart from Jeanette Nolan's wet Lady M.

Delicatessen

(Jean-Jacques Jeunet and Marc Caro, 1991)

12.35am, FilmFour

One of the funniest, weirdest comedies of the 90s: it makes the Coen brothers look like Blake Edwards. The hero is little Dominique Pinon (the disabled space pirate in Jeunet's Alien Resurrection), an out-of-work circus clown who becomes oddjob man at a dismal boarding house, his predecessor having been axed by the cannibalistic butcher (Jean-Claude Dreyfus) downstairs. Amid the monstrous meatiness a touching love blossoms between Pinon and butcher's daughter Marie-Laure Dougnac, and only his circus skills and ultra-veggie group Les Troglodistes can save him from the chop. The visuals are out of Hieronymus Bosch; the stuff of nightmares, and belly-aching laughter too.

Smilla's Feeling For Snow

(Bille August, 1997)

1.45am, Sky Premier

Interesting if ultimately rather disappointing adaptation of Peter Hoeg's bestseller. Julia Ormond is very impressive as Miss Smilla, an alienated woman who starts to find herself while investigating the death of her one friend, a 12-year-old Inuit boy; and with its chilly snowscapes it's always more than watchable, but the story drifts between romance, thriller and Bergmanesque soul searching. The fine cast includes Gabriel Byrne, Richard Harris and Vanessa Redgrave.

fields.headline: Behind the mask
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: "Flaunting, extravagant quean."
fields.body:
"Flaunting, extravagant quean."

- School for Scandal.

The Liberace Show burst on austerity Britain like a Bombe Surprise, at a time when, as Cassandra's son, Robert Connor, now says, "An awful lot of people were making a crust by doing bird impersonations or ventriloquism on the radio." His father's famous counterattack in the Daily Mirror sounds like the machine-gun rattle of an old-fashioned typewriter. I don't think that such a stream of fire power could come from a clackety plastic keyboard.

Cassandra wrote, "He is the summit of sex - the pinnacle of Masculine, Feminine and Neuter. Everything that He, She or It can ever want. This deadly, winking, sniggering, snuggling, chromium-plated, scent-impregnated, luminous, quivering, giggling, fruit-flavoured, mincing, ice-covered heap of mother love is the biggest sentimental vomit of all time."

Perhaps the Daily Mirror lawyers should have pursed their lips at fruit-flavoured, though I doubt if many English lawyers were fluent in American slang in 1956. Liberace sued and the whole show-stopping case turned on his homosexuality. Lying widely through his smile ("Are you a homosexual?" "No, sir" "Have you ever indulged in homosexual practices?" "Never in my life") he won. Cassandra, appropriately, considering his pen name, was not believed.

Reputations (BBC2), a sympathetic exposé, concentrated on Liberace's life-long secrecy about his sexuality and how it was revealed in a macabre last act. As his body was being driven to the Forest Lawn crematorium ("Take me when I'm gorn to Forest Lawn") the Palm Beach coroner ordered it to be returned for an autopsy. Unfortunately, the coroner ("I guess you could say I did enjoy the limelight") was a publicity hound too. Liberace died of Aids.

Bob Monkhouse remembered how hard he worked to be liked. "He walked around the Boreham Wood studios introducing himself to everyone and using a mnemonic system, which was based upon Korinda's Amazing Memory System, in order to memorise their names, and he called everybody by their names and inquired after their children and wives by name. And there were 200 people working there." Four years later he returned and - remembered every name. Monkhouse himself, having a certain sleek similarity to Liberace, used to do a spoof act in which his suit lit up. Liberace, interestingly, advised adding a sequined handbag. Sadly, I suppose, Monkhouse's suit of lights exploded during a bravura performance in the Albert Hall.

There was a thick seam of horror under the surface. Liberace had his young lover's face reshaped to look like him. The young man, now hooked on cocaine, urged Liberace to have a face lift. He said the plastic surgeon drank vodka and sniffed cocaine during the operation and the result was a ghastly mask. Only the smile remained, like someone shrieking behind a sheet.

At the start of Liberace's career, his manager drove him from Beverly Hills to the down-market San Fernando Valley and asked if he could see the difference. There were no TV aerials in Beverly Hills. In the San Fernando Valley they sprouted from every roof like storm-torn umbrellas. "That", he said, "is your audience." Liberace brought a new warmth to TV, winking, twinkling, blowing kisses directly at the one woman watching. Why do I feel Dame Edna was watching?

You will be eager to know woz goin' on in EastEnders (BBC2) Everyone else is. Beppe has found Steve's secret store of speed and is writhing on the floor ("Woz goin' on?") Steve has not been the same man since he whacked Saskia with an ashtray and buried her body in Epping Forest. Steve's sister, Jackie, is in the throes of pre-menstrual tension and battering Beppe's brother with a well-aimed hail of crockery. I particularly admired her backhander with a saucepan, which should have had every English tennis scout on the edge of their seats. Perhaps a coffee shop is not the ideal job for a woman with such a slippery grip on her temper, but you do feel that the Owen siblings have a lot of something to offer. If you could put your finger on it.

Meanwhile, Walford General is in its customary uproar, with Beppe's relations fighting over his bed of pain and one overworked man in a white coat crying "Nurse, can you get them out of here!"

webTitle: Random views: What car breakers watch on television

fields.headline: Random views: What car breakers watch on television
fields.trailText: Max Paignton: "I have never seen a TV show in my life, honest, hahahah. I really haven't. Come on, I'm a gypsy, hahahaha! All right, I might have seen a couple. Which ones? Well there's something. Top Gear? I always miss that, funnily enough. I don't really enjoy the busman's holiday type thing, I'd rather watch something else I know nothing about... I get to see quite a lot of the antiques programmes on Sunday and Car Boot Challenge, because my partner likes antiques and collectibles. Sometimes I bring her back an old gear box or antique chassis but she's not so responsive, hahahah! Nor to my antique overalls and socks."
fields.body:
Max Paignton: "I have never seen a TV show in my life, honest, hahahah. I really haven't. Come on, I'm a gypsy, hahahaha! All right, I might have seen a couple. Which ones? Well there's something. Top Gear? I always miss that, funnily enough. I don't really enjoy the busman's holiday type thing, I'd rather watch something else I know nothing about... I get to see quite a lot of the antiques programmes on Sunday and Car Boot Challenge, because my partner likes antiques and collectibles. Sometimes I bring her back an old gear box or antique chassis but she's not so responsive, hahahah! Nor to my antique overalls and socks."

Mike Jessop: "We have the telly on in the office sometimes and I catch a bit of Trevor McDonald on the news or Kirsty Young or whoever. I always like to check whether any of my kids has been out on the rob on the local news, heheh! I like um, I like a bit of sport, bet they all say that anyway. Which car's yours? Peugeot D-reg? Well you could make an ancient history programme about that, couldn't you, hahahahahah!?"

Raj: Nothing going on TV is there? I liked Ali G but I got bored of that. I prefer to go round my mates' and play Nintendo. Last programme I watched?? Some porn, haahhha! Digital TV. It has its pluses."

Tina Fordsham : "I like the Royle Family and I like EastEnders and I like... anything that's got a bit of drama to it. I quite like our Anthony off the Royle Family, he's very sweet, isn't he? Do you know if he's attached? Do you know who he hangs out with? He looks a bit like my brother, though - that's disturbing isn't it? I quite enjoy the cooking programmes but sometimes I make the mistake of trying them out on my boyfriend - something I've seen on Ready Steady Cook - and they just taste disgusting. I gave him food poisoning with some prawn stir fry. No one in my family knows why I bother. I burn baked beans, I do."

Sin Pattenden spoke to breakers in Tottenham, North London.

fields.headline: Let's dance
fields.standfirst: Youth crazes come and go but the 80s Acid House scene was something different. At least that's what the people who were there reckon, according to a new documentary.  Matthew Collin  revisits the second summer of love
fields.trailText: Youth crazes come and go but the 80s Acid House scene was something different. At least that's what the people who were there reckon, according to a new documentary. Matthew Collin revisits the second summer of love
fields.body:
There comes a time when a youth culture begins to jockey for position in the hit parade of pop cultural history, to prove that it really mattered , and that its legacy will endure. It usually occurs when a pop movement's originators are old enough to have stopped living it full-time and begin looking fondly backwards. Over the past three years, this is exactly what has happened with acid house and Ecstasy culture; a phenomenon which comes to a head this week with the Channel 4 documentary The Chemical Generation.

This is the first televisual attempt to investigate the late-80s origins of the British dance-drug scene, seen through the eyes of those who not only survived it, but thrived on it - the DJs, musicians (such as Boy George), promoters and journalists who constitute what is now called the "dance industry": the legal profiteers from an illicit subculture. The film makes this explicit by shooting them in decidedly upscale locations - trendy cappuccino bars, designer-minimalist kitchens, chic modern British restaurants. Everyone's clothes look much more svelte and expensive than the sweaty rave gear of a decade earlier. Many are tanned and conspicuously affluent. History, it seems, is still written by the winners, while the drop-outs and casualties are cast adrift in time. (At this point I must declare that, as the author of a book on the subject, I also appear as a talking head in the film).

The film cuts straight to the big question: what did it all mean? Most of the answers are decidedly and disappointingly Blairite. Acid house, opine several, unleashed a huge wave of creativity which enabled young people to set up their own small businesses, promoted the reputation of Britain as a cultural beacon to the world, and paved the way for Cool Britannia icons like Oasis and Trainspotting. A more adventurous point is made by Radio 1 DJ Judge Jules, who sees it as a final break with post-war austerity and the last tremble of the stiff upper lip. "British people have the reputation of being the maddest rather than the most boring, tame and conservative", he states.

No one dares to suggest that it in any way "changed the world" - except for establishing a mass recreational drug culture - and even Ken Tappenden, the garrulous Kent policeman who ran the Pay Party Unit responsible for busting raves in the late 80s admits that it probably wasn't as subversive as he once thought. "I wonder whether the amount of [police] time, resources, money that has been ploughed into this has all been worth it", he says wistfully.

Like Justin Kerrigan's big-screen hit Human Traffic, which pictured nightlife as a rite of passage into adulthood with the endless lost weekend as a transformative catalyst, The Chemical Generation positions E culture firmly in the tradition of weekender hedonism dating back to the mods. Little is said about outlaw techno-travellers like Spiral Tribe, who hooked the rave scene into the direct-action eco-protest movement, and nothing about the neo-hippies who imagined acid house as a digitally enhanced continuation of Timothy Leary's psychedelic consciousness-expansion programme.

Jon Reiss's forthcoming film on the US rave scene, Better Living Through Circuitry, does exactly the opposite, featuring a parade of wide-eyed freaks insisting that E culture is a form of spiritual ritual (one even propounds the theory that the Last Supper was a dance party where Jesus and his crew grooved 'til dawn). While they may sound naive, at least they're not cynical. And yet none of these documentaries explores house and techno's roots in black and gay culture, despite token references to the racial unity and sexual tolerance of raves. History is being rewritten and the usual suspects are being left out.

Then there are those who saw raves simply as a way to make some cash. Ecstasy culture, a by-product of Thatcherite on-yer-bike individualism, was always entrepreneurial - mainly on the wrong side of the law. However, as it has become assimilated into the mainstream (even The Sun, which once declared acid house a threat to the morality and health of British youth, now has a regular club-culture column), the breadheads and marketing men have moved in to clean up. Mark Rodol, MD of the Ministry of Sound, states that he provides "civilised raving" in a "safe, well-managed environment". Much as I appreciate his concern for the welfare of his customers, without an element of sheer uncivilised, anarchic abandon, where exactly is the excitement?

How will The Chemical Generation appear to the teenage initiates of today, the pilled-up cyberkids gurning their way through the trance anthems at Gatecrasher, or to the Versace-clad UK garage massive down at Twice As Nice? Will they see acid house as an ancestry to be revered, or just a bunch of old gits blethering on about their golden years? Personally, I hope it is the latter. The most vital youth cultures treat the past with irreverence - as a resource to be sampled and abused at will, to be sacrificed on the altar of the eternal present. History can be inspirational, but it should never be your master.

The Chemical Generation, Saturday, 11.05pm, Channel 4. Matthew Collin is the author of Altered State: The Story Of Ecstasy Culture And Acid House (Serpent's Tail).

webTitle: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge

fields.headline: Court circular: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: In a refreshing change from the usual Mammonite rucks which preoccupy American celebrity, Dana Carvey - best known as artless stoner Garth in Wayne's World - has taken a nobler tack in suing the heart surgeon who, he claims, operated on the wrong artery during his double coronary bypass back in March '98. With the case having finally made its way to San Francisco Superior Court this week, Carvey - who has a family history of high cholesterol - wasted no time in assailing errant medic Elias Hanna, telling the jury "I remember just lying in my bed sobbing. I was absolutely terrified that I was going to have another open-heart surgery operation."
fields.body:
In a refreshing change from the usual Mammonite rucks which preoccupy American celebrity, Dana Carvey - best known as artless stoner Garth in Wayne's World - has taken a nobler tack in suing the heart surgeon who, he claims, operated on the wrong artery during his double coronary bypass back in March '98. With the case having finally made its way to San Francisco Superior Court this week, Carvey - who has a family history of high cholesterol - wasted no time in assailing errant medic Elias Hanna, telling the jury "I remember just lying in my bed sobbing. I was absolutely terrified that I was going to have another open-heart surgery operation."

Having gone under the knife, Carvey then claimed tests by doctors in LA pinpointed the operation as a failure (or, in the words of one, a "goof-up") and a clear-cut case of gross medical negligence. Rather uninspiringly, Hanna's attorneys blamed the botch job on what they described as Carvey's "unusual anatomy" (a statement which raises slightly more questions than it answers). Having been obliged to turn down offers for a TV series and a guest spot on celebrity quiz show Hollywood Squares, Carvey is now seeking $7.5 million in compensation, which rather sends the first sentence here up in smoke...

Meanwhile, regular readers may recall the messy struggle among punk icons the Dead Kennedys , who recently opted to sue their former frontman Jello Biafra over unpaid royalties. Well, it all came out pear-shaped for the hapless vocalist last week, with a San Francisco jury finding he was liable for $220,000 in damages. "This is the ugliest thing that's ever happened to me", wailed Biafra, who claims his erstwhile bandmates acted out of spite after he refused permission for the group's Holiday In Cambodia to be used in a Levi's ad. That's showbiz.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: One of the advantages that apes have over their nearest relations - homo sapiens - is that they do not catch many of our infectious diseases, have far greater resistance to Aids, and are unaffected by various types of cancer.
fields.body:
One of the advantages that apes have over their nearest relations - homo sapiens - is that they do not catch many of our infectious diseases, have far greater resistance to Aids, and are unaffected by various types of cancer. As Peter Evans discovers in Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4), Professor Ajit Varki's team of genetic researchers has established that the simian genome differs by only 1.6 per cent from mankind's. Could these apparently tiny differences suggest new ways of acquiring immunities we now lack?

In Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) Philip Dodd talks to biographer Gitta Sereny about the National Theatre's adaptation of her study of the Nazi leader Albert Speer. The three-hour script, which brings Adolf Hitler and 70 other characters on stage, was written by playwright David Edgar. Sereny admits she was apprehensive about what he might do, having suffered a ghastly Parisian rendition of one of her other books, but seems content with this outcome.

fields.headline: A mumbling experience
fields.standfirst: Adam Sweeting sees the incomparable, incomprehensible Bob Dylan
fields.trailText: Last week in Stockholm, Bob Dylan was presented with the Polar Music Prize, a prestigious award established by Abba's former manager Stig Andersson "for the purpose of awarding persons, groups or institutions that have created something of major importance within the musical field".
fields.body:
Last week in Stockholm, Bob Dylan was presented with the Polar Music Prize, a prestigious award established by Abba's former manager Stig Andersson "for the purpose of awarding persons, groups or institutions that have created something of major importance within the musical field". Dylan joined an illustrious list of recipients, including Stevie Wonder, Bruce Springsteen and Joni Mitchell, not to mention Mstislav Rostropovich and - on the same day as Bob - violinist Isaac Stern.

The citation for Dylan stressed the way he had moved from folk music to rock, "a development that cemented his role as one of the greatest rock artists of our time". It concluded: "Even those who might not have shared his views would find it impossible to argue against Bob Dylan's musical and poetic brilliance."

He has been touring in Europe over the last couple of weeks, and I joined a posse of British reviewers to see one of the early shows in Stuttgart. The city's Hanns Martin Schleyer Halle is an unlovely, soulless prefab velodrome. I'd be surprised if it was even two-thirds full.

Dylan took the stage in an off-white suit and frizzy hair, and promptly led his quartet into a brisk little number called Gambling Man, twisting his left leg rather mincingly to the beat. It was a promising start, and we began to entertain hopes that the show might be on a par with the tough, sinewy performances he delivered in the wake of Time Out of Mind, but it was not to be. It dissipated swiftly into what has become a familiar Dylan ritual, whereby he selects a batch of his best-loved songs and turns them into a scrappy decipher-the-lyric competition. The Times They Are A-Changin' wasn't too difficult, although Bob had adopted the ploy of mumbling almost all the words except for the "They are!!!" part of the chorus. Desolation Row droned on for ages with barely a comprehensible syllable, Gates of Eden would have been brilliant if somebody else had been singing it, and Tangled up in Blue sounded as if it had been wrapped in a blanket and was being held under water. Like a Rolling Stone - despite an impressive surge of power from the band - was sung in a warble which Bob had, perhaps, picked up from some Taiwanese karaoke bar.

Yet there was a little bit of yang to balance against this infuriating yin. Country Pie, one of the most throwaway songs in his catalogue, had been redesigned in a funky triple electric guitar arrangement and sounded remarkably like The Mighty Quinn the way Bob played it with the Band at the Isle of Wight in 1969. Maggie's Farm had been converted into a clattering rockabilly stomp, and I'll Be Your Baby Tonight emerged in a sleek arrangement reminiscent of Bob Wills, the master of Western Swing.

Most significantly, a trio of songs from Time Out of Mind were sung with conspicuously more clarity and attention to detail than the rest of the set. Bob's message seemed to be that he knows he can't evade the obligation to play his old standards, but don't expect him to feign more than a bare minimum of interest. His attention is centred on his newer material, even though he spurned the opportunity to play the excellent Things Have Changed, which he wrote for the soundtrack of the Michael Douglas movie Wonder Boys.

But there's more to a Dylan show than the performance. It's a gathering of the faithful from all over the world and an opportunity to express some lingering solidarity with the ideals that Dylan still supposedly represents. People in top hats and Once Upon a Time In the West-style range-rider overcoats gathered in the foyer to dissect the show and those that had preceded it, sifting intelligence for imminent dissemination on the terrifyingly well-informed Dylan website ExpectingRain www.expectingrain.com

It has always been a part of Dylan's mystique that he does not attempt to explain himself or his songs, and it's partly this that has made him such a fruitful object of speculation among critics, academics and fans. But anything Bob does or says carries its own self-destruct programme. Once, having succumbed to the interview process at the hands of Rolling Stone's Jann Wenner, Dylan cautioned his interrogator, "I might remember it all differently tomorrow."

In the end, though, all we need to know is that Dylan's work endures. To become incurably addicted, any putative new Dylan convert would need only to investigate his output through 1965 and 1966, which encompasses the epic trilogy of Bringing it all Back Home, Highway 61 Revisited and Blonde On Blonde, plus the 1966 Albert Hall live album.

It isn't simply that these records are enough to throw the bulk of current pop into the shade - more that it may make the listener think he or she has stumbled on to some world-shattering scientific formula, so dangerous that it had to be suppressed. The savage wit and cascading imagery that Dylan brought to his breakthrough into rock ensured that these albums still stand as the uncontested skyscrapers of their genre. And probably not even Dylan knows how he did it.

webTitle: This one will run and run

fields.headline: This one will run and run
fields.standfirst: Jem Finer, one-time banjo player with the Pogues, thinks he has created a piece of music that will last 1,000 years.  Mark Espiner reports
fields.trailText: Jem Finer, one-time banjo player with the Pogues, thinks he has created a piece of music that will last 1,000 years.
fields.body:
From an early age musician Jem Finer had what he calls "a recurring daymare". It went like this: if he wanted to record everything that ever happened to him in detail, he would spend his whole life writing down what he was doing, and that would mean he would be writing that he was writing - and then, ultimately, writing that he was writing that he was writing. You might call it infinity anxiety.

Years later, while playing the banjo with punk folk band the Pogues, an idea came to him in the back of the tour bus. It helped him partially resolve his panic. Fed up with the limits of the three-minute songs he was playing, he decided to write something truly long term. He conceived of a piece of music that would play for 1,000 years without repetition. It would be a way to mark every atom of time without having to write it down. He called it Longplayer and set about writing the music and figuring out a way it could be performed continuously for the requisite 365,243 days.

Longplayer struck its first note on millennium midnight and the music is still playing as you read this. Its concert hall is as unorthodox as the piece itself. For the first year of its life it is being performed at the disused Trinity Buoy Wharf Lighthouse on the north bank of the Thames opposite the Millennium Dome. Calling it music, might be stretching a point - the clock-like sounds have no conventional harmony or melody, no discernible rhythm pattern. But Finer insists it was composed "with elements to do with the pure physics of music. I recorded a 20-minute piece of music using metal Tibetan prayer bowls and gongs. You can play them in different ways: you can make them vibrate by drawing a stick around their edge, you can hit them, you can put water in them and bring out new overtones."

He fed a piece of the recorded music into a computer, replicated it six times, then wrote a code (as a pre-Pogue he gained a degree in computing) for the computer to play each sample at a different speed, thus altering the pitch of the sounds. He dictated the pitch shifts to make "arithmetically exact" intervals between the samples. These intervals - octaves, fifths and fourths - are the ones that appear recurrently in folk songs across the world as well as in classical music. "It's impossible to say what people are going to consider music in 200 years or even 20 years, but these harmonic intervals have a resonance," he says.

Sitting up in the lighthouse's old lamp room, surrounded by speakers playing Longplayer's ambient strains, Finer surveys a panorama of post-industrial wasteland, Canary Wharf tower and the dome. With the collar of his donkey jacket turned up, and his earring, he looks the part of a lighthouse keeper.

"I thought it was a bit strange to have a lighthouse on the Thames," he says. "So I did some research. This was never a functioning lighthouse but a place for experiments in optics." Longplayer interrupts him with a jarring sequence of dissonance.

The same piece of metallic music plays against itself at six different speeds. After playing for two minutes, Finer explains, each of the six extracts is instructed to go back almost to its start point. The amount of time between each extract's start and restart points has been strictly defined with the result that the sample playing at the fastest speed will only take four days to complete a full cycle of two-minute episodes, whereas the slowest will take a thousand years to get back to its original start point. So, every second of the piece creates a new moment of music. It isn't infinite, but it's close.

If infinity anxiety spawned the piece, it is performance anxiety that is now driving Finer. What if there were a power cut? What if there were a war or natural disaster? What if the computer crashes?

"The long-term project is to translate it from computer to something else," he says. "Something sustainable - a simple mechanical device." He is thinking of a punch-card system, along the lines of the old pianola rolls, and a trust has been set up to oversee the switch-over. The trust is also investigating sending the sound to a string of obsolete satellites (although its lawyer is, according to Finer, more excited by the copyright issues that a 1,000-year-long piece of music introduces). Finer himself favours the idea of Longplayer occupying its own radio frequency.

Playing opposite Lord Rogers' folly, Longplayer mocks the temporary and limited zones of the Millennium Experience. It marks time like a sonic Stonehenge. There's no real rush to catch it, it will outlive you, but listening to it in that lighthouse somehow makes you a part of its determined beam of sound. "The air is full of sound information," says Finer, "from the radio waves of mobile phones to an exploding star. I like the fact that that's all going on around us. The fact that this piece just exists is reassuring."

You can hear Longplayer at the Trinity Buoy Wharf Lighthouse, London E14, at weekends between 11am and dusk. Admission is free. There is a special family workshop this Monday. To mark the first six months of Longplayer, Artangel is running a series of talks, Keeping Time, exploring issues raised by the project. From June 5. Details and tickets: 020-7336 6803.

fields.headline: Scotland's bout of stupidity
fields.standfirst:
On why Tyson is not a Scottish issue
The real AA Gill
Charlton Heston's last stand
fields.trailText: You have to tread carefully in these pages. It's tempting, for instance, to start a column discussing the current Mike Tyson debate by reminding ourselves what a nasty big bastard he is.
fields.body:
You have to tread carefully in these pages. It's tempting, for instance, to start a column discussing the current Mike Tyson debate by reminding ourselves what a nasty big bastard he is. However, given that this columnist is white, Tyson is black, and lots of people are understandably sensitive about the whole thing, it's simply not on. Tyson's nasty big bastardom apparently is not the point. It's a black issue, a women's issue, a political issue, even a "sport" issue. All correct, of course, so thank heavens for one area where we can still confidently say that Tyson's re-entry into the UK is not an issue at all. It is not a Scottish issue.

You could be forgiven for thinking otherwise if you were sufficiently misguided to take anything as currently volatile and contradictory as a Scottish daily newspaper. The Daily Record, a previously harmless tabloid which mutated horribly under its new recent editorship, has become so repulsive in its warped views that one requires long tongs and a strong stomach to turn its pages.

Such an organ is, of course, making a great play on the fact that it is Scotland that has been slighted, insulted and offended. Not Britain you understand, not rape victims, not black people, not women, not justice, not demoralised immigration officials. No indeed, nothing compares with the wrong done to Scotland by the evil death star of arrogant English administration. Not even a grotesque reference to kind, honourable Frank Bruno when he was described in the press by a certain female columnist who should be killed, resuscitated and killed again, as "a great hulk of a black man equally as capable of violence in the ring who, unlike Tyson, chose not to use it outside". Ah yes, the great hulking black men. All potential rapists, eh? Some just choose not to do what comes naturally.

Offensive? Er, just a bit. But no. None of these offences amounts to anything in the face of Scotland's shame. Straw was blatantly acting contrary to the will of the Scottish people. The Daily Record, for those of you who are not familiar with its peculiarities, has a very special magic power that tells it what the "will of the Scottish people" is without actually having to ask any of us. But this kind of utter pish was not simply confined to the tabloids, where pish resides so happily in its natural habitat. The Scottish Parliament joined in the fray with useful contributions from Alex Salmond, who appeared to believe that the immigration laws in Scotland were somehow different from the rest of the UK and should be put to good use. The New Labour chaps yapped like tiny toy poodles, threatening Blair with the terrifyingly militant prospect of maybe mentioning it next time they see him, if he's not too busy.

Part of me doesn't want to go on, really. It's like telling tales on a friend. Why spoil the main blessing of devolution, namely that all the depressing, low-brow, red-neck nonsense that has surfaced since we innocently voted "yes", has been going on quietly up here, while England irritatingly basks in post-conservatism, confidently regaining a sense of civilisation and decency lost to it for more than two decades. That wasn't supposed to be the way it was going to happen, damn you. You see no one reads the Guardian, the Times or the Telegraph in Scotland, and no one in England reads the Scotsman. Actually, come to think of it, no one in Scotland reads the Scotsman either since Andrew Neil took over, but that's a different story.

It's worth breaching the privacy of our new Scottish stupidity over the Tyson unpleasantness, because the covert misogyny that's at the core of Straw's decision must be highlighted as a national issue. The fact that the location for Tyson's second post-conviction entry to the UK happens to be Scotland is completely irrelevant. The fact that he is being granted a second entry is not. Women in Scotland who are the victims of violence felt the isolation, impotence, misplaced shame and worthlessness over Tyson's Manchester visit in January, just as much as English women in the same sorry condition. There is no border divide between the betrayal of the fragile trust they might have had in the government, a trust they imagined was going to keep them safe from such triumphant and potent symbols as Tyson has become, of how rape can be survived by the rapist if not by the victim.

The dumbing down of Question Time debate is a rather tiresome one. Boy George as an amusing, articulate, one-issue foil to the inarticulate, unamusing, one-issue Brian Souter was rather good TV. Dumbing down can work when it has a point.

More interesting is why journalists agree to appear on the programme. Such exposure involves an enormous risk and one wonders why they take it. Many print journalists who never or rarely broadcast, are strange, cowardly, vain little creatures. They spend a great deal of time at home honing their prose to make themselves appear spontaneously witty and analytical. It's always a shock to meet some personality interviewer who has been consistently vindictive to film stars or footballers and to find that this high court judge of human achievement is a greasy haired psychopath with the personality and talent of loft insulation. The delight in reverse, of course, is when good journalists turn to broadcasting and reveal themselves as thoroughly decent coves. Tony Parsons and Alison Pearson come to mind on the sadly missed Late Review. In their case, television merely revealed more of their articulate, intelligent humanity. But when good writers appear on television and shame themselves it's a little heartbreaking. I always secretly admired AA Gill. He is, of course, horribly cruel, but there's a wit that suggests he doesn't really mean it. For instance, his close pal Jeremy Clarkson pretends to be horrid and hate everyone, but is in fact a perfectly lovely man. One hoped Adrian might the same. So to see Gill on Question Time, teeth bared in a perpetual snarl, a silly public school boy's nervous giggle heralding each new piece of ill-informed, populist thinking, and generally being a thoroughly nasty piece of work, was a crushing disappointment. I'm sure to all the people he's been cruel about it was delicious, but to me it was quite awful. Of course, TV can sometimes lie. But do you know what? It doesn't very often.

I forced my sister-in-law to get me Charlton Heston's autograph when she worked with him recently. Yes I know he's right-wing monster, but let's face it, the man was El Cid, Ben Hur, even Moses, for heaven's sake. I simply wanted to put the bit of paper in Halliwell's under his name, so future browsers would be impressed when they looked him up. So it's irritating that he's growing ever more beastly as the National Rifle Association's front man and is going to be remembered for being an arse instead of parting the Red Sea. Worse still is my reaction when I read that his gun will only be taken away from "cold dead hands". My shame is that despite deploring violence, his invitation strikes me as rather an attractive prospect.

Tyson's nasty big bastardom apparently is not the point. It's a black issue, a women's issue, a political issue, even a "sport" issue. All correct, of course, so thank heavens for one area where we can still confidently say that Tyson's re-entry into the UK is not an issue at all. It is not a Scottish issue. You could be forgiven for thinking otherwise if you were sufficiently misguided to take anything as currently volatile and contradictory as a Scottish daily newspaper. The Daily Record, a previously harmless tabloid which mutated horribly under its new recent editorship, has become so repulsive in its warped views that one requires long tongs and a strong stomach to turn its pages. Such an organ is, of course, making a great play on the fact that it is Scotland that has been slighted, insulted and offended. Not Britain you understand, not rape victims, not black people, not women, not justice, not demoralised immigration officials. No indeed, nothing compares with the wrong done to Scotland by the evil death star of arrogant English administration. Not even a grotesque reference to kind, honourable Frank Bruno when he was described in the press by a certain female columnist who should be killed, resuscitated and killed again, as "a great hulk of a black man equally as capable of violence in the ring who, unlike Tyson, chose not to use it outside". Ah yes, the great hulking black men. All potential rapists, eh? Some just choose not to do what comes naturally. Offensive? Er, just a bit. But no. None of these offences amounts to anything in the face of Scotland's shame. Straw was blatantly acting contrary to the will of the Scottish people. The Daily Record, for those of you who are not familiar with its peculiarities, has a very special magic power that tells it what the "will of the Scottish people" is without actually having to ask any of us. But this kind of utter pish was not simply confined to the tabloids, where pish resides so happily in its natural habitat. The Scottish Parliament joined in the fray with useful contributions from Alex Salmond, who appeared to believe that the immigration laws in Scotland were somehow different from the rest of the UK and should be put to good use. The New Labour chaps yapped like tiny toy poodles, threatening Blair with the terrifyingly militant prospect of maybe mentioning it next time they see him, if he's not too busy. Part of me doesn't want to go on, really. It's like telling tales on a friend. Why spoil the main blessing of devolution, namely that all the depressing, low-brow, red-neck nonsense that has surfaced since we innocently voted "yes", has been going on quietly up here, while England irritatingly basks in post-conservatism, confidently regaining a sense of civilisation and decency lost to it for more than two decades. That wasn't supposed to be the way it was going to happen, damn you. You see no one reads the Guardian, the Times or the Telegraph in Scotland, and no one in England reads the Scotsman. Actually, come to think of it, no one in Scotland reads the Scotsman either since Andrew Neil took over, but that's a different story. It's worth breaching the privacy of our new Scottish stupidity over the Tyson unpleasantness, because the covert misogyny that's at the core of Straw's decision must be highlighted as a national issue. The fact that the location for Tyson's second post-conviction entry to the UK happens to be Scotland is completely irrelevant. The fact that he is being granted a second entry is not. Women in Scotland who are the victims of violence felt the isolation, impotence, misplaced shame and worthlessness over Tyson's Manchester visit in January, just as much as English women in the same sorry condition. There is no border divide between the betrayal of the fragile trust they might have had in the government, a trust they imagined was going to keep them safe from such triumphant and potent symbols as Tyson has become, of how rape can be survived by the rapist if not by the victim. The dumbing down of Question Time debate is a rather tiresome one. Boy George as an amusing, articulate, one-issue foil to the inarticulate, unamusing, one-issue Brian Souter was rather good TV. Dumbing down can work when it has a point. More interesting is why journalists agree to appear on the programme. Such exposure involves an enormous risk and one wonders why they take it. Many print journalists who never or rarely broadcast, are strange, cowardly, vain little creatures. They spend a great deal of time at home honing their prose to make themselves appear spontaneously witty and analytical. It's always a shock to meet some personality interviewer who has been consistently vindictive to film stars or footballers and to find that this high court judge of human achievement is a greasy haired psychopath with the personality and talent of loft insulation. The delight in reverse, of course, is when good journalists turn to broadcasting and reveal themselves as thoroughly decent coves. Tony Parsons and Alison Pearson come to mind on the sadly missed Late Review. In their case, television merely revealed more of their articulate, intelligent humanity. But when good writers appear on television and shame themselves it's a little heartbreaking. I always secretly admired AA Gill. He is, of course, horribly cruel, but there's a wit that suggests he doesn't really mean it. For instance, his close pal Jeremy Clarkson pretends to be horrid and hate everyone, but is in fact a perfectly lovely man. One hoped Adrian might the same. So to see Gill on Question Time, teeth bared in a perpetual snarl, a silly public school boy's nervous giggle heralding each new piece of ill-informed, populist thinking, and generally being a thoroughly nasty piece of work, was a crushing disappointment. I'm sure to all the people he's been cruel about it was delicious, but to me it was quite awful. Of course, TV can sometimes lie. But do you know what? It doesn't very often. I forced my sister-in-law to get me Charlton Heston's autograph when she worked with him recently. Yes I know he's right-wing monster, but let's face it, the man was El Cid, Ben Hur, even Moses, for heaven's sake. I simply wanted to put the bit of paper in Halliwell's under his name, so future browsers would be impressed when they looked him up. So it's irritating that he's growing ever more beastly as the National Rifle Association's front man and is going to be remembered for being an arse instead of parting the Red Sea. Worse still is my reaction when I read that his gun will only be taken away from "cold dead hands". My shame is that despite deploring violence, his invitation strikes me as rather an attractive prospect.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Distressing, if slightly prurient news, from the world of politics. Any possibility of Gordon Brown launching a counterstrike against the enemy with a baby of his own appears to have evaporated. According to sources exceedingly close to the weirdo chancellor, Gordon and Sarah Macaulay, the woman Charlie Whelan assured us he would marry in what was billed as last year's "wedding of the year", have split up.
fields.body:
Distressing, if slightly prurient news, from the world of politics. Any possibility of Gordon Brown launching a counterstrike against the enemy with a baby of his own appears to have evaporated. According to sources exceedingly close to the weirdo chancellor, Gordon and Sarah Macaulay, the woman Charlie Whelan assured us he would marry in what was billed as last year's "wedding of the year", have split up.

There was no one explosive incident, it seems. Perhaps predictably it was more a case of the two deciding, a month ago, to end it and become - what else? - just good friends. Indeed (heaping poignancy upon wistfulness), they recently went to her brother's wedding together in the US. "Everyone's very sad about this," a close political ally has said. "But they're no longer an item. They've just grown apart." Some of Gordon's circle blame Charlie for hyping the imminent nuptials - but Gordon did once pose for a tabloid holding Sarah's hand over a candlelit dinner. And what was the message intended by that shot of the two surrounded by little children at a teaparty? Children, however, there will not be. There's only one thing for it. Gordon, get a dog!

Speaking of which, I am shocked to find my so-called rival in the Times reporting that the Barbara Woodhouse de nos jours, Mandy Mandelson, has taken on a second puppy, a playmate for Bobby. This one is called Jack. According to Mandy's people that's because it's a Jack Russell, but in fact of course it is another dangerously amusing Kennedy reference. Rumours abound that Mandy is poised to take on a third puppy, Edward, which he intends to take sailing on the lakes around Hartlepool - a Chappaquiddick reference in very poor taste (although not as poor as the one that goes "another 98 and he'll have enough for a coat").

Now that all the dot.com fever has so spectacularly broken, it seems that the reputed national obsession with the internet may also be wavering. At Earls Court yesterday, there were two exhibitions - Internet World 2000, and the other a boring old fair for stamp collectors. I will not insult your intelligence by spelling out which had queues like Madame Tussauds in high summer and which, bless it, looked more like the dome on a quiet day. Perhaps, with the election in mind, Mr T might consider changing that famous pledge, and promise to put a Stanley Gibbons catalogue in every school.

A Broadcasting Standards Commission adjudication reaches us. While accepting comedian Mark Thomas's reputation for "approaching important issues in an accessible way", the BSC upholds a complaint on the grounds that "the tirade against the Rt Hon Robin Cook MP . . . exceeded acceptable boundaries." How draconian. All Mark did on his Channel 4 show was highlight the gulf between the hobgoblin's "ethical dimension at the heart of foreign policy" and the reality. "Robin Cook should be here, the f****** evil little corporate knob-polishing, hypocritical lying scum-f****** f***," was his conclusion - a little crude, perhaps, but nothing there anyone could seriously argue with. Even so, Mark is penitent, admitting: "I'd be happy to withdraw 'f****** f***'."

Communcations break down yet again with David Yelland. After a recent rebuke over his failure to return calls, the alopecian Sun editor rang to say he never received the message, and that in future we should fax a request for a chat. This we did twice yesterday, hoping to discuss a leader arguing that the entire European economic structure will crumble if Denmark votes against joining Emu - and nothing. God knows why David couldn't respond -apart from his deputy Rebekah Wade replacing Phil Hall as News of the World editor, yesterday was a quiet day at Wapping - but if he could call today perhaps we can thrash the matter out then.

fields.headline: BA plunges £244m into red
fields.standfirst: Lord Marshall's job on the line after airline suffers worst results since privatisation
fields.trailText: Lord Marshall, British Airways' long-serving chairman, may become the latest victim of the company's slide after it yesterday reported a pre-tax loss of £244m, its worst financial figures since privatisation.
fields.body:
Lord Marshall, British Airways' long-serving chairman, may become the latest victim of the company's slide after it yesterday reported a pre-tax loss of £244m, its worst financial figures since privatisation.

The view emerged among some executives as the company issued a veiled warning to staff that further jobs were at risk because of the company's investment in the internet.

Lord Marshall has moved swiftly to appoint Bob Eddington its new chief executive in succession to Bob Ayling, sacked two months ago. But Lord Marshall was yesterday ready to accept some of the blame for the swift collapse in BA's profits.

Mr Eddington's most pressing problem may be the increasing cost of fuel which alone may add an extra £140m to the company's outgoings.

The warning on job losses came from BA's financial director, Derek Stephens, who admitted that there had to be "changes in working practices" and significant increases in productivity to overcome the challenges faced in the next 12 months.

BA's figures relieved the City where some brokers had been forecasting a loss of more than £300m. The £244m loss was struck before a one-off disposal of assets of £249m.

After exceptionals, the airline made a £5m profit, down from £225m the previous year. Shares fell by only 6p to 368p, but recovered later.

After the sudden sacking of Bob Ayling in March, reports from within the company suggested that he may be followed by Lord Marshall, once a close ally of Mr Ayling, who may decide to stand down.

Lord Marshall conceded that mistakes had been made in the past year.

"Obviously it would be silly to say that all the factors were beyond BA's control. With hindsight we might have chosen to do things in a different way and with different timing. Perhaps we might have moved into our new strategy rather sooner than we chose to do."

Lord Marshall's comments echoed those of Mr Ayling who said last week: "If anyone says they would never have done anything differently, they are either a fool or a fraud."

Lord Marshall said BA had now passed through the trough of the cycle, but recovery would be slow because of the continuing high cost of fuel and intense competition in its major markets.

A "very disappointed" Lord Marshall tried to draw a line under the Ayling period, saying: "We are really determined to put this behind us and give Rod Eddington maximum support going forward, and in getting back where we ought to be."

Mr Eddington, former head of the Australian airline Ansett, gave little comfort to those who hoped that his arrival would herald an end to cost-cutting. "In my view, this programme is never-ending - it just has to be part and parcel of the business."

He said that he had inherited a "terrific" airline that had been challenged by the new competition from the low cost carriers and domestic rivals, British Midland and Virgin Atlantic.

BA's next big step may be a closer link wIth the Dutch carrier, KLM, although this is being officially denied.
