webTitle: Belgrade's youthful opposition struggles for legitimacy

fields.headline: Belgrade's youthful opposition struggles for legitimacy
fields.standfirst:
Hundreds of schoolchildren join the resistance despite their movement being branded terrorist

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Tanja Zivanovic shares a Belgrade flat with her mum and dad and a mongrel dog. She likes reggae and techno music and spending Saturdays hanging around town. Her government brands her a terrorist.
fields.body:
Tanja Zivanovic shares a Belgrade flat with her mum and dad and a mongrel dog. She likes reggae and techno music and spending Saturdays hanging around town. Her government brands her a terrorist.

A cigarette sits between the artistic fingers of Vukasin Petrovic. His slim limbs twist over each another, like elegant wrought iron. A 23-year-old in suit, tie and waistcoat, he wants to become a top magazine editor. His government calls him a terrorist.

Branko Ilic drowns in a large T-shirt. He is borrowing clothes and can't sleep in his own flat.

"I'm playing hide-and-seek with the police," he says.

Barely 20, Branko spent Monday urging students to support a campaign of civil disobedience, then slipped through a closing police net. Minutes later, before the press, he publicly declared himself a founder of the Otpor ("resistance") movement.

Otpor applied this week for registration as a civic group in the hope that it could protect Serbia's young people from accusations of terrorism.

Tanja joined three months ago. "Directly after school I would go to the offices. I didn't have time to eat or sleep. My parents told me several times it could be dangerous, but they never tried to stop me.

"Being in Otpor is fun. We are all working together there really hard. I talk to the school children who come to the offices to join. In the schools we called for proper pay for our teachers, an end to the final exams and an end to the law which makes head teachers appointees of the regime. "In February there were about 250 secondary school members of Otpor. Now there are 950. I recruited 200."

When Serbia's interior minister vowed to arrest Tanja and her friends as terrorists, saying their movement was illegal and not registered, the schoolgirls responded by carrying lilies to the police station. Before a posse of journalists, Tanja pleaded for the police to protect her and the people of Serbia. One officer revved the engine of his Land Rover. It lurched forward and nearly ran the girls over.

One of Tanja's recruits was a 17-year-old girl.The two fled a police charge and tear gas together, but police struck her friend on the skull. She now has six stitches in her head.

"People started running and I was frightened. She was just behind me. But after what happened to her, I became angry. Her parents have begged us now to leave her alone. But we phoned to see if she was okay. She said: 'Be careful. Don't be beaten like me! I will come back, as soon as I can'."

Vukasin was among those who formed the movement in October 1998. He did it partly because of his family experience. His father, a leading communist idealist, resigned from the party when Vukasin was 12. His mother was then fired from her job as director of a state chemical company. His well-to-do family slid into near poverty.

"During the 1990s many terrible things happened. We had all the wars. My family never dreamed of a Greater Serbia. This was all part of what made me join Otpor."

Eighteen months ago, Vukasin and other Otpor activists organised small protests.

"Then we realised sporadic actions were useless. We de cided to raise the struggle to a higher level. We figured out that the struggle had to be against the regime - actually against Milosevic."

Boyish Branko was among those early activists. "I started to organise high school demonstrations calling for the dismissal of the school principal, because he said nothing about the police beating protesting students in Belgrade," he said. "I was 17 then."

As his home town is close to the Bosnian border, his father was called up for the Bosnian war. "I just couldn't stand that situation. I wanted to be a part of some organisation."

It is not safe for Branko to go home to Arilje. His mother has been fired from her job as a police driving instructor because of him. He did dare to go back to Arilje once and organised a rally of 500 people at which he criticised a local police general, Obrad Stevanovic.

"Arilje is a wonderful place, famous for its raspberries. But I told them that people all over Serbia only talk of it as a place of repression, where people cannot speak their minds," he said.

"After that, one cafe was bombed and now the police are accusing me of that. They came to my parents' house looking for me."

Since then, Branko has been on the run. After Monday's registration he spoke to journalists and then helped to plan a campaign of passive disobedience. "We want elections to stop the terror on the street and the violence."

Yugoslavia's deputy foreign minister held a rare press conference yesterday to declare that the country would battle the "evil" of terrorism just as it had defended itself against Nato "aggression".

The government is working on an anti-terrorism law but he would not give a date for its introduction.

fields.headline: Hey, big spenders
fields.standfirst: Californian businesses spend four times as much as the entire United Kingdom on research and development. Yet in some areas, we still lead
fields.trailText: Ministers have been California dreamin'. Trying to find a key to a prosperous future for the United Kingdom, they have often been impressed by the entrepreneurial buzz surrounding the cluster of hi- tech businesses around the south San Francisco bay, silicon valley.
fields.body:
Ministers have been California dreamin'. Trying to find a key to a prosperous future for the United Kingdom, they have often been impressed by the entrepreneurial buzz surrounding the cluster of hi- tech businesses around the south San Francisco bay, silicon valley.

Former trade and industry secretary Peter Mandelson came back convinced that we too could develop the next Microsoft, or Hewlett Packard - if only we could translate the fruit of university research into the next wave of new technology start-up firms. Inspired after his own American tour, Gordon Brown announced a £64m grant for Cambridge to help it pick up entrepreneurial tips from the US, especially the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

But a study out today says there is little chance the UK can become the California of Europe. For a start Californian businesses spend four times as much as the entire UK on research and development. If the UK were an American state, it would roughly be on par with Virginia or Oregon, not known as hotbeds of innovative activity.

Commissioned by vice-chancellors for the Whitehall spending review, the report puts paid to the UK's pretensions to be on its way to becoming one of the leading technologically advanced nations. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) figures show the investment gap in research is widening. The Blair government's preoccupation with encouraging academics to be more commercial is misguided. It is in company board rooms that more needs to be done to open minds to new ideas and developments.

Aggregate research and development spending in the UK - by government and businesses together - has remained stagnant since the mid-80s. We have the slowest rate of growth in the OECD in R&D spending and the gap between the UK and top OECD performers is increasing every year.

In terms of the research budgets of government departments, the UK spends less than half as much as the OECD leaders. This gap is also escalating. And the industrial capacity to exploit research in the UK is weak in comparison to other OECD countries. The table sums up the position on company spending: the UK spends half as much as Sweden and the US per capita on business R&D and the gap is widening.

"The 90s were a lost decade for UK private investment in R&D," concludes the report (Talent, not Technology: Publicly Funded Research and Innovation in the UK, available on www.sussex.ac. uk/spru/index.html). While France and Germany invested inadequately over the same period, each also showed a poor overall economic performance. Other factors help explain their poor performance, such as the integration of the east into Germany and meeting entry conditions for the euro. In the UK, however, 1992-1997 were years of expansion.

As for the universities, their research spending per head of population is less than half the amount spent in academic institutions in the United States. The UK has the 16th lowest growth rate in higher education R&D in the OECD.

Despite all that, researchers in this country perform well enough. Whatever measurement system is used, the UK is still among the world leaders across different scientific subjects. For example among the OECD countries, UK researchers produced the highest number of publications per millions of pounds of research funding in higher education in 1997. Of 152 recognised fields of research, the UK is a world leader in 26 of them.

The number of citations (in scientific journals) per unit of funding is also high in the UK relative to other countries. This may however reflect past investment in university laboratories and infrastructure and the next generation of UK researchers may not be able to sustain this record. What returns does the UK get from this research? We do not know, at least the evidence is patchy, despite the best efforts of the authors of this report, from the science and and technology policy research group at the University of Sussex. Studies find a rate of return falling in the range between 20% and 50% of initial investment. Research does however have identifiable qualitative benefits: increasing the stock of useful knowledge; supplying skilled graduates; enhancing technological problem- solving capacity; creating new instrumentation; generating new firms; and providing new social knowledge.

Schemes introduced by the present government have encouraged the exploitation of knowledge produced by the universities - which was highlighted in the 1998 recent competitiveness white paper. But there are limits to the commercial role that uni versities can play. Universities could be more entrepreneurial and in general universities tend to be poor commercial agents. The report suggests that an exaggerated emphasis on promoting university commercialisation is misplaced because it treats universities as a source of technology rather than scientific talent.

"The government needs to be conscious of the limits to commercial exploitation of university research, and should attempt to emulate the best of US practice. Where US universities have been most successful in supporting economic development, they have been allowed the academic freedom to develop and publish new ideas freely and to recruit and retain talented people."

fields.headline: Railtrack chief says trains intolerable
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A frustrated Railtrack director last night launched an attack on the inadequacy of his own rail service. He referred to it as "pretty bloody intolerable" and called on the government to invest in the industry.
fields.body:
A frustrated Railtrack director last night launched an attack on the inadequacy of his own rail service. He referred to it as "pretty bloody intolerable" and called on the government to invest in the industry.

Richard Middleton, Railtrack's commercial director, who travels from Euston to Kingston, south-west London, most days, said that the problem was endemic in the industry and could not be "magicked away".

Referring to the Waterloo to Kingston service, run by South West Trains, a subsidiary of Stagecoach, he said he was sometimes forced to use his car because of overcrowding in the carriages and because he could not afford to be late for meetings.

Mr Middleton's remarks two days before the government's latest rail summit, chaired by John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, are designed to cause a reaction among ministers. For some time, Railtrack has called for further government assistance by way of funding without results.

Mr Middleton said that generally transport congestion around large cities was mounting and that Railtrack "had to have more money". He also thought that the fares structure was unfair and the cost of rail travel expensive. "We can't just price people off trains and put them on to roads," he said, adding that this was a tough problem that had to be addressed now as passengers were not getting a fair deal.

Railtrack made profits of more than £300m last year, but has often been criticised by the government for lack of investment. Its seedcorn has been a series of declining subsidies, first dispensed by the Conservatives when they privatised rail in 1996. The subsidies started off at £2bn in the first year, but have dropped; this year they are about £1.3bn, and by 2002 will be £900m.

Railtrack had done all it could to improve its performance to the customer, Mr Middleton said, with a 10% improvement in reliability (covering aspects such as train arrivals) over the past year, that had been recognised by the rail regulator. "We have been accused of promising jam tomorrow, but tomorrow is here," he said.

Within the past few weeks, Railtrack published its rail review, calling for a further £1bn of government investment. Mr Prescott is known to be ready to provide up to £2bn extra if he sees some results before the election.

fields.headline: No: 1641 Rachel de Thame
fields.trailText: Status: The New Charlie Dimmock.
fields.body:
Status: The New Charlie Dimmock.

You mean there's two of them? This time human cloning really has gone too far. Don't worry. We're not looking at some nightmarish four-armed, two-trowelled, no-brassiered doppel-Dimmock situation here.

What, then? De Thame, a former ballerina, is the fast-flowering new co-presenter of BBC Gardeners' World: a fresh bloom to Alan Titchmarsh's hardy perennial, you might say.

And now a pretender to the compost-encrusted throne of the queen of lifestyle television? According to whispers in the wisteria - not to mention murmurs in the marigolds - at the Chelsea Flower Show, which opens to the general public tomorrow, de Thame could be the biggest thing to hit gardening since Bernard Lavery first foisted his enormous cucumbers upon the world.

Is Dimmock worried about the competition? "There is no rivalry between us," says Charlie Dimmock - who was once, as readers with longer memories may recall, the original Charlie Dimmock.

And does de Thame see herself as the new Charlie Dimmock? "I don't see myself as the new Charlie Dimmock," says de Thame.

That's torn this whole "new Charlie Dimmock" thing, then, hasn't it? Ssshhh.

Who is she, anyway? De Thame trained at the Royal Ballet School and danced in The Nutcracker with Nureyev, but had to quit when she contracted glandular fever. She made around 80 commercials as a model, then enrolled on a course at the English School of Gardening - and voila: the horticultural big time.

Is her name connected to the picturesque market town of Thame? Possibly.

Don't say: "She's the new Alan Titchmarsh!"

Not to be confused with: Carol Vorderman (another competitor for the New Charlie Dimmock crown, thanks to her series Better Gardens); Charlie Dimmock.

fields.headline: Swoop to conquer
fields.standfirst:
Global warming brings butterflies to Britain earlier

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Butterflies are appearing up to two weeks earlier because of warmer temperatures, and some are living longer.
fields.body:
Butterflies are appearing up to two weeks earlier because of warmer temperatures, and some are living longer.

The biggest beneficiary of the one degree centigrade warming in central England over the last 23 years is the red admiral. It migrates from France and is appearing nearly 16 days earlier than previously and staying longer. One was monitored after crossing the Channel on New Year's Day, which was a mild day.

A dozen other species, including the orange tip, marbled white, Adonis blue, ringlet and comma, are emerging between four and 13 days earlier than in previous generations - these findings are in line with other studies of earlier nesting dates for small birds. Both analyses are thought to be early signs of global warming in Britain.

News of the changing life cycle of the butterfly comes with the publication of a report in the scientific journal, Global Change Biology, by David Roy and Tim Sparks, of the centre for ecology and hydrology at Monks Wood, Cambridgeshire.

Their study is based on analysis of data from 1976 to 1998 provided by the butterfly monitoring scheme, whose members check more than 100 sites in Britain each week from April to September. Mr Roy said yesterday: "There is no doubt that the warmer weather is causing butterflies to emerge much earlier.

"Butterflies are regulated by temperature and global warming is having an effect on their life cycle."

webTitle: England branded to pull in tourists

fields.headline: England branded to pull in tourists
fields.standfirst:
Holiday operators urged to adopt 'humorous and engaging tone' to lure visitors as £150,000 campaign draws on innovation and tradition

What is Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Never mind the violence of English soccer hooligans, the most enduring images of England are its heritage, tranquillity, culture, innovation, vibrancy, youth culture and city life according to tourist chiefs who today refuel the debate over national identity by trying to "brand" the country.
fields.body:
Never mind the violence of English soccer hooligans, the most enduring images of England are its heritage, tranquillity, culture, innovation, vibrancy, youth culture and city life according to tourist chiefs who today refuel the debate over national identity by trying to "brand" the country.

Their new logo represents such "English values" with a rampant lion, a country road winding towards a distant village and its church spire, the masks of comedy and tragedy and an "energy rose", linked by the traditional cross of St George.

Research among home consumers and foreign visitors by the English tourism council is said to have revealed "a personality" of England, "hidebound by tradition on the one hand, yet progressive on the other; conventional yet unconventional, controlled but spontaneous; majestic and also humble ... conformist in our approach, being part of the crowd but at other times being non-conformist; straight and even formal, but also with a well developed sense of irony".

There is little irony evident in the £150,000 packaging of the new Englishness which also advises holiday operators about brand speak.

They are encouraged to entice visitors with promises such as: "From dreaming spires to millennium domes - there's nowhere quite like England."

This tone of voice is "humorous, confident and engaging", whereas a "downbeat and dull" description of "England - where tradition never dies" is said to imply "that's the only thing there is".

Likewise, "England - there is always something different around the corner" is "intriguing, quirky and confident" while "England - always new and exciting" is "one-dimensional and rather flat".

The council insisted yesterday that the money had been well spent and was far less than the £1m or more often invested in brand strategy by multinational companies.

"Branding doesn't apply simply to consumer products and services. Countries can also benefit from developing positive brand images."

About 85% of the 26m people likely to visit Britain this year will simply see England, and half of all foreign visitors see London, but competition from dragon-branded Wales, and Scotland, represented by its thistle, is growing. The tourism council also wants to persuade more English people to stay at home for their holidays and not be lured away by sun, sea and sand images of Spain, or the attractions of neighbouring France.

The new brand follows years of debate not only about whether the English need or want devolved political institutions like other parts of the United Kingdom to help preserve their identity but also about the nature of modern Britishness. While John Major famously appealed to traditional images of England, warm beer and cricket on the village green, Tony Blair seems happier with promoting Britain as a hothouse of industrial and artistic innovation.

As an alternative to the new "flag" branding, tour operators can use a smaller "signature" mark which simply has the energy rose hovering over the curves of the gentler English countryside.

Mary Lynch, chief executive of the tourism council, said England was a "fantastic country, full of contrasts, and it is these contrasts which define England's uniqueness - beautiful countryside and vibrant cities, avant garde culture and old landscapes, seaside towns and rural villages ... our individuality is central to the brand."

Colin Doyle, secretary of the Countrywide Holidays Association, said: "In a vast moving world, with consumer choice at previously unimagined levels, brands are vital to capture customers."

webTitle: Three die, several hurt in house fire

fields.headline: Three die, several hurt in house fire
fields.trailText: A mother and two teenagers were killed when fire swept through their maisonette home early yesterday. Four other children were injured as they jumped 30ft from the third floor to escape.
fields.body:
A mother and two teenagers were killed when fire swept through their maisonette home early yesterday. Four other children were injured as they jumped 30ft from the third floor to escape.

The blaze, which started at about 5am in the second floor lounge and cut off the stairway, rapidly engulfed the maisonette in Penge, south-east London, which had hollow wooden doors and no smoke alarm.

The only adult in the house, Natasha Tatarova, 31, who perished after she helped three children leap to safety, jumped to the ground herself, and then ran back to try to save the two teenagers still inside. The fire and smoke overwhelmed her and she was trapped in a third floor bedroom along with two children unrelated to her, Melan Sivak, 15, and his sister Lucy, 14. All three died.

The dead and injured were members of two Slovak families who had been living in the apartment since October, neighbours said.

It took 45 minutes for firefighters to control the blaze, the cause of which has not been established. A neighbour who dragged mattresses from his home to help the family escape described the scene as "like a burning hell".

Arian Tippings, 32, a council worker, was woken by the screaming of the children. "I will never forget that screaming as long as I live. There was burning debris being blown out of the windows and the people inside were screaming for help. They were clinging to the windows desperately trying to avoid the flames.

"A little boy who was black with smoke was lying on the ground with his eyes wide open and blood pouring from his head. I thought he was dead."

Mr Tippings described how Mrs Tatarova jumped from the top window after the children, missing the mattresses and coming down painfully on a garden wall. "She fell behind the wall into some hedges. She was alive but she was screaming in agony. I've never seen anything like it before - and I hope I never see it again.

"I just can't imagine what those poor kids inside must have suffered. We just could not get near them."

Two of the children who jumped to safety were seriously injured. Raz Sivak, 16, brother of Melan and Lucy, was last night fighting for his life at St Thomas's hospital, London. Mrs Tatarova's son, Martin, 12, was being treated for serious head injuries and severe smoke inhalation at King's College hospital, in London.

The dead woman's daughters Marcella, 16, and Natasha, 15, were both treated at Bromley hospital for cuts and bruises.

fields.headline: The leaving of Lebanon
fields.standfirst:
A defining moment fraught with danger

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: It is a time for cool heads in the Middle East, although there were precious few to be found in south Lebanon yesterday.
fields.body:
It is a time for cool heads in the Middle East, although there were precious few to be found in south Lebanon yesterday. The accelerating Israeli withdrawal, the sudden, dramatic collapse of Israel's proxy militia, the South Lebanese Army, and the overruning of the 15-year-old Israeli-controlled security zone by Hizbullah forces and Lebanese civilians represent, in their region-wide political and strategic implications, a momentous and definitive event.

Although long foreshadowed, this abrupt new reality is a cause of justified exultation for the Shia Muslims dispossessed by Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon who, in opposing it, have paid in blood and suffering ever since.

It is a joy, too, for the majority in Israel who, weary of weeping for their slaughtered sons, backed prime minister Ehud Barak's 1999 election pledge to bring the boys home.

It changes both the overall balance of power and the dynamics of immediate political calculation. This is, above all, a very hazardous moment. This present danger should concentrate minds about the future.

The Lebanese government faces a number of pressing issues requiring decisive action, something for which it is not famous. Its sovereign territory has, de facto, almost been restored. But Hizbullah, not Beirut, has control on the ground.

The Lebanese have assured the UN they will not make difficulties over the disputed Sheba'a Farms area, which Israel retains. But Hizbullah insisted yesterday that without a total pull-out and the release of prisoners held in Israel, like the leading cleric, Sheikh Abdul Karim Obeid, its war will go on.

Lebanon has a duty to ensure that the inevitable settling of accounts with the SLA does not lead to excesses; and that the rights of Christian and Druze civilians living in the zone are respected. It has a self-evident interest, given the certain violence of Israel's reaction, in preventing the continuing Hizbullah attacks on Israel proper from Lebanese territory.

Having initially, cynically opposed Israel's withdrawal, Syria must also recalibrate the knee-jerk responses which pass for policy in Damascus. Syria (and Iran) have lost their principal means of fighting and pressurising Israel. Syria's domination of Lebanon with a 35,000-strong garrison will look much less excusable with the Israelis gone.

President Hafez Assad may claim credit, fatuously, for a great Arab triumph over the Zionist foe while continuing to block a deal on the Golan Heights. The Palestinians, whose peace talks with Israel are again marooned, may see in Israel's hasty departure an argument for violence, as in the West Bank last week, rather than dialogue as the best means of attaining their ends. But this would be merely to repeat the mistakes of the past.

Syria has told the US that it wants to avoid a post-withdrawal military escalation with Israel. Perhaps Mr Assad really means that. The best way of showing it would be a Syrian offer to resume peace talks.

As this, hopefully the final act of the Lebanon tragedy plays out, Mr Barak is accused of humiliating miscalculation and worse. His indeed has been a flawed performance so far. But what really matters? In Lebanon, he has kept his word.

He has done what others dared not do. He has struck a blow for peace, even as parting blows rain down. By most estimates, there are five months left for Mr Barak to attain his objective of a comprehensive peace and a final settlement of borders. It remains the best chance in years.

At this moment of crisis, this policy needs support. But as the Middle East's bloody history shows, peacemakers are more often cursed than blessed.

Although long foreshadowed, this abrupt new reality is a cause of justified exultation for the Shia Muslims dispossessed by Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon who, in opposing it, have paid in blood and suffering ever since. It is a joy, too, for the majority in Israel who, weary of weeping for their slaughtered sons, backed prime minister Ehud Barak's 1999 election pledge to bring the boys home. It changes both the overall balance of power and the dynamics of immediate political calculation. This is, above all, a very hazardous moment. This present danger should concentrate minds about the future. The Lebanese government faces a number of pressing issues requiring decisive action, something for which it is not famous. Its sovereign territory has, de facto, almost been restored. But Hizbullah, not Beirut, has control on the ground. The Lebanese have assured the UN they will not make difficulties over the disputed Sheba'a Farms area, which Israel retains. But Hizbullah insisted yesterday that without a total pull-out and the release of prisoners held in Israel, like the leading cleric, Sheikh Abdul Karim Obeid, its war will go on. Lebanon has a duty to ensure that the inevitable settling of accounts with the SLA does not lead to excesses; and that the rights of Christian and Druze civilians living in the zone are respected. It has a self-evident interest, given the certain violence of Israel's reaction, in preventing the continuing Hizbullah attacks on Israel proper from Lebanese territory. Having initially, cynically opposed Israel's withdrawal, Syria must also recalibrate the knee-jerk responses which pass for policy in Damascus. Syria (and Iran) have lost their principal means of fighting and pressurising Israel. Syria's domination of Lebanon with a 35,000-strong garrison will look much less excusable with the Israelis gone. President Hafez Assad may claim credit, fatuously, for a great Arab triumph over the Zionist foe while continuing to block a deal on the Golan Heights. The Palestinians, whose peace talks with Israel are again marooned, may see in Israel's hasty departure an argument for violence, as in the West Bank last week, rather than dialogue as the best means of attaining their ends. But this would be merely to repeat the mistakes of the past. Syria has told the US that it wants to avoid a post-withdrawal military escalation with Israel. Perhaps Mr Assad really means that. The best way of showing it would be a Syrian offer to resume peace talks. As this, hopefully the final act of the Lebanon tragedy plays out, Mr Barak is accused of humiliating miscalculation and worse. His indeed has been a flawed performance so far. But what really matters? In Lebanon, he has kept his word. He has done what others dared not do. He has struck a blow for peace, even as parting blows rain down. By most estimates, there are five months left for Mr Barak to attain his objective of a comprehensive peace and a final settlement of borders. It remains the best chance in years. At this moment of crisis, this policy needs support. But as the Middle East's bloody history shows, peacemakers are more often cursed than blessed.

webTitle: Gates eyes Cambridge for global scholarship fund

fields.headline: Gates eyes Cambridge for global scholarship fund
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The American software billionaire Bill Gates is in talks with the University of Cambridge to set up a global scholarship programme worth at least £130m, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The American software billionaire Bill Gates is in talks with the University of Cambridge to set up a global scholarship programme worth at least £130m, it was confirmed yesterday.

The scheme would be the largest scholarship of its kind launched in Britain, financing at least 230 bursaries every year for the world's brightest students.

It would be funded from the Microsoft founder's personal £14bn foundation, extending a relatively new scheme already running in the US.

As well as significantly raising the profile of Cambridge in the US, the Gates scholarships could also overshadow the prestigious Rhodes scholarships, which attract students to Oxford University.

Yesterday a University of Cambridge spokeswoman confirmed that formal discussions with Mr Gates were under way.

"The University of Cambridge has put a proposal to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, proposing that the foundation endows a global scholarship programme," she said.

"The proposal would allow Cambridge to offer scholarships to academically talented and promising students who have the potential to be future leaders in their communities and enhance society throughout the world."

Discussions were continuing, she added. But the final scheme would have to be formally approved by the academic community in Cambridge. It seems likely that although students would be able to apply for any course, most would be attracted to study science and technology given Cambridge's strong hi-tech reputation.

A spokesman for the foundation, based in Seattle, said he was unable to comment on the details of the scheme as it was still only a proposal. But he confirmed that Mr Gates was keen to extend the Gates millennium scholars' programme - now in its first year in the US - to Britain.

He also underlined the commitment by 44-year old Mr Gates - who dropped out of Harvard at the age of 20 - to helping bright youngsters get into higher education.

"One of the missions of the new programme is to break down the financial barriers that prevent deserving students from taking up university places," he said.

If the scheme is approved it will be the biggest partnership between Mr Gates and Cambridge. The entrepreneur has already given £12m towards a computer laboratory.

It will be seen to rival Oxford University's Rhodes scholarships, originally financed by a £4m endowment by the former diamond prospector, politician and colonialist Cecil Rhodes after his death in 1902, and open to English speaking students. The scheme has since enabled thousands of Americans to study at Oxford.

Mr Gates, who has given away more money than any other American since founding his Microsoft computer empire, has also become a high profile figure in Britain

Last October he had a private meeting with prime minister Tony Blair at Downing Street, when it was also announced that he was investing £2.5m in new computer-based "adult learning centres" in Britain.

News of the discussions was welcomed yesterday by education secretary David Blunkett, who told MPs on the education and employment select committee that the government was committed to opening up higher education in Britain to talented youngsters from other countries.

Anne Campbell, Labour MP for Cambridge, added: "This is extremely good news. The university has been very successful in bringing in industrial money and this is another example of the close links being forged with business for the benefit of students."

webTitle: Court says Straw can deport cleric

fields.headline: Court says Straw can deport cleric
fields.standfirst: 'Security threat' ruling reversed
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, yesterday won the right to deport a Muslim cleric, Shafiq ur Rehman, in a judgment establishing a new definition of what - and who - constitutes a threat to national security.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, yesterday won the right to deport a Muslim cleric, Shafiq ur Rehman, in a judgment establishing a new definition of what - and who - constitutes a threat to national security.

The court of appeal overturned a ruling by the special immigration appeals commission saying that the threat to national security was primarily for the government to determine and should be broadly defined .

But the ruling also means that in future any individual who is considered a threat to any of Britain's "allies" - not just Britain itself - could be seized and deported.

"Whatever may have been the position in the past, increasingly the security of one country is dependent upon the security of other countries," said Lord Woolf, master of the rolls.

He added: "Here, if there were terrorist activities to which Mr Shafiq ur Rehman was giving encouragement, which were directed against India's links with Kashmir, then the involvement of individuals coming from this country could damage relations between this country and India".

In a ruling which will be seized on by Whitehall as well as by foreign governments seeking the extradition of their militant opponents based in Britain, Lord Woolf continued: "The promotion of terrorism against any state is capable of being a threat to our own national security".

Lord Woolf, who allowed an appeal to the law lords for a higher ruling on the definition of national security, added: "In any national security case, the secretary of state is entitled to make a decision to deport not only on the basis that the individual has in fact endangered national security but that he is a danger to national security".

Mr Rehman, the imam of Ross Street mosque in Oldham, was stopped by immigration officials at Manchester airport when he returned from a visit to Pakistan in December 1997.

MI5 alleged he was involved in fundraising and recruiting rebels for fighting in Kashmir for the Lashkar Tayyaba Mujahideen group while working in Britain for its political wing, MDI.

Mr Rehman, who first came to Britain in 1993, has admitted providing cash for MDI - Centre for Invitation to the Divine Teachings - but has insisted the money was for building schools and hospitals in Pakistan.

His counsel, Sibghat Kadri QC, told the three appeal court judges - Lord Woolf, Lord Justice Laws, and Mr Justice Harrison - that their judgment had redefined the meaning of national security.

"Your lordships' decision may have put the clock back, giving carte blanche to the secretary of state to decide what is national security."

He added: "This group of people is suffering from Islamaphobia."

Mr Kadri went on: "Your lordships seem to be saying that from now on, any non-British citizen must prove they are innocent of posing any threat of damage to Britain."

Mr Rehman said after yesterday's ruling : "I am very upset. My case was heard by the commission and I won.

"Now this court has changed the meaning of national security."

Lord Woolf said that the special commission would redetermine the case, "applying the approach indicated in our judgment".

webTitle: Ex-head in knife attack on wife

fields.headline: Ex-head in knife attack on wife
fields.trailText: A 77-year-old former headmaster who attacked his wife with a combat knife when she left him for a driving instructor after 35 years' marriage said yesterday that he still loved her.
fields.body:
A 77-year-old former headmaster who attacked his wife with a combat knife when she left him for a driving instructor after 35 years' marriage said yesterday that he still loved her.

Herbert Andrew said he had been devastated when his wife Ann, 20 years his junior, walked out.

Andrew, who admitted assault causing actual bodily harm, causing damage to his wife's Nissan Micra car, and two charges of having an offensive weapon, said after the hearing: "I still love her. I just came to the end of my tether that day."

Andrew, whose plea of not guilty to attempted wounding with intent was accepted, will be sentenced at Manchester crown court in August. Judge Timothy Mort told him he was unlikely to be jailed.

Robin Kitching, prosecuting, said that Mrs Andrew left their home in Marple, Greater Manchester, in February and went to live with her daughter.

On February 12, Mrs Andrew, a driving instructor, saw her husband put his head through the window of her car and peer inside. Her husband was carrying a knife and a poker.

"He began to strike her about the head with both weapons," said Mr Kitching. "She was screaming for help. Two women intervened but he became more angry, muttering about a married man, and began hitting the car."

Mrs Andrew needed treatment to her head and ribs and repairs to the car cost more than £500.

The court heard that police who arrested Andrew, who had acquired the 12in knife during police service in Malaya from 1950 to 1953, found him "upset".

He said he believed his wife had taken up with a work colleague.

webTitle: Trade in your old car for a bus pass

fields.headline: Trade in your old car for a bus pass
fields.trailText: Motorists were yesterday given an invitation to "swap your banger for a bus" by a bus and train operator, which is offering free bus passes worth up to £1,000 each by taking 500 old cars off the road.
fields.body:
Motorists were yesterday given an invitation to "swap your banger for a bus" by a bus and train operator, which is offering free bus passes worth up to £1,000 each by taking 500 old cars off the road.

FirstGroup is setting up centres in London, Manchester, Glasgow, Bristol, Swansea, and other cities to dispose of old cars. They will issue annual bus season tickets in return.

Under the initiative being introduced in the run-up to green transport week, which starts on June 10, car owners will have to register their interest in advance with FirstGroup.

The company will contract out the work to a scrap firm.

Moir Lockhead, FirstGroup's chief executive, said: "We are putting our money where our mouth is and encouraging owners of smoky old bangers to give our fleet a try instead."

The company first tried out the idea in Glasgow, when 65 drivers traded their cars in for annual season tickets with a value of £36,400.

fields.headline: Expenses rebuke for charity chief
fields.trailText: The former chief fundraiser of the Roy Castle Cancer Foundation is to be heavily criticised for allegedly abusing foundation funds in a charity commission report next week.
fields.body:
The former chief fundraiser of the Roy Castle Cancer Foundation is to be heavily criticised for allegedly abusing foundation funds in a charity commission report next week.

Leaked extracts from the draft report allege that Sylvia Ingham, who resigned last October after six years as chief fundraiser, misused her expense account and failed to control spending of employees.

Among abuses alleged are that Mrs Ingham switched flights on a charity trip to the US to fit in with a personal arrangement at extra cost; used free facilities donated to the charity for her benefit; and claimed expenses for petrol on private journeys.

Mrs Ingham, who is claiming unfair dismissal from her £50,000 a year job, has admitted some abuse of perks and will repay some money, according to the Liverpool Echo yesterday.

The charity commission was called in when Sir Phillip Carter, chairman of trustees, asked accountants to examine Mrs Ingham's spending.

Sir Philip and the other trustees are criticised for failing properly to manage the charity and Mrs Ingham's spending.

During her tenure, the foundation raised millions of pounds and built and equipped a lung cancer research centre in Liverpool.

"I never did anything dishonest, and I am sure the charity commissioners will confirm that," Mrs Ingham said.The commission declined to comment until the report had been published.

The charity was founded after the death of entertainer Roy Castle from lung cancer in 1994. A spokesman for the charity said that it had been conducting a review of procedures in response to the commission's investigation.

fields.headline: Hoax call shocked star's family
fields.trailText: Two hotel workers who found the mobile phone of Absolutely Fabulous star Julia Sawalha rang her father and, posing as policemen, told him she was "seriously injured" in a car crash.
fields.body:
Two hotel workers who found the mobile phone of Absolutely Fabulous star Julia Sawalha rang her father and, posing as policemen, told him she was "seriously injured" in a car crash.

Cardiff magistrates yesterday heard how Ms Sawalha, 31, dropped her phone on a night out with Men Behaving Badly star Neil Morrissey and actor Stephen Tompkinson.

Jamie Rees and Gethyn Abraham found the phone at the four star Jury's hotel in Cardiff. The pairpressed the pre-set "home" button to connect with Ms Sawalha's father, veteran actor Nadim Sawalha.

Martin Thomas, prosecuting, said: "Mr Sawalha and his wife Roberta were shocked and traumatised at the message. Rees and Abraham made further calls, before panicking and destroying the phone."

After the call, Mr Sawalha, 65, rang police to check - and found out that his daughter was safe working on the set of the Flint Street Nativity - an ITV Christmas special - in a Cardiff school.

Rees, 25, of Caerau, Cardiff, admitted stealing a £90 Nokia mobile phone and malicious communication causing gross offence. Abraham, 21, of Senghennydd, Mid Glamorgan, admitted malicious communication. The two were given conditional discharges and ordered to pay £30 costs.

Both were sacked by Jury's hotel.

fields.headline: Prisoners win Chelsea gold medal
fields.trailText: Six prisoners won a Royal Horticultural Society gold award at the Chelsea Flower Show yesterday with their garden, Time the Healer.
fields.body:
Six prisoners won a Royal Horticultural Society gold award at the Chelsea Flower Show yesterday with their garden, Time the Healer.

The men from Leyhill open prison in Gloucestershire, serving sentences for offences including fraud and assault, spent 12 months perfecting the garden, which features overgrown meadow, woodland and pond plants. They were allowed out on day release for three weeks to complete the job of bedding in the plants at the show's Royal hospital site in Chelsea, west London.

Jeff Goundrill, head of inmate activities at Leyhill and leader of the project, said: "I am delighted with the award, which is a credit to the team at the prison."

Leyhill has won silver-gilt, silver and bronze awards for its three previous entries.

Gardens from the Daily Telegraph/RF Hotels, the Evening Standard, the Alpine Garden Society, the Garden History Society, Cabbages & Kings, and Gardens Illustrated also won gold awards.

webTitle: GPs missed fatal cancer in patient

fields.headline: GPs missed fatal cancer in patient
fields.trailText: A woman who died from bowel cancer was sent home 20 times by doctors before her condition was spotted.
fields.body:
A woman who died from bowel cancer was sent home 20 times by doctors before her condition was spotted.

Dorothy Carr, 57, was, on one occasion, told to take liver salts, and on another that she had a pulled muscle. It was not until her partner, Steve Jones, took her to the Freeman hospital, Tyneside, for a check-up that her condition was discovered.

Mrs Carr, a care assistant with two adult daughters, died six weeks later.

Doctors at the West Road surgery, Newcastle, where she was a patient, said it was difficult for family doctors to diagnose early stages of cancer. They also claimed the patient had all necessary care.

Mr Jones said: "Dot first felt ill last summer and went to see her GP. She had hip pains and was told it was a pulled muscle. In August she had chest and back pains but doctors didn't know what it was." He claimed she then suffered breathing problems in January but was told it was the flu virus.

In February, he said, she saw a doctor four times with stomach pains and she was told to take liver salts and return to work. After three days at work Mrs Carr was sent home. On March 9, the cancer was diagnosed.

The GP surgery concerned said it was happy with the treatment given to Mrs Carr, who had seen all four of the practice doctors.

One of them, Martin Heardman, said: "There was never an opportunity to make an early diagnosis. All the earlier complaints were unrelated. I understand Mr Jones's feelings but I am satisfied we could not have known earlier."

webTitle: 'Not enough fish' in the British diet

fields.headline: 'Not enough fish' in the British diet
fields.trailText: Threequarters of Britain's youth do not eat enough fish and a third do not touch it at all, with potentially serious implications for their health, a scientist said yesterday.
fields.body:
Threequarters of Britain's youth do not eat enough fish and a third do not touch it at all, with potentially serious implications for their health, a scientist said yesterday.

Britain was failing to learn from the big fish eating nations in the world, Iceland and Japan, whose populations were the healthiest, said Michael Crawford, director of the institute of brain chemistry and human nutrition at North London University.

Fish such as trout, salmon, herring, mackerel and sardines contain the essential fatty acid DHA which "lubricates" both blood vessels and the brain's nervous system.

Prof Crawford said: "We need to get back to feeding our minds as well as our bodies." Trials had shown that eating oily fish two or three times a week could prevent repeat heart attacks. The same lack of oils led to a deterioration in mental health.

fields.standfirst:
Russians in Chechnya have every reason to fear for their lives

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: On a ridge above this battered Muslim village in the foothills of southern Chechnya, 30 young Russian servicemen are digging in to wait for the enemy. They are in forbidding, hostile territory. They say they are reclaiming it for Mother Russia from Chechen separatist guerrillas. They are very frightened.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Tangi Chu, Chechnya
fields.body:
On a ridge above this battered Muslim village in the foothills of southern Chechnya, 30 young Russian servicemen are digging in to wait for the enemy. They are in forbidding, hostile territory. They say they are reclaiming it for Mother Russia from Chechen separatist guerrillas. They are very frightened.

The steep slopes facing the young soldiers are densely wooded and the lush new spring foliage provides perfect cover for the mountain partisans for whom the Russians are a sitting target. Birds rustling the trees are enough to set the Russians on edge.

"Down in the village there are only women and old people, although we can see the men's dirty shoes sitting at the door. We ask where they are and they say they've gone visiting relatives," explains Lieutenant-Colonel Vyacheslav Volosnikov, the deputy commander of the unit of interior ministry troops on the ridge. "But we know the men are in the hills and we're expecting them to come over the mountains any time."

The ridge trenches are the southern-most fixed Russian position on the war's western flank. Eight months after President Vladimir Putin committed 93,000 troops to bludgeon Chechnya into submission, the lumbering Russian military machine is becoming bogged down, while the nimble guerrillas take their hit-and-run war to the Russians.

"There was a time when we were the hunters and the [Chechen] fighters were the prey. Now things are becoming the other way round," mumbles Colonel Alexander Likhachev, an acting regiment commander at the sprawling Russian military base at Urus Martan four miles north of Tangi Chu.

Every Russian convoy on the roads of Chechnya is at risk of ambush. The occupying forces generally stay within their heavily fortified garrisons for fear of attack. There is minimal contact with the locals they are meant to be "liberating".

"I feel it is my duty to be here if my people are in danger," says Col Volosnikov, a Moscow volunteer who has signed a five-year contract to serve with special police troops in Chechnya. "But some might say I'm a fool."

Vladimir Kostin, 26, on sentry duty at the Urus Martan base says: "It can be terrifying here. Five of my friends have been killed. Only a fool would not be afraid."

Last week 51 Russian servicemen were killed in Chechnya. But there is no public clamour for the war to end nor any sign that the Kremlin is ready to back down. Officially the Russian death toll is twice that of the eight-year war in Afghanistan. In 18 months of war in Chechnya in 1994- 96, the Russians officially lost 1,954 troops. Since last October they have officially lost 2,004.

But if the Russians, trapped by their "victory" in Chechnya, are the hunters becoming the hunted, in Tangi Chu it is not difficult to see why.

It was here, 20 miles south of Grozny, in March that a Russian officer raped and murdered Heda Kungayeva, an 18-year-old Chechen girl, in the sole war atrocity admitted by the Russian top brass. According to Human Rights Watch, the Russians laid siege to Tangi Chu for three months, cutting water and power, stripping men naked at funerals and beating them in public, dragging them into the hills and holding them in pits in the ground until their families paid ransoms.

Four escaped witnesses to the terror tactics told US human rights monitors that the villagers had to buy weapons from the Russian troops which they would then give back to the Russians in return for their menfolk. One man was taken away, beaten, then bought back three times, the witnesses said.

But the Chechens of Tangi Chu, insists Lieutenant-Colonel Valery Chenoveryan, a Russian regional army spokesman, are friendly. He said they were supplying water and materials to help the Russians build a sentry post. But when questioned further he quickly changed his tune. A group of western reporters visiting the area under tight Russian control asked to be allowed to talk to the villagers.

"That's not a question, that's a provocation," said the officer. "There can be fighters in every house. The weapons are not there in the mornings. But they come out in the evenings."

And not just in Tangi Chu. A bomb blast in Urus Martan at the weekend killed one Russian and wounded several others. So wary are the Russians that the base outside the town is ringed by five security perimeters. Guard duty is doubled at night because if the Russians have tenuous control of the towns and villages during the day, in the hours of darkness they belong to the separatists.

Mikhail, a veteran of 24 years in the Russian military who has just been granted leave because his daughter is ill, says of his three months in Grozny: "This is not our war. I don't know what we're doing there.

"It's terrible and it will go on for a long, long time. Everybody hates us. The women in the markets tell us we'll all be killed, that the rebels will recapture Grozny just like they did the last time."

It is not just the Russian military that is the target of such venom. Life for indigenous Russian civilians in a Chechnya under the Russian military yoke is just as hazardous and fearful.

Nina Vasilyeva is head of the local authority in the village of Mekenskaya in relatively quiet northern Chechnya. The village has been under Russian control since October and is in an area that is historically more pro-Russian.

But only 300 Russians remain. There were once 2,000. "Everyday life is impossible here. You can't go anywhere," says Ms Vasilyeva. "They don't tell you they hate you, but you can see it in their eyes. I don't know if there is a solution to this hatred."

She did not want the job, but was talked into it by the local military commander. She asked him to provide 20 Russian military police for the village. He said he could not because he could not guarantee their security.

She used a Chechen driver to chauffeur her during the day. But he has now said he can no longer drive her because the Chechen leaders in the shadows have warned him he will be killed for "working for the Russians".

Even miles from the main war theatre, the Russians appear to be under siege. The military headquarters in the village of Naurskaya is like a cold war fortress - coils of razor wire, mines, fences, concrete bollards, snipers on the roof.

In a field full of forget-me-nots outside Mekenskaya, simple blue wooden Orthodox crosses mark the graves of dozens of Russians killed when a Chechen bus driver went on a shooting spree last year.

"We just try to keep to ourselves, not bother them and hope they won't bother us," says Tatyana Kupushkina, a Mekenskaya Russian whose brother has been killed, by her Chechen neighbour, she said. "Now we have the Chechens dancing on our graves. How would you feel about that?"

webTitle: Dutch legal ruling hits ecstasy fight

fields.headline: Dutch legal ruling hits ecstasy fight
fields.trailText: Foreign ecstasy traffickers wanted by police in their home countries may be allowed to walk free from Dutch jails because Europe's most popular illicit party drug is now being manufactured in so many different variants that no existing judicial definition can cover them all.
fields.body:
Foreign ecstasy traffickers wanted by police in their home countries may be allowed to walk free from Dutch jails because Europe's most popular illicit party drug is now being manufactured in so many different variants that no existing judicial definition can cover them all.

In a decision that will further strain relations between Europe's biggest "E" producer and its neighbours, the Dutch high court has ruled that foreign suspects will be freed unless requests for their extradition include a precise chemical formula for the pills concerned, and the formula matches one banned under Dutch drug laws.

"The problem is that heroin, cocaine and hash or marijuana all have a fixed, internationally-recognised composition. That's not the case for ecstasy," said Jozef Rammelt, a Dutch lawyer specialising in international law.

"In cross-border legal terms, ecstasy no longer really exists because so many compounds are now on the market. What this ruling amounts to is a signal that international norms for synthetic drugs have to be established urgently. Other European countries may not like this decision, but we can no longer go on like this."

The little-noticed February ruling, which has so far gone unreported, marks a new victory for manufacturers around Europe who for the past decade have played a cat-and-mouse game with police, constantly altering the composition of their synthetic drugs to avoid prosecution.

One such ecstasy variant, 2C.T.2, is potentially lethal but legal in many European countries and sold over the counter in Amsterdam coffee shops. Described as a "psychedelic amphetamine", it comes from the family that includes MDMA, the banned ecstasy compound.

Even more worryingly, another pill posing as ecstasy, yellow with dark brown flecks but without a trademark logo, was recently found on sale in Holland containing 8mg of the poison strychnine.

A Dutch justice ministry spokesman said suspected drug dealers from Germany, Britain and France were currently in Dutch prisons pending extradition hearings. He could not say how many suspects were involved, but Mr Rammelt said he knew of at least two who had been released since the high court's decision.

First synthesised in 1912, ecstasy began to be widely used in the US as a recreational drug before being banned there in 1985, and is now outlawed across Europe.

Evidence is increasingly emerging that the small white tablets, initially seen as a harmless clubber's pick-me-up with few side-effects, could have disastrous long-term consequences, and even the traditionally liberal Dutch authorities launched a campaign earlier this year telling teenagers that "one pill can kill".

The drug and its variants can be produced by anyone with rudimentary knowledge of chemistry, using recipes obtained from the internet and a small manually-operated pill-making machine. Industrial-scale laboratories can make 10,000 pills an hour, at a cost of 10-20p each.

"Compared to cocaine and heroine, synthetic drugs offer major advantages to traffickers," said a report from the French police anti-drugs unit last year. "They are the drugs of the future: easy to make, easy to modify to evade the law, easy to transport and easy to sell for vast profit."

According to British police figures, 87% of ecstasy consumed in Britain is either manufactured in or imported from the Netherlands. Part of that production may now have shifted to eastern Europe following a crackdown by Dutch police that has seen 35 underground laboratories discovered in recent years.

But August De Loor, who runs a drugs advice clinic in Amsterdam, says the crackdown has made things worse. "All it has done is reduce the quality of the ecstasy because it's harder to produce pure stuff now. The consumers still want it, so they will still look for it. But they end up taking junk - possibly dangerous junk - instead," he said.

webTitle: Who cares about the heroes of Iwo Jima?

fields.headline: Who cares about the heroes of Iwo Jima?
fields.trailText: James Bradley's skills as a pots and pans salesman did him no good when it came to hawking his book idea around publishing houses.
fields.body:
James Bradley's skills as a pots and pans salesman did him no good when it came to hawking his book idea around publishing houses.

Flags of Our Fathers, a new volume about Iwo Jima, the battle fought by the US against Japan 55 years ago for a tiny volcanic island in the Pacific, was just what the world did not need. One of the 27 rejection slips went as far as to say: "No one wants to read a book about old men weeping into the telephone."

But finally Bradley did find a taker and now the book is number three on the New York Times non-fiction list, with 270,000 copies in print.

His story of the six young Americans who raised the flag during the 36-day second world war battle in which 22,000 Japanese and 7,000 from the US died has struck something in the public that the publishers did not see.

Working with Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Ron Powers, Bradley tells the tale of the six flag-raisers, one of whom was his father, John. Stephen Ambrose, a military historian, says the writers have come up with "the best battle book I have ever read". The New York Times said it was "one of the most instructive and moving books on war and its aftermath that we are likely to see."

The photograph of the flag being raised became a symbol for the triumph of the righteous 6,000 miles from the US, a classic moment of grace and danger.

Joe Rosenthal's picture pressed all the patriotic buttons but in fact the Associated Press photographer almost failed to press the shutter on his camera because he was talking to a colleague at the time and did not know what he had on film until later.

It was reported that the flag was raised on Mount Suribachi under gunfire. Not only was this untrue, but Rosenthal's picture shows a replacement flag going up: the original was removed because an officer wanted it kept as a souvenir. And the image of triumph wrought from endurance was taken on the fifth day, not at the end, of the 36-day battle.

But the main purpose of the book is to humanise the six, whose names are long forgotten, although the three survivors were treated, says 46-year-old Bradley, like the Beatles when they came home.

The three who didn't make it were Mike Strank, 25, who was probably killed by friendly fire; Harlon Block, 20, a star high school footballer; and Franklin Sousley, 19.

The others were marked by what Bradley calls The Photograph and the myths of its making for the rest of their lives.

In common with many veterans, John Bradley never talked about Iwo Jima and it was not until his death in 1994 that his family even knew he had won the Navy Cross for bravery. It was in one of three boxes he left behind and the contents of these and interviews with survivors helped Bradley piece together the men's stories and to reveal the nature of his father's courage.

"My breast didn't swell with pride because I understand they were all doing things like that," said the author. "No one would have cooperated with me if I was out to show these guys were unusual heroes.

"What they represent is the best of America, but they were boys of common virtue. My dad just did what he was trained to do but, under fire, when it's observed, it's called heroism."

Another of the three, Rene Gagnon, died of a heart attack at 54, frustrated that his faded celebrity translated ultimately into no more than work as a janitor.

Bradley believes that the final flag-raiser, Ira Hayes, who lived on an Indian reservation in Arizona, never received the help he needed for post-traumatic stress syndrome. He died, 10 years after one of the most famous photographs of the century was taken, from alcohol poisoning.

fields.headline: Gates backs Clinton's China bill
fields.trailText: Bill Gates put capitalism before politics yesterday and joined his long time enemy Bill Clinton in a last-minute appeal to Congress to open up trade with China in a crucial vote that is expected later today.
fields.body:
Bill Gates put capitalism before politics yesterday and joined his long time enemy Bill Clinton in a last-minute appeal to Congress to open up trade with China in a crucial vote that is expected later today.

The Microsoft chairman has spent most of the past year fighting the Clinton administration's attempts to break up his giant software business.

Today's vote on the administration's China trade bill - which would permanently normalise US-China trade relations - has become the toughest political battle of the year in Congress, with the outcome still uncertain.

The intervention by Mr Gates came in the form of an article in yesterday's issue of the Washington Post newspaper under the headline "Yes, More Trade With China", which argued that what was good for Microsoft would be good for the US economy.

"With 1.2bn citizens, it's only a matter of time before China's marketplace explodes, providing enormous opportunities for Chinese and US companies as well as businesses around the world," Mr Gates wrote.

"What the vote really comes down to is whether the United States is going to join with other major countries in creating open global markets or is going to forgo the opportunity to benefit from a fast-growing Chinese marketplace," he added.

Today, only 2.5% of the Chinese population own a computer and fewer than 1% have internet access, Mr Gates said, but the numbers were growing "at an astonishing rate", with 20m Chinese internet users expected by the end of this year.

Responding to critics who say that China's human rights record should preclude normalisation of trade, the Microsoft boss said "I believe our best opportunity to exert a positive influence in these areas is to do more - not less - to encourage China's position in the global community."

Mr Clinton went on NBC network news to press the case for the trade bill. "In China the main people who don't want this to pass are the ultraconservative communists in the military and those who run the state-run industries," he said.

Most observers believe that the supporters of the bill are winning the upper hand, but both sides acknowledge that the result is too close to call.

fields.headline: Harding Dunnett
fields.standfirst: Practical romantic on a mission to preserve Antarctic hero Shackleton's legacy
fields.trailText: Harding Dunnett, who has died aged 91, retained a lifelong sense of wonder at the exploits of the great Antarctic explorer, Sir Ernest Shackleton, who, in 1914 with four companions, sailed through the mountainous seas between Elephant Island, at the tip of the Antarctic peninsula, and South Georgia in search of a rescue party for the 28-strong crew of the Endurance after it was crushed in the ice during Shackleton's 1914-16 expedition.
fields.body:
Harding Dunnett, who has died aged 91, retained a lifelong sense of wonder at the exploits of the great Antarctic explorer, Sir Ernest Shackleton, who, in 1914 with four companions, sailed through the mountainous seas between Elephant Island, at the tip of the Antarctic peninsula, and South Georgia in search of a rescue party for the 28-strong crew of the Endurance after it was crushed in the ice during Shackleton's 1914-16 expedition.

Two events triggered Harding's fascination. In 1922, a few months after the explorer's death, he became a pupil at Shackleton's old school, Dulwich College, in south-east London. Two years later, the James Caird, the 23-feet open whaler in which the Shackleton's voyage had been made, was presented to the college. Harding vividly recalled the memorial setting for the boat, alongside the shooting range.

Even then, it seemed incredible to him that five men could have existed, frozen and drenched for 16 days, in so cramped a space. In 1922, they moved to London, where, after Dulwich College, Harding read economics at the London School of Economics.

In 1935, he won a Cassell travelling scholarship to study industrial design in Europe, and then became secretary to the Design Industries Association, where he met and married Monica Corfield in 1937. During the second world war, he served with the Royal Air Force Coastal Command in Iceland and Northern Ireland. In 1945-6, he was an intelligence officer and interpreter at Celle, outside Belsen.

After the war, Harding joined the Architectural Review, working alongside John Betjeman and John Piper, and writing a number of special editions, including, with Maurice Gorham, a survey of public house interior design. He also worked with Hugh Casson on brochure designs for the 1951 Festival of Britain. Public relations became his speciality.

He retired in 1974, but continued to pursue dreams and ideas. In the meantime, the National Maritime Museum, at Greenwich, had restored and exhibited the James Caird, which had been neglected during the war in Dulwich. In the mid-1980s, Harding visited the museum's children's polar gallery, and, as he gazed at the portrait of Shackleton, beside the unrigged boat in its glass box, he found his mission.

Harding drove straight home and telephoned the then master of Dulwich College, David Emms, demanding that the boat be brought back to the college. Emms put him through to me, knowing that, as the college librarian and archivist, I had been working with Ann Savours Shirley, the museum's polar scholar. Within the hour, Harding was at my side, memories, plans, proposals tumbling out.

This initiative led to a small book about old boys from Dulwich, Eminent Alleynians, but Harding's main interest was still to pursue Shackleton. Coincidentally, the National Maritime Museum was seeking a new venue for the James Caird, and, after months of negotiations, she returned home to Dulwich College, high on a trailer, along the south circular road. It was one of the happiest moments of Harding's life.

While the boat was stored in the groundsmen's sheds, we enlisted the help of Lord Shackleton and, in 1989, the James Caird finally came to rest, on pebbles from the beaches of South Georgia and Aberystwyth, in the north cloister of the college.

Since then, she has been to the Boat Show at Earl's Court, and to New York and Washington for the Endur- ance Exhibition. This November, Dulwich will host a major Shackleton exhibition, with much new material, and the James Caird Society, which Harding founded six years ago, will continue to meet biannually for lectures and dinners beside the boat in the cloister. The society now has more than 500 members and has become the principal contact point for the descendants of Shackleton's crew.

Harding produced, with his friend John Bardell, a video of the boat's treacherous journey. The book, Shackleton's Boat: The Story Of The James Caird, which he designed and wrote, records 80 years of its existence.

Last year, Harding visited Shackleton's grave in South Georgia. He himself died peacefully in his chair at home, overlooking a garden he had tended for more than 50 years. He is survived by his wife Monica, two daughters, a son, six grandchildren and one great-grandson. The family called him Magna. Exactly right.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Dennis Brooks writes: As your obituarist (May 8) notes, Hugh Tinker's tenure as director of the Institute of Race Relations (IRR) was not a happy time. After his departure, he described his role as that of "the Alexander Kerensky of the IRR," with representatives of big business cast as the imperial Russian government and his successors as the Bolsheviks. Not that his successors were, or are, Bolsheviks - but, apart from that, the analogy is fitting.
fields.body:
Dennis Brooks writes: As your obituarist (May 8) notes, Hugh Tinker's tenure as director of the Institute of Race Relations (IRR) was not a happy time. After his departure, he described his role as that of "the Alexander Kerensky of the IRR," with representatives of big business cast as the imperial Russian government and his successors as the Bolsheviks. Not that his successors were, or are, Bolsheviks - but, apart from that, the analogy is fitting.

Helen Currie writes: I have a sweet memory of Penelope Fitzgerald (Obituary, May 3). She was speaking about Janey Morris at a weekend seminar on the Pre-Raphaelites in Cambridge. Her talk was charming and witty, and she mentioned that she "did a bit of writing herself" - a modest remark indeed. Her book, Offshore, had just won the Booker prize. Afterwards, I said that having met her I must buy Offshore. She replied: "My dear, don't buy it, you may not like it. Borrow it."

fields.headline: Raymond Edde
fields.standfirst: Moderate Lebanese leader caught between warring factions
fields.trailText: It is a paradox of Lebanese politics that Raymond Edde, known as "Lebanon's conscience" and one of his nation's greatest patriots, who has died following a stroke in Paris aged 87, was born and died in exile. Even former enemies respected the Maronite Christian's powerful intellect, commitment to principle and penchant for straight talk.
fields.body:
It is a paradox of Lebanese politics that Raymond Edde, known as "Lebanon's conscience" and one of his nation's greatest patriots, who has died following a stroke in Paris aged 87, was born and died in exile. Even former enemies respected the Maronite Christian's powerful intellect, commitment to principle and penchant for straight talk.

His father, Emile Edde, was president of Lebanon from 1936 to 1941. Raymond succeeded him as amid (or ruler) of the National Bloc in 1949. Yet his desire to mend fences between his country's warring communities was out of kilter with the times, and ultimately ended in failure. He swore by legal and constitutional solutions in an age when the rifle and chequebook proved more potent.

Edde represented the Byblos district from 1953 to 1976 and held various cabinet positions, including minister of the interior. Yet three presidential bids failed, in 1958 and 1965, and then to Syria's protégé, Elias Sarkis, in 1976. Timing was never Edde's strong suit; in both 1958 and 1976 Lebanon was in the thick of civil war. As Syrian "peacekeeping" troops poured into the Beq'a valley, he went into permanent exile in Paris. Having already survived two attempted assassinations, he refused to return home until all foreign troops - Syrian and Israeli - had left Lebanese soil.

This was not the first time that powerful forces had threatened the Eddes. Before the first world war, the family was forced to flee Lebanon's Ottoman authorities; they settled in Egypt, where Raymond was born, only returning to Beirut in 1920. Edde attended a Jesuit school, graduating in law in 1934.

As Maronites, his family were members of a community that constitutes about a fifth of Lebanon's resident population. They had migrated to Beirut from Jbeil, their mountainous heartland. Like other Jbeilis whose names were to become legendary - the Chamouns and the Gemayels, for instance - the Eddes prospered under the French mandate.

Emile became Beirut's leading lawyer, and, in 1937, was the first Maronite president to appoint a Sunni Muslim as his prime minister, so setting a lasting precedent. That year, too, he met the Zionist leader, Chaim Weizmann, in Paris and toasted a future Jewish republic in Palestine.

Raymond, however, was loath to nurture this tentative alliance, especially after anti-Israel feeling swept Lebanon. He also differed from his Francophile father by embracing the reality of French departure in 1943. But both detested the quasi-fascist Maronite group, the Phalange, created in 1936 by Pierre Gemayel. They warned that militant sectarianism would rip apart the fragile fabric of Lebanese society.

Nonetheless, at times, Edde had to make common cause with this trend. With Gemayel and former President Kamil Chamoun, he formed an opposition triple alliance, which criticised the 1969 Cairo accord that allowed Palestine Liberation Organisation units to carry arms alongside the Lebanese army.

Gemayel's men went on to attack Palestinians and Muslim Lebanese; and, in 1974, Edde made an alignment with Sunni Muslim politicians Rashid Karami and Sa'eb Salam. But hopes of Muslim-Christian rapprochement crumbled, and the ensuing civil war forced Edde to leave for Paris.

Years of exile only intensified his concern for Lebanon, especially after his sister Andree's death from a sniper's bullet in 1978. He continued to protest against the country's dismemberment, rejecting the 1989 Taif accords and urging Christians to boycott elections in 1992 and 1996. Taif may have ended a vicious 15-year war, but, in Edde's view, it also sealed Lebanon's fate as a Syrian satrapy.

A decade later, he lambasted the United States for "ceding" Lebanon's precious southern water resources to Israel, and for bullying European nations into abandoning their historic ties to Beirut.

The US also approved in 1990 Syria's military demolition of Michel Aoun, a renegade general and Lebanese nationalist icon. Aoun joined Edde in Paris. They shared almost identical vews, but soon became rivals. Aoun show Edde scant respect, while Edde condemned the general for shedding innocent blood. Nonetheless, Edde leapt to Aoun's defence when the Lebanese authorities blacked out a television interview with the exiled general.

For all his failings, Edde left a lasting legislative legacy. His 1956 banking secrecy law unleashed Lebanon's innate entrepreneurial genius. He advocated civil marriage as a way of diminishing inter-religious hatred, and championed the stationing of UN troops in south Lebanon. In 1996, he briefed the French president, Jacques Chirac, before his visit to Beirut.

Edde never married.
