fields.headline: Jean-Pierre Rampal
fields.standfirst: Musician whose virtuosity popularised the flute on record, stage and the Muppet Show
fields.trailText: " It must be a passion - as important as the water you drink or the bread you eat." This is how the French flautist Jean-Pierre Rampal, who has died aged 78, described his relationship with his instrument. The passion fuelled a remarkable career, which spanned more than 50 years.
fields.body:
" It must be a passion - as important as the water you drink or the bread you eat." This is how the French flautist Jean-Pierre Rampal, who has died aged 78, described his relationship with his instrument. The passion fuelled a remarkable career, which spanned more than 50 years.

Until the 1950s, it was unusual for a wind instrumentalist to appear as a soloist with an orchestra, but Rampal's talent, flair and commanding stage presence broke through this barrier, bringing the flute into the limelight and paving the way for other flute soloists, such as James Galway. He also became one of the world's most recorded artists, with more than 400 records spanning the essential flute repertoire, quantities of new discoveries and first recordings of hitherto unknown works.

Born in Marseilles, Rampal was the son of a flautist: his father was a professor at the Marseilles Conservatoire, and first flute in the city's orchestra. As a boy, Rampal listened to the radio constantly, devouring music of all kinds, but symphonic music in particular. At the age of 12, he was given his own flute and went to the conservatoire to study with his father.

Each day after school he would choose three new pieces from the music shop, to be played after he had done his homework. When he had exhausted the flute repertoire, he plundered the oboe, clarinet, violin and cello shelves for new material. In addition, a publisher friend of his father sent weekly parcels of new pieces from Paris. Rampal was already beginning to search in libraries for unpublished music; later, he edited such works for publication.

Although an exacting teacher, Rampal's father did not encourage his son to become a professional musician, and the beginning of the second world war saw him entering medical school, where he studied for three years. Towards the end of that time the Nazi occupation forces drafted him for compulsory labour in Germany. He refused, went underground and made his way to Paris, where he began attending classes at the Paris Conservatoire.

Five months later, he graduated with the first prize, and after the liberation of Paris became first flute at the Paris Opera, where he stayed for six years. He quickly gained recognition as a soloist, making his first broadcast in 1945 with Ibert's Flute Concerto, and his first record, Mozart's Flute Quartet in D, in 1946.

As Rampal's solo career blossomed, he established a 30-year partnership with the pianist Robert Veyron-Lacroix, popularising the notion of a complete recital of flute music. He also belonged to the French Wind Quintet, and in 1952 founded the Ensemble Baroque de Paris, one of the first groups to bring to light the repertoire of that era.

On recital tours to the United States, Rampal often met resistance from city orchestras to his performing concertos with them, generally fuelled by the resident flautists, who regarded the idea as a threat. Gradually, however, he broke through this resistance and, in fact, paved the way for many orchestral flautists to perform more often as soloists.

From the 1960s onwards, Rampal was regularly giving at least 150 concerts a year, while simultaneously teaching, making records and researching and editing new works for the publishing houses of Georges Billaudot, in Paris, and the International Music Company, in the US.

He was also the much-loved professor of flute at the Paris Conservatoire from 1969-81. He believed that flute-playing should be "natural", and not a forced discipline. He encouraged his pupils to have a presence, style, expression, and, above all, spontaneity - not to be afraid to take risks. He felt that technique should be so well mastered as to be forgotten in performance.

Rampal paved the way for a surge in the popularity of the flute, and for the current high standards of performance. Works considered extremely difficult in the 1950s are now played as a matter of course by college students. But, while highly regarded outside France, he thought his own reputation within the country "curious". Writing in Le Monde in 1990, he said that no musical critic in France took any notice of his records. "Everything continues as if I didn't exist. This doesn't matter; I still play to full houses."

Rampal was interested in music beyond the classic repertoire. He recorded an album of Japanese folk songs and Claude Bolling's Suite For Flute And Jazz Piano, and even performed with Miss Piggy on The Muppet Show. He also played a legendary instrument, the most famous flute in the world. The only gold flute made by Louis Lot in 1869, was mislaid after the death of its first owner in 1880. Somehow, one day in 1948, it found its way into the hands of the young Jean-Pierre.

He is survived by his wife, a son and a daughter.

 Jean-Pierre Rampal, flautist, born January 7 1922; died May 20 2000

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our profile of Paul Myners, head of the Treasury review of institutional development (and non-executive chairman of the Guardian Media Group), page 30, May 20, we said he divided his time between the City and "the Cornish home where his second wife lives with their two young children ..." In fact they all live together in London and have a holiday home in Cornwall.
fields.body:
In our profile of Paul Myners, head of the Treasury review of institutional development (and non-executive chairman of the Guardian Media Group), page 30, May 20, we said he divided his time between the City and "the Cornish home where his second wife lives with their two young children ..." In fact they all live together in London and have a holiday home in Cornwall.

In an article headed No RAE of hope, page 11 Education, yesterday, we referred to "last weekend's" annual conference of the lecturers' union, Natfhe. The conference was not last weekend. It does not happen until next weekend, May 27 to 29.

Keble College, Oxford, is spelt like that and not Keeble (Education, page 13, yesterday).

A jazz event scheduled for Friday, May 26, mentioned in some editions of The Guide, gave incorrect details. Here are the right ones: Tony Scriven's Best of British Jazz with Ian Wheeler, clarinet, and Pauline Pearce, gospel & blues singer. Silkstone Lodge near Barnsley. 8.30. £5. (01226 290105).

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. In an article headed No RAE of hope, page 11 Education, yesterday, we referred to "last weekend's" annual conference of the lecturers' union, Natfhe. The conference was not last weekend. It does not happen until next weekend, May 27 to 29. Keble College, Oxford, is spelt like that and not Keeble (Education, page 13, yesterday). A jazz event scheduled for Friday, May 26, mentioned in some editions of The Guide, gave incorrect details. Here are the right ones: Tony Scriven's Best of British Jazz with Ian Wheeler, clarinet, and Pauline Pearce, gospel & blues singer. Silkstone Lodge near Barnsley. 8.30. £5. (01226 290105). fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Women inmates go free in Sudan
fields.body:
Women inmates go free in Sudan

Sudanese authorities have freed 563 female prisoners, the first to be released under a presidential pardon for women, the independent newspaper al-Sahafa reported yesterday.

The women were freed from a women's prison in Omdurman, near Khartoum, on Monday, leaving behind 96 inmates.

The pardon covers women sentenced by public order courts and does not apply to financial crimes, al-Sahafa said. It said more than 80% of those released were non-Muslims convicted of making or selling alcohol.
Reuters, Khartoum

Declaration to be sold on web

One of 25 known surviving copies of the US Declaration of Independence is expected to fetch up to £4m when it goes up for auction on Sotheby's website on June 29.

The document is from the declaration's first printing on July 4-5, 1776. A spokeswoman for Sotheby's said the document, being privately shown in Boston yesterday, will go on public display in Los Angeles and New York in June.
Reuters, Boston

Row over Paris mayoral race

After a chaotic selection process, a former minister, Philippe Séguin, was yesterday declared the Gaullist RPR's official choice candidate for Paris mayor. Behind-the-scenes pressures by President Jacques Chirac upset some senior figures, opening the way to a rival maverick bid by the incumbent mayor, Jean Tibéri. Paul Webster, Paris

Mobile blow for Dhaka Speaker

Angered by huge unpaid bills caused by the use of mobile phones for private purposes, Bangladesh's prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, has ordered the immediate withdrawal of all phones from senior figures including the parliamentary speaker.

The phones were given free of cost to 32 people, who also included the parliamentary affairs minister, the leader of the opposition in parliament and some officials.

The action is seen as a bid to improve the image of the government which has come under fire for squandering public money.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Ancient tomb reveals secrets

An Egyptian archaeologist, Zahi Hawass, said yesterday that he had discovered the tomb of the mayor of the Bahariya Oasis region, Djed Khonsu Eus Ankh, who lived around 500 BC. The mayor's place in history was secured by a temple in which he portrayed himself as the king's equal in paintings. His mummified body, mostly deteriorated, was found inside two finely carved sarcophagi, surrounded by amulets.

The tomb was to reveal its secrets to the world last night with a visit by a US television crew into the recently unearthed burial chamber.
AP, Bawiti, Egypt

Twin to die to save her sister

Italian doctors made a heart-wrenching decision yesterday - determining which of two four-month-old Peruvian Siamese twins to save and which to let die.

Doctors said that Marta and Milagro, who are joined at the chest and share the same heart, liver and parts of intestines, could not both live and one would have to "donate" organs to the other. Their decision that Milagro, the weaker of the two, would have to die, will be examined by an ethics committee.
Reuters, Palermo

Man convicted of eating dogs

A French kennel-owner was yesterday fined £300 and ordered to pay another £100 to an animal charity for eating an unknown number of his dogs. Police testified that while they had found 39 dogs alive at Jean-Louis Lacoste's kennels near Agen in southern France, they also discovered a substantial number of dog skins which were hidden away in cardboard boxes.
Jon Henley, Paris

webTitle: More to do with the dome

fields.headline: More to do with the dome
fields.trailText: In all the gloom surrounding the Millennium Dome (Dome chief forced to quit, May 23), it seems to have escaped everyone's notice that it is actually a huge success. To get 6-7m visitors to a paying attraction, especially one with such a nebulous theme, is a major achievement.
fields.body:
In all the gloom surrounding the Millennium Dome (Dome chief forced to quit, May 23), it seems to have escaped everyone's notice that it is actually a huge success. To get 6-7m visitors to a paying attraction, especially one with such a nebulous theme, is a major achievement. The next top paying attraction, Alton Towers, gets 2.5m. In addition, most dome visitors seem to enjoy the experience. All other UK attractions would kill for this. The only thing the dome is failing to do is to meet the expectations of a wildly over-inflated business plan. Anyone involved in operating visitor attractions could have told them it was never going to happen.
Ian Simmons
Norwich nspire@science-project.org

 As a small shopkeeper I find trading at present very difficult, mainly due to the strong pound and the poor weather since Easter. Why should the dome be any different?
Pat Veale
Dulverton, Somerset

 Bob Ayling was a convenient scapegoat (High flyer brought down to earth, May 23). The active intervention by two politicians - Peter Mandelson and Lord Falconer - in shaping and approving the design, content, look and scope of the dome's interior has been publicly documented and is also well known to the designers involved in the dome's creation. If Ayling is expected to fall on his sword, both Mandelson and Falconer should do as well. The 1997 election included the question in voters' minds about the accountability of Conservative politicians. The same question will be asked at the next election for the Labour party.
Richard Lorch
London

 Hugo Young (The folly built by our leaders makes fools of us all, May 23) skewers the excuses of the political class, which have led to a further £28m grant to the flatulent dome. Meanwhile, the nation's regional and children's theatres, starved and neglected for decades, wait anxiously for almost exactly the same amount in order to survive. A modest proposal: can't they sell off the bogus dome to Group Four, since they say they need more "reception centres"? The proceeds could help British culture. And asylum-seekers would get a crash course in the delusions of British society.
Michael Kustow
London

 I find this persistent, vitriolic dome bashing from the media irritating and tedious. However ambivalent you may have felt about the initial project, now the money has been spent, surely it must be time to stop aggressively condemning the project - and driving people away - and start promoting its good points. Even the much maligned £20 entry fee is good value for what is offered, especially considering the punishing prices in the rest of central London. I believe the greater fool is one who judges harshly without viewing.
Jim Carter
London

 The dome wants another £30 million? I thought the recipients of lottery money had to be good causes, not lost causes.
F Harland
Appleby-in-Westmorland

 Goodness me, row after row of empty seats at the dome's main arena. Telling photo. Hardly surprising, though, when the show isn't being performed at the time, is it?
D Clifford
Clare Hall, Cambridge djhc2@hermes.cam.ac.uk

 With the dome's staff totalling 5,000, how long will it be before the staff outnumber the visitors?
KJ Burrows
Chorley, Lancs

fields.headline: Maggie's tarnished icons
fields.standfirst: Time to revise the assumptions of the 80s
fields.trailText: Schadenfreude is not an attractive emotion, but sometimes it is hard to resist. In the 80s Margaret Thatcher used to go around scolding people who worked for the public sector as inefficient and anachronistic.
fields.body:
Schadenfreude is not an attractive emotion, but sometimes it is hard to resist. In the 80s Margaret Thatcher used to go around scolding people who worked for the public sector as inefficient and anachronistic.

Why, oh why - she would say in that inimitable hectoring tone - can you not be more like Marks and Spencer. She even introduced Derek Rayner to bring the firm's retailing skills to Whitehall's benighted. Well here is M&S struggling, out of touch, a victim of the markets forces it was once supposed to personify. Some retailing skills.

Meanwhile that other 80s icon, BT, stumbles. And BA, another of Maggie's exemplars, goes from bad to worse. That is not, of course, an argument for renationalisation, but a reminder of the capriciousness of corporate fortune - and the short-sightedness of politicians who stake their reputations, let alone policies, on the turn of the wheel.

Bad company results are not something to celebrate; people's livelihoods depend on them. Besides, as the GMB union pointed out bitterly yesterday, M&S's £417m profits are not bad for a company in trouble. BA's condition is more parlous. Only one-off sales stopped it plunging into the red and there still seems to be no coherence about its marketing, up, down or mid-market. The reasons it gives for its commercial difficulties, higher fuel prices and exchange rate risk, affect everyone else too.

The gloss has certainly disappeared from the Thatcher privatisations in water and rail. Their golden years of high profits are over. A hard question looms. The capital markets demand big returns; the public demands safety and environmental quality as well as reasonable prices. In between sit such odd companies as Railtrack and Thames Water.

Under Labour, state regulators have been coming down on them harder than ever - not hard enough, many would say. It is high time to start revising the models and assumptions of the 80s.

fields.headline: Victims not villains
fields.standfirst: Child prostitutes need better protection
fields.trailText: Child prostitutes need better protection: William Stead would not believe it. He was the campaigning journalist who as editor of the Pall Mall Gazette uncovered the extent of child prostitution in 19th-century England. He exposed the double standards of Victorian Britain by visiting brothels and buying a child prostitute. Yet over a century later, the double standards continue.
fields.body:
William Stead would not believe it. He was the campaigning journalist who as editor of the Pall Mall Gazette uncovered the extent of child prostitution in 19th-century England. He exposed the double standards of Victorian Britain by visiting brothels and buying a child prostitute. Yet over a century later, the double standards continue.

Any man who has sex with an under-aged child in his home can expect a visit from social services and the police; but if he goes down the road and pays £30 to a child prostitute, he has been relatively immune. As the new campaigners succinctly ask in their literature: "A man has sex with a 12-year-old prostitute - who should pay for it?" Rarely the pimp or client in current Britain. Yet in a four-year period in the 90s, almost 4,000 young women under 18 - including one as young as 10 - were either cautioned or convicted of offences related to prostitution.

Belatedly, reform is on the way. Ministers introduced new guidelines this week aimed at recognising child prostitutes as victims rather than offenders. The guidance is backed by police chiefs, social service directors and magistrates. Tribute should be paid to the Children's Society, which began the modern campaign and Barnardo's, which followed up with surveys and reports on child prostitute lives. No one knows how many child prostitutes there are, but when the Children's Society opened its first hostel for runaways in 1985, 7% of the first 500 said they had turned to prostitution to survive. There are 100,000 child runaways every year.

Pilot schemes which have already operated the new guidelines in Nottingham and Wolverhampton have demonstrated they will work. (Indeed, Nottingham was a winner in this year's Guardian/Department of Health social care awards.) But are they enough? Ministers have set up a review of sex offences, which must include heavier sentences for pimps and punters who use child prostitutes. Decriminalisation should remain on the agenda until the effects of the new guidelines are measured. Policy-makers should take note of the warning set out in our Society section today, of the vacuum which could be created if police are no longer picking up suspect children. Finally, more resources are needed for hostels for runaways. We need a national network, not a mere two. It must not be left to charities to raise the cash, but should be a central responsibility.

fields.headline: What the fox thinks
fields.trailText: In our draft report to the hunting inquiry chaired by Lord Burns, Roger Harris and I surveyed the meagre scientific evidence for the welfare problems associated with hunting foxes with hounds and culling them by other methods. Contrary to your headline (Blow to anti-hunt campaigners, May 22), we simply state that not enough is known to justify a firm conclusion.
fields.body:
In our draft report to the hunting inquiry chaired by Lord Burns, Roger Harris and I surveyed the meagre scientific evidence for the welfare problems associated with hunting foxes with hounds and culling them by other methods. Contrary to your headline (Blow to anti-hunt campaigners, May 22), we simply state that not enough is known to justify a firm conclusion. Absence of evidence does not mean evidence of absence. However, it is not difficult to see how even the limited amount that is known can be used to justify giving the animal the benefit of the doubt.
Prof Patrick Bateson
King's College, Cambridge
ppgb@cus.cam.ac.uk

 I took Linda Gilroy's private member's bill on fireworks through the Lords and was very interested in David Hencke's article (Firework safety law foiled by pro-hunt plot, May 22). I confirm Lord Kimball's involvement. Even before we started debating the bill he advised me he had no interest in fireworks or the bill but he demanded at least two amendments to ensure it went back to the Commons. This was to ensure Michael Foster's anti-fox hunting bill could be stopped (Private member's bills with Lords amendments take precedence over bills still in the Commons.)

We tried to get the bill through without amendment, but Kimball's tactics of getting cronies to table amendments and speak at length threatened important government business so we had to concede. I learned that Lord Kimball has used his undoubted parliamentary skills to defeat every measure against foxhunting since he entered the House of Commons in 1956.

Mike Foster recognised the threat posed to important private members bills like the fireworks bill and withdrew his anti-foxhunting bill. Tony Blair was right to point out some months ago that the anti-foxhunting bill was defeated in the House of Lords. I had assumed that the fireworks bill was talked out in the Commons by overzealous foxhunters who had not realised that Mike Foster had withdrawn his bill. Now we see that even more sinister forces at work, namely Conservative politicians who, in the name of "freedom", are quite prepared to prevent legislation that would have stopped people being killed and maimed by fireworks.
Lord Monkswell
London
monkswell@supanet.com

 If "only" 3% of lambs are killed by foxes that means "only" 600,000 lambs are eaten alive by them. Oddly, the lambs' plight seems of little concern to the "animal rights" lobby.
JP Young
Editor, The Field

fields.headline: Babies we forgot
fields.trailText: The case for child facilities in art galleries was made loud and clear within Tate Modern's inner sanctum (Letters, May 23). I made it myself. I sat on the jury that chose the architects Herzog and de Meuron.
fields.body:
The case for child facilities in art galleries was made loud and clear within Tate Modern's inner sanctum (Letters, May 23). I made it myself. I sat on the jury that chose the architects Herzog and de Meuron. In discussions about the brief all the competitors were to be given, I spoke up regularly for the need for a creche, not only for visiting families, but also for the benefit of female employees. Even with such an abundance of space this hasn't happened. I haven't been told why.
Joan Bakewell
London

 The obituaries for Barbara Cartland (May 22) did not mention her pioneering defence of Gypsies to whom she gave land for a private site. She withstood fierce opposition from the local authority when seeking planning permission. Then when the authority had to help organise the national census of Gypsies in the late 60s, officials argued that her site, called Barbaraville, should be counted as part of their own official duty of site provision. Cartland set a very different example from that voiced by the home secretary last year.
Prof Judith Okely
University of Hull

 If, as Shere Hite tells us (Charlotte Raven, G2, May 23), two-thirds of British women are dissatisfied with their sex lives, maybe men should try concentrating less on the length of their sentences (Letters, May 23) and more on the meaning behind them.
Jean Hewson
Berkhamsted, Herts jeanhewson@psychol.org.uk

 Joan Smith may be wrong to assume (Enough already, May 22) that "man has sex with wife" would rate as a "non-story". On the contrary: ample anecdotal evidence would seem to suggest that this would be a highly newsworthy item.
Elena Lappin
Barnet, Herts
elena@clara.net

fields.headline: Activists persecuted me
fields.trailText: Under the new prevention of terrorism bill (Four threats to the public right to know, May 22) animal rights activists, among others, will be treated as terrorists, and those contributing money to their cause must be reported.
fields.body:
Under the new prevention of terrorism bill (Four threats to the public right to know, May 22) animal rights activists, among others, will be treated as terrorists, and those contributing money to their cause must be reported.

At last, some common sense on this issue. Five years ago, while acting as public relations adviser to an air transport company involved in the export of calves to mainland Europe, after animal rights thuggery had closed the ferries to livestock exporters, I was on the receiving end of the animal rights lot.

For four months I endured written and verbal death threats, two dummy letter-bombs, threats to kidnap me and inject me with HIV-contaminated blood and damage to my vehicle and home. I was prevented by foul-mouthed and aggressive protesters from going in and out of my house as I wanted and accused of personally torturing animals by this loathsomely small-minded, hysterical, repressive movement - all because I presented through the media the other side of the export debate.

That they failed to deter me does not lessen the unpleasantness of what they did. Reading that the police may at last get the powers to act firmly and effectively against these people made my day.

fields.headline: Tyson's fight
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson is a role model for black males in America and the broader African diaspora, not only because he represents the physical power of black men in an economic system that has emasculated them, but also because his snarling, unapologetic persona winds up the white establishment and fuels their deepest racist prejudices (Gary Younge, May 22). Mike is about as far from Frank Bruno's clowning caricature as it's possible to get, yet for all his Muslim gestures, his militancy is that of the nihilistic gangster rapper, not the righteous teacher.

Liverpool

fields.headline: Look to Cuba for childcare
fields.trailText: I have just spent four weeks working as a chiropractor in a hospital in Cuba. It is amusing to return home and hear our politicians calling for better day care (Middle England calls for better childcare, May 22). Is it possible we have something to learn from this much maligned nation?
fields.body:
I have just spent four weeks working as a chiropractor in a hospital in Cuba. It is amusing to return home and hear our politicians calling for better day care (Middle England calls for better childcare, May 22). Is it possible we have something to learn from this much maligned nation? The US blockade means they have not been exposed to the extremes of modern health care and farming (drugs and pesticides). They are prioritising their limited resources to concentrate on well-being and prevention of disease.

This starts with education in their day care centres, which have to be seen to be believed. The centre I visited in the town of Neuva Gerona had 161 children, with a carer for every seven children. Children can start at six months and working parents pay a small fraction of their monthly wage for their children to attend. The carers organise stimulating activities and children get their meals free - as they do in the primary schools, where all under-12s get milk every day. At 5pm all the babies were bathed before being collected by their parents.

During their recession in the early 90s, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, Cuba did not cut spending on health or education, but slashed its military budget. They have more doctors and teachers per head of population than any country in the world.
Dr Richard Lanigan
Kingston upon Thames

 David Brindle is spot on (Towards a second term, May 22), Labour must include the proposal for a Children's Commissioner in the manifesto. Labour was in favour of a commissioner in 1992, but dropped the idea. Children urgently need a powerful champion and watchdog to force the pace of change on child protection law, policy and services.
Liz Atkins
Head of policy, NSPCC

webTitle: The best beach scene:  Kevin and Perry go large

fields.headline: The best beach scene:  Kevin and Perry go large
fields.trailText: An Ibiza beach. Kevin (Harry Enfield) and Perry (Kathy Burke) wade along, the sea up to their waists, listening to a communal Walkman of which they each appear to own one headphone. The volume is loud; so loud, in fact, that neither teenager has any idea that everyone on the beach can hear every word they say.
fields.body:
An Ibiza beach. Kevin (Harry Enfield) and Perry (Kathy Burke) wade along, the sea up to their waists, listening to a communal Walkman of which they each appear to own one headphone. The volume is loud; so loud, in fact, that neither teenager has any idea that everyone on the beach can hear every word they say.

Glancing around, they notice the two girls they have taken a fancy to sitting in a beach-front café.

"I got an idea Per", bawls Kevin, as hundreds of sunbathers sit up to eavesdrop. "What we'll do is walk up to the girls and ignore them. They'll be really sad, and then we'll turn around and go..."

Kevin adopts what is supposed to be a suave, worldly manner.

"Oh, hello ladies. And they'll be overjoyed!"

"I love my big baby so much, Kev", yells Perry. "She's got such lovely bouncy boobies. Look!"

They make a series of pelvic thrusts and grunting noises in the direction of the beach. As they begin to make their way back to land, Kevin is held back by Perry.

"What you stopped for?"

"I'm having a piss."

"Urgh!"

The beach groans in disgust.

"You've got to have a piss in the sea," Perry explains patiently.

"It's the law."

See also: Jaws, Rumblefish, Brighton Rock, The Warriors, Saving Private Ryan

Don't see also: The Beach

webTitle: Hague pension plans 'rob Peter to pay Paul'

fields.headline: Hague pension plans 'rob Peter to pay Paul'
fields.standfirst:
William Hague's full speech
Comment by Michael White
fields.trailText: Proposed increases in state pension to be put forward today by Conservative leader William Hague have been criticised as "just robbing Peter to pay Paul" by veteran pensions campaigner Jack Jones.
fields.body:
Proposed increases in state pension to be put forward today by Conservative leader William Hague have been criticised as "just robbing Peter to pay Paul" by veteran pensions campaigner Jack Jones.

Mr Jones, 87, told the BBC: "His proposals of a £10 a week increase is not an increase at all. It is pensioners' own money transferred from one pocket to another. The Tories took away our link with earnings back in 1980 - that is what we want back."

Mr Hague plans for pensioners, outlined in a speech to the LSE today, is part of a concerted attempt by the Tories to win back the "grey vote", capitalising on anger among pensioners over this year's 75p a week increase in the basic pension.

But Mr Jones, a former trade union leader and chairman of the national pensioners convention, said the only policy vote winner would be an immediate restoration of the link with average earnings.

He said if the link had never been taken away, the basic pension would now be over £90 instead of £67 and called this year's rise "derisory".

Mr Hague dismissed as "gimmicks" measures such as chancellor Gordon Brown's plan to give free TV licences to the over 75s - arguing that the money which funds them should go straight into pensioners' pockets to spend as they see fit.

He outlined how the Tories would redirect into the basic pension the money now used to pay for the £150 winter fuel allowance, the £10 Christmas bonus, free TV licences and the £13-a-year age addition for the over-80s.

Savings on administrative costs, and a high court ruling which equalised the age for winter fuel payments, as well as reduced spending on the government's social fund, and scrapping the New Deal for lone parents - which the Tories argue has no impact on their employment prospects - would free more money.

In all, the Tories believe they can find an extra £2 billion to inject into basic pensions, the bulk of that - £1.16 billion - coming from dropping winter fuel payments.

Shadow social security secretary David Willetts told the Today programme: "Pensioners have a choice. They can have a guaranteed weekly income as part of their contributory benefit or they can have all the gimmicks.

"I think pensioners will want the respect and dignity and the power to choose that comes from having something that is part of their weekly pension."

But social security secretary Alistair Darling claimed the Tory plans would leave the oldest and poorest pensioners worse off.

"David Willetts is promising money the Labour government is delivering anyway. This is a one-off gimmick and another example of William Hague's opportunism. Everybody knows that with their tax guarantee, pensioners will have to pay.

"We are helping the poorest pensioners and clearing up the Tory mess."

webTitle: Ageing nuclear power stations to be shut down

fields.headline: Ageing nuclear power stations to be shut down
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels announced the immediate closure of its Hinkley Point nuclear reactor in Somerset yesterday and the phased shutdown of the remaining seven ageing Magnox stations.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels announced the immediate closure of its Hinkley Point nuclear reactor in Somerset yesterday and the phased shutdown of the remaining seven ageing Magnox stations.

The company made the announcement yesterday as part of its plan to regain public trust after criticism over secrecy and lack of safety.

The programme will allow the company to close the older of the two reprocessing works at Sellafield in 2012. The B205 building, as it is called, is 50 years old and is responsible for two-thirds of the radioactive discharges into the Irish Sea which have caused so much anger in Ireland and in the Nordic countries.

The timetable of closure, which involves 3,200 jobs, and accounts for 8% of the country's electricity production, has been ordered by BNFL's new chief executive, Norman Askew, who was appointed on March 13 to improve management at the company.

The company estimates the closure programme will cost £10bn.

Hinkley Point A, opened in 1971, has been in trouble for some time with faulty pipework causing safety concerns.

Next to go will be the Bradwell station in two years time, followed by Dungeness A and Sizewell A in 2006 - all being phased out when they reach their 40th anniversaries, twice their original design life.

More than 300 people work at each station and many will be kept on after closure for the first three years while the fuel is removed. About 100 will lose their jobs in the first year and remaining posts will be phased down to 50 when the shells of the reactors are put on a "care and maintenance" basis.

Next to go will be the oldest reactors, Calder Hall and Chapelcross, operated by BNFL for the Ministry of Defence. Calder Hall's four reactors will close between 2006 and 2008, and Chapelcross, in Scotland, will close between 2008 and 2010.

Once the fuel from these stations has been unloaded and reprocessed BNFL will be able to close the Magnox reprocessing works.

The company hopes to keep the two remaining stations, Oldbury in Gloucestershire, and Wylfa in Anglesey, open longer by using a new fuel called Magrox. The company hopes that this will allow it to keep Oldbury until 2013 and Wylfa until 2016 or even 2021, but it has not yet received permission.

The company said all closure dates might be brought forward for safety or commercial reasons.

Greenpeace welcomed the Hinkley Point A decision but said all the other stations should also be closed immediately.

"Every day these stations add to the discharges into the Irish Sea, every day they are an accident waiting to happen," said Helen Wallace, Greenpeace's nuclear campaigner.

The environment agency, which is responsible for the regulation of radioactive discharges from nuclear installations in England and Wales, welcomed the announcement.

The closures put the government in some difficulty in meeting its targets for reducing by 20% its carbon dioxide emissions by 2010. At present the emissions are 9% below the 1990 figures because of the switch to gas from coal but they are set to increase as the nuclear stations are shut down.

The shadow industry secretary, Angela Browning, said: "It is now critical that the government develops a coherent energy policy. Will it spell out in detail how it intends to meet its target of 10% of electricity generators coming from renewables by 2010?"

Friends of the Earth said none of the Magnox stations should be allowed to continue in service and called for the end of reprocessing at Sellafield.

The decision will leave the privatised British Energy running the remaining newer nuclear stations.

webTitle: Portugese leader raises prospects of an end to EU sanctions against Austria

fields.headline: Portugese leader raises prospects of an end to EU sanctions against Austria
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: European Union sanctions against Austria could be lifted within weeks if discussions launched by Portugal are successful, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
European Union sanctions against Austria could be lifted within weeks if discussions launched by Portugal are successful, it emerged yesterday.

Prime minister Antonio Guterres, whose country holds the EU's rotating presidency, said he was consulting fellow leaders about Austria's demand for a speedy end to the controversial measures.

In an unprecedented move in February, Austria's 14 EU partners froze bilateral political contacts over concern at the presence in Vienna's new coalition of the far-right Freedom party, then led by Jörg Haider.

But in the clearest signal yet that the isolation of Vienna may be approaching its end, Mr Guterres said he had started "a range of contacts to define the position [on Austria] at an EU level".

Officials in Copenhagen confirmed last night that the Portuguese leader had spoken to his Danish counterpart, Poul Rasmussen, about ending the boycott. Denmark is one of several countries now pressing hard for the sanctions to end.

But diplomats said it was not clear whether agreement could be reached before France assumes the EU presidency at the beginning of July.

France, along with Belgium, has adopted a hawkish position on Austria. Both countries fear that their own rightwing extremists will draw encouragement from the rise to power of a like-minded party in another EU member state.

"My view is very simple: there was consensus among the 14 countries [to impose sanctions] and obviously there won't be a change until there is a consensus to do so," Mr Guterres said.

Austria has expressed the hope that the final summit of the Portuguese presidency, in Oporto next month, may mark the end of the confrontation.

Since February, the 14 have boycotted photo sessions, walked out of meetings which were being addressed by Austrian delegates, and refused to shake hands with Austrian representatives.

But at an EU meeting in the Azores earlier this month, all 15 foreign ministers, including Austria's, posed for a group photograph in an apparent sign of a slight thaw in relations.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, suggested then that the 14 consider their "exit strategy" and define more precisely what was expected of Austria before the quarantine could end.

The Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, has been told in general terms that his government must prove its commitment to democracy and human rights before sanctions are lifted.

Ireland, Italy, Finland, Spain, Denmark and Greece all favour ending the measures, fearing that the workings of the EU will start to suffer unless relations with Vienna are swiftly normalised.

Mr Schüssel has warned that he will call a referendum on attitudes towards the union and its treatment of his country if there is no change soon.

Mr Haider, notorious for his anti-foreigner rhetoric and controversial remarks about the Nazi period, is no longer leader of the Freedom party. But he has infuriated EU leaders by continuing to launch verbal attacks.

He called the French president, Jacques Chirac, a "pocket-sized Napoleon" and a "political failure who doesn't know what heís talking about."

webTitle: An end to war or prelude to conflagaration?

fields.headline: An end to war or prelude to conflagaration?
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: It now seems to be only a matter of time before Hizbullah takes complete and exclusive control of the territory left by the retreat of Israeli troops and the collapse of   the South Lebanon Army.
fields.body:
It now seems to be only a matter of time before Hizbullah takes complete and exclusive control of the territory left by the retreat of Israeli troops and the collapse of the South Lebanon Army.

The fundamental question that this upheaval poses is the same as it was when the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, first announced his plan to get his troops out of the Lebanese "mud" by July this year. And the answer is almost as uncertain as it ever was. Is this convulsion going to bring an end to the war, or is it the prelude to a much larger, regional conflagration?

At first it was the Israelis, who held the initiative; now, with its remarkable triumph, it is the Hizbullah. As the pro-Syrian Beirut newspaper al-Sharq said yesterday: "Israel thought it could impose a new status quo on the ground, with the SLA pulling the strings. Now it is Hizbullah which calls the shots, while the Israelis and their SLA agents run for safely like scared rabbits."

If Hizbullah is content with its triumph, it is reasonable to forecast that the south Lebanon crisis is on the way to a solution. If it is not, then a greater crisis lies in store.

All that is now left of the "security zone" is the eastern sector. And that is now falling apart after the local population stormed the notorious prison at Khiam, freeing 100 inmates as the SLA guards fled. Khiam is close to the joint headquarters of the Israelis and SLA in Marjayoun, "capital" of the strip.

Hizbullah had always said that it would not even con sider laying down its arms until Israel had made a complete withdrawal. So its interpretation of complete withdrawal is critical. At a news conference in Beirut yesterday, its leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, made two conditions. One was that Israel should release all Lebanese detainees. Even as he spoke, Khiam jail's doors were opening.

But another condition is one that neither Israel nor the UN is ready to accept. In a report to the security council, the secretary general, Kofi Annan, has said that the UN is prepared to play its part in filling the security vacuum left by the departing Israelis, and to assist in restoring Lebanese government authority up to the international frontier. But this will only happen if the local protagonists agree to certain conditions. One - for the Israelis - is that the SLA should "cease to exist". Which, now, it has.

One - for Lebanon, Syria and Hizbullah - is that they should respect the UN's definition of the frontier to which Israel must withdraw. But Mr Nasrallah insisted that the Israelis must hand back a small area known as the Shebaa farms, located at the foot of the Golan Heights. The Israelis say it is Syrian; the Lebanese and Syrians say it is Lebanese.

The significance of this lies less in the territory itself than in what it says about Hizbullah's wider, long term intentions - whether, in fact, it regards the liberation of Lebanese territory as an end in itself, or whether it is looking for any pretext to continue the war on Syria's behalf, as well as its own. For it is no secret that, in producing the claim to Shebaa, the Lebanese government was doing Syria a favour. President Hafez al- Assad was anxious to find any means of preventing an Israeli withdrawal - which deprives him of critical bargaining power in his negotiations over the Golan Heights - or any justification for Hizbullah's continued war.

If Hizbullah sticks to this position, it means that Syria is doing so too, and that, despite the withdrawal, Syria is determined to continue to use south Lebanon as a bargaining counter. If that is the case then the pessimistic scenario is in order: the withdrawal is but the prelude to wider regional crisis. The question is how far Mr Assad is ready to go.

He has approved of the deployment of the UN interim force in lebanon in the south, and now in a joint statement with the US, his government has called for the "avoidance of military escalation" in the south. The Lebanese government, too, is backing off its former hard line.

If Hizbullah decides to accept that too, it could signify the difference between peace and continued, wider war.

fields.headline: Lebanon bursts free to uncertainty
fields.standfirst:
Freedom - 100 inmates released after villagers storm prison camp

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Scores of villagers used rifle butts and their bare hands yesterday to free about 100 people jailed in south Lebanon's notorious Khiam prison, after its pro-Israeli militia guards fled.
fields.body:
Scores of villagers used rifle butts and their bare hands yesterday to free about 100 people jailed in south Lebanon's notorious Khiam prison, after its pro-Israeli militia guards fled.

The mostly Shi'ite Muslim residents of Khiam stormed the detention camp where, according to human rights groups, about 160 men, women and children were subjected to torture.

Guards belonging to Israel's proxy militia, South Lebanon Army (SLA), which ran the prison, left the jail in a convoy of about 20 civilian cars, leaving behind tanks, armoured personnel carriers and ammunition to be seized by the victorious villagers.

"We're actually free at last," shouted a white-haired prisoner after villagers broke down his cell door with their bare hands.

Overjoyed prisoners, some detained since the late 1980s, fainted with emotion on seeing their relatives. A man tumbled out of his cell, kissing the ground and sobbing.

"We didn't know what was going on at all, but we had a feeling we'd be out soon because of all the shelling and bombing we've been hearing," said Mohammad as he ran from the prison. "We chased them away. Our people actually won. They avenged us."

Human rights groups have criticised Israel and the SLA for holding prisoners in Khiam without trial. The compound, with its dirty white buildings topped with barbed wire, often echoed with the screams of detainees tortured during interrogation.

According to the Lebanese Follow-up Committee for Detainees in Israeli Jails, electrocutions and beatings were routine procedures during the SLA interrogations. It said detainees were often hung from posts for hours, and beaten with steel rods on their heads and genitalia.

"I'm an engineer, I've been here for four years, they've also arrested my wife, my child, my mother and my sister but now it's all over," said Ali, tears streaming from his one good eye. "Our people released us. The resistance has released us. We are all resistance. Long live Hizbullah."

Most of the detainees were arrested by the SLA on charges of either aiding Hizbullah guerrillas or fighting alongside them. The Islamist group has taken at least 30 villages abandoned by the Israelis and SLA in the past two days.

Khiam was a Lebanese army barracks before the SLA transformed it into a detention centre in 1985. Hundreds of villagers from throughout the zone have served time there and yesterday was their chance to take revenge.

Gaunt and exhausted, some prisoners joined in the destruction of the compound. Doors were broken open, windows shattered and most of the equipment smashed.

Villagers climbed up the vacant guard towers, planting green flags with religious emblems and firing into the air.

Others crammed into an abandoned armoured personnel carrier and drove it down the slope to Khiam village, where dozens of waiting families pelted the detainees with flower petals and rice.

Children ran through the compound, picking up handcuffs and ammunition to play with, while cars bearing the prisoners to the village tooted their horns and women sang.

"The nightmare is over," said a wild-haired detainee as he sobbed. "I can't believe the nightmare is actually over."

webTitle: Iraqi nerve gas 'could paralyse western cities'

fields.headline: Iraqi nerve gas 'could paralyse western cities'
fields.standfirst: Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, has built up a deadly arsenal of chemical, biological and possibly nuclear weapons over the past 18 months capable of creating mayhem in London, New York and Tel Aviv, according to the former UN weapons inspector, Richard Butler.
fields.body:
The Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, has built up a deadly arsenal of chemical, biological and possibly nuclear weapons over the past 18 months capable of creating mayhem in London, New York and Tel Aviv, according to the former UN weapons inspector, Richard Butler.

His warning runs counter to the Iraqi government's claim that it has destroyed all its weapons of mass destruction in compliance with UN resolutions agreed after the Gulf war.

The issue is at the heart of one of the most complex problems confronting the UN. Some campaigners against UN sanctions on Iraq insist there is no evidence that Baghdad still retains weapons and that sanctions should be lifted.

Mr Butler, who headed the UN weapons inspectorate in Baghdad until the UN pulled out in 1998 alleging obstruction by the Iraqi government, said he had evidence from his time in Baghdad that President Saddam had kept weapons of mass destruction hidden from the UN.

But he said that more worryingly President Saddam had used the absence of the UN in the intervening period to build up his arsenal of missiles and chemical and biological weapons.

Mr Butler had also been presented with evidence that President Saddam had re-convened his nuclear development team and had the capability to build nuclear weapons.

His warning came as President Saddam praised Iraqi scientists for their innovative work in finding ways of combatting US and British fighters flying missions over the country. The Iraqi leader said he had "listened to a detailed explanation on innovations and work conducted by a group of researchers and fighters to confront and stop the aggressors". He added: "I am very proud of you and all Iraqi scientists."

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Butler, an Australian diplomat dubbed "Mad Dog" by the Iraqi government, said: "This stuff is out there and it is serious. This man has a track record. We do not want to wait until this stuff turns up in Trafalgar Square or Times Square and say we did not see it coming."

Iraq had been building up the range of its missiles to 375 miles over the past 18 months, he said. "I have seen evidence they have been attempting to procure missile manufacturing equipment from the west through front companies."

"Missiles are only a delivery system. They can carry conventional warheads but Iraq has wanted them for chemical, nuclear and biological weapons."

He said he was convinced that President Saddam had stores of the nerve agent VX, which he described as more dangerous than Sarin and anthrax.

"A Scud missile with 140 litres of VX can kill up to a million people," he said, recalling that President Saddam had fired Scuds at Israel during the Gulf war.

He warned that Iraq had, or could soon have, the nuclear weapons to "hollow central London". The Iraqi government had never yielded its nuclear weapons designs to his team. It had the know-how and all it needed was the uranium, which it could get on the black market or from its own mineral supplies.

The US and Britain bombed Baghdad in 1998 after Mr Butler reported that the Iraqi government had been obstructive.

The UN is at present putting together another weapons inspection team under Hans Blix, but Iraq has so far said it would not allow an inspection team back in. The UN will formally ask Iraq to allow its team in this summer.

Mr Butler said that either President Saddam would allow Mr Blix and his team back into Baghdad or he would ignore it. He believed the latter was the more likely.

He blamed three of the five permanent members of the UN security council - France, China and Russia - for the UN's impotence, saying they all put self-interest ahead of tackling Iraq. France's main aim was protecting its oil interests.

Mr Butler has written a book about his bruising encounters with the Iraqi government, Saddam Defiant, which is to be published shortly. Although he wants tougher action against Iraq, he says in his book that sanctions have proved to be largely ineffective.

fields.headline: Wednesday put faith in Kinnear
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited interview with Joe Ashton MP
fields.trailText: Joe Kinnear will be unveiled as Sheffield Wednesday's new manager today - six months too late, according to Joe Ashton MP.
fields.body:
Joe Kinnear will be unveiled as Sheffield Wednesday's new manager today - six months too late, according to Joe Ashton MP.

The Wednesday board, facing a vote of no confidence at a forthcoming emergency general meeting, gave Kinnear until yesterday to decide whether to take the job. The 53-year-old former Wimbledon manager has accepted the deal and will be introduced at a press conference this morning.

"If it's true, it's very, very good news," said Ashton, one of the "gang of four" local MPs who called for Danny Wilson to be sacked late last year. "I just wish they had signed him on before Christmas when all four MPs suggested it.

"I met Joe Kinnear at an England match, quite by chance, and talked to him then and he was very, very keen. I told all the board and the chairman and I phoned the directors, and I couldn't make any headway."

Kinnear, who resigned as Wimbledon's manager soon after suffering a mild heart attack at Hillsborough in March last year, still sounds very keen.

"I am delighted and excited to be so close to returning to football at such a big club with what I see as enormous potential," he is quoted as telling the club's website. "There have been some tempting approaches since I left Wimbledon, but Wednesday represents a special challenge."

Wednesday finally sacked Wilson on March 21, after a 1-0 defeat at Watford. They won successive games in April under Peter Shreeves, but it proved an all too brief revival. They finished five points below the safety line and were relegated along with Watford and Wimbledon.

"Joe Kinnear could make them fight, which they never did," Ashton said yesterday. "The Hillsborough crowd were disgusted to see that Bradford City fought to the last gasp and they survived. Sheffield Wednesday had packed it in by Christmas."

Kinnear faces a difficult summer. The defenders Peter Atherton, Jon Newsome, Lee Briscoe and Ian Nolan are all out of contract; much of the rest of the team is likely to be up for sale. Wednesday are reported to be about £18m in debt.

"Money is a problem," the Wednesday chairman Howard Culley recently admitted. "The new manager will have to work within a budget and be careful of the players' wage bill which is the most important part of the expenses of the club."

Kinnear, a former Tottenham and Republic of Ireland full-back, took over as Wimbledon manager in 1992 when they were bottom of the old First Division with 12 games left to play. They finished 13th.

His best season was 1996-97, when Wimbledon reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup and League Cup and finished eighth in the Premiership.

He has also been manager of Doncaster Rovers, Sharjah and India.

 Gary McAllister, the former Scotland midfielder out of contract at Coventry, has agreed to sign for Liverpool.

 Chelsea have been fined £16,000 by the Football Association for poaching a 12-year-old, Dean Silvester, from Luton Town.
